('18', 42, 4, 12, 89082) 37. THE SWADESHI VOW 1
('18', 42, 5, 13, 89105) May 13, 2 1915
('18', 42, 6, 14, 89120) PURE AND MIXED VOWS EXPLAINED SIGNATORIES TO THE PLEDGE 3
('18', 42, 7, 15, 89178) The idea of swadeshi was first broached at the 6th of April meeting at Chowpati where thousands of men and some women met together, but the swadeshi vow was not taken on that day.
('18', 42, 7, 16, 89358) It has now been fully thrashed out and the way is clear.
('18', 42, 7, 17, 89415) It is our duty to take the swadeshi vow; in it lies the true prosperity of India.
('18', 42, 7, 18, 89497) To use foreign articles rejecting those produced or manufactured in India is to be untrue to India, it is an unwarranted indulgence.
('18', 42, 7, 19, 89630) To use foreign articles because we do not like indigenous ones is to be a foreigner.
('18', 42, 7, 20, 89715) It is obvious that we cannot reject indigenous articles even as we cannot reject the native air and the native soil because they are inferior to foreign air and soil.
('18', 42, 7, 21, 89882) Cotton imports amounted to about Rs. 57,00,00,000 and silk import to Rs. 4,00,00,000 in the year 1917 18. India has a population of three hundred millions and so it [means] that we sent out in that year about Rs. 2 per head, with starvation as the
('18', 42, 8, 22, 90130) 1 This was the first leaflet on swadeshi, vide The Swadeshi Vow, 16 6 1919. 2 May 13 according to Young India but May 14 according to Mahadevbhai ki Diary which describes this as second leaflet on swadeshi vow.
('18', 42, 8, 23, 90341) 3 The first two names were those of Gandhiji and Kasturba and the other signatories included Vinoba Bhave.
('18', 43, 0, 1, 90448) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 43, 1, 2, 90489) result.
('18', 43, 1, 3, 90497) More than thirty million men in India hardly get more than one meal a day.
('18', 43, 1, 4, 90572) Such starvation must have been unknown when every house in India had its spinning wheel and when thousands of people were busy with their handlooms.
('18', 43, 1, 5, 90721) No wonder that starvation and other ills arise whenever people depart from the path of duty.
('18', 43, 1, 6, 90814) One of the remedies for these ills is swadeshi.
('18', 43, 1, 7, 90862) The swadeshi vow of which the text is given at the foot of this article has therefore been proposed and it has been divided into two classes.
('18', 43, 1, 8, 91004) The first represents purer swadeshi vow, but the purest is that under which those taking it restrict themselves to the use of hand woven clothes made out of hand spun yarn.
('18', 43, 1, 9, 91177) The ruin of the handloom industry makes such a vow for the time being impossible.
('18', 43, 1, 10, 91259) But if those who take the first vow keep the ideal swadeshi as their goal, we shall ere long be able to obtain sufficient hand woven cloth.
('18', 43, 1, 11, 91399) I have already pointed out the great difference between swadeshi and boycott.
('18', 43, 1, 12, 91477) 1 I for one am sure that boycott cannot benefit India in the least.
('18', 43, 1, 13, 91545) Resorting to boycott amounts to cutting off the nose to spite the face.
('18', 43, 1, 14, 91617) Shall we open our door wider for Japan boycotting British goods in order to rid ourselves of the evil of the Rowlatt Bill?
('18', 43, 1, 15, 91740) The fact is that swadeshi has nothing to do with the agitation against the Rowlatt Bills.
('18', 43, 1, 16, 91830) A great movement like satyagraha sets the people a thinking about their duties and it is thus that the idea of the swadeshi has possessed the people.
('18', 43, 1, 17, 91980) We shall continue to observe the vow even after the repeal of the Rowlatt legislation and after India becomes an honoured partner in the British Empire.
('18', 43, 1, 18, 92133) And our vow will then not be the limited swadeshi vow today, it will be a far wider one as we shall then have been capable of meeting in India itself many of our requirements.
('18', 43, 1, 19, 92309) We shall appeal 2
('18', 43, 2, 20, 92327) to our English brethren also to join us in this swadeshi vow.
('18', 43, 2, 21, 92389) In order to enable lacs of men and women to take and observe the swadeshi vow, commercial honesty will be sine qua non.
('18', 43, 2, 22, 92509) The mill owners will have to fix their rates in a patriotic spirit.
('18', 43, 2, 23, 92577) Merchants, great and small, will also likewise have to keep honest dealings.
('18', 43, 2, 24, 92654) I have no doubt that swadeshi cannot advance unless thousands of petty shopkeepers from whom the poor millions buy introduce honesty into their dealings.
('18', 43, 2, 25, 92808) The organizers of swadeshi have ventured to place before the nation the swadeshi pledge for its acceptance upon the
('18', 43, 3, 26, 92924) 1 Vide Swadeshi Vow I, 8 4 1919. 2 Vide Letter to Sir Stanley Reed, 30 4 1919 and Letter to J. L. Maffey, 5 5 1919.
('18', 44, 0, 1, 93040) VOL. 17 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 45
('18', 44, 1, 2, 93084) belief that our merchants possess the patriotic spirit and that for the sake of the country they will be kind to the poor and truthful towards them.
('18', 44, 1, 3, 93233) Those who have foreign clothing seem to hesitate to take the pledge.
('18', 44, 1, 4, 93302) Though this is natural, it is also painful.
('18', 44, 1, 5, 93346) We want swadeshi to produce big results.
('18', 44, 1, 6, 93387) These cannot be attained without sacrifice.
('18', 44, 1, 7, 93431) Moreover, it is hoped that the spirit of swadeshi will bring in that of simplicity, and those who take to simple, though more durable clothing, will be able to recoup themselves for any loss sustained by reason of the giving up of foreign articles.
('18', 44, 1, 8, 93680) It is necessary to give the warning that none should lay by a large stock of swadeshi clothing.
('18', 44, 1, 9, 93776) There is not enough cloth in Hindustan to enable many of us to have a stock to last four or five years.
('18', 44, 1, 10, 93880) When there are many swadeshists, there is no doubt that we will have many swadeshi shops and that day by day we shall have more cloth woven in India.
('18', 44, 1, 11, 94030) Those who take the pledge should have faith in the possibility of their being able to buy swadeshi cloth whenever they need it.
('18', 44, 1, 12, 94158) As a matter of fact, everyone should learn to weave his own cloth and those who cannot should engage their own weavers.
('18', 44, 1, 13, 94278) So doing, they would avoid all cause for deceit and they would be able to have durable and pure cloth for their use.
('18', 44, 1, 14, 94395) This is what we used to do in days gone by.
('18', 44, 1, 15, 94439) Swadeshi depends upon women adopting it.
('18', 44, 1, 16, 94480) I hope that thousands of them will give up foreign cloth in their possession and take the swadeshi pledge.
('18', 44, 1, 17, 94587) It behoves us to suffer some inconvenience if only by way of penance for our past mistakes.
('18', 44, 1, 18, 94679) Moreover, it is possible to put foreign cloth to other uses.
('18', 44, 1, 19, 94740) It can even be sold for despatch out of India.
('18', 44, 1, 20, 94787) Further the nation has a right to expect its women to clothe their children in swadeshi garments.
('18', 44, 2, 21, 94885) M. K. GANDHI
('18', 44, 3, 22, 94898) PURE SWADESHI VOW
('18', 44, 4, 23, 94916) I solemnly declare that henceforth in Hindustan I shall not wear clothing except such as is made in India out of Indian cotton, silk or wool spun in India.
('18', 44, 4, 24, 95072) This vow shall be binding on me for life/years.
('18', 44, 5, 25, 95120) MIXED SWADESHI VOW
('18', 44, 6, 26, 95139) I solemnly declare that henceforth in Hindustan I shall not wear
('18', 45, 0, 1, 95204) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 45, 1, 2, 95245) any clothing except such as is woven in India whether made out of foreign or Indian yarn, silk or wool.
('18', 45, 1, 3, 95349) This vow shall be binding on me for life/years.
('18', 45, 1, 4, 95397) ExplanationThe true swadeshi ideal consists in the use of hand woven cloth only made out of hand spun yarn, but it is physically impossible today to secure a supply of such cloth for any large number of people.
('18', 45, 1, 5, 95608) It is expected, however, that true lovers of swadeshi and real art will not only themselves, even at some inconvenience, wear hand woven cloth made out of hand spun yarn but will also endeavour to set going as many handlooms and spinning wheels as possible.
('18', 45, 1, 6, 95866) Note 1It should be remembered that this movement has not hing to do with the agitation for securing repeal of the Rowlatt legisla tion.
('18', 45, 1, 7, 96002) Repeal of that legislation or the granting of other concessions or reforms will make no alteration whatsoever in the swadeshi vow or the movement for the spread of swadeshi.
('18', 45, 1, 8, 96176) Note 2The suggestion for destruction of foreign cloth in the possession of the signatories to the pledge has been totally abandoned lest a mistaken interpretation of the suggestion may lead to the growth or the promotion of ill will against Europeans, the idea of ill will being entirely foreign to the originators of the present swadeshi movement.
('18', 45, 1, 9, 96525) But the pledge precludes the use of any personal clothing of foreign make that the signatory may possess at the time of taking the vow.
('18', 45, 1, 10, 96661) Note 3Mahomedans, Parsis, Christians and Jews taking the swadeshi pledge are not precluded from using and wearing foreign cloth having a religious significance.
('18', 45, 2, 11, 96822) Young India, 17 5 1919

('18', 48, 12, 15, 101072) 42. LETTER TO J. L. MAFFEY
('18', 48, 13, 16, 101099) BOMBAY, May 16, 1919
('18', 48, 14, 17, 101120) DEAR MR. MAFFEY, Enclosed is a copy of the telegram I sent you yesterday.
('18', 48, 14, 18, 101194) I have said not a word about the events in the Punjab, not because I have up to now not thought or felt over them, but because I have not known what to believe and what not to believe.
('18', 48, 14, 19, 101379) Even the official communiques have not been over frank.
('18', 48, 14, 20, 101435) I was, as I am still, hoping that very soon there would be the fullest investigation made as to the causes of disturbances and the measures adopted to quell them.
('18', 48, 14, 21, 101598) But a shock like the one caused by the reported flogging has been delivered by the arrest with the attendant circumstances of Mr. Govardhandas and the prohibition order against Messrs Norton and Roy engaged as counsel for the defence of the Editor of The Tribune.
('18', 48, 14, 22, 101862) You will forgive me for troubling you at the present juncture.
('18', 48, 14, 23, 101925) But I know, you will recognize the urgency of my inquiry.
('18', 48, 14, 24, 101983) I observe that the storm 1 from Afghanistan has almost blown over.
('18', 48, 15, 25, 102050) Yours sincerely, M. K. G.

('18', 49, 1, 2, 102187) 43. LETTER TO SAKARLAL DAVE
('18', 49, 2, 3, 102215) ON THE TRAIN TO BOMBAY, May 19, 1919
('18', 49, 3, 4, 102252) BHAISHRI SAKARLAL 1, I have taken longer to write this letter than I had expected.
('18', 49, 3, 5, 102335) I am looking out for Amritlal.
('18', 49, 3, 6, 102366) I am confident that Mama will be there in June, and I know that he will acquit himself well enough.
('18', 49, 3, 7, 102466) We must be able to run the school well.
('18', 49, 3, 8, 102506) I was very glad that you pointed out all those grammatical errors.
('18', 49, 3, 9, 102573) Mahadev will write to you further about them.
('18', 49, 3, 10, 102619) I make every effort to write correctly but it is quite likely the mistakes remain, for, what command I have over Gujarati is the fruit of my love.
('18', 49, 3, 11, 102766) I had no time to learn the language systematically.
('18', 49, 3, 12, 102818) My use of the root shak [be able to] is deliberate.
('18', 49, 3, 13, 102870) Nirbhaya and other words have not been so used but I find Mahadev defending them.
('18', 49, 3, 14, 102952) I shall accept any decision on which you two agree and correct myself accordingly.
('18', 49, 3, 15, 103035) Where there is a difference of opinion between you, I shall accept your view till I get further light on the point, for I think yours will be more objective.
('18', 49, 3, 16, 103193) Please do keep suggesting improvements in my language.
('18', 49, 3, 17, 103248) I shall take it as a sign of your pure love.
('18', 49, 3, 18, 103293) Now, as for the meaning I have read in the Bhagavad Gita, if I had not found it in the work independently of all else, I would have certainly said that the principle of satyagraha was right, despite the contrary teaching of the Bhagavad Gita.
('18', 49, 3, 19, 103536) The work is being put to an utterly wrong use, and so it is that, now that the time is ripe, I have placed before the people the meaning I have accepted for so many years.
('18', 49, 3, 20, 103708) I very much respect Anandshankarbhais views, but I would not give up any opinion of mine which has stood the test of experience even if it were contested by him.
('18', 49, 3, 21, 103870) It is certainly the Bhagavad Gitas intention that one should go on working without attachment to the fruits of work.
('18', 49, 3, 22, 103987) I deduce the principle of satyagraha from this.
('18', 49, 3, 23, 104035) He who is free from such attachment will not kill the enemy but rather sacrifice himself.
('18', 49, 3, 24, 104125) Killing an enemy proceeds from impatience and impatience proceeds from attachment.
('18', 49, 3, 25, 104208) This is but one point in my argument, but I have no desire to convince you or anyone else with the help of arguments.
('18', 49, 3, 26, 104326) Even if I wished, I do not think I have the
('18', 49, 4, 27, 104370) 1 Sakarlal Amritlal Dave, Gujarati educationist
('18', 50, 0, 1, 104418) VOL. 17 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 51
('18', 50, 1, 2, 104462) ability.
('18', 50, 1, 3, 104471) I have something far more powerful than argument, namely, experience.
('18', 50, 1, 4, 104541) As far back as 1889, when I had my first contact with the Gita, it gave me a hint of satyagraha and, as I read it more and more, the hint developed into a full revelation of satyagraha.
('18', 50, 1, 5, 104727) That a man of Krishnas intelligence should indulge in all this wisdom of the Gita for the benefit of an Arjuna in flesh and blood, would be like killing the buffalo for a leather strap.
('18', 50, 1, 6, 104913) To believe he did so is to tarnish his name, if it is true that he was the Supreme God, and to do injustice to Arjuna if he was a warrior of experience and judgment.
('18', 50, 1, 7, 105079) I know you will not dismiss these ideas off hand.
('18', 50, 1, 8, 105129) I would rather you embraced and developed them.
('18', 50, 1, 9, 105177) You will readily admit, I am sure, that learned commentaries are of much less value than the experience of one limited intelligence.
('18', 50, 1, 10, 105310) [From Gujarati]
('18', 50, 2, 11, 105326) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. V
('18', 50, 3, 12, 105354) 44. LETTER TO MANIBEHN PARIKH
('18', 50, 4, 13, 105384) ON THE TRAIN TO BOMBAY, May 19, 1919
('18', 50, 5, 14, 105421) DEAR MANIBEHN,
('18', 50, 6, 15, 105436) I heard yesterday of your fathers passing away, but could not go and see you to offer my condolences.
('18', 50, 6, 16, 105538) Separation from our dear ones is bound to give pain, for but selfish are the friends of this one who has his abode in the body, in the end they will go their way.
('18', 50, 6, 17, 105701) So sings one of our poets.
('18', 50, 6, 18, 105728) I forget his name.
('18', 50, 6, 19, 105747) If we examine the matter closely, [we shall see that] it is not love which causes the pain, but our selfishness.
('18', 50, 6, 20, 105860) Otherwise, just as we are happy changing from an old house to a new one, we have no cause, surely, to mourn when an atman friend gives up a worn out body and assumes a new one.
('18', 50, 6, 21, 106037) This would be true, whether the person died young or old.
('18', 50, 6, 22, 106095) When exactly a body ceases to be serviceable, its Creator alone knows.
('18', 50, 6, 23, 106166) We may not aspire to know it.
('18', 50, 6, 24, 106196) I had not thought of saying all this to you.
('18', 50, 6, 25, 106241) It came out because, at the moment, my thoughts flow in a rather unusual direction.
('18', 50, 6, 26, 106325) What I wanted to say was this.
('18', 50, 6, 27, 106356) We should wish that everyone meets a death as grand as your fathers.
('18', 50, 6, 28, 106425) It is not often we hear of a person dying a painless death, dropping off, as it were, without exacting service from anyone.
('18', 50, 6, 29, 106549) Your father will always be remembered as one who had such a death.
('18', 50, 6, 30, 106616) It is in vain that we mourn any death; a
('18', 51, 0, 1, 106657) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 51, 1, 2, 106698) death such as this ought not to be mourned.
('18', 51, 1, 3, 106742) And so I offer you, not condolences but congratulations.
('18', 51, 1, 4, 106799) [From Gujarati]
('18', 51, 2, 5, 106815) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. V
('18', 51, 3, 6, 106843) 45. LETTER TO SATYAGRAHIS OF SURAT
('18', 51, 4, 7, 106878) BOMBAY, May 20, 1919 Your letter wandered from place to place and came to my hand only today.
('18', 51, 4, 8, 106972) I think it is wrong of you to covet my signature.
('18', 51, 4, 9, 107022) My physical condition being what it is, I cannot sign, nor dictate, all letters.
('18', 51, 4, 10, 107103) So long as India has not understood the true nature of satyagraha, the doubts you have raised are bound to occur and you will have to have patience.
('18', 51, 4, 11, 107252) Satyagraha, once started, ends only when it has achieved its aim.
('18', 51, 4, 12, 107318) At times it does seem to have ended, but in fact it has not.
('18', 51, 4, 13, 107379) When satyagraha is likely to be confused with duragraha, suspending it will be a way of launching true satyagraha.
('18', 51, 4, 14, 107494) It is such a subtle thing that only through experience and constant reflection do we come to understand a little of it.
('18', 51, 4, 15, 107614) As I see things today, satyagraha in the form of disobedience to laws is likely to start in July.
('18', 51, 4, 16, 107712) Circumstances may, however, arise even earlier in which it may be resumed.
('18', 51, 4, 17, 107787) Some of the forms of satyagraha may conceivably have to be suspended repeatedly.
('18', 51, 4, 18, 107868) I think it is impossible, beyond a certain point, to explain to you what power there is in fasts and other religious practices; since you have been keeping fasts all these yearsI am sure you have beenand you would not have thought of saying some of the things you have said if there had been any satyagraha in your fasts.
('18', 51, 4, 19, 108190) If you could see no difference between the fasts you kept in the past and the one on Sunday for Horniman, I must say you have deceived yourselves.
('18', 51, 4, 20, 108337) I am emphatically of the view that our struggle grows protracted in the measure that our satyagraha is deficient.
('18', 51, 4, 21, 108451) Renunciation is no renunciation if the desire for the things renounced has not disappeared.
('18', 51, 4, 22, 108543) Those of you who have sacrificed their jobs and all will have done so to no purpose if they think they have gained nothing as a result.
('18', 51, 4, 23, 108679) He alone has truly given up his job who could not do otherwise.
('18', 51, 4, 24, 108743) Those who gave up their jobs should have felt happy
('18', 52, 0, 1, 108795) VOL. 17 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 53
('18', 52, 1, 2, 108839) doing so, not unhappy, but I see that that is not how they felt.
('18', 52, 1, 3, 108904) This is why you feel yourselves in the position of Trishanku 1. Who am I that I should provide an opportunity for satyagraha?
('18', 52, 1, 4, 109030) A satyagrahi is ever his own master.
('18', 52, 1, 5, 109067) You can discuss things with me.
('18', 52, 1, 6, 109099) It is quite true that, when an organization offers satyagraha, individuals should submit themselves to its discipline.
('18', 52, 1, 7, 109218) But, once a person has become a satyagrahi, he will always find opportunities for offering satyagraha.
('18', 52, 1, 8, 109321) How can those who are full of doubts and fears be reckoned as satyagrahis?
('18', 52, 1, 9, 109396) To be a satyagrahi is like walking on the blade of a sword.
('18', 52, 1, 10, 109456) If I have not succeeded, despite what I have said, in solving your doubts, I can only counsel patience.
('18', 52, 1, 11, 109560) If you think that satyagraha only means courting imprisonment somehow, you can go to jail by breaking any law.
('18', 52, 1, 12, 109671) If one can offer satyagraha in this way, every prisoner is a satyagrahi.
('18', 52, 1, 13, 109744) There can be satyagraha only in civilly disobeying a law, for sufficient reason, without violating a moral law.
('18', 52, 1, 14, 109856) If I could show any such way to you, I would myself offer satyagraha.
('18', 52, 2, 15, 109926) MOHANDAS GANDHI
('18', 52, 3, 16, 109942) [From Gujarati]
('18', 52, 4, 17, 109958) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. V
('18', 52, 5, 18, 109986) 1 Sent to heaven alive by Vishwamitra, but Indra would not permit him to enter it.
('18', 52, 5, 19, 110069) In the result, he found himself in midspace, unable either to enter heaven or descend to the earth.

('18', 55, 1, 2, 112414) 50. LETTER TO ALI BROTHERS
('18', 55, 2, 3, 112441) LABURNUM ROAD GAMDEVI, BOMBAY, May 23, I919
('18', 55, 3, 4, 112485) MY DEAR FRIENDS, I write with a heavy heart, for I see that I have disagreed with you on these things and my disagreement must pain you, as it has already considerably pained me.
('18', 55, 3, 5, 112664) I wonder whether Mr. Ghate ever received my letter 1 which was meant for you, and whether if he did, you got it.
('18', 55, 3, 6, 112777) That letter explains my position regarding your memorial to the Viceroy.
('18', 55, 3, 7, 112850) I shall try briefly to re explain it, as having received no reply from you, I fear that you have not seen my letter to Mr. Ghate.
('18', 55, 3, 8, 112980) I consider that your memorial was too undignified for the great cause you are espousing and of which I have felt you are pre eminently the embodiment and for which you have suffered without a murmur all the long years and are still suffering.
('18', 55, 3, 9, 113223) Your language was inflammatory and too full of declamation for a memorial.
('18', 55, 3, 10, 113298) Your statement of the Mohammedan claim instead of representing an irreducible minimum was an exaggeration.
('18', 55, 3, 11, 113405) I am sure, you do not propose to raise questions affecting issues that were rightly or wrongly settled long before the war.
('18', 55, 3, 12, 113529) You have a right to claim the restoration of the temporal status of Islam as it existed at the time of the outbreak of war.
('18', 55, 3, 13, 113653) I would like you even now to redraft your memorial, make a reasoned and logical statement that must arrest and command the attention of the world.
('18', 55, 3, 14, 113800) The success of any cause naturally necessarily depends finally upon the will of God.
('18', 55, 3, 15, 113885) But that will is almost conditioned by the manner in which we who approach the throne of the Almighty conduct ourselves and nothing avails there but cold reason sanctified by truth, humility and strictest moderation.
('18', 55, 3, 16, 114102) In the new memorial, I would omit all mention of personal suffering.
('18', 55, 3, 17, 114171) It stands as a living record speaking for itself.
('18', 55, 3, 18, 114221) If you adopt my proposal, I would love to revise your draft.
('18', 55, 3, 19, 114282) The two other things in which I have disagreed with you are
('18', 55, 4, 20, 114342) 1 Dated 8 5 1919
('18', 56, 0, 1, 114359) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 57
('18', 56, 1, 2, 114403) your two letters sent to the Press for publication.
('18', 56, 1, 3, 114455) You now know why I stopped the publication of your first letter.
('18', 56, 1, 4, 114520) The second letter just received has also been stopped for the same reasons, but the additional reason for not printing it is that your plea for Mr. Nazim is unmerited.
('18', 56, 1, 5, 114688) When the crucial movement came, he stood not for truth but for untruth.
('18', 56, 1, 6, 114760) I am sorry for him, but I cannot feel with you that the action [the] authorities took was wrong.
('18', 56, 1, 7, 114857) He made a deliberately false statement, when he was challenged and when it was his special duty to make a correct statement.
('18', 56, 1, 8, 114982) I will not weary you with the full particulars of this painful episode.
('18', 56, 1, 9, 115054) I must confess too that I do not like your half disobedience of the order of the internment.
('18', 56, 1, 10, 115147) I do not know that you got my message sent to you, after my discharge at Bombay, that you need not disobey the order of internment and I would like you, if you could summon up the courage, to recall the notice of disobedience and tell the Viceroy that upon mature consideration and for the sake of the cause for which you stand, you have decided not to disobey the order for the time being.
('18', 56, 1, 11, 115538) You may not know that in my recent confidential letters to the Viceroy and the Governor of Bombay, I have definitely raised the Mohammedan question confining it to Khilafat and the holy places.
('18', 56, 1, 12, 115732) Please remember me to Aman Sahib and ask the childrenI forget the names of the blessed onesto write to me as they did before.
('18', 56, 2, 13, 115858) Yours sincerely,

('18', 56, 4, 15, 115903) 51. LETTER TO N. P. COWIE
('18', 56, 5, 16, 115929) [BOMBAY,] May 25, 1919
('18', 56, 6, 17, 115952) DEAR MR. COWIE, One Mr. Manilal Jadavji Vyas of Kathiawar and Dr. Popatlal, also of Kathiawar, who were resident in Karachi have, I understand, received orders under Act 3 of 1864 to leave British India, being classed as foreigners under that Act.
('18', 56, 6, 18, 116200) In virtue of these orders the parties left Sind and are now in Kathiawar.
('18', 56, 6, 19, 116274) I venture to consider that this act of the local authority in Karachi was high handed in treating subjects of native States as foreigners for the purpose of summarily
('18', 57, 0, 1, 116441) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 57, 1, 2, 116482) deporting them from Karachi.
('18', 57, 1, 3, 116511) My submission, however, receives legal justification from a perusal of the amendment of Section 1 of Act 3 of 1864. It appears to me that the Sind authorities were not cognisant of the recent amendment of that Act.
('18', 57, 1, 4, 116726) I observe that in 1914 that was thus amended:
('18', 57, 2, 5, 116772) In Section 1 of the Foreigners Act, 1864, for the words not being either or natural born subject of Her Majesty within the meaning of Statute 3 and 4 William IV, Chapter 85, Section 81, or a Native of British India, the following words shall be substituted namely:
('18', 57, 3, 6, 117037) (a) who is not a natural born British subject as defined in sub sections
('18', 57, 4, 7, 117110) (1) and (2) of Section 1 of the British Nationality & Status of Aliens Act, 1914, or
('18', 57, 5, 8, 117195) (b) who has not been granted a certificate of naturalization as a British subject under any law for the time being in force in British India;
('18', 57, 6, 9, 117337) Provided that any British subject who, under any law for the time being in force in British India, ceases to be a British subject, shall thereupon be deemed to be a foreigner. The operative part of Section 1 of the British Nationality and Aliens Act referred to in the above amendment reads as follows:
('18', 57, 7, 10, 117640) (I) The following persons shall be deemed to be natural born British subjects, namely,
('18', 57, 8, 11, 117727) (a) any person born within H. M.s dominions and allegiance;
('18', 57, 9, 12, 117787) (b) provided that the child of a British subject, whether that child was born before or after the passing of the Act, shall be deemed to have been born within H. M.s allegiance if born in a place where by treaty, capitulation, grant, usage, sufferance or other lawful means, H. M. exercises jurisdiction over British subjects.
('18', 57, 9, 13, 118114) It is quite clear that both these Native States subjects could not be treated as foreigners but being born in British Dominions or allegiance are natural born British subjects.
('18', 57, 9, 14, 118291) Alike therefore on grounds of equity and justice, I venture to submit that these deportees and such other deportees, if any, are entitled to return to their places of business and residence in Sind.
('18', 57, 9, 15, 118490) I trust therefore that H. E. will be pleased to order cancellation of the orders above mentioned.
('18', 57, 10, 16, 118588) From a photostat: S.N. 6624
('18', 58, 0, 1, 118616) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 59

('18', 58, 6, 12, 119248) 53. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI

('18', 64, 1, 4, 133285) I should have thought of this in the very beginning.

('18', 64, 1, 8, 133642) I shall try to explain what it means.
('18', 64, 1, 9, 133680) It has been stated in the Satyagraha Pledge itself that, so long as the Rowlatt Bills are not repealed, civil disobedience should be committed in respect of such laws as the committee may decide.
('18', 64, 1, 10, 133876) This, however, is only one part of the Pledge, and not a very important one at that.
('18', 64, 1, 11, 133961) Moreover, a satyagrahi should have certain qualities to be entitled to disobey laws.
('18', 64, 1, 12, 134046) We should consider, before everything else, what comes first in satyagraha.
('18', 64, 1, 13, 134122) Till we have thought this out and acted on it, disobeying laws will take us nowhere.
('18', 64, 1, 14, 134207) The first thing, then, is to employ nothing but truth in any agitation we may carry on to secure permanent repeal of this Act, and the second thing is to refrain from injuring anyone in person or property.
('18', 64, 1, 15, 134413) It seems to me that even satyagrahis have not followed these two things scrupulously.
('18', 64, 1, 16, 134499) I am sure that, if the more than 2,000 satyagrahis in the different parts of India had loyally carried out the Pledge, the things that happened would not have happened.
('18', 64, 1, 17, 134668) Their satyagraha would have had such an effect on the whole of India that the people would have understood its meaning quite well.
('18', 64, 1, 18, 134799) I admit, at the same time, that it is difficult to practise such satyagraha.
('18', 64, 1, 19, 134876) To refrain from injuring anyone means that even in our mind we should have no feeling of hostility against anyone.
('18', 64, 1, 20, 134991) This requires tapascharya 1. It is, then, of the very essence of satyagraha that, even while we resist oppression uncompromisingly, we may harbour no desire for revenge against the oppressor.
('18', 64, 1, 21, 135183) It is the weak in the world who seek revenge.
('18', 64, 1, 22, 135229) The strong can master the desire.
('18', 64, 1, 23, 135263) Strength does not mean physical strength.
('18', 64, 1, 24, 135305) He is a strong man or she a strong woman who knows how to die.

('18', 66, 1, 13, 139672) If we observe the first vow, we have another duty arising out of it.
('18', 66, 1, 14, 139741) In former times, India produced her own needs of cloth and also exported some.
('18', 66, 1, 15, 139820) Today, on the contrary, we produce only one fourth of our requirements.
('18', 66, 1, 16, 139892) In other words, we fail to discharge three fourths of our duty.
('18', 66, 1, 17, 139956) In consequence of this, more than three crores of people go starving.
('18', 66, 1, 18, 140026) I know that there are other reasons as well for this, but the most important cause is our violation of the principle of swadeshi.
('18', 66, 1, 19, 140156) I am, therefore, justified in requesting you to do prayashchitta 1 for the sin we have committed in violating that principle.
('18', 66, 1, 20, 140282) The prayashchitta consists in wearing khadi, since it is our fault that India does not produce fine cloth at the present day but produces only khadi.
('18', 66, 1, 21, 140432) I do not mean that nothing except khadi is available.
('18', 66, 1, 22, 140486) It must be our resolve, however, to make do with khadi should it be the only kind of cloth available.
('18', 66, 1, 23, 140588) This is our prayashchitta.
('18', 66, 1, 24, 140615) It is our plain duty to follow the rule of swadeshi henceforth.
('18', 66, 1, 25, 140679) By doing so, we shall save a sum of 60 crores of rupees, which was what we paid abroad during 1917 18. We shall keep our money in this country to the extent that we follow this rule.
('18', 66, 1, 26, 140862) There may be risk or difference of opinion about disobeying laws by way of satyagraha, but there can be no such risk in following the rule of

('18', 70, 1, 2, 146387) 59. NOTE ON THE INFORMAL PRIVATE SATYAGRAHA CONFERENCE 1
('18', 70, 2, 3, 146444) BOMBAY, May 30, 1919 This Conference met in Bombay on the 28th instant.
('18', 70, 2, 4, 146516) It was attended by delegates from Sind, Ahmedabad, Allahabad and Lucknow.
('18', 70, 2, 5, 146590) Mr. Gandhi explained the situation about the Punjab and said that in view of the impending abolition of martial law, time had arrived to consider the position from the satyagraha standpoint.
('18', 70, 2, 6, 146781) He added that technically speaking the Satyagraha Pledge on the Rowlatt legislation could not cover any contemplated action regarding the Punjab.
('18', 70, 2, 7, 146927) Every satyagrahi, therefore, had to consider the Punjab question on its own merits untrammelled by the Rowlatt Pledge.
('18', 70, 2, 8, 147046) Mr. Gandhi wanted the advice of those present on his proposal that he should approach the Viceroy with a view to the appointment of an independent and impartial committee of enquiry to examine the causes of the Punjab disturbances, the administration of martial law, and to revise the sentences passed by the Martial Law Tribunal and that, failing to secure the appointment of such a committee after carrying on a public agitation to the extent of an appeal to the Secretary of State for India, satyagraha should be taken up.
('18', 70, 2, 9, 147572) Mr. Gandhi said that he did not fear any outbreak of violence upon satyagraha (civil disobedience) being started, whether on the Punjab matter or on the Rowlatt legislation.
('18', 70, 2, 10, 147746) His advice would be in either case to confine civil disobedience to the satyagrahis for the time being of the Bombay Presidency.
('18', 70, 2, 11, 147875) There should be no hartal on any account whatsoever in connection with the movement, not even on prominent satyagrahis being arrested for civil disobedience.
('18', 70, 2, 12, 148033) No demonstration of any kind whatsoever should be made whilst there was the slightest danger of violence being committed by anybody.
('18', 70, 2, 13, 148166) Such undemons trative satyagraha would be almost the purest form.
('18', 70, 2, 14, 148232) To be able to offer such satyagraha required faith on the part of satyagrahis in the efficacy of silent suffering.
('18', 70, 2, 15, 148347) Mr. Gandhi anticipated no difficulty in the resumption of civil disobedience on the Rowlatt legislation, and he
('18', 70, 3, 16, 148459) 1 This was dated May 30, marked Not for Publication and was signed M. K. Gandhi.
('18', 71, 0, 1, 148540) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 71, 1, 2, 148581) said in answer to a question that it was possible that satyagraha on the Punjab matter might have to be undertaken after two weeks at the earliest, but he was not without hope that the Viceroy would grant the request for the appointment of a committee of inquiry.
('18', 71, 1, 3, 148845) After some discussion, with the exception of Mr. Jamnadas, all present approved of Mr. Gandhis proposal.
('18', 71, 1, 4, 148950) Mr. Jamnadas 1, whilst he liked the idea itself, could not approve of the proposal, as he felt certain that imprisonment of Mr. Gandhi or any prominent satyagrahi would be followed by violence.
('18', 71, 1, 5, 149144) A letter from Sannyasi Swami Shraddhanandji was read withdrawing himself from the movement and giving the information that the Delhi Committee was disbanded nearly a month ago.
('18', 71, 1, 6, 149321) A letter was also read from Mr. Hassan Imam who, whilst he was prepared to abide by the decision that Mr. Gandhi might arrive at, himself opined that, in view of the past experience, it would be wise to drop civil disobedience.

('18', 71, 3, 9, 149644) 60. LETTER TO S. R. HIGNELL
('18', 71, 4, 10, 149672) LABURNUM ROAD BOMBAY, May 30, 1919
('18', 71, 5, 11, 149707) DEAR MR. HIGNELL 2, It is within His Excellencys knowledge that I have made no public declaration regarding the events in the Punjab.
('18', 71, 5, 12, 149841) Even at the risk of being misunderstood by my countrymen, I have refrained from saying anything in public because I had no reliable data to enable me to form an opinion.
('18', 71, 5, 13, 150011) I was not prepared to condemn martial law as such; I was unwilling to do anything calculated needlessly to irritate local authority; and lastly I was not prepared to infer from Sir Michael ODwyers 3 reported severe administration during peace period that martial law measures would be unduly hard.
('18', 71, 6, 14, 150309) 1 He resigned from the Satyagraha Sabha due to these differences.
('18', 71, 6, 15, 150375) 2 Private Secretary to the Viceroy 3 Lieutenant Governor of the Punjab, 1913 9
('18', 72, 0, 1, 150454) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 73
('18', 72, 1, 2, 150498) But the virtual abolition of martial law in the Punjab in so far as it was the result of mob violence of April last makes it possible to refer to its administration without any impropriety.
('18', 72, 1, 3, 150688) I must own too that the official explanation regarding flogging and the bar against legal practitioners living outside the Punjab, together with the inspired justification therefor appearing in the Civil and Military Gazette, fill me with the greatest misgivings.
('18', 72, 1, 4, 150952) The official communiques have not been overfrank.
('18', 72, 1, 5, 151002) Some of them are remarkable for omissions and admissions.
('18', 72, 1, 6, 151060) The secrecy that has surrounded the events in the Punjab has given rise to much hostile criticism.
('18', 72, 1, 7, 151159) The complete gagging of the Indian Press has created the greatest resentment.
('18', 72, 1, 8, 151237) And the heavy sentences passed against the accused persons there have filled the public mind with consternation.
('18', 72, 1, 9, 151350) No one can dispute the right of the State to declare martial law under certain circumstances, but it will be conceded on behalf of the State that it should justify to the public the measures adopted under it, specially under circumstances described above.
('18', 72, 1, 10, 151606) I therefore venture to associate myself with the request made by the Press for an impartial and independent committee of inquiry to examine the causes of disturbances in the Punjab and the administration of martial law in the Province, including the sentences passed by the Martial Law Tribunal.
('18', 72, 1, 11, 151902) I am sure that if such a committee is appointed, it would calm the public mind and restore confidence (much shaken by the events in the Punjab) in the good intentions of the Government.
('18', 72, 1, 12, 152088) If the principle of granting such a committee of inquiry be accepted, as I hope it will, I trust that the committee to be appointed will be composed of such official and non official members as to inspire full confidence.
('18', 72, 1, 13, 152310) May I ask you to place this letter before His Excellency and to favour me with an early reply.
('18', 72, 2, 14, 152405) Yours sincerely,

('18', 74, 4, 8, 154638) 62. TRIBUTE TO B. G. TILAK BOMBAY
('18', 74, 5, 9, 154672) BOMBAY, May 31, 1919
('18', 74, 6, 10, 154693) A public meeting was held on Saturday evening at Shantarams Chawl, Girgaum, Bombay, under the presidency of Mr. Gandhi, for the purpose of expressing appreciation of the services rendered by Mr. Tilak to India and calling upon his countrymen to contribute to the expenses incurred by him in his case against Sir Valentine Chirol.
('18', 74, 6, 11, 155023) The following is a full translation of his speech in Gujarati:
('18', 74, 7, 12, 155086) I am thankful to the organizers of the meeting for asking me to preside.
('18', 74, 7, 13, 155159) The goal of every thinking Indian must be the same, though the methods for its attainment may be different and it is a matter known to all that my ways differ from Mr. Tilaks.
('18', 74, 7, 14, 155335) And yet I would wish to heartily associate myself with every occasion to pay a tribute to his great services to the country, his self sacrifice, and his learningand with the present occasion in especial.
('18', 74, 7, 15, 155539) The nation does not honour him any the less for his defeat in his case against Sir Valentine Chirol.
('18', 74, 7, 16, 155640) It honours him, if that were possible, all the more, and this meeting is but a token of it.
('18', 74, 7, 17, 155732) I have come to offer my hearty support to it.
('18', 74, 7, 18, 155778) Truly speaking, I am in no love with fighting in law courts.
('18', 74, 7, 19, 155839) Victory there does not depend on the truth of your case.
('18', 74, 7, 20, 155896) Any experienced vakil will bear me out that it depends more on the judge, the counsel, and the venue of the court.
('18', 74, 7, 21, 156011) In English there is a proverb that it is always the man with the longest purse that wins.
('18', 74, 7, 22, 156101) And there is a good deal of truth in this, as there is exaggeration in it.
('18', 74, 7, 23, 156176) The Lokamanyas defeat therefore made me only wish he was a satyagrahi like me, so that he would have saved himself the bother of victory or defeat.
('18', 74, 7, 24, 156324) And when I saw that far from losing heart at the result of his case, far from being disappointed, he faced the English public with cool resignation and expressed his views to them with equal
('18', 75, 0, 1, 156515) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 75, 1, 2, 156556) fearlessness, I was proud of him.
('18', 75, 1, 3, 156590) He has been in his life acting to the very letter up to what he has believed to be the essential teaching of the Gita.
('18', 75, 1, 4, 156709) He devotes himself entirely to what he believes to be his karma, and leaves the result thereof to God.
('18', 75, 1, 5, 156812) Who could withhold admiration from one so great?
('18', 75, 1, 6, 156861) I think it our duty to contribute to the expenses of his suit.
('18', 75, 1, 7, 156924) He surely did not fight for his personal ends, he fought in the public interests.
('18', 75, 1, 8, 157006) I am sure, therefore, that you will accept the resolution that is going to be proposed this evening to find for Mr. Tilak the expenses of his suit, and to express our gratefulness for his services to the country.

('18', 76, 1, 4, 158974) When I first went to South Africa, I did not know what a P. Note meant.

('18', 76, 2, 19, 160506) With the passing of time, desire will grow weaker, your physical and mental strength will increase and you will forget the thought of marriage.

('18', 76, 2, 23, 160915) In this matter, forget that I am your father and treat me as a good friend and see whether I pass the test.

('18', 76, 3, 27, 161193) I am occupied with some work or other from six in the morning to ten in the evening.
('18', 76, 3, 28, 161278) I cannot do now without a nap of 30 to 40 minutes during the day.
('18', 76, 3, 29, 161344) Despite so much work, the brain is not particularly tired at ten in the evening.

('18', 77, 5, 20, 162617) June 1, 1919
('18', 77, 6, 21, 162630) MAGANLAL, I heard about your having gone to Vijapur on my arrival here.
('18', 77, 6, 22, 162702) You did well, though I was quite eager to see you.

('18', 77, 6, 24, 162801) How can I rebuke you?

('18', 77, 6, 26, 162916) What I wanted to say, and would still say, is that we should be ready to curtail as many of the other activities as possible.
('18', 77, 6, 27, 163042) Who should curtail which, is for you to consider and decide.

('18', 77, 6, 29, 163270) On further reflection, I realized that this earlier demand was mistaken.
('18', 77, 6, 30, 163343) We should drop or curtail, one by one, those of our activities which we think others are likely to take up; and pay
('18', 77, 7, 31, 163459) 1 Prayer with set formula

('18', 78, 1, 2, 163529) more attention to those in which others have less faith, or none, but which are all the same essential.
('18', 78, 1, 3, 163633) Spinning is one such activity.
('18', 78, 1, 4, 163664) Besides, the more experience I gain, the more I realize that machinery will keep us in permanent slavery, and I find that what I said about it in Hind Swaraj is literally true.
('18', 78, 1, 5, 163841) About satyagraha, too, I have been discovering new truths.

('18', 78, 1, 9, 164184) The day before yesterday, some Punjabis came to see me.
('18', 78, 1, 10, 164240) They told me that, on their side, women of all castes, high and low, spin at home and get weavers to make cloth out of the yarn.
('18', 78, 1, 11, 164369) Thus, the cost of yarn comes to no more than that of cotton.

('18', 79, 3, 4, 165517) DEAR MISS SCHLESIN, Ramdas advises me that you have passed your teachers examination with some distinction.

('18', 79, 3, 10, 166023) Satyagraha is going on merrily.
('18', 79, 3, 11, 166055) Civil disobedience is expected to commence very soon.
('18', 79, 3, 12, 166109) How I often wish you were here for more reasons than one!
('18', 79, 3, 13, 166167) But I must plough the lonely furrow.
('18', 79, 3, 14, 166204) It often makes me sad when I think of all my helpers of South Africa.
('18', 79, 3, 15, 166274) I have no Doke here.
('18', 79, 3, 16, 166295) I have no Kallenbach.
('18', 79, 3, 17, 166317) Dont know where he is at the present moment.
('18', 79, 3, 18, 166362) Polak in England.
('18', 79, 3, 19, 166380) No counterpart of Kachalia or Sorabji.
('18', 79, 3, 20, 166419) Impossible to get the second edition of Rustomji.
('18', 79, 3, 21, 166469) Strange as it may appear, I feel lonelier here than in South Africa.
('18', 79, 3, 22, 166538) This does not mean that I am without co workers.
('18', 79, 3, 23, 166587) But between the majority of them and me, there is not that perfect correspondence which used to exist in South Africa.
('18', 79, 3, 24, 166706) I do not enjoy the same sense of security which you all gave me there.
('18', 79, 3, 25, 166777) I do not know the people here; nor they, me.
('18', 79, 3, 26, 166822) This is all gloomy, if I were to brood over it.
('18', 79, 3, 27, 166870) But I do not.
('18', 79, 3, 28, 166884) I have not the time for it.
('18', 79, 3, 29, 166912) I have a few moments of leisure just now.
('18', 79, 3, 30, 166954) Ramdas letter reminds me of your existence in South Africa, and I am giving myself the momentary pleasure of sharing my innermost thoughts with you.
('18', 79, 3, 31, 167103) But now no more.

('18', 80, 1, 2, 167192) 67. SPEECH ON SWADESHI VOW, BOMBAY
('18', 80, 2, 3, 167227) June 4, 1919
('18', 80, 3, 4, 167240) Gandhiji presided at the inaugural ceremony of The Hindi Vastra Prasarak Mandali at the Morarji Gokuldas Hall, Bombay, on June 4, 1919.
('18', 80, 4, 5, 167376) Mr. Gandhi explained in a few words what Mr. C. P. Ramaswami Aiyer 1 had said in English, for the benefit of those who did not know English.
('18', 80, 4, 6, 167517) He said that unless theyevery one of themresolved to use only swadeshi goods as much as possible, there could not be any hope for the country.
('18', 80, 4, 7, 167660) If they could take the swadeshi vow, so much the better; but if they could not, then they must firmly resolve to use swadeshi goods as much as possible.
('18', 80, 4, 8, 167813) They must also resolve to use Indian made cotton goods, so that not only Indias weavers might get employment, but their wives and children also.
('18', 80, 4, 9, 167958) He hoped they would take to heart all that Mr. Aiyer had told them that evening and act accordingly.

('18', 85, 1, 15, 177447) But I do not know if she does even this.

('18', 85, 1, 17, 177555) Do in this matter as Vallabhbhai or Indulal may advise.
('18', 85, 1, 18, 177611) See that Chhotalal and Jagannath learn spinning immediately.
('18', 85, 1, 19, 177672) These two and Mavji should be employed wholly on weaving.
('18', 85, 1, 20, 177730) You hope to raise the money for the Ashram expenses through agriculture.
('18', 85, 1, 21, 177803) Work on it as much as necessary for this purpose and no more.
('18', 85, 1, 22, 177865) Please consider it our duty to give most of our time at present to spinning and weaving, for we do not lose to other countries crores of rupees because of agriculture.
('18', 85, 1, 23, 178033) Thanks to the disappearance of weaving, we lost sixty crores during last year alone.
('18', 85, 1, 24, 178118) Certainly, we do not want to give up agriculture; in fact we want to improve and develop it.
('18', 85, 1, 25, 178211) But we cannot work on two things at a time and, therefore, it will be proper to attend to what is more important for the immediate present.
('18', 85, 1, 26, 178351) Even then, you may certainly work on agriculture as much as it is possible to do with hired men, without loss to us.
('18', 85, 1, 27, 178468) Ask the boys to give some of their time to this work.
('18', 85, 1, 28, 178522) I hope you have followed my point.
('18', 85, 1, 29, 178557) We shall also be generally in difficulty for money.
('18', 85, 1, 30, 178609) I can ask for only as much as I may get with little effort.
('18', 85, 1, 31, 178669) Personally, I very much like the changes we have introduced in regard to weaving.
('18', 85, 1, 32, 178751) They will also help us to be free, to a very great extent, from difficulties about money.

('18', 86, 5, 12, 179421) 75. MR. ANDREWS APPEAL 2
('18', 86, 6, 13, 179446) June 7, 1919
('18', 86, 7, 14, 179459) There are obvious difficulties in the way of Mr. Andrews appeal on behalf of the Punjab prisoners being taken up by the public.
('18', 86, 7, 15, 179587) There is no appeal to the Privy Council in the ordinary course against decisions of Martial Law Tribunals.
('18', 86, 7, 16, 179694) We understand from an eminent lawyer that a prisoner sentenced by such a Court might appeal to the King in Council who mightask the judicial committee of the Privy Council to review the Martial Law Court proceedings.
('18', 86, 7, 17, 179911) The King has naturally to be advised by his ministers.
('18', 86, 7, 18, 179966) The first act therefore has to be of a political nature in other words the decisions of the King in Council will be influenced by what the Viceroy might have to say in the first instance.
('18', 86, 7, 19, 180154) It was therefore better to move H. E. the Viceroy to grant a committee of inquiry with power to revise the sentences passed by the Martial Law Tribunal.
('18', 86, 7, 20, 180307) The petition to the King in Council can only be from the prisoners concerned; the appeal to the Viceroy goes from the public.
('18', 86, 7, 21, 180433) The latter is in every way therefore a more expeditious and effective process though the former if successful undoubtedly carries greater weight by reason of the

('18', 87, 1, 2, 180858) eminent traditions of the august body examining the cases.

('18', 87, 3, 7, 181364) 76. MR. HORNIMAN
('18', 87, 4, 8, 181381) Mr. Montagus references to Mr. Horniman bear out the remarks we made in our last issue 1 about the difficulty of getting justice at the centre, where only one side of questions presented there is really represented.
('18', 87, 4, 9, 181597) Mr. Montagu made out a complete case for Mr. Hornimans deportation on statements which he assumed to be true, but which in reality are not true.
('18', 87, 5, 10, 181742) When Mr. Horniman began to use his paper, in the midst of riots, to fan the flame and published an accusation that British troops had used soft nosed bullets in Delhi and his paper was distributed free to British troops in Bombay, hoping to excite insubordination, it was high time that he left India.
('18', 87, 5, 11, 182044) In normal times he would have been tried but in view of the riots prompt, swift action for restoration of order was necessary.
('18', 87, 5, 12, 182171) It would be difficult to pack more mis statements into two sentences than Mr. Montagu has managed to into the above two.
('18', 87, 5, 13, 182292) There were no riots in Bombay, he never fanned the flame, he actually advised suspension of civil disobedience when it was in danger of being unscrupulously used.
('18', 87, 5, 14, 182455) The statement regarding soft nosed bullets, as Mr. Jinnahs cable to Mr. Montagu shows, would have been promptly withdrawn had the censor allowed the telegram correcting the error to be sent or delivered without delay; lastly, the Chronicle was not distributed free, or at all, to British troops, and there could be no question of hoping to excite insubordination.
('18', 87, 5, 15, 182819) That Mr. Montagu, when he uttered the mis statements, did not know them to be such, does not lessen the severity of the punishment inflicted on Mr. Horniman and the public of Bombay.
('18', 87, 5, 16, 183002) His Excellency the Governor

('18', 88, 1, 3, 183292) It is the clear duty of the Bombay public not to rest satisfied until the wrong done is righted by the order against Mr. Horniman being withdrawn.

('18', 88, 3, 5, 183461) 77. LETTER TO A YOUNG JOURNALIST
('18', 88, 4, 6, 183494) BOMBAY, June 7, 1919 It is dangerous to call me Revered Father, as you will see presently.
('18', 88, 4, 7, 183585) I have no doubt about your prodigality.
('18', 88, 4, 8, 183625) The very slo venliness of your writing is eloquent proof of it and it certainly requires a prodigal son to write to his adopted Revered Father a letter containing almost as many corrections as there are lines in it written anyhow and unrevised.
('18', 88, 4, 9, 183870) A son frugal in his adjectives, obedient in reality, would write to his father, especially when he is deliberately adopted, a careful letter written in his best handwriting.
('18', 88, 4, 10, 184044) If he has not enough time, he will write only a line, but he would write it neatly.
('18', 88, 4, 11, 184128) Your article on Mr. Jamnadas was ill conceived and hurriedly written.
('18', 88, 4, 12, 184198) It could not be printed in Young India, nor is it worth printing in any other paper.
('18', 88, 4, 13, 184283) You will not reform Jamnadas by letters of that character, nor will you benefit the public thereby.
('18', 88, 4, 14, 184383) Your second article is not much better....
('18', 88, 4, 15, 184426) You really lose yourself in the exuberance of your own verbosity.
('18', 88, 4, 16, 184492) If you will give more attention to the thought than a mere lengthening out of your story, you will produce readable matter.
('18', 88, 4, 17, 184616) Why have you inflicted certificates on me?
('18', 88, 4, 18, 184659) How can they influence me when I know you so well?
('18', 88, 4, 19, 184710) I neither consider you well informed nor forceful as a writer and Mr. Menon must know very little of journalistic capacity if he really considered that you were able to acquit yourself with credit in any journalistic capacity.
('18', 88, 4, 20, 184937) Now you see how difficult it will be for you to please me and yet it will be easy enough.
('18', 88, 4, 21, 185027) If you will take pains in future, I would certainly take you as helper for Young India in spite of your many limitations as soon as you are free from your Ahmedabad obligation.
('18', 88, 4, 22, 185204) I think you owe it to Mr. Chatterjee and the A.P. to finish the work you have.
('18', 88, 4, 23, 185283) You can even help from Ahmedabad by giving me bright and graphic notes on the trials, not in the nature of carping criticism of the

('18', 93, 2, 3, 192545) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, June 9, 1919
('18', 93, 3, 4, 192581) DEAR MR. HIGNELL, I thank you for your letters in reply to my letter 1 suggesting the appointment of a committee regarding the Punjab disturbances, and I thank you, too, for your inquiry about my health which is tolerable.
('18', 93, 3, 5, 192804) I have just been studying the case of Babu Kalinath Roy, Editor of The Tribune of Lahore.
('18', 93, 3, 6, 192894) I have read the articles on which, and on which alone, he was tried under Section 124A of the Indian Penal Code.
('18', 93, 3, 7, 193007) A study of the case has left me with the impression that a very great wrong has been done to Babu Kalinath Roy.
('18', 93, 3, 8, 193119) I have gone through the file of The Tribune from the 1st of April and I have not seen another newspaper to surpass it for sobriety of statement and self restraint.
('18', 93, 3, 9, 193283) I commend the case to the very serious attention of His Excellency the Viceroy.
('18', 93, 3, 10, 193363) A glaring injustice like this ought not to be allowed to continue.
('18', 93, 3, 11, 193430) I therefore hope that a way would be found, and that soon, of releasing Mr. Roy.
('18', 93, 3, 12, 193511) The judgment says that Mr. Roy even tendered an apology.
('18', 93, 3, 13, 193568) I have not seen a single sentence in the articles concerned for which an apology need have been given.
('18', 93, 3, 14, 193671) But it is a thousand pities that even the apology of a gentleman was brushed aside.
('18', 93, 3, 15, 193755) I hope you will kindly place this letter before His Excellency as early as possible.
('18', 93, 3, 16, 193840) I enclose herewith for His Excellencys perusal a portion of Young India referring to Mr. Roys Case.
('18', 93, 4, 17, 193940) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('18', 94, 1, 2, 194098) 82. LETTER TO N. P. COWIE
('18', 94, 2, 3, 194124) BOMBAY, [On or after June 9, 1919]
('18', 94, 3, 4, 194159) DEAR MR. COWIE, I thank you for your letter of the 9th instant.
('18', 94, 3, 5, 194223) (I am asking Mr. Manilal Vyas himself to make a representation to His Excellency regarding his case.) But I venture to draw H.E.s attention to the fact that I did not write seeking for mere individual relief; I brought the case to H.E.s notice 1 as the case involved an important general principle.
('18', 94, 3, 6, 194522) Your letter however seems to question the right of a public man to request relief even in such cases.
('18', 94, 3, 7, 194624) The hardship caused by shutting off public men in the manner I appear to have been, is made apparent even in the present instance.
('18', 94, 3, 8, 194755) As I happen to know Mr. Manilal Vyas address, though I do not know him personally, I am able to write to him and suggest what he should do to secure relief.
('18', 94, 3, 9, 194912) I have, as stated in my previous letter, heard of other similar cases but I do not know the names of all the parties.
('18', 94, 3, 10, 195030) In Mr. Manilal Vyas own case, too, the matter will now take time.
('18', 94, 3, 11, 195096) Meanwhile the parties aggrieved have to continue to suffer although they might subsequen tly be proved to have done no wrong.
('18', 94, 3, 12, 195222) I would therefore still respect fully urge that the policy of treating subjects of Native States as forei gners under Act 3 of 1861 be examined and revised by His Excellencys Government without waiting for representations from the individuals affected by the orders of the Sind authorities.
('18', 94, 4, 13, 195513) Yours sincerely.

('18', 95, 0, 1, 195918) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 95, 1, 2, 195959) 84. BABU KALINATH ROY
('18', 95, 2, 3, 195981) By the courtesy of the Young India syndicate, composed as it is largely of satyagrahis since the deportation of Mr. Horniman, I have been permitted to supervise the editing of this journal.
('18', 95, 2, 4, 196171) I asked for such supervision because I was anxious that nothing should appear in it that was in any way inconsistent with the general principles of satyagraha, i.e., of truth and non violence to person or property.
('18', 95, 2, 5, 196386) In pursuance of the plan, I have hitherto also written some leading articles in the usual editorial style.
('18', 95, 2, 6, 196493) But for this issue I wish to take the sole responsibility, if there be any, of writing on the case of Babu Kalinath Roy, the Editor of the now defunct Tribune.
('18', 95, 2, 7, 196653) Personally, I consider that even from the point of view of the authorities, there is nothing wrong or out of the way in what I am about to say.
('18', 95, 2, 8, 196797) But lest they may think otherwise, it is due to the public and to the Young India syndicate that the authorship of this writing should be known.
('18', 95, 2, 9, 196942) With reference to the Punjab disturbances, by my complete silence over them I have allowed myself to be misunderstood by many friends, and, as is now well known, I have been deprived of the co operation, though never the friendship, of so respected and renowned a leader and co worker as Sannyasi Swami Shri Shraddhanandji.
('18', 95, 2, 10, 197266) But I still believe that I have done well in persisting in my silence, for I had no conclusive data to go upon.
('18', 95, 2, 11, 197378) No public declaration of mine could have in any way affected for the better the action of the authorities.
('18', 95, 2, 12, 197485) But Babu Kalinath Roys case materially alters the situation.
('18', 95, 2, 13, 197546) In my humble opinion, the ....
('18', 95, 2, 14, 197577) 1 represents a manifest and cruel wrong.
('18', 95, 2, 15, 197618) I have not the honour of knowing him personally.
('18', 95, 2, 16, 197667) When I took up the judgment in the case, I approached it with a feeling that there would be at least a prima facie case made out against the accused on some isolated passages in his writings.
('18', 95, 2, 17, 197859) But as I proceeded with it, the impression grew on me that it was a kind of special pleading in order to justify a conviction and a heavy sentence.
('18', 95, 2, 18, 198007) In order to check myself, I took up the numbers of The Tribune referred to in the judgment and on which the serious charge against Babu Kalinath Roy under Sec.
('18', 95, 2, 19, 198167) I24A of the Indian Penal Code was based, and a careful reading of every one of the writings in The Tribune more than confirmed the impression produced by a perusal of the judgment and led me to
('18', 95, 3, 20, 198361) 1 Some words are missing here in the source which is damaged.
('18', 96, 0, 1, 198423) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 97
('18', 96, 1, 2, 198467) think that the Martial Law Court had allowed its judgment to be warped and clouded by the atmosphere of suspicion and distrust surrounding it.
('18', 96, 1, 3, 198610) The best proof of my statement must be the judgment and the writings on which it is based.
('18', 96, 1, 4, 198701) They are therefore reproduced in this issue in full.
('18', 96, 1, 5, 198754) I have prefaced the judgment and the offending articles in The Tribune with extracts from the other numbers showing the whole tendency and tone of the writings from the beginning of April just after the Delhi affairs.
('18', 96, 1, 6, 198972) They are not extracts torn from their context but they are representative of the issue of The Tribune published after the 30th March last.
('18', 96, 1, 7, 199111) The dominant note pervading all the issues is that the agitation against the Rowlatt legislation should be conducted with sobriety, truth and non violence.
('18', 96, 1, 8, 199267) I could nowhere trace in them ill will, either against Englishmen in general, or against the English Government in particular.
('18', 96, 1, 9, 199394) Indeed, it would be difficult to surpass The Tribune in calmness and self restraint in the face of circumstances brought about by the Delhi affairs.
('18', 96, 1, 10, 199543) This is the test that the Special Tribunal put before itself for its guidance:
('18', 96, 2, 11, 199622) You will have to consider whether this publication was or was not a calm and temperate discussion of the events that had occurred.
('18', 96, 2, 12, 199753) The people have a right to discuss any grievances that they may have to complain of, but they must not do it in a way to excite tumult.
('18', 96, 2, 13, 199889) You may point out to the Government their errors .
('18', 96, 3, 14, 199940) The question is always as to the manner.
('18', 96, 3, 15, 199981) A question is made whether they (writings) show an intention to instruct by appealing to the judgment or to irritate and excite to sedition.
('18', 96, 3, 16, 200122) In other words, whether they appeal to the sense or the passions.
('18', 96, 4, 17, 200188) Judged by the standard set before the Court, the articles complained against do not warrant a conviction.
('18', 96, 4, 18, 200294) They cannot excite tumult, when daily during a period of exceeding stress the writer asks his readers to refrain from all violence, telling them in unmistakable terms that disturbance can only damage their cause.
('18', 96, 4, 19, 200507) The Editor has continuously appealed to the judgment of the readers by asking them not to prejudge, but to await the results of an inquiry which he persistently asked for.
('18', 96, 4, 20, 200679) The Courts discussion of the passages and articles fails to convince one of the propriety of its decision.
('18', 96, 4, 21, 200786) The Court has resented the use of the term Delhi Martyrs in the issues of the 6th and the 8th April.
('18', 96, 4, 22, 200887) When you read the contents under the headings, the one has reference to prayer at the Jumma Masjid and the
('18', 97, 0, 1, 200994) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 97, 1, 2, 201035) other to a Relief and Memorial Fund.
('18', 97, 1, 3, 201072) The Crime in the language of the Court was that the accused chose to emphasize the memorial for martyrs and not the relief, and the Court proceeds, the inference from this is plain. The plain inference from this that whoever put the heading felt that those who were shot down at Delhi were so dealt with, without sufficient cause.
('18', 97, 1, 4, 201403) Why this should be considered seditious passes comprehension.
('18', 97, 1, 5, 201465) And if such an inference shows, as it undoubtedly does, that the action of the magistrate who gave the order for firing was wrong, is the drawing of such a deduction to be punished?
('18', 97, 1, 6, 201647) We are told by the Court that one may point out to Government their errors.
('18', 97, 1, 7, 201723) I submit that Mr. Roy justly pointed out the error of one of the local authorities.
('18', 97, 1, 8, 201807) (Incidentally, I may mention that there is no such Editorial heading as Memorial to Delhi Martyrs referred to in the judgment.) The next indictment consists in the Editor having used the word dupe in connection with the action of some honorary magistrates and Municipal Commissioners who tried to dissuade shopkeepers from closing their shops.
('18', 97, 1, 9, 202151) This is what the article describing the demonstration of the 6th April says:
('18', 97, 2, 10, 202228) The masses of India are no fools....That they cannot be successfully duped ought to be clear from the very ignominious failure in this very case of certain Municipal Commissioners and honorary magistrates and several others who went round the city trying to persuade shopkeepers to keep their shops open.
('18', 97, 2, 11, 202533) This is a bare statement of fact as the accused knew it.
('18', 97, 2, 12, 202590) Then follows an examination of the other articles as to which the gravamen of the charge is the assertion of the Editor that the action of the Punjab Government was both unjust and unwarranted, and that it had exposed itself to the severest criticisms at the bar of public opinion.
('18', 97, 2, 13, 202872) Here, too, the Editor has after having reasoned to the reader led him to the conclusion to which he himself has arriveda procedure held to be entirely justifiable under the test accepted by the Court itself.
('18', 97, 2, 14, 203080) The wrong would undoubtedly be if the Editor had mis stated facts.
('18', 97, 2, 15, 203147) But in every case, as would appear from the articles reproduced herewith, the writer has fortified himself with what he believed to be facts, and which so far as the judgment allows us to see, have not been controverted.
('18', 97, 2, 16, 203368) The other two articles referred to by the Court are Delhi Tragedy in the issue of the 9th, and Blazing Indiscretion in the issue of the 10th April.
('18', 97, 2, 17, 203516) The Delhi Tragedy is a dispassionate review of the tragedy of the 30th March, and ends with an exhortation to the Government of India to appoint a public
('18', 98, 0, 1, 203670) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 99
('18', 98, 1, 2, 203714) inquiry.
('18', 98, 1, 3, 203723) Blazing Indiscretion is undoubtedly an indictment against Sir Michael ODwyer about his speech before the Punjab Legislative Council.
('18', 98, 1, 4, 203856) The speech analysed in the article in question certainly contains more than blazing indiscretion.
('18', 98, 1, 5, 203954) The truth of the matter is that the wrong man was in the wrong box, the right man to have been in the box of the accused should certainly have been Sir Michael ODwyer.
('18', 98, 1, 6, 204122) Had he not made inflammatory and irritating speeches, had he not belittled leaders, had he not in a most cruel manner flouted public opinion and had he not arrested Drs.
('18', 98, 1, 7, 204292) Kitchlew and Satyapal, the history of the last two months would have been differently written.
('18', 98, 1, 8, 204387) My purpose however is not to prove Sir Michael ODwyers guilt, but it is to prove Babu Kalinath Roys complete innocence, and to show that he has suffered a grievous wrong in the name of British justice, and I do not hesitate to ask Englishmen as I ask my countrymen to join me in the prayer for Babu Kalinath Roys immediate release.
('18', 98, 1, 9, 204719) As Mr. Norton has shown, and quite recently Sir P. S. Shivaswami Aiyer, that a Martial Law Tribunal was never contemplated to be one for the trial of cases involving delicate interpretations of difficult sections of ordinary enactments.
('18', 98, 1, 10, 204956) Such tribunals are properly designed only for summary justice being meted out to men who are caught red handed in acts of rebellion or crimes which means, if left unchecked, complete disruption of society.
('18', 98, 1, 11, 205162) One thing more remains to be considered.
('18', 98, 1, 12, 205203) Why should this case be singled out for special treatment when it is highly likely that an independent and impartial committee is likely to be appointed to overhaul the martial law administration in the Punjab and to revise the sentences passed by the Martial Law Court?
('18', 98, 1, 13, 205474) My answer is that Mr. Roys case does not admit of any doubt about it.
('18', 98, 1, 14, 205544) It is capable of being immediately considered by the Government and if the articles on which the charge against Mr. Roy was based do not amount to seditionas I hold they do nothe should be immediately set free.
('18', 98, 1, 15, 205755) Moreover, time is an important consideration in this case, for Mr. Roy, as Mr. Andrews has pointed out, has a very delicate constitution.
('18', 98, 2, 16, 205893) GANDHI Young India, 11 6 1919
('18', 99, 0, 1, 205923) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 99, 1, 2, 205965) 85. MEMORIAL TO VICEROY 1
('18', 99, 2, 3, 205991) BOMBAY, [June 11, 1919] We, the undersigned citizens of the Bombay Presidency, crave leave to approach Your Excellency with their humble prayer that Your Excellency may be graciously pleased, in the exercise of your prerogative, to direct the release from prison of Babu Kalinath Roy, late Editor of The Tribune newspaper of Lahore, who has been convicted by a Martial Law Commission of the offence of seditious writings under Section 124 A of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to 2 years rigorous imprisonment together with a fine of Rs. 1,000 or, in default, six months further rigorous imprisonment.
('18', 99, 2, 4, 206596) In so praying, the petitioners have no desire to enter into the legal merits of the case or of the judgment of the Commission, beyond submitting grounds strictly appropriate as relevant to the prayer for the exercise of the prerogative.
('18', 99, 2, 5, 206833) The first ground is that the articles in The Tribune indicated as seditious and held by the Commission to be such, contain no words of disaffection or incitement to violence, lawlessness, or rebellion.
('18', 99, 2, 6, 207035) They are the criticism of certain Acts and measures of the Punjab Government, expressly made with a view to an impartial inquiry by Government.
('18', 99, 2, 7, 207179) The sole legal justification for the Commissions finding that they are seditious must, therefore, be sought in the extreme of the law of sedition, that whether any words and writings, are seditious as endangering peace, depends on the character of the times when they are published.
('18', 99, 2, 8, 207462) That legal theory renders the law as to sedition so uncertain as to prove (according to some eminent English jurists and lawyers) a pitfall even to innocent journalists, and makes no distinc tion between criticisms, right or wrong, of specific measures of Gover nment and deliberate attacks on it with a view to endanger peace.
('18', 99, 2, 9, 207790) To that ground the petitioners beg to add these further considerations in favour of Mr. Roy, viz., (1) the habitually sober character of his writings in The Tribune during his editorship; (2) the
('18', 99, 3, 10, 207986) 1 Presented on behalf of the citizens of Bombay, this was signed by Gandhiji and others including Sir Narayan G. Chandavarkar, Sir Dinshaw Wachha, G. K. Parekh and K. Natarajan.
('18', 99, 3, 11, 208164) Gandhiji sent it to the Viceroy on June 27, 1919; vide Letter to S. R. Hignell, 27 6 1919.
('18', 100, 0, 1, 208255) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 101
('18', 100, 1, 2, 208300) poor state of his health, and the effect any prolonged incarceration is likely to produce on it; and (3) the apology he tendered previous to his trial before the Commission.

('18', 100, 6, 10, 208981) (2) In our humble opinion, all of these writings are perfectly capable of entirely innocent interpretation and we respect fully submit to Your Excellency that, in the light of the habitually sober character of Mr. Roys writing in The Tribune during the period of his editorship, it is but just and fair that they should be understood in a liberal and unconstrained sense.

('18', 101, 1, 2, 210050) 87. CIRCULAR LETTER ON KALINATH ROYS CASE
('18', 101, 2, 3, 210092) June 11, 1919
('18', 101, 3, 4, 210106) DEAR I enclose herewith a portion of Young India containing full text of the judgment in Babu Kalinath Roys case, the articles on which it is based and my remarks thereon.
('18', 101, 3, 5, 210278) In my opinion, there should be wide and prompt agitation throughout the country for the release of Babu Kalinath Roy on grounds of simple justice.
('18', 101, 3, 6, 210425) I venture to suggest (1) a memorial by local lawyers (2) a memorial by local editors and (3) resolutions at public meetings for the release of Babu Kalinath Roy to His Excellency the Viceroy.
('18', 101, 3, 7, 210617) The lawyers memorial will show that the conviction is a legal wrong.
('18', 101, 3, 8, 210686) The editors memorial will show that they would have written nothing less than Mr. Roy wrote and public meetings will pass resolution requesting release of Babu Kalinath Roy on grounds of justice.
('18', 101, 3, 9, 210882) If you fall in with my suggestion, I would suggest your writings to the traders in your district to adopt similar memorials and resolutions.
('18', 101, 3, 10, 211023) We ought to invite Englishmen to associate with us, if they will, in asking for the redress of a clearly demonstrable injustice.
('18', 101, 3, 11, 211152) Time is of the essence in this matter.
('18', 101, 3, 12, 211191) Whatever is done must be done promptly.
('18', 101, 3, 13, 211231) If it is a shame that the Government should permit this manifest wrong to continue, it will be an equal shame after knowing the existence of a proven wrong for the public to rest still and satisfied until it is removed.
('18', 101, 4, 14, 211451) Yours sincerely, M. K, G.

('18', 106, 4, 7, 217973) 95. LETTER TO E. S. MONTAGU
('18', 106, 5, 8, 218001) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, June, 14, 1919
('18', 106, 6, 9, 218039) DEAR MR. MONTAGU, At the time I sent you a message through Sir Prabhashankar Pattani 1, I told him I would probably be writing to you on the subject 1 discussed with him.
('18', 106, 6, 10, 218210) But I have refrained till now, as I was loath to trouble you more than I could help in the midst of your multifarious duties.
('18', 106, 6, 11, 218336) I however did send another message through Mr. Shastriar as also Dr. Sir Stanley Reed.
('18', 106, 6, 12, 218423) Your kindly reference to me as also your hope that I would act more responsibly necessitates my writing to you.
('18', 106, 6, 13, 218535) Our common interest in an Empire to which both you and I belong is my excuse for asking you to spare a few moments for this letter.
('18', 106, 6, 14, 218667) I would like to assure you that I have acted with the greatest deliberation and with a due sense of responsibility.
('18', 106, 6, 15, 218783) I had not the vaguest notion of the deep seated and widespread anger against the Government.

('18', 106, 6, 17, 218989) But the idea struck the religious imagination of an angry people.
('18', 106, 6, 18, 219055) They thought that deliverance lay through some such demonstrative and penitential act.

('18', 106, 6, 20, 219366) I was proceeding to Delhi not to offer civil disobedience but was going at the instance of the Delhi leaders to calm the popular mind there and thence to the Punjab on a similar mission.
