('18', 111, 3, 6, 227113) 100. THE SWADESHI VOW 1
('18', 111, 4, 7, 227137) Monday, June 16, 1919
('18', 111, 5, 8, 227159) We advisedly deferred issuing this leaflet so long, for the reason that we thought it necessary to make some provision for the supply of cloth to intending signatories before giving the vow wider publicity.
('18', 111, 5, 9, 227366) Mr. Naranji Purushottam has succeeded in securing the co operation of Mr. Vithaldas Jerajani, lately manager of the Swadeshi Co operative Stores, and has invested his own capital in starting a Pure Swadeshi Cloth Store, the opening ceremony of which will take place on Wednesday next.
('18', 111, 5, 10, 227651) Any person will be able to get at this Store pure swadeshi cloth woven from yarn spun out of indigenous cotton, wool or silk.
('18', 111, 5, 11, 227777) Messrs Narandas and Jerajani have vowed not to charge more than 5 per cent on cost price as profits.
('18', 111, 5, 12, 227878) A fixed rate of prices will be strictly observed.
('18', 111, 5, 13, 227928) These gentlemen have also vowed not to charge anything by way of profits on hand woven cloth out of hand spun yarn.
('18', 111, 5, 14, 228044) Pure swadeshi cloth within the meaning of our vow, as also cloth which alone can be called pure swadeshi, but which is not yet available enough for a large number of vow takers, will thus be obtainable at this Store from Thursday next.
('18', 111, 5, 15, 228280) As this Store is going to be run on purely patriotic lines, and not on business lines, nothing but cloth necessary for swadeshi vow No.
('18', 111, 5, 16, 228416) 1 and No.
('18', 111, 5, 17, 228426) 2 will be sold at the Store.
('18', 111, 5, 18, 228455) Only shops run on these lines and a hearty public response to them can materially promote swadeshi.
('18', 111, 5, 19, 228555) We hope other liberal minded merchants will copy Mr. Naranji Purushottams example, and provide facilities for these taking the swadeshi vow.
('18', 111, 5, 20, 228696) But it must be fully borne in mind that merely opening swadeshi stores will never satisfy the objects of swadeshi.
('18', 111, 5, 21, 228811) One great object of the propagation of swadeshi is to prevent the countrys wealth
('18', 111, 6, 22, 228893) 1 Described as the second leaflet in the source.
('18', 111, 6, 23, 228942) For the first leaflet, vide The Swadeshi Vow, 13 5 1919.
('18', 112, 0, 1, 228999) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 113
('18', 112, 1, 2, 229044) fromgoing out of it.
('18', 112, 1, 3, 229065) And this can be attained only if import of foreign cloth is stopped and more cloth produced at home.
('18', 112, 1, 4, 229166) The thing to be borne in mind in this connection is not that swadeshi cloth produced in the country remains unsold for want of buyers.
('18', 112, 1, 5, 229301) The fact is that we do not produce enough cloth to meet our needs.
('18', 112, 1, 6, 229368) Every man and woman taking the swadeshi vow must therefore keep one aim in view, viz., that he or she should produce, or get somebody to produce, cloth necessary for his or her requirements.
('18', 112, 1, 7, 229559) If lakhs of men and women were to do this, much of the money going out of our country would remain here, and the exorbitant prices of cloth our poor people have to pay would be saved.
('18', 112, 1, 8, 229743) In view of these considerations, it is clear that he helps swadeshi more who produces or helps to produce more swadeshi cloth, than one who simply rests satisfied with using swadeshi cloth.
('18', 112, 1, 9, 229933) Let us now consider how production of cloth can be increased in the country.
('18', 112, 1, 10, 230010) I here are three ways of doing this: (1) by starting more mills; (2) by purchasing foreign yarn and weaving it on handlooms; (3) by weaving oneself or getting woven cloth out of yarn spun by oneself or by someone else in ones own country.
('18', 112, 1, 11, 230249) Now apart from any views against machine made cloth, it will be seen that it is no easy thing to start mills as quickly as we would It certainly takes some time to erect buildings for the mill, to get machines from abroad and to procure labour.
('18', 112, 1, 12, 230494) Assuming, therefore, for a moment that there would be no difficulty in obtaining capital, it is not possible for us to add to the stock of our cloth by means of having new mills.
('18', 112, 1, 13, 230673) It is no doubt possible to weave cloth from yarn obtained from abroad, and the second swadeshi vow was devised with the view that it is far better to use cloth woven in our country out of foreign yarn, and thus to save some money at least going out of the country, than not to use swadeshi cloth at all.
('18', 112, 1, 14, 230977) But the more I think, the more I see dangers in this.
('18', 112, 1, 15, 231031) Our demand for foreign yarn in a quantity sufficient for cloth necessary for lakhs of men is likely to send up the prices of foreign yarn to such an extent that the rise will be equal to the wages we have to pay for labour here, which would mean that we had gone ahead, only to fall back.
('18', 112, 1, 16, 231320) If, therefore, we could find some way out, we would not have to depend on foreign yarn.
('18', 112, 1, 17, 231408) This brings us to the third way, viz., to get yarn spun here, and
('18', 113, 0, 1, 231474) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 113, 1, 2, 231516) to get it woven on handlooms.
('18', 113, 1, 3, 231546) This is the royal road, and the surest to lead us to the goal.
('18', 113, 1, 4, 231609) If this is adopted by the people, the goal will be reached with the least possible labour and in the shortest possible time.
('18', 113, 1, 5, 231734) This would also provide thousands of men with an independent calling, and hundreds of thousands of poor women and widows with a means of livelihood to be pursued in their own homes.
('18', 113, 1, 6, 231916) The experiment does not require any very large capital, but it does require two things to be successful.
('18', 113, 1, 7, 232021) The first thing necessary is a number of volunteers.
('18', 113, 1, 8, 232074) They need not be highly educated or highly intelligent.
('18', 113, 1, 9, 232130) Honesty and perseverance are indispensable.
('18', 113, 1, 10, 232174) Education and intelligence cannot be had at will, but honesty and perseverance can be had if one but makes up ones mind for them.
('18', 113, 1, 11, 232304) The volunteers can be useful in two ways: (1) They can learn spinning and/or weaving and can dedicate some hours of their labour to the country, or (2) they can find out men knowing spinning and weaving and introduce them to the public.
('18', 113, 1, 12, 232541) If a number of such volunteers came forward, we would within a very short time produce cloth worth thousands of rupees.
('18', 113, 1, 13, 232661) But of more importance than even the volunteers is pure love of country, a sacrifice of some luxuries which it entails.
('18', 113, 1, 14, 232781) It will take a long time, of course, to raise the art of spinning to its original level and to produce yarn sufficiently fine to weave fine muslin out of it.
('18', 113, 1, 15, 232939) At the present moment, numerous men and women can learn the art of spinning to start with.
('18', 113, 1, 16, 233030) Spinning fine yarn is a matter of practice and careful effort.
('18', 113, 1, 17, 233093) In the meantime, people will have to be satisfied with what cloth they can get made out of hand spun yarn.
('18', 113, 1, 18, 233200) If they are not ready even for this little sacrifice, it will not be possible for us to fulfil a great pledge like the swadeshi.
('18', 113, 1, 19, 233329) We hope to consider this third method of increasing the stock of our cloth at some more length in our next leaflet.
('18', 113, 2, 20, 233445) M. K. GANDHI Young India, 18 6 1919

('18', 114, 10, 16, 234603) 102. SPEECH ON SWADESHI, BOMBAY 1
('18', 114, 11, 17, 234637) June 17, 1919 The ideas which I used to express piecemeal since the year 1900 have been confirmed by my experience here in India.
('18', 114, 11, 18, 234767) So long as we do not bring ourselves to observe scrupulously the rule of swadeshi, we shall not succeed in attaining swaraj.
('18', 114, 11, 19, 234892) Those who have read any book on Indian history will instantly recall that the Dutch, the French and the British came to India for the sole purpose of trade.
('18', 114, 11, 20, 235049) We had no navy at that time, though of course we had a merchant fleet.
('18', 114, 11, 21, 235120) The concern of our people for dharma is evidence enough that India depended entirely on her skills for defending her trade.
('18', 114, 11, 22, 235244) The kind of fine cloth which India produced then no other country did, and it was
('18', 114, 12, 23, 235326) 1 The meeting was held near Carnac Bunder, Gandhiji was in the chair.
('18', 115, 0, 1, 235396) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 115, 1, 2, 235438) this which attracted foreign merchants to India.
('18', 115, 1, 3, 235487) The tracery work formerly done in India was so good and artistic that it had no equal anywhere else.
('18', 115, 1, 4, 235588) With the advance of research, European scholars testify that our sciences, and even our holy books, went abroad following the very lines of our trade.
('18', 115, 1, 5, 235739) This caught the eyes of merchants from all the three countries and they took shiploads of wonders from India.
('18', 115, 1, 6, 235849) So wonderful were the things produced in the country in those days that these merchants thought it profitable to carry away shiploads of them.
('18', 115, 1, 7, 235992) They also carried spices and herbs from here.
('18', 115, 1, 8, 236038) This very India which was reputed to be a prosperous country, leading in trade, has fallen into the present plight, being obliged to import her needs from abroad.
('18', 115, 1, 9, 236201) In no other country will you find such a state of affairs.
('18', 115, 1, 10, 236260) The chief reason, in my view, for this miserable condition is our loss of interest in swadeshi goods, and you, too, if you but think, will feel the same way; for you will find no country which advanced by turning its back upon its own goods.
('18', 115, 1, 11, 236502) Not many centuries have passed since free trade was introduced in England; even then, she has never permitted herself to be in the same condition in which we find ourselves [today].
('18', 115, 1, 12, 236684) The people of Australia, New Zealand and of South Africa, of which I have personal experience, freely use goods produced in their own countries and impose customs duties as they think best on imported goods; for they are not dependent on such goods.
('18', 115, 1, 13, 236934) We in India lost even our freedom only because we abandoned swadeshi.
('18', 115, 1, 14, 237004) Though the Moghul Emperors are in a sense regarded as foreigners, under their rule India was not reduced to the plight which she is in today; for at that time India flourished in trade and industry and even the luxuries which surrounded the Emperors were the produce of indigenous craftsmanship so that the countrys wealth remained in the country.
('18', 115, 1, 15, 237352) The sight of our old monuments like the Taj Mahal, the Kutub Minar, etc., cannot but recall to us the prosperity of our by gone days.
('18', 115, 1, 16, 237486) When we scrupulously follow the law of swadeshi, even British rule will cease to be foreign rule and will become swadeshi rule.
('18', 115, 1, 17, 237614) When we cease to import any goods from outside, our relations with foreign countries will no longer be based on considerations of self interest but will be inspired by concern for general welfare.
('18', 115, 1, 18, 237811) Only when all the nations of the world seek their welfare with a sense of kinship among themselves as among members of a family, will England adopt such an attitude towards us.
('18', 115, 1, 19, 237988) We are not even able to follow our dharma of using swadeshi; how, then, can we compare ourselves with England?
('18', 115, 1, 20, 238099) Swadeshi is our primary dharma;
('18', 116, 0, 1, 238131) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 117
('18', 116, 1, 2, 238176) not to follow it and yet hope for Indias progress is like hoping to find a flower in the sky.
('18', 116, 1, 3, 238270) When swadeshi was introduced in Bengal, the people there were not ready for it, nor the traders.
('18', 116, 1, 4, 238367) The leaders then embarked upon the task of spreading swadeshi far and wide among the people, and gave it up, for, in the attempt to take too big a step, they lost everything.
('18', 116, 1, 5, 238542) We should embrace again what we have abandoned all these 200 years.
('18', 116, 1, 6, 238610) If we think of using everything swadeshi all at once, the result will be that we shall succeed in using none.
('18', 116, 1, 7, 238720) I am placing before the people a programme which they can assimilate and carry out.
('18', 116, 1, 8, 238804) If we start using only swadeshi cloth, we shall prevent the loss of 60 crores of rupees to foreign countries on that account.
('18', 116, 1, 9, 238930) This will be no small gain.
('18', 116, 1, 10, 238958) The purest swadeshi vow will be to use cloth made out of yarn spun by ones wife, sisters and children in the home.
('18', 116, 1, 11, 239073) Even mill made cloth cannot be treated as pure swadeshi, for the yarn [used in it] is produced here and [finished] on costly machines abroad with foreigners intelligence.
('18', 116, 1, 12, 239244) That means that we are entirely dependent [in respect of mill made cloth] on foreign sources.
('18', 116, 1, 13, 239338) You will see at Narandass shop on Thursday a stock of swadeshi goods which will supply the cloth required to observe the vow of undiluted swadeshi.
('18', 116, 1, 14, 239486) The chief reason so far for our being in such a state is our lethargy and lack of patriotic sentiment.
('18', 116, 1, 15, 239589) There was a time in India when they worked on perfect machines which a carpenter of ordinary abilities could make in a day.
('18', 116, 1, 16, 239713) Shri Narandas and Shri Vithaldas have undertaken to run this pure swadeshi store and spread the idea throughout the country.
('18', 116, 1, 17, 239838) I hope you will take advantage of this shuddha 1 Swadeshi Store.

('18', 117, 1, 2, 239981) 103. LETTER TO S. R. HIGNELL
('18', 117, 2, 3, 240010) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, June 18, 1919
('18', 117, 3, 4, 240047) DEAR MR. HIGNELL, It is just likely that this letter will cause pain to His Excellency.
('18', 117, 3, 5, 240135) But I fear that it is my duty to inform H.E. that I contemplate renewing civil disobedience in July next unless circumstances alter my plans.
('18', 117, 3, 6, 240277) The awful experiences of the past two months and a half have shown me that there is nothing save satyagraha of which civil disobedience is an integral part, that can possibly save India from Bolshevism and even a worse fate.
('18', 117, 3, 7, 240502) In spite of the indications to a superficial observer may appear to be contrary, satyagraha alone can smooth the relations between Englishmen and Indians.
('18', 117, 3, 8, 240657) I would like His Excellency to believe with me that the exhibition of anti English feeling during the second week of April was not due to the advent of satyagraha which is designed among other things to remove the acerbity 1 between the two members of the Empire but to pre existing causes and the further belief (and this is the more important) that the madness was confined to certain small parts only of this great continent because satyagraha had arrived and it was doing its silent but most efficient and effective work during the critical period.
('18', 117, 3, 9, 241210) I will not deny that the military preparations had, too, something to do with the preservation of peace in the other parts of India.
('18', 117, 3, 10, 241343) But I venture to suggest that satyagraha had a greater deal to do with it.
('18', 117, 3, 11, 241418) Anyway, such being my opinion of satyagraha and its efficacy, I would be no longer justified in further suspending civil disobedience.
('18', 117, 3, 12, 241553) I wish I could persuade the Viceroy to see eye to eye with me in the matter of the Rowlatt legislation.
('18', 117, 3, 13, 241657) It is legislation which irrespective of merits ought not to stand after the expression of public feeling against it during the months of March and April.
('18', 117, 3, 14, 241811) No doubt, there were many causes operating in favour of the vast demonstrations witnessed on the 6th of April last.
('18', 117, 3, 15, 241927) But the Rowlatt legislation was the causa causans.
('18', 117, 3, 16, 241978) I trust that His Excellency will see his way to withdraw the legislation.
('18', 117, 4, 17, 242052) 1 The source has acerbation.
('18', 118, 0, 1, 242081) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 119
('18', 118, 1, 2, 242126) My letter regarding the appointment of a committee of inquiry 1
('18', 118, 2, 3, 242190) is already before H.E. as also my letter requesting the release of Babu Kalinath Roy.
('18', 118, 2, 4, 242276) 2 Both these are matters of the greatest importance and have an intimate connection with the Rowlatt legislation agitation.
('18', 118, 2, 5, 242400) I hope that both my requests will receive H.E.s favourable consideration.
('18', 118, 2, 6, 242474) It now remains for me to add that should a renewal of civil disobedience become necessary, it will be confined only to myself, the other satyagrahis will qualify themselves for civil disobedience by assisting to preserve peace and by other services of an ennobling character.
('18', 118, 2, 7, 242750) My earnest desire is in the present circumstances of the country to confine civil disobedience to the narrowest limits possible.
('18', 118, 2, 8, 242879) For the time being, all demonstrations including hartal will be avoided.
('18', 118, 3, 9, 242952) Yours sincerely,

('18', 118, 5, 11, 242997) 104. SPEECH ON OPENING SHUDDHA SWADESHI VASTRA BHANDAR, BOMBAY 3
('18', 118, 6, 12, 243062) June 18, 1919 Mr. Gandhi, addressing the meeting, said that the first thing that he would like to point out was that the idea of making money was farthest from the organizers of the Store whose only end and aim was to minister to the needs of the people, charging the least possible rates.
('18', 118, 6, 13, 243352) The Store deserved their most active sympathy and support which could only be proved if a number of rich merchants followed by opening many such stores not only in Bombay, but in other parts of India.
('18', 118, 6, 14, 243553) Mr. Gandhi next read a letter from Mr. Jamnadas wherein he had expressed his inability to attend the function as he had to be away at Poona, and expressed a wish that many of his brethren in Bombay would follow Mr. Narandas 4 example.
('18', 118, 6, 15, 243788) Proceeding, Mr. Gandhi said that there were no two opinions as to the importance of swadeshi.
('18', 118, 6, 16, 243882) It was as much a necessity of daily life
('18', 118, 7, 17, 243923) 1 Vide Letter to J. L. Maffey, 16 5 1919. 2 Vide Letter to S. R. Hignell, 9 6 1919. 3 At the Morarji Gokuldas Cloth Market 4 One of the proprietors of the Store
('18', 119, 0, 1, 244084) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 119, 1, 2, 244126) as air, water and food.
('18', 119, 1, 3, 244150) The truth of this could only be realized by looking at swadeshi in a religious spirit.
('18', 119, 1, 4, 244237) No nation on earth had risen without adopting swadeshi as a principle of life.
('18', 119, 1, 5, 244316) It was beyond his purpose to dilate any more on the necessity and importance of swadeshi, he only wanted to offer a few suggestions as to how swadeshi could be put into practice and how it could be promoted.
('18', 119, 1, 6, 244524) This first thing was to understand ones limitations, and in the present wretchedly dependent state of the country, one could not but restrict the principle to clothing alone.
('18', 119, 1, 7, 244699) India produced only twenty five per cent of cloth necessary to clothe its people.
('18', 119, 1, 8, 244781) It was therefore their principal duty to produce more cloth.
('18', 119, 1, 9, 244842) He wished to point out to all the members of the mercantile community present, with all the force that he could command, that without producing a sufficient stock of pure swadeshi cloth, their salvation was impossible.
('18', 119, 1, 10, 245061) He hoped, therefore, that those who had money and those who had expert knowledge would place their money and their knowledge at the disposal of the country.
('18', 119, 1, 11, 245218) He asked those present to hark back to the past when swadeshi was practised without any effort, as effortlessly as one took in air and water, and he asked them to consider how that was possible.
('18', 119, 1, 12, 245413) The simplest and the most effective contrivance of handloom rendered that possible.
('18', 119, 1, 13, 245497) He did not for a moment think Europe had a monopoly of intellect and enterprise.
('18', 119, 1, 14, 245578) When other nations were leading the most primitive life, when they could find no better clothing than the bark of trees or hides of animals, Indians invented the art of growing cotton, of spinning cotton and weaving it into cloth.
('18', 119, 1, 15, 245809) He believed that the intellect of the man who devised the simple spinning wheel and the handloom was far greater than that of the man who invented the power spindle and the power loom.
('18', 119, 1, 16, 245994) He was glad to inform them that in the Punjab at the present moment thousands of ladies even of high families were spinning yarn in their own homes, that he had himself secured the willing service of a Punjabi lady who conducted a spinning class at his own residence in Bombay.
('18', 119, 1, 17, 246272) He referred with touching effect to the fine music of the spinning wheel that he had the privilege to hear nowadays and invited them to share that privilege with him and to convince themselves what a jarring contrast was produced by the harsh noise of the spindles and looms in a modern factory.
('18', 119, 1, 18, 246568) He was pained to point out that there were 56,00,000 sadhus in India who lived entirely on begging.
('18', 119, 1, 19, 246668) It was their
('18', 120, 0, 1, 246681) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 121
('18', 120, 1, 2, 246726) clear duty to tempt these sadhus out of their idleness and to persuade them to employ themselves in spinning and weaving.
('18', 120, 1, 3, 246848) There were, besides the sadhus, many widows who spent most of their time in temples and idle ritual.
('18', 120, 1, 4, 246949) He would most earnestly advise these and other ladies of rich families who had no other work to do to take to spinning and weaving and give some hours of their labour to the country.
('18', 120, 1, 5, 247132) He added that he did not need to point out to them that swadeshi cloth was much more durable than foreign cloth, as that was a matter of everyones experience.
('18', 120, 1, 6, 247291) Mr. Gandhi then said that he had prepared after some consultation and discussion with Mrs. Ramibai Kamdar and others a third vow 1 which allowed those taking it to continue the use of foreign clothes that were in their possession before taking the vow.
('18', 120, 1, 7, 247544) He had done this in deference to the earnest wishes of some ladies, and he was not sure there were no dangers in that vow.
('18', 120, 1, 8, 247667) He therefore emphasized that those taking the third vow would keep as their goal the first vow and try to dispose of the foreign clothes in their possession as speedilyas they could, by using them for daily use and reserving pure swadeshi cloth for important ceremonial occasions.
('18', 120, 1, 9, 247948) Mr. Gandhi exhorted the audience to realize the importance of commercial morality.
('18', 120, 1, 10, 248031) He laid special emphasis on the fact that so long as speculation was rife in Bombay, it was bound to be a great barrier in the success of swadeshi.
('18', 120, 1, 11, 248179) It was high time that they resolved to keep studiously aloof from it.
('18', 120, 1, 12, 248249) The Japan magnates laid their titles and their treasures at the disposal of their country.
('18', 120, 1, 13, 248340) The magnates of India could also copy their example and render lasting service to their country.
('18', 120, 1, 14, 248437) Humanity and honesty should be their watchwords and true patriotism which was the only effective motive force should guide them.
('18', 120, 1, 15, 248566) Swadeshi, he concluded, was one of the very few subjects on which there was absolutely no difference of opinion and he expected all who were concerned in some way or other with the shaping of the countrys destiny to grasp the fact and actively move in the direction of propagating swadeshi which only could rid people of their poverty.

('18', 121, 1, 2, 249013) 105. LETTER TO A LADY FRIEND IN SOUTH AFRICA
('18', 121, 2, 3, 249058) [After June 18, 1919] 1
('18', 121, 3, 4, 249082) At the rapid pace things are moving, it is difficult to do full justice to any particular movement.
('18', 121, 3, 5, 249182) Economic distress, political repression and an awakening amongst the masses in particular in all countries have all played an important part in bringing about the present world conditions where, enquiring of every country, you find them affected without exception by unrest of a deep seated character.
('18', 121, 3, 6, 249484) In America, it is class warfare; in England, it is labour unrest; in Russia, Bolshevism, and in India, it is an all round unrest due to repression, famine and other causes.
('18', 121, 3, 7, 249657) The situation which now faces the western nations was inevitable; for western civilization, based on the basic principle of brute force as a guiding motive, could have ultimately led only to mutual destruction.
('18', 121, 3, 8, 249868) But in India against all odds, the high principles of our hoary civilization have still a strong hold on the masses; and if the rapidly widespread growth of Bolshevism which is attacking one nation after another in Europe was to be successfully arrested in India, and even any possibility of its finding a congenial soil safeguarded against, it was necessary that the people of India should be reminded of the legacy of their civilization and culture, which is comprised in the one word satyagrahathe highest mantra one can know of.
('18', 121, 3, 9, 250401) In the last week of January, 1919, the Government of India published the text of two Bills, now popularly known here as the Rowlatt Bills.
('18', 121, 3, 10, 250540) The Bills secured to the Government of India arbitrary powers which they had under the Defence of India Act, specially passed as a war measure for the duration of the war and six months after.
('18', 121, 3, 11, 250733) But what could be tolerated in a time of war cannot be permitted in times of peace when the Government should solely devote their attention to problems of reconstruction and not instead be over anxious and stubborn in claiming arbitrary powers as essential for maintenance of peace and order.
('18', 121, 3, 12, 251026) At a time when the Parliament itself has felt the need of indianizing the administration of this country and the Montagu Chelmsford Reform proposals were before the country for criticism, and when the member of the Civil Service and the
('18', 121, 4, 13, 251263) 1 The Swadeshi Store to which there is a reference in the last paragraph of this letter was opened on June 18, 1919.
('18', 122, 0, 1, 251380) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 123
('18', 122, 1, 2, 251425) Anglo Indian capitalists, fearing that they may lose the privileged positions they have been holding at the expense of the Indian masses, employ fair and unfair means to nullify the utility of the Reform proposals, and the Viceroy, the highest authority in India, openly countenances them by an announcement in the Imperial Council akin to a surrender to the clamour of vested interests, no Indian can calmly contemplate the future of public life in this country, with the Rowlatt legislation in the Statute book.
('18', 122, 1, 3, 251939) The opposition in the country to the Rowlatt legislation has been unanimous beyond comparison, and in the Imperial Council when the Rowlatt Bill No.
('18', 122, 1, 4, 252088) 1 was passed into law, on March 18th, not a single Indian member voted for it.
('18', 122, 1, 5, 252167) On account of the strong opposition to the Bill, the Rowlatt Act No.
('18', 122, 1, 6, 252236) 1 was made temporary for three years and also specially designated as The Revolutionary and Anarchical Crimes Act.
('18', 122, 1, 7, 252351) But these concessions amounted to nothing practically.
('18', 122, 1, 8, 252406) After consideration of all the circumstances, I came to the conclusion to inaugurate the offering of satyagraha against the Rowlatt Act.
('18', 122, 1, 9, 252543) At the end of February, 1919, the Satyagraha Pledge was taken by me and other leaders and the people were also invited to take the Pledge, which states that, being conscientiously convinced of the injustice of the Rowlatt legislation, until it is repealed, the signatories will resort to civil disobedience and binding themselves to follow Truth and refrain from violence.
('18', 122, 1, 10, 252916) I toured over India preaching the principles of satyagraha, and after the passing of the Rowlatt Act No.
('18', 122, 1, 11, 253021) 1, recommended, as a first step, a hartal and 24 hours fast and 30thMarch, 1919 was fixed for the same.
('18', 122, 1, 12, 253125) Later, it was postponed to 6th April, but in some places it was observed on 30th March, and on that day, at Delhi the mob was fired upon, on some ground or other, by the authorities, resulting in some deaths and many wounded.
('18', 122, 1, 13, 253351) This incident roused such feeling in the country that the demonstration arranged for 6th April was largely attended and even Anglo Indian critics had to admit it was an unprecedented demonstration.
('18', 122, 1, 14, 253549) On 7th April, copies of proscribed literature, including Hind Swaraj, were sold by the satyagrahis in all the centres.
('18', 122, 1, 15, 253668) On the evening of 8th April, I left for Delhi to personally acquaint myself with the conditions at Delhi, and I was served with an order by the Punjab Government and the Government of India, not to enter the Punjab by the former and to reside within Bombay Presidency by the latter.
('18', 122, 1, 16, 253951) As a satyagrahi, I could not obey the order, and, on entering the Punjab, was arrested.
('18', 122, 1, 17, 254039) I felt so glad at it, for the soul was now free while the body was taken
('18', 123, 0, 1, 254112) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 123, 1, 2, 254154) care of by the Government.
('18', 123, 1, 3, 254181) I sent message to the people asking them to welcome it as happy news and celebrate the event.
('18', 123, 1, 4, 254275) But, instead of being kept in confinement, I was brought into the Bombay Presidency and set free.
('18', 123, 1, 5, 254373) I returned to Bombay only to find the city full of disturbances.
('18', 123, 1, 6, 254438) That evening, I addressed a huge mass meeting on the sea sands, where I gave expression to my keen disappointment at the misguided action of the people and characterized their action as duragraha, and told them that, if they should again betray the trust reposed in them by acting as duragrahis, the only course open to me would be to offer satyagraha against them by observing dharana 1 and giving up this body as a penance for inaugurating satyagraha and taking the huge moral responsibility for the good conduct of the movement and its followers.
('18', 123, 1, 7, 254988) But disturbances in the Punjab at Lahore, Amritsar and other places and at Ahmedabad, near which the Ashram is situated, have been of very grave character, involving the proclamation of martial law.
('18', 123, 1, 8, 255187) Loss to life and property has been enormous.
('18', 123, 1, 9, 255232) But the disturbances in the Punjab are not due to the satyagraha movement but the outbreaks in Bombay and Ahmedabad were sufficient to show to me that real satyagraha would consist in suspending the civil disobedience programme and in preaching the principle of ahimsa.
('18', 123, 1, 10, 255502) The Satyagraha Sabhas, accordingly, suspended civil disobedience on 20th April, which event was shortly followed by the deportation of Mr. B. G. Horniman, a noble hearted Englishman and fearless Editor of The Bombay Chronicle.
('18', 123, 1, 11, 255729) Orders of forfeiture of security and pre censorship were passed on the Chronicle and it is only for the last fortnight the Chronicle has been appearing without comments under pre censorship and it is only a few days ago the censorship has been removed from the paper, the maximum security of Rs. 10,000, having been deposited by the proprietors.
('18', 123, 1, 12, 256075) During the six weeks from 20th April, the events in the Punjab have been of an unprecedently cruel character.
('18', 123, 1, 13, 256185) Martial law had been proclaimed in several areas and was withdrawn only a week or two ago.
('18', 123, 1, 14, 256276) Aeroplanes have been used to throw bombs, machine guns have been used, and educated public leaders have been arrested under serious charges of waging war against the King, etc., and are being tried by a Martial Law Commission.
('18', 123, 1, 15, 256503) Mr. K. N. Roy, Editor of The Tribune, has been tried for seditious writings and tried by a Special Tribunal and denied legal
('18', 123, 2, 16, 256628) 1 Sitting at one spot without food or drink for the purpose of exerting moral pressure.
('18', 123, 2, 17, 256716) The source has dharama, evidently a misprint.
('18', 124, 0, 1, 256762) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 125
('18', 124, 1, 2, 256807) help of his choice and sentenced to two years rigorous imprison ment.
('18', 124, 1, 3, 256877) After perusing the connected records, I am convinced that in Mr. K. N. Roys case, a serious miscarriage of justice has occurred.
('18', 124, 1, 4, 257006) The actions of the mobs during the disturbances also have been unworthy and of a highly condemnable character.
('18', 124, 1, 5, 257117) The circumstances that led to the suspension of civil disobedience exist no longer and the civil disobedience campaign might be safely begun now with sufficient safeguards to see the satyagrahis do their part of duty in keeping the peace.
('18', 124, 1, 6, 257356) In order to keep the people fully engaged and teach them that the best way of expressing ones sympathy with the principles of satyagraha is to practise them, I have begun an active swadeshi campaign; and within the short period of six weeks, it has spread very rapidly.
('18', 124, 1, 7, 257626) Many Indian sisters have bravely volunteered in the cause, of the movement, and, in addition to themselves observing the vow by wearing Indian made clothes woven from Indian yarn and also setting up handlooms, have found men to work them.
('18', 124, 1, 8, 257865) A true sympathizers duty with the swadeshi movement is not only to wear swadeshi clothes but also to help in producing them.
('18', 124, 1, 9, 257990) In Bombay, the shuddha Swadeshi Stores have been already opened and other centres will also be opening similar stores soon.
('18', 124, 1, 10, 258114) Shuddha swadeshi consists in wearing clothes hand woven from hand spun yarn.
('18', 124, 1, 11, 258191) Of course, at this early stage, it will not be possible to get fine shuddha swadeshi clothes but one should not mind that.

('18', 125, 7, 14, 259583) 108. SPEECH AT SWADESHI SABHA MEETING, BOMBAY
('18', 125, 8, 15, 259629) June 19, 1919
('18', 125, 9, 16, 259643) A crowded meeting was held under the auspices of the Swadeshi Sabha at the Morarji Gokuldas Hall on Thursday evening to hear addresses on swadeshi.
('18', 125, 9, 17, 259791) Mr. Gandhi was in the chair....
('18', 125, 10, 18, 259823) The chairman, winding up the proceedings, said that it was a happy augury for the future that according to the information given to him by Mr. Jerajani the sales at the shuddha Swadeshi Bhandar amounted for the very first day over Rs. 1,800 whereas they had expected much less.
('18', 125, 10, 19, 260101) The purchasers included a large and an equal number of Hindu and Parsee ladies.
('18', 125, 10, 20, 260181) There were also many Mohammedan buyers who bought swadeshi cloth especially for the approaching Id festival.
('18', 125, 10, 21, 260290) Salesmen were kept busy throughout the day.
('18', 125, 10, 22, 260334) Mr. Gandhi hoped that all who had not taken the vow would go to the Swadeshi Sabha office and take the vow.
('18', 125, 10, 23, 260442) He then drew attention to Mr. Jamnadas impending departure to England and invited the audience to associate with him in wishing Mr. Jamnadas a safe voyage and success in his mission.
('18', 125, 10, 24, 260625) He remarked that he
('18', 126, 0, 1, 260645) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 127
('18', 126, 1, 2, 260690) had received letters adversely criticizing Mr. Jamnadas resignation from the Satyagraha Sabha.
('18', 126, 1, 3, 260785) Mr. Gandhi said that Mr. Jamnadas had honest difference of opinion with him.
('18', 126, 1, 4, 260862) He had grave fears that the approaching renewal of civil disobedience might result in violence.
('18', 126, 1, 5, 260958) He (Mr. Gandhi) did not share Mr. Jamnadas fear but holding the view that Mr. Jamnadas did he was entitled to secede from the Satyagraha Sabha without in any way laying himself open to the charge of ceasing to be a satyagrahi.
('18', 126, 1, 6, 261185) Mr. Gandhi said that his regard for Mr. Jamnadas remained absolutely undiminished in spite of his resignation.
('18', 126, 1, 7, 261296) The chairman thanked the speakers 1 for having responded to the invitation of the Swadeshi Sabha to speak at the meeting and the audience for giving them a patient hearing.

COWIE 2, I have just seen the petition submitted to His Excellency for mercy in the case of one Chand, a lad of 15 or 16 years, who has been sentenced to be hanged for the murder of the late Sergeant Fraser 3. There is in my opinion no doubt that the young boy was one of the murderers of an innocent police officer.
('18', 126, 5, 12, 261888) I do not share the view taken by Chands pleader in his petition.
('18', 126, 5, 13, 261953) But I do respectfully share the view taken by the prosecuting counsel who is reported by The Times of India (12th instant Dak Edition) to have said in his address before the Court: The only extenuating circumstance in favour of the 1st accused (Chand) was his age. There is no doubt too that this was not a murder deliberately planned by Chand or anybody else but that Chand evidently did the act in a fit of mad excitement.
('18', 126, 5, 14, 262378) Regard being had to all the circumstances of the case I venture to submit that the ends of justice will be better met by tempering it with His Excellencys prerogative of mercy and by commutation of the sentence in any manner that may appear to His Excellency to be most proper.
('18', 126, 5, 15, 262656) I may observe that Chand has a widowed mother.
('18', 126, 5, 16, 262703) I trust that

('18', 127, 4, 5, 263112) 110. LETTER TO SADIQ ALI KHAN
('18', 127, 5, 6, 263142) [June 23, 1919] 2
('18', 127, 6, 7, 263160) MY DEAR SADIQ ALI KHAN, I have your letter.
('18', 127, 6, 8, 263204) I am glad grandmother and all the children have reached there safely and glad that the Begum Sahiba had the opportunity of seeing the Brothers.
('18', 127, 6, 9, 263348) I never had any doubt that they will be treated in the gaol with every consideration.
('18', 127, 6, 10, 263434) I am most anxious to get a most correct answer to the charge made in the Government communique; as I have already said, for the present, we should avoid all agitation in the Press regarding the Brothers.
('18', 127, 6, 11, 263638) I do not know what action can lie against the Government of India.
('18', 127, 6, 12, 263705) I would like to know more about it.
('18', 127, 6, 13, 263741) Civil disobedience may now be commenced any day, but it wouldnt be before Monday week.
('18', 127, 6, 14, 263828) But even then I do not want any other satyagrahi but myself to actually commence civil disobedience, i.e., to say, not for one month after my incarceration.
('18', 127, 6, 15, 263985) Some instructions 3 are being printed, of which I shall send you a copy, and which you may explain to Azimuddin Khan.
('18', 127, 6, 16, 264103) Please remember me to the Begum Sahiba and all other friends.
('18', 127, 7, 17, 264165) Yours sincerely,

('18', 129, 1, 2, 265933) 112. SPEECH AT SATYAGRAHA SABHA MEETING, BOMBAY
('18', 129, 2, 3, 265981) June 24, 1919
('18', 129, 3, 4, 265995) Under the auspices of the Satyagraha Sabha, a public meeting was held on June 24, 1919, at the Morarji Gokuldas Hall to protest against the Rowlatt Act and Bill and Mr. B. G. Hornimans deportation.
('18', 129, 3, 5, 266193) Mr. Gandhi presided.
('18', 129, 4, 6, 266214) Mr. Gandhi, after apologizing for being late, said there were many reasons of an important kind for meeting there that night.
('18', 129, 4, 7, 266340) One of them was the Rowlatt Act and Bill and they had to pass a resolution protesting against them.
('18', 129, 4, 8, 266440) The second was the resolution against the deportation of Mr. Horniman.
('18', 129, 4, 9, 266511) The meeting was held under the auspices of the Satyagraha Sabha and he requested all the speakers to speak in such a manner as would become true satyagrahis.
('18', 129, 4, 10, 266669) At these satyagraha meetings, it was desirable that all the speakers should be satyagrahis, but they had not definitely decided on that question.
('18', 129, 4, 11, 266815) He then called upon Mr. Jamnadas M. Mehta to move the first resolution.
('18', 129, 5, 12, 266887) Mr. Gandhi put Mr. V. Jerajanis resolution [relating to Mr. Horniman] to vote and asked them to pass it in silence, all standing to show their respect to Mr. Horniman.
('18', 129, 6, 13, 267055) He then said if they could hold similar meetings all over India and conduct them in as orderly a manner as they had done that night, the Government would have to cancel their order against Mr. Horniman.
('18', 129, 6, 14, 267258) Let the people do their duty and the Government would have to do theirs.
('18', 129, 6, 15, 267331) Let them hold meetings and pass similar resolutions, and their objects would be easily attained.
('18', 129, 6, 16, 267428) The Bombay Chronicle, 25 6 1919
('18', 129, 7, 17, 267460) 113. LETTER TO G. A. NATESAN
('18', 129, 8, 18, 267489) BOMBAY, June 25, 1919
('18', 129, 9, 19, 267511) MY DEAR FRIEND, Here are instructions 1 issued for this Presidency.
('18', 129, 9, 20, 267579) You will see they have been issued in virtue of power given to me by the Working Committee.
('18', 129, 9, 21, 267671) 2 I suggest the same thing for Madras with the necessary
('18', 129, 10, 22, 267728) 1 Vide Instructions for Satyagrahis, 30 6 1919, the draft whereof appears to have been sent.
('18', 129, 10, 23, 267821) These were to be followed after Gandhijis incarceration; also Letter to H. S. L. Polak, 27 6 1919. 2 Vide Satyagraha Sabha resolution of June 15, 1919, not reproduced here; also Letter to Secretaries, Satyagraha Committee, 12 6 1919.
('18', 130, 0, 1, 268055) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 131
('18', 130, 1, 2, 268100) changes.
('18', 130, 1, 3, 268109) The only centres I know are Trichinopoly and Madura, besides Madras itself.
('18', 130, 1, 4, 268185) But you know better.
('18', 130, 1, 5, 268206) I therefore leave you to do what you may think best for your Presidency.
('18', 130, 1, 6, 268279) It would not matter in the least if no other civil resister courts imprisonment.
('18', 130, 1, 7, 268360) Remember what I have often said, One real satyagrahi is enough for victory.
('18', 130, 1, 8, 268436) This is becoming clear to me day by day.
('18', 130, 1, 9, 268477) Even as a true coin fetches its full value, so does a true satyagrahi fetch his full value, i.e., attain the intended result.
('18', 130, 1, 10, 268603) And even as false coins or coins of lesser value mixing with the true may diminish for the time being the value of the true coin, it seems to me that a Satyagraha Sangh (Sabha) being a mixture is a weakness from the pure satyagraha standpoint.
('18', 130, 1, 11, 268847) I do not therefore regret the mixture but I point out the spiritual cause of the temporary setback we received in April.
('18', 130, 1, 12, 268968) Good often cometh out of evil.
('18', 130, 1, 13, 268999) It always does in satyagraha.
('18', 130, 1, 14, 269029) But I must pause now.
('18', 130, 1, 15, 269051) I have written so much in order to share with you my inmost thoughts as they come to me this morning.
('18', 130, 1, 16, 269153) (It is now 6.30 a.m.) For on you and the few we are will lie the burden.
('18', 130, 1, 17, 269226) I enclose also copy of a cable which is being sent to Mr. Montagu.
('18', 130, 1, 18, 269293) You may send copies of this to fellow satyagrahis.
('18', 130, 1, 19, 269344) Please show this to Devdas.
('18', 130, 2, 20, 269372) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('18', 130, 3, 21, 269402) From a photostat: S.N. 6681

('18', 132, 4, 6, 272018) 116. LETTER TO S. R. HIGNELL
('18', 132, 5, 7, 272047) [BOMBAY,] June 26, 1919
('18', 132, 6, 8, 272071) DEAR MR. HIGNELL, I enclose herewith petition (petition for submission) to His Excellency praying for Babu Kalinath Roys release.
('18', 132, 6, 9, 272201) This petition, as per Sir Narayan Chandavarkars telegram, should have gone forward on Monday last.
('18', 132, 6, 10, 272300) My secretary had the matter of despatching in his hands, but he fell ill, and is now in Ahmedabad.
('18', 132, 6, 11, 272399) The work of taking signatures was in other hands, and I know nothing about the contents of the telegram sent until this morning when Sir Narayan Chandavarkar dropped in and asked me whether the petition had been duly forwarded.
('18', 132, 6, 12, 272627) He was naturally hurt when I told him that it had not yet gone forward as friends were still taking signatures.
('18', 132, 6, 13, 272739) Even now, I cannot send you the copy signed by Sir Narayan, Sir Dinshaw Wachha and others.
('18', 132, 6, 14, 272830) I hope to get hold of it tomorrow and forward it.
('18', 132, 6, 15, 272880) I apologize for the delay but I know that it will receive that consideration from His Excellency to which it is entitled weighted as it is by the name of a jurist of Sir Narayan Chandavarkars eminence.
('18', 132, 7, 16, 273082) Yours sincerely,
('18', 132, 8, 17, 273099) From a photostat: S.N. 6686

('18', 135, 1, 2, 275926) 121. LETTER TO ESTHER FAERING
('18', 135, 2, 3, 275956) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, June 27, 1919
('18', 135, 3, 4, 275993) MY DEAR CHILD, Your letter just received makes me extremely sad.
('18', 135, 3, 5, 276058) I cannot conceive the possibility of their deporting you.
('18', 135, 3, 6, 276116) But if they should, you have to cheerfully submit to the fate.
('18', 135, 3, 7, 276179) If you wish me to, I shall gladly correspond with the Government.
('18', 135, 3, 8, 276245) I may fail in my attempt.
('18', 135, 3, 9, 276271) That would not matter.
('18', 135, 3, 10, 276294) My advice to you also is that if they impose conditions on which alone you could stay, you should accept the conditions in so far as they are not humiliating.
('18', 135, 3, 11, 276453) I may commence in my person civil disobedience next week.
('18', 135, 3, 12, 276511) It is therefore at the present moment hardly possible for us to meet.
('18', 135, 3, 13, 276581) As for swadeshi, there is no need for you to discard what you have from home.
('18', 135, 3, 14, 276659) It is enough for you to confine all your present need to swadeshi things.
('18', 135, 3, 15, 276733) The vow is only restricted to personal clothing.
('18', 135, 3, 16, 276782) Subject to your Boards1 consent, you should introduce spinning wheels in your school.
('18', 135, 3, 17, 276868) Regarding yourself, I suggest also your consulting Mr. Bittmann and being guided by him.
('18', 135, 3, 18, 276957) Shall I write to him?
('18', 135, 3, 19, 276979) I am so anxious that not a single step be taken by you in haste or in anger.
('18', 135, 3, 20, 277056) Then whatsoever happens will be for the best.
('18', 135, 3, 21, 277102) Please write to me often.
('18', 135, 3, 22, 277128) With deep love, Written in haste and unrevised.
('18', 135, 4, 23, 277176) Yours, BAPU My Dear Child, pp.

('18', 137, 1, 2, 278334) 124. LETTER TO S. T. SHEPPARD
('18', 137, 2, 3, 278364) June 27, 1919
('18', 137, 3, 4, 278378) DEAR MR. SHEPPARD, I thank you for your letter and more especially for yourdrawing attention to what has appeared to you to be a discrepancy between the trading article and the Bill.
('18', 137, 3, 5, 278561) I have certainly not wished to exaggerate the effect of the Section in question.
('18', 137, 3, 6, 278642) If you deprive the Indians from having controlling interest in a company, in my opinion, you prevent them from holding fixed property in the Transvaal as shareholders of a duly registered company.
('18', 137, 3, 7, 278839) My reading of the Bill is that under it the majority of shareholders cannot be Indians.
('18', 137, 3, 8, 278927) Today the majority can be and, as a matter of fact, are Indians in all such companies.
('18', 137, 3, 9, 279014) The object of the Bill is to stop and de legalize the present practice.
('18', 137, 3, 10, 279086) I have sent for the law you want and hope to let you have it soon.
('18', 137, 4, 11, 279153) Yours sincerely,
('18', 137, 5, 12, 279170) From a microfilm: S.N. 6484 b

('18', 138, 1, 2, 279671) 126. SPEECH AT SATYAGRAHA SABHA MEETING,BOMBAY
('18', 138, 2, 3, 279718) June 27, 1919
('18', 138, 3, 4, 279732) Gandhiji presided over a public meeting held on June 27, 1919, at Shantarams Chawl, Bombay, under the auspices of the Satyagraha, to protest against the Rowlatt Act and the deportation of Mr. B. G. Horniman.
('18', 138, 4, 5, 279940) Mr. Gandhi said many persons had not come to the meeting on account of the rain, and he thought that they were not real and staunch satyagrahis.
('18', 138, 4, 6, 280085) The two resolutions were to protest against the Rowlatt Bill and the deportation of Mr. Horniman.
('18', 138, 4, 7, 280183) He requested the speakers to be as brief as possible.
('18', 138, 5, 8, 280237) Mr. Gandhi put the resolution to vote and it was carried unanimously.
('18', 138, 5, 9, 280307) The Bombay Chronicle, 28 6 1919
('18', 138, 6, 10, 280339) 127. LETTER TO H. S. L. POLAK

('18', 138, 8, 12, 280415) MY DEAR HENRY, I am dictating this after 11 p.m.

('18', 139, 4, 11, 282007) LABURNUM ROAD, GAMDEVI, BOMBAY, June 28, 1919
('18', 139, 5, 12, 282053) DEAR MR. HIGNELL, I have your letter of the 25th instant for which I thank you.
('18', 139, 5, 13, 282133) After much consideration, I thought that I should send a cablegram to Mr. Montagu which I did yesterday and of which I send you a copy herewith.
('18', 139, 6, 14, 282278) Your letter was not unexpected by me.
('18', 139, 6, 15, 282316) I share the Viceroys regret but sometimes in life duty compels one to do things, although one may regret having to do them.
('18', 139, 6, 16, 282440) May I, however, draw His Excellencys attention to the fact that the unfortunate events that happened in April last were not precipitated by any manifestation of satyagraha?
('18', 139, 6, 17, 282613) The Government well knew that I was proceeding to Delhi purely and simply on an errand of peace, not to offer civil disobedience.
('18', 139, 6, 18, 282743) And looking back upon the black days of April, I cannot help feeling that if the Government had not committed the error of serving the orders that it did upon me, the history of that month might have been written differently.
('18', 139, 6, 19, 282969) Moreover, I am taking extraordinary precautions in order to avoid any excitement that may follow upon my arrest and imprisonment.
('18', 139, 6, 20, 283099) You will observe from the proof copy of the instructions that I am issuing for the fellow satyagrahis that for the time being civil disobedience is to be confined

('18', 140, 4, 9, 284118) 129. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH
('18', 140, 5, 10, 284146) BOMBAY, June 28, 1919
('18', 140, 6, 11, 284168) DEAR MR. JINNAH 1, I was delighted to receive your letter.
('18', 140, 6, 12, 284227) I shall certainly keep you informed of the doings here.
('18', 140, 6, 13, 284283) I cannot say anything about the Reforms Bill.
('18', 140, 6, 14, 284329) I have hardly studied it.
('18', 140, 6, 15, 284355) My preoccupation is Rowlatt legislation; add to that the Punjab, Kalinath Roy, Transvaal and swadeshi and I have more hay on my work than I can carry.
('18', 140, 6, 16, 284506) Our Reforms will be practically worthless, if we cannot repeal Rowlatt legislation, if a strong committee of enquiry is not appointed to investigate the Punjab affairs and to revise what appear to be excessive sentences, if the glaring wrong done to Kalinath Roy is not redressed and the Transvaal Indians not protected from further encroachments on their liberty, and if India does not take up and appreciate the work of swadeshi.
('18', 140, 6, 17, 284938) The first four are needed as much to test our strength as to test the measure of the goodwill of Englishmen, and the last, viz., swadeshi, is an earnest of our love for our country, and I am, therefore, concen trating all my energy upon these things.

('18', 141, 4, 16, 286630) 130. SPEECH ON SWADESHI, BOMBAY 1
('18', 141, 5, 17, 286664) June 28, 1919 The idea of swadeshi is of great importance and the progress of the country in dharma is bound up with it.
('18', 141, 5, 18, 286785) A country which has forsaken swadeshi can be said to have no patriotic sentiment and will never be able to follow its dharma.
('18', 141, 5, 19, 286911) We do not find this said in our shastras; on the contrary, it is even deduced from them that patriotism may be an obstacle on the path of dharma.
('18', 141, 5, 20, 287057) This is an utterly absurd and misleading idea.
('18', 141, 5, 21, 287104) Everyone ought to be mindful of his duty and failure to do so is to reduce the path of karma to sheer confusion.
('18', 141, 6, 22, 287217) 1 The meeting was held in Jain Upashraya at Lalbaug under the auspices of the Cutchchi Jain Mandal.
('18', 142, 0, 1, 287317) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 143
('18', 142, 1, 2, 287362) Jainism, the secret of this path is explained with much greater insight than in any other faith.
('18', 142, 1, 3, 287459) The friends who have assembled here do not need to be told what it is.
('18', 142, 1, 4, 287530) If a man is born in India, there must be some reason behind the fact; that being so, we need to consider what is our especial duty.
('18', 142, 1, 5, 287662) That duty is swadeshi and is included in dharma.
('18', 142, 1, 6, 287711) Jainism teaches compassion towards living creatures and the duty of non violence; it even teaches the protection of violent animals against small creatures.
('18', 142, 1, 7, 287868) This, however, is no justification for our neglecting the duty of compassion and non violence towards human beings.
('18', 142, 1, 8, 287984) If our neighbours are in pain or misfortune, it is our duty to share their suffering and help them.
('18', 142, 1, 9, 288084) All over the world, the religious life has lost importance to such an extent that irreligion is spreading in the name of religion and men everywhere are deceiving themselves.
('18', 142, 1, 10, 288259) We claim to be men of dharma, whereas all our actions are tainted with adharma.
('18', 142, 1, 11, 288339) We cannot claim to have followed dharma by earning money through adharma, and giving it in charity for promoting pious causes.
('18', 142, 1, 12, 288466) Most of the people assembled here are traders by profession.
('18', 142, 1, 13, 288527) We are told that trade cannot be carried on without some admixture of dishonesty.
('18', 142, 1, 14, 288609) I shall be plain and tell you that, if that is so, you had better give up trade.
('18', 142, 1, 15, 288690) Ones dharma lies in refusing to forsake truth even if that means starving, and, unless we live in this manner, dharma will not be the central purpose of our lives.
('18', 142, 1, 16, 288854) There is a painful thing I am obliged to mention, and it is that our religious leaders, whose duty it is to enlighten people, have forgotten that duty.
('18', 142, 1, 17, 289006) This is true, however much it may hurt us.
('18', 142, 1, 18, 289049) Religious leaders have it in them to set an example to their followers by their conduct.
('18', 142, 1, 19, 289138) Mere preaching will have no effect on those who assemble to listen to their discourses.
('18', 142, 1, 20, 289226) Religious leaders, too, should follow the rule of swadeshi.
('18', 142, 1, 21, 289286) They have plenty of time on hand.
('18', 142, 1, 22, 289320) They should take to the spinning wheel and spin and thus set an example to their followers.
('18', 142, 1, 23, 289412) More than in the repetition of Rama as they tell the beads, in the music of the spinning wheel will they hear the voice of the atman with a beauty all its own.
('18', 142, 1, 24, 289572) Swadeshi is our primary obligation because natural to us.
('18', 142, 1, 25, 289630) We have forsaken this natural obligation.
('18', 142, 1, 26, 289672) Because of its neglect of swadeshi, the nation has been ruined.
('18', 142, 1, 27, 289736) Three crores in India, that is, a tenth of the total population of the country, get only one meal a day, just plain bread and no more.
('18', 142, 1, 28, 289871) Crores of rupees are annually lost to foreign countries.
('18', 142, 1, 29, 289928) If this wealth of crores could remain in the country, we would be able to save our starving countrymen.
('18', 142, 1, 30, 290032) Thus, our
('18', 143, 0, 1, 290042) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 143, 1, 2, 290084) economic well being is also bound up with swadeshi, and in its observance there lies compassion for living beings.
('18', 143, 1, 3, 290199) Moreover, swadeshi cloth is likely to be cheaper than English cloth.
('18', 143, 1, 4, 290268) I submit to you that you should make your own cloth or get it made.
('18', 143, 1, 5, 290336) The vow of swadeshi is not a difficult one to keep.
('18', 143, 1, 6, 290388) Through it, we shall remove the hardships of our countrymen.
('18', 143, 1, 7, 290449) If we work at the spinning wheel for eight hours, we can spin one pound of yarn.
('18', 143, 1, 8, 290530) The cloth being produced in India today can meet the needs of only 25 per cent of the population; we should therefore produce enough to meet the needs of the remaining 75 per cent.
('18', 143, 1, 9, 290711) If, thus, people take to turning the spinning wheel, not only we shall succeed in keeping the vow of swadeshi but shall also ensure production of cloth in plenty.

('18', 143, 2, 11, 290909) 131. OBSERVATIONS ON SWADESHI AT MEETING IN BOMBAY 1
('18', 143, 3, 12, 290962) June 28, 1919 We should take the first vow, that of pure swadeshi, and always follow the rule of swadeshi.
('18', 143, 3, 13, 291069) Any person placing himself under a vow should take all possible steps to ensure that he is able to keep it, otherwise there is every danger of its having to be violated at some future time.
('18', 143, 3, 14, 291259) He should, therefore, use foresight and take all necessary steps for being able to keep it.
('18', 143, 3, 15, 291351) We should make an effort to promote the production of hand woven cloth and handspun yarn so that we may succeed in keeping our vow.
('18', 143, 3, 16, 291483) Today I went to a womens meeting at half past four and, following my request to them, it is likely that most of them will start working at the spinning wheel.
('18', 143, 3, 17, 291642) If both women and men join this movement for swadeshi, it will be a great success and we shall be able to follow the rule of swadeshi with ease.
('18', 143, 3, 18, 291787) This movement has nothing to do with boycott.
('18', 143, 3, 19, 291833) I have placed this rule before the people because I think it to be our duty and a part of our dharma.
('18', 143, 3, 20, 291935) I request my countrymen not to mix up the movement for swadeshi with boycott.

('18', 148, 0, 1, 297130) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 149
('18', 148, 1, 2, 297175) 135. SPEECH ON SWADESHI, AHMEDABAD 1
('18', 148, 2, 3, 297212) June 29, 1919 A movement for swadeshi was launched on a large scale at the time of the Bengal Partition during Lord Curzons regime, but, as I have said at many places, it left much to be desired.
('18', 148, 2, 4, 297408) There are bound to be deficiencies in every new movement.
('18', 148, 2, 5, 297466) I have no desire to harp on such deficiencies; we only consider how we may avoid them.
('18', 148, 2, 6, 297553) If there were any faults in the movement at that time, there were also plenty of enthusiasm and other virtues.
('18', 148, 2, 7, 297664) Those who would do sound and beautiful work, or would learn well, should examine the deficiencies to which experience has drawn attention and, after due inquiry, sift these deficiencies and prepare a truthful account.
('18', 148, 2, 8, 297882) The fault, then, which I have noticed in the earlier movement is this, that it was organized on too large a scale.
('18', 148, 2, 9, 297997) It is plain enough that we cannot have everything swadeshi all at once.
('18', 148, 2, 10, 298069) A vow is a vow in fact only if it is such as we can keep.
('18', 148, 2, 11, 298127) This will be easy to understand with the help of an illustration, that of a right angle.
('18', 148, 2, 12, 298216) We cannot have everything swadeshi, which will meet all our needs at the same time and in equal measure, and if we take a vow which will require this, the result cannot but be imperfect.
('18', 148, 2, 13, 298403) If, however, we are inspired with the necessary moral fervour, we may take a vow of perfect swadeshi and resolve to do without things of any kind which we cannot get swadeshisuch firmness will yield the desired result in future.
('18', 148, 2, 14, 298632) I have felt since 1908 that we can start the experiment in this respect with cloth.
('18', 148, 2, 15, 298716) There was a time when India was on top of other countries.
('18', 148, 2, 16, 298775) If we can form a definite idea of the kind of arrangements which obtained then, the way to success in the experiment will have been opened.
('18', 148, 2, 17, 298915) The population of India was divided mainly into two classes, some were agriculturists and others weavers.
('18', 148, 2, 18, 299021) I shall go further and assert that the people who followed the profession of agriculture also occupied themselves with weaving in their spare time.
('18', 148, 2, 19, 299169) I address this to the ladies, for it is on them that the development of this craft depends.
('18', 148, 3, 20, 299261) 1 At the meeting under the auspices of the Swadeshi Sabha, with Gandhiji in the chair.
('18', 148, 3, 21, 299348) A summary of the speech appeared in Young India, 2 7 1919.
('18', 149, 0, 1, 299407) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 149, 1, 2, 299449) You are perhaps no strangers to Dr. Harold Mann 1. He carried out a survey of villages in the neighbourhood of Poona and published two books.
('18', 149, 1, 3, 299591) He has proved, on the basis of his observations, that during the six months following the period of Ashadh 2 to Margashirsha 3 the agricultural class spend their time doing nothing.
('18', 149, 1, 4, 299773) They can take up weaving during the period when they have no work.
