('18', 155, 1, 2, 313814) 137. INSTRUCTIONS FOR SATYAGRAHIS
('18', 155, 2, 3, 313848) NOT FOR PUBLICATION BOMBAY, June 30, 1919
('18', 155, 3, 4, 313890) INSTRUCTIONS FOR SATYAGRAHIS IN TERMS AND IN VIRTUE
('18', 155, 4, 5, 313942) OF THE RESOLUTION OF THE COMMITTEE OF THE SABHA PASSED ON THE 15TH JUNE 19
('18', 155, 5, 6, 314017) (TRANSLATED FROM GUJARATI)
('18', 155, 6, 7, 314044) (1) As it is or should be the belief of satyagrahis that those are the best fitted for offering civil disobedience who are the most free from anger, untruth and ill will or hatred and as I consider myself to be from this point of view the best fitted amongst the satyagrahis, I have decided that I should be the first to offer civil disobedience.
('18', 155, 7, 8, 314391) (2) The manner in which I propose to offer civil disobedience about the beginning of July is by disobeying the orders against me of internment and externment.
('18', 155, 7, 9, 314550) (3) I firmly believe that our victory lies in the nation preserving perfect peace and equanimity at the time of, after and during my incarceration.
('18', 155, 7, 10, 314698) Such preservation will be the best way of bringing about the withdrawal of the Rowlatt legislation.
('18', 155, 8, 11, 314798) (4) I therefore advise that upon my incarceration there should be no demonstration of any kind whatsoever, no hartal and no mass meetings.
('18', 155, 9, 12, 314937) (5) I advise that civil disobedience by the others be not resumed at least for one month after the day of my incarceration as distinguished from my arrest or some such final act on the part of the Government.
('18', 155, 9, 13, 315146) (6) This month should be treated as one of discipline and preparation for civil disobedience and, assuming that no disturbances take place after my incarceration, it should be devoted to the following constructive programme: (a) The preaching of the cardinal principles of the doctrine of satyagraha, namely, the necessity of strictest adherence to truth and ahimsa and the duty of civil disobedience as the natural corollary and the equally paramount duty of
('18', 156, 0, 1, 315606) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 157
('18', 156, 1, 2, 315651) refraining from criminal disobedience and, with this end in view, literature such as Thoreaus Civil Disobedience, Hind Swaraj, Defence of Socrates by me, Tolstoys Letter to Russian Liberals and Ruskins Unto this Last should be widely distributed.
('18', 156, 1, 3, 315898) It is true that we sold some of this literature as part of the plan of actual civil disobedience.
('18', 156, 1, 4, 315996) But now we have the knowledge that the Government have been advised that reprints and the sale of prohibited literature is not an offence except in so far as such or any literature may be covered by Section 124A.
('18', 156, 1, 5, 316209) We should therefore now sell this literature as part of our propaganda but not as an act rendering us liable to penalty for breach of any law.
('18', 156, 1, 6, 316352) (b) Propaganda of swadeshi should be taken up on an intensive and extensive scale.
('18', 156, 1, 7, 316435) It should cover so far as possible the whole of India.
('18', 156, 1, 8, 316490) Propaganda should be free from all bitterness and from even a suspicion of boycott, swadeshi being regarded as an economic, political and even religious necessity for all time.
('18', 156, 1, 9, 316667) And this propaganda should include in an equal degree both the presentation of the different pledges to the public for acceptance and activity for the new production of cotton cloth, principally by the encouragement of hand spinning and weaving,even though it may be for the time being at a loss.
('18', 156, 2, 10, 316964) (c) The advocating of the Hindu Muslim unity not by means of public speeches but by concrete acts of help and kindness on the part of Hindus towards Mohammedans and on the part of the latter towards the former.
('18', 156, 2, 11, 317175) Hindus would, therefore, naturally give enthusiastic support to the Mohammedans in their just claims regarding the retention of Turkey as a Mohammedan sovereign State with full regard for their feelings as to the holy places and the Khaliphate.
('18', 156, 2, 12, 317420) (d) Meetings should be held to pass resolutions praying for the repeal of the Rowlatt legislation, the appointment of an independent impartial committee of enquiry with the power to enquire into the causes of the Punjab disturbances, the administration of martial law and to revise the sentences passed by the Punjab Martial Law
('18', 157, 0, 1, 317749) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 157, 1, 2, 317791) Tribunal, the release of Babu Kalinath Roy without the necessity of an enquiry and cancellation of the order of deportation against Mr. Horniman.
('18', 157, 1, 3, 317937) (7) If full peace is observed for one month as per para three and it has been ascertained that the people have understood the doctrine of satyagraha, time will have arrived for offering further civil disobedience assuming, of course, that the Rowlatt legislation has not been repealed.
('18', 157, 1, 4, 318223) (8) Civil disobedience may then be offered by those who may be selected by the leaders appointed in para 15. I, however, advise that not more than two at a time should offer civil disobedience from any one centre nor should civil disobedience be commenced simultaneously at all the centres.
('18', 157, 1, 5, 318514) But the effect of resumption of civil disobedience in one or more centres on the public mind should be watched before resuming it in the other centres.
('18', 157, 1, 6, 318666) (9) The recommending of the laws for civil disobedience is a most difficult task.
('18', 157, 1, 7, 318748) In the present state of the country, when it is highly debatable whether the spirit of civil disobedience replacing and entirely superseding crininal disobedience has been understood by the masses, I am unable to advise civil disobedience of the revenue laws, i.e., the salt tax, land tax and the forest laws.
('18', 157, 1, 8, 319058) I also feel that the satyagrahis may not disobey any orders issued by the Government regarding processions and mass meetings.
('18', 157, 1, 9, 319184) (10) The income tax is a feasible proposition on the ground of safety from any violent disturbance but I am more than doubtful as to any response being made by those who pay the income tax.
('18', 157, 1, 10, 319374) Nevertheless, if any satyagrahi desires to offer satyagraha by not paying this tax, he may do so at his own cost with the permission of his leader.
('18', 157, 1, 11, 319522) There remain, therefore, the political laws, and only the Press Act and other laws regarding printing lend themselves to civil disobedience but there also the only possible manner of civil breach is the establishing of unlicensed printing presses or of issuing an unlicensed newspaper, to do so at his own cost with the permission of his leader.
('18', 157, 1, 12, 319868) (11) I can, therefore, only advise that individual satyagrahis when they receive orders of internment or orders prohibiting them from speaking or publishing any matter which the Government may consider to be obnoxious but which from the satyagraha standpoint may be flawless, such orders should be disregarded.
('18', 158, 0, 1, 320179) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 159
('18', 158, 1, 2, 320224) (12) It may be that the Government may not view with indifference the propaganda of the doctrine of civil disobedience or the distribution of reprints of prohibited literature, although such literature from the moral, i.e., satyagraha standpoint are perfectly innocuous.
('18', 158, 1, 3, 320495) In that even civil disobedience is offered in the easiest and most dignified way.
('18', 158, 1, 4, 320577) It is open, however, to the leaders to add the ways above mentioned by thinking out other laws which may have escaped my notice.
('18', 158, 1, 5, 320706) But it will be no fault in them to confine themselves to the limits mentioned in these paragraphs but it would be considered agrave indiscretion on their part if they select laws which do not hold proper matter for civil disobedience or a civil breach of which is likely to lead to a criminal breach.
('18', 158, 1, 6, 321007) (13) In the event of a prosecution for civil disobedience, a satyagrahi, if he has committed it, should plead guilty, offer no defence and invite the severest penalty.
('18', 158, 1, 7, 321175) If he is falsely charged with civil disobedience, he should make that statement but not enter upon any further defence and accept the penalty he receives.
('18', 158, 1, 8, 321330) If a satyagrahi is prosecuted for criminal breach as, for instance, for having actually uttered sedition or incited to sedition, he should make a statement denying the guilt and producing his witness.
('18', 158, 1, 9, 321531) It is open to him also to engage a lawyer if he wishes to, but it is no part of the duty of the Sabha or of co satyagrahis to find funds for engaging lawyers, as the essence of satyagraha lies in inviting penalty for deliberate civil disobedience and in accepting penalty where one is falsely charged with criminal disobedience because a satyagrahi is indifferent to the pain of imprisonment.
('18', 158, 1, 10, 321924) He glories in it when it is self invited and resigns to it when a false and malicious charge has been brought against him.
('18', 158, 1, 11, 322047) That he may, by not making effort to get the best lawyer possible, be found guilty not only by the court but be considered such by the public should not concern a satyagrahi.
('18', 158, 1, 12, 322222) The voice of a clear disciplined conscience is the final arbiter for him.
('18', 158, 1, 13, 322296) (14) I have come to the conclusion that it is better to divide the Bombay Presidency into so many independent self sustained centres, each seeking co operation with the advice from the rest but none being under the orders of any, and I select Bombay, Surat, Broach, Nadiad and Ahmedabad as such centres.
('18', 158, 1, 14, 322600) I make no selection in the other Presidencies, for the Bombay Sabhas jurisdiction is limited only to that Presidency and the resolutions giving me extensive
('18', 159, 0, 1, 322757) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 159, 1, 2, 322799) powers can refer only to this Presidency.
('18', 159, 1, 3, 322841) (15) I, therefore, propose to give separate brief instructions using this as a basis to be adopted by the centres outside the Presidency.
('18', 159, 1, 4, 322979) The centres appointed under this paragraph will be responsible each for its own district, for instance, Nadiad for the whole of Kaira.
('18', 159, 1, 5, 323114) For Bombay, I appoint Mrs. Naidu if she has returned in time, Messrs Umar Sobhani, Shankarlal G. Banker and I. K. Yajnik if he can be spared from Ahmedabad, successively, as leaders.
('18', 159, 1, 6, 323297) In Surat, Messrs Dayalji Manubhai Desai and Kalyanji Vithalbhai Mehta.
('18', 159, 1, 7, 323368) In Broach, Mr. Haribhai Javerbhai Amin.
('18', 159, 1, 8, 323408) In Nadiad, Messrs Foolchand Bapooji Shah and Mohanlal K. Pandya.
('18', 159, 1, 9, 323473) In Ahmedabad, Messrs Vallabhbhai J. Patel, Balwantrai Narasingh Prasad Kanuga, Indulal Kannaiyalal Yajnik, all successively leaders as in Bombay.
('18', 159, 1, 10, 323619) I advise the leaders to form small committees and for their guidance consult the feelings of such committees and other fellow satyagrahis.
('18', 159, 1, 11, 323758) (16) All along I have assumed that there will be no disturbance.
('18', 159, 1, 12, 323823) If, however, the worst happens and there is a disturbance, every satyagrahi living in the disturbed centre will be expected to lose his life in preventing loss of other lives, whether English or Indian.
('18', 159, 1, 13, 324026) He will at the same peril prevent destruction of property and if he thought there was shooting of innocent men, he will offer himself also to be shot.
('18', 159, 2, 14, 324177) (17) Wherever there are individual satyagrahis whether within the Presidency or outside who either for want of ability, confidence in themselves or otherwise are unable to remain in their respective places, it is open to them to go preferably to Bombay or to some other active centre and work under the direction of the leader acting for the time being.
('18', 159, 3, 15, 324531) (18) The above instructions are for general guidance but in emergencies every leader is free to depart from them at his own risk.
('18', 159, 3, 16, 324661) Read paragraph 11 in this connection.
('18', 159, 3, 17, 324699) (19) Satyagraha in action is in some respects like physical warfare.
('18', 159, 3, 18, 324768) The laws of discipline, for instance, are most common to satyagraha (spiritual) warfare and the physical warfare.
('18', 159, 3, 19, 324882) Therefore, a satyagrahi is expected to render implicit obedience to the instructions of the leader and is not to reason why.
('18', 159, 3, 20, 325007) He must obey instructions first and then question the leader as to the propriety of a particular action but, unlike as in physical warfare, a satyagrahi does retain his final independence in vital matters and then on occasions of such vital
('18', 160, 0, 1, 325248) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 161
('18', 160, 1, 2, 325293) difference as a true satyagrahi yielding to the leader the same right of independent judgment will without irritation place his resignation in his hands.
('18', 160, 1, 3, 325447) But it should be remembered that in the vast majority of cases, differences arise not on vital matters but on trifles.
('18', 160, 1, 4, 325566) A satyagrahi, therefore, will not mistake the voice of Satan for the voice of conscience and dignify trifles into things of the essence and then precipitate differences.
('18', 160, 1, 5, 325736) My experience is that it is only he who has obeyed in nine hundred and ninety nine things finds the thousandth perhaps to be a legitimate matter for difference.
('18', 160, 1, 6, 325897) With him everyone else is first, himself last.
('18', 160, 2, 7, 325944) M. K. GANDHI From a printed copy: S.N. 6662
('18', 160, 3, 8, 325988) 138. MESSAGE
('18', 160, 4, 9, 326001) [About June 30, 1919] 1
('18', 160, 5, 10, 326025) As my arrest may come upon me unawares, I wish to leave the following as my message.
('18', 160, 5, 11, 326110) I appeal to all my countryrnen and countrywomen throughout India to observe absolute calmness and to refrain from violence to person and property in any shape or from.
('18', 160, 5, 12, 326278) The greatest injury that can be done to me is deeds of violence after my arrest and for my sake.
('18', 160, 5, 13, 326375) Those who love me will show their true affection only by becoming satyagrahis, i.e., believers in Truth and ahimsa (non violence) and self suffering as the only means for securing redress of grievances.
('18', 160, 5, 14, 326578) To the Government of India, I respectfully wish to submit that they will never establish peace in India by ignoring the causes of the present discontent.
('18', 160, 5, 15, 326732) Satyagraha has not bred lawlessness and violence.
('18', 160, 5, 16, 326782) It is a vital force and it has certainly hastened the crisis that was inevitable.
('18', 160, 5, 17, 326864) But it has also acted as a restraining force of the first magnitude.
('18', 160, 5, 18, 326933) Government as well as the people should recognize this fact and feel thankful for it.
('18', 160, 5, 19, 327019) Without the purifying and soothing effect of satyagraha, violence would have been infinitely greater, for mutual retaliation would have produced nothing but chaos.
('18', 160, 5, 20, 327183) Mahomedans are deeply resentful of what they believe to be Englands attitude towards the question of Turkey, Palestine and Mecca Sharif.
('18', 160, 5, 21, 327320) The people are deeply distrustful of Englands attitude towards the forthcoming Reforms and they want repeal of the Rowlatt legislation.
('18', 160, 5, 22, 327456) No repression
('18', 160, 6, 23, 327470) 1 The date of this item appears to be the same as that of the preceding item.
('18', 161, 0, 1, 327548) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 161, 1, 2, 327590) can possibly avail to secure even a shadow of peace in the land.
('18', 161, 1, 3, 327655) Substantial peace can only be had by conciliating Mahomedan religious sentiments by granting reforms in a liberal and trusting spirit, even as was done by the late Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman in the case of South Africa and by recognizing the sacredness of public opinion by immediate repeal of the Rowlatt legislation.
('18', 161, 1, 4, 327976) But the British Government all the world over have demanded proof of a peoples earnestness.
('18', 161, 1, 5, 328068) The chosen European method of expressing earnestness is to create disorder by violence.
('18', 161, 1, 6, 328156) The Government have given a crushing reply to this method.
('18', 161, 1, 7, 328215) It may prosper in Europe, but not in India.
('18', 161, 1, 8, 328259) To satyagraha, there can be no reply but that of acceding to satyagraha demands.
('18', 161, 1, 9, 328340) Government of a country is possible when people support it by contributing revenue, by filling public services and such like actions symbolic of approval.
('18', 161, 1, 10, 328495) When a Government does justice, i.e., is broadbased upon the will of a people, such support is a duty in spite of its temporary aberrations.
('18', 161, 1, 11, 328636) Withdrawaltotal or partialof such support becomes equally a duty when Government is carried on in defiance of peoples will and such withdrawal of support is pure satyagraha when it is unaccompanied by violence in any shape or form and unadulterated by untruth.
('18', 161, 1, 12, 328897) Satyagrahis, then, knowing the sanctity and invincibility of satyagraha will not lend themselves to violence and untruth and will refrain from offering civil disobedience until they are assured that there will be no violence on the part of the people, whether such a state of things was brought about by the peoples willing acceptance of the doctrine of Truth and non violence or by the military dispositions of the Government.
('18', 161, 1, 13, 329325) In the former case, the whole of India will have participated in the joy of satyagraha and will have given a lesson to the world.
('18', 161, 1, 14, 329455) In the latter case, the Government will realize that no physical force that they can summon to their aid will ever bend the spirit of satyagrahis.

('18', 163, 6, 10, 331108) 142. LETTER TO RANCHHODDAS PATWARI 1
('18', 163, 7, 11, 331145) Wednesday, [June 1919] 2
('18', 163, 8, 12, 331170) RESPECTED BHAISHRI, I do not remember to have received your letter earlier.
('18', 163, 8, 13, 331246) I was myself wondering if you had forgotten me.
('18', 163, 8, 14, 331294) If a person like you would adopt swadeshi, it can be spread in India in no time.
('18', 163, 8, 15, 331375) The work which the native states can do in the .
('18', 163, 8, 16, 331424) condition cannot be done in British India.
('18', 163, 8, 17, 331467) I think it is difficult to visit Kathiawar at present.
('18', 163, 8, 18, 331522) If one spinning wheel is plied for 360 days and it is done everyday, 180 lbs.
('18', 163, 8, 19, 331600) of yarn would be spun, and if one loom weaves cloth from 360 lbs.
('18', 163, 8, 20, 331666) of yarn and every man (villager) takes 12 yards of cloth .
('18', 163, 8, 21, 331725) .that one loom would provide cloth for 30 persons in a year.
('18', 163, 8, 22, 331786) The mill yarn which is suitable for khadi costs Rs. 37 per maund at present.
('18', 163, 8, 23, 331863) This yarn is made from the waste cotton left after preparing fine yarn.
('18', 163, 8, 24, 331935) The mill spends Rs. 15 per maund for this cotton.
('18', 163, 8, 25, 331985) Thus, the mill makes a profit of Rs. 22, or takes Rs. 22 as spinning charge for the cotton worth Rs. 15. Cotton for hand spinning must be of good quality and it costs Rs. 25. Deducting from that figure the labour and
('18', 163, 9, 26, 332202) 1 Omissions in the letter are as in the source.
('18', 163, 9, 27, 332250) 2 From the contents; vide Letter to Ranchhodlal Patwari, 9 9 1918 and Speech on Swadeshi, Ahmedabad, 29 6 1919.
('18', 164, 0, 1, 332362) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 165
('18', 164, 1, 2, 332407) waste, it would come to Rs. 15. Thus, looking at the prices at present, we have to spend Rs. 3 more.
('18', 164, 1, 3, 332508) But the cloth made from hand spun yarn is twice more durable.
('18', 164, 1, 4, 332570) There is likelihood of much difference in this price, because the cotton market keeps on changing every day.
('18', 164, 1, 5, 332679) If good cotton is used for spinning there, the Ashram is prepared to buy the whole stock of that yarn at the rate of three annas a seer.
('18', 164, 1, 6, 332816) I have no provision if the stock is very large.
('18', 164, 1, 7, 332864) Thus, with the increased price of cotton, one would get three annas per seer as the spinning charge.
('18', 164, 1, 8, 332965) This is the way I get the work done by 200 women at Bijapur.
('18', 164, 1, 9, 333026) These women were sitting idle before they got this job.
('18', 164, 1, 10, 333082) Altogether, cloth worth Rs. 20,000 was prepared in the Ashram or under the auspices of the Ashram during the last year.
('18', 164, 1, 11, 333202) It provided employment to 400 men and women.
('18', 164, 1, 12, 333247) Apart from this cloth worth Rs. .
('18', 164, 1, 13, 333281) .was ordered to be woven for the Famine [Relief] Committee.
('18', 164, 1, 14, 333341) This was done in an atmosphere of hostility.
('18', 164, 1, 15, 333386) People are very much attracted by machinery.
('18', 164, 1, 16, 333431) Hence I have rarely found help except from the poor people.
('18', 164, 1, 17, 333491) A couple of friends have given financial help.
('18', 164, 1, 18, 333538) It is only now that hand weaving has become a fashion.
('18', 164, 1, 19, 333593) If you can adopt this work for Kathiawar, the people would be prosperous and they would easily be delivered from the state of dependence.
('18', 164, 1, 20, 333731) The nation whose needs are provided from outside either remains dependent, or it has to be prepared to fight with force by maintaining an army.

('18', 164, 4, 24, 334000) 143. NAVAJIVAN WEEKLY
('18', 164, 5, 25, 334022) At the time of Hornimans deportation, Young India, published from Bombay in English, was a weekly.
('18', 164, 5, 26, 334121) Simultaneously with his deportation, The [Bombay] Chronicle was put under censorship.
('18', 164, 5, 27, 334207) In the circumstances, the management stopped publication of the Chronicle.
('18', 164, 5, 28, 334282) Thereupon the management of Young India decided to make it a bi weekly, so that it might serve, partly, the purpose which the Chronicle had served and entrusted me with supervision of its contents.
('18', 164, 5, 29, 334480) Though the Chronicle has now resumed publication as usual,
('18', 165, 0, 1, 334539) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 165, 1, 2, 334581) Young India continues to be brought out as a bi weekly.
('18', 165, 1, 3, 334637) Some friends posed a question to me whether it was not my duty, seeing that I was burdening myself with the supervision of an English paper, to bring out a similar paper in Gujarati.
('18', 165, 1, 4, 334820) This same question had occurred to me.
('18', 165, 1, 5, 334859) I think I have a service to render to India by delivering a message to her.
('18', 165, 1, 6, 334935) Some ideas I have come by as a result of my thinking are such as will advance us towards our welfare.
('18', 165, 1, 7, 335037) It has ever been my endeavour to explain these.
('18', 165, 1, 8, 335085) I have not succeeded as well as I should have liked to for want of ability or time or favourable circumstances.
('18', 165, 1, 9, 335197) For instance, even about satyagraha, I see a great deal of misunderstanding prevailing yet.
('18', 165, 1, 10, 335289) I am convinced that I have no gift better than this for India.
('18', 165, 1, 11, 335352) I have always been avid of placing before the people this priceless thing, and several others of which I have had ample experience.
('18', 165, 1, 12, 335484) One powerful modern means for this purpose is the newspaper.
('18', 165, 1, 13, 335545) The founders of Navajivan ane Satya have agreed to place it under my supervision and undertaken to secure facilities for its publication as a weekly.
('18', 165, 1, 14, 335695) Shri Indulal Kannaiyalal Yajnik is a busy man in the public life of Gujarat.
('18', 165, 1, 15, 335772) Even so, he has pledged himself to make Navajivan his chief concern and help it to the utmost.
('18', 165, 1, 16, 335867) These circumstances are no mere accident.
('18', 165, 1, 17, 335909) I would be ashamed not to welcome them.
('18', 165, 1, 18, 335949) And so, though my health is not what it used to be a year ago, I have ventured to assume the burden of running Navajivan.
('18', 165, 1, 19, 336071) I seek the blessings of Gujarat in this and invite the help of its men of letters in running the paper and of others in ensuring a wide circulation for it, and I am perfectly confident that I shall get it.
('18', 165, 2, 20, 336277) Navajivan will be published every Sunday and arrangements have been made to see that it is available on the same day at a number of places in Gujarat.
('18', 165, 3, 21, 336428) The management has no desire to run the paper for profit.
('18', 165, 3, 22, 336486) Accordingly, it has decided to keep the rate of subscription as low as possible, at Rs. 3 8 0 a year including postage.
('18', 165, 3, 23, 336606) This is the very figure which had been decided upon for the monthly Navajivan from its July issue onwards, with some increase in its size.
('18', 165, 3, 24, 336745) A copy of Navajivan will be priced at 1 anna and the first number will be issued on Sunday, September 7. The subscription rate mentioned above is regarded as the minimum for the reason, mainly, that the weekly will carry no advertisements.
('18', 165, 3, 25, 336985) I realized from my experience of running Indian Opinion in South Africa for many years that advertisements bring
('18', 166, 0, 1, 337098) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 167
('18', 166, 1, 2, 337143) little profit to the people.
('18', 166, 1, 3, 337172) Ultimately, they are paid for by the public itself, and all sorts of them appear, moral and immoral.
('18', 166, 1, 4, 337273) For this reason, Indian Opinion has been running for years without carrying any advertisements.
('18', 166, 1, 5, 337369) For the present, Navajivan will have eight pages of foolscap size.
('18', 166, 1, 6, 337436) As circulation increases and facilities improve, the size, too, will be enlarged.
('18', 166, 1, 7, 337518) Those, other than subscribers of the monthly Navajivan, who desire to enrol themselves as such should send their names to the Manager at Ahmedabad.
('18', 166, 1, 8, 337666) I earnestly hope that Navajivan will have a great many subscribers.
('18', 166, 2, 9, 337734) MOHANDAS K. GANDHI
('18', 166, 3, 10, 337753) [From Gujarati]

('18', 166, 5, 12, 337801) 144. SWADESHI SABHA RULES 1
('18', 166, 6, 13, 337829) [Before July 1, 1919] 2
('18', 166, 7, 14, 337853) 1. This Association shall be called the Swadeshi Sabha.
('18', 166, 7, 15, 337909) 2. Its head office shall be situated in Bombay.
('18', 166, 7, 16, 337957) 3. Its objects are: (a) to popularize the swadeshi vow attached as schedule hereto by explaining fully the meaning and importance of it; (b) to devise schemes for an increased production of swadeshi cloth, whether silk, woollen or cotton, and to make every effort to carry them into effect; (c) to devise methods for the introduction of swadeshi regarding other articles of use besides cloth and for the manufacture of all such articles in the country.
('18', 166, 7, 17, 338410) 4. Any person who has taken the swadeshi vow, pure or mixed, referred to in Rule 3, can become an A, B, C, D class member of the Sabha by paying an annual subscription of Rs. 25, Rs. 12, Rs. 6, Re.
('18', 166, 7, 18, 338608) 1, respectively, the subscription being payable for the whole official
('18', 166, 8, 19, 338679) 1 Presumably drafted by Gandhiji 2 The Central Swadeshi Sabha was inaugurated at Bombay on July 1, 1919.
('18', 167, 0, 1, 338784) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 167, 1, 2, 338826) Members of all the classes shall have the same rights and privileges.
('18', 167, 1, 3, 338896) 5. Any person who has taken the swadeshi vow, pure or mixed, referred to in Rule 3, can become a life member of the Sabha by contributing Rs. 500 or more to the Sabha.
('18', 167, 1, 4, 339064) 6. Donations will be accepted from sympathizers of the swadeshi movement even though they have not taken the swadeshi vow.
('18', 167, 1, 5, 339187) 7. Persons under 18 and school and college students shall not be admitted as members of the Sabha but they can take the swadeshi vow.
('18', 167, 1, 6, 339321) 8. The Sabha shall have a president, a vice president, three secretaries, and two treasurers.
('18', 167, 1, 7, 339415) 9. The Managing Committee of the Sabha shall consist of 30 members including the office bearers.
('18', 167, 1, 8, 339512) 10. All vacancies in the Managing Committee, office bearers, and auditors due to resignation or any other cause shall be filled up by the Committee.
('18', 167, 1, 9, 339661) 11. The Managing Committee shall be in charge of all the books and records of the Sabha and it shall stand possessed of all its funds.
('18', 167, 1, 10, 339796) 12. The Managing Committee shall have the power to do each and everything necessary to effect the objects of the Sabha.
('18', 167, 1, 11, 339916) 13. The Managing Committee may recognize and start branches of the Sabha in the Bombay Presidency.
('18', 167, 1, 12, 340015) Each branch shall have at least ten members.
('18', 167, 1, 13, 340060) The Managing Committee shall have the power to supervise the work and examine the accounts of the branches but shall not incur any responsibility for their debts.
('18', 167, 1, 14, 340223) 14. The Managing Committee shall meet at least once a fortnight.
('18', 167, 1, 15, 340288) 15. A special meeting of the Managing Committee shall be called on a written requisition of four or more members of the Committee within three days of the receipt of such requisition.
('18', 167, 1, 16, 340472) 16. At all meetings of the Managing Committee, five members and at all general meetings 12 members shall form a quorum.
('18', 167, 1, 17, 340592) No quorum shall be necessary at any meeting adjourned for want of quorum.
('18', 167, 1, 18, 340666) 17. A general meeting of the members of the Sabha shall be held at least once a month.
('18', 167, 1, 19, 340753) A special meeting shall be called on a suggestion
('18', 168, 0, 1, 340803) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 169
('18', 168, 1, 2, 340848) from the Managing Committee or on a written requisition of not less than ten members, within eight days of the receipt of the requisition.
('18', 168, 1, 3, 340987) 18. The official year of the Sabha shall commence from the 1st of June.
('18', 168, 1, 4, 341059) 19. The annual general meeting of the Sabha shall be held in the month of August to transact the following business: (a) to receive and adopt the annual report and the audited statement of accounts, (b) to elect president, a vice president, three secretaries, two treasurers, two auditors and the Managing Committee, (c) to transact such other business as may have been duly notified.
('18', 168, 1, 5, 341444) 20. The secretaries shall keep a list of members with their addresses; they shall also keep a list of the names and addresses of those who have not joined the Sabha but have taken the swadeshi vow.
('18', 168, 1, 6, 341642) 21. The secretaries shall record the minutes of the proceedings of all meetings of the Managing Committee and of the general meetings of the Sabha.
('18', 168, 1, 7, 341790) 22. The treasurers shall collect all subscriptions, be the custodians of the funds of the Sabha subject to the directions of the Managing Committee, shall keep regular accounts, and furnish a quarterly statement of accounts in which they shall bring to the notice of the Managing Committee all defaults in the payments to be made to the Sabha.
('18', 168, 2, 8, 342134) 23. The Managing Committee may without assigning any reason expel any member of the Sabha by a two third majority of the total number of its members.
('18', 168, 3, 9, 342284) 24. All subscriptions shall be paid within three months from the date of joining the Sabha and thence forward from the commencement of the official year.
('18', 168, 3, 10, 342438) If the subscription of a member be in arrears, the secretaries shall give him notice to pay, and if he fails to pay within a month after such notice, the Managing Committee shall remove his name from the list of members.
('18', 168, 3, 11, 342659) 25. The foregoing rules shall be subject to alterations and additions as may be made from time to time by the Sabha.

('18', 169, 4, 5, 342882) THIRD VOW I solemnly declare that henceforth I will buy for my use only such cloth as is woven in India, from Indian and foreign cotton, wool or silk, spun in India, and outside.
('18', 169, 4, 6, 343061) Explanation: Those desirous of buying only pure swadeshi cloth will remove the words and foreign and and outside from the pledge.
('18', 169, 4, 7, 343191) Note: The pledge has been prepared for the convenience of those who do not desire or are unable to discard such foreign cloth as they already possess; but it is hoped that those taking this vow will discard foreign clothes as early as possible and at all auspicious occasions will use only swadeshi clothes.

('18', 170, 1, 2, 343759) 145. WRITTEN STATEMENT ON FUTURE PLANS 1
('18', 170, 2, 3, 343800) BOMBAY, July 1, 1919 I have received through Mr. Robertson 2 the message kindly sent by the Government of India with reference to my plans.
('18', 170, 2, 4, 343940) I wish to state that whenever I actually resume civil disobedience, I shall give due notice to the local authority.
('18', 170, 2, 5, 344056) Civil disobedience will be restricted only to myself and my co workers will not take it up for at least one month after my incarceration except at their own risk.
('18', 170, 2, 6, 344219) As I have written to His Excellency the Viceroy a letter 3 to which I expect a reply and as I have sent a cable 4 to Mr. Montagu in order to wait for reply to these two communications, I do not propose to offer civil disobedience up to Tuesday 5 next.
('18', 170, 2, 7, 344471) The manner in which I propose to offer civil disobedience is by crossing the border of this Presidency at some point.
('18', 170, 2, 8, 344589) So far as I can think at present, it is not my desire to cross the border by attempting to go to the Punjab, as I feel that I would be unnecessarily disturbing the process of peace going on there at present and doing an act which might irritate the local Government.
('18', 170, 2, 9, 344856) If the Government of India or the local Government would wish me to cross the border of the Presidency at any particular point, I would gladly do so.
('18', 170, 2, 10, 345006) My movements up to Tuesday are as follows: I intend to take the Gujarat Mail on Saturday evening and reach Nadiad on Sunday morning, staying in the Kaira District practically the whole of Sunday, during that time if necessary pay a visit to Kathlal for the sake of delivering an address at Kathlal on swadeshi.
('18', 170, 2, 11, 345317) In that event, I would take the evening train from Nadiad to Ahmedabad on Sunday and stay in Ahmedabad during the whole of Monday, taking the return Gujarat Mail from Ahmedabad to Bombay, which accordingly I reach on Tuesday morning at 8 oclock.
('18', 170, 2, 12, 345563) The day in

('18', 171, 1, 2, 346146) Ahmedabad I propose to pass by talking to my friends about the manner of preserving peace after my civil disobedience and I propose to address the same day a meeting of women in Ahmedabad on swadeshi.
('18', 171, 1, 3, 346347) I would like respectfully to state that if the Government desire that I should suspend the resumption of civil disobedience for any definite time not too distant, I would consider it my duty to respect their wish, as I am most anxious that no action on my part should in any shape or form cause embarrassment to Government, save what embarrassment is inevitable by reason of civil disobedience on the ground of the refusal of Government to listen to the appeal for withdrawal of the Rowlatt legislation.
('18', 171, 1, 4, 346851) I have heard on, what is in my opinion, good authority that it is the intention of the Government of India as also the Secretary of State for India to revise their opinion on the Rowlatt legislation and at a suitable time not very far distant they propose to withdraw the Rowlatt Act and that they have abandoned the intention of processing with the sister Bill.
('18', 171, 1, 5, 347214) If my information is correct and if the Government will so far as they can at present give the assurance, not for publication, that such is their intention, I would indefinitely postpone civil disobedience.

('18', 172, 1, 2, 347973) 147. LETTER TO JEHANGIR B. PETIT
('18', 172, 2, 3, 348006) LABURNUM ROAD, [BOMBAY ,] July 2 [1919]
('18', 172, 3, 4, 348046) DEAR SHRI JEHANGIRJI,
('18', 172, 4, 5, 348068) I am thankful to you for the courteous hearing you gave to the message I sent you.
('18', 172, 4, 6, 348151) Your failure to do anything in the matter of South Africa has hurt me very much.
('18', 172, 4, 7, 348232) I wrote to the editor of The Times of India four days ago; he immediately sent for literature, read it, and today we have a fine article.
('18', 172, 4, 8, 348370) Compare this promptness with your indifference.
('18', 172, 4, 9, 348418) I had expected much from you.
('18', 172, 4, 10, 348448) Even now, I entreat you to shake off your apathy on this issue and do your duty.
('18', 172, 4, 11, 348529) This was one thing, and not so very important either.
('18', 172, 4, 12, 348583) I have some money with me, given by friends to help me in my activities, and I manage with it to meet my requirements; but dont you think it was improper of you to have unnecessarily kept me all these days without the money offered to Mrs. Polak?
('18', 172, 4, 13, 348830) I have already incurred some expenses on affairs concerning South Africa.
('18', 172, 4, 14, 348904) I want to send them a long cable today.
('18', 172, 4, 15, 348944) You have promised to meet all the expenditure that may be incurred on this account, but I have grown nervous because of your indifference.
('18', 172, 4, 16, 349083) How can I go begging elsewhere for money which it is for the Imperial Citizenship Association to provide?
('18', 172, 4, 17, 349189) If, therefore, you think it right that the Association should pay the money, you have to send me Rs. 1,000 towards this expenditure.
('18', 172, 4, 18, 349322) I shall send you the account.
('18', 172, 4, 19, 349352) A good many cables have to be sent.
('18', 172, 5, 20, 349388) Yours, MOHANDAS GANDHI
('18', 172, 6, 21, 349411) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 6484

('18', 173, 1, 2, 349497) 148. LETTER TO THE PRESS ON SOUTH AFRICAN QUESTION 1
('18', 173, 2, 3, 349550) [BOMBAY, July 3, 1919] 2
('18', 173, 3, 4, 349575) TO THE EDITOR THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE
('18', 173, 4, 5, 349610) SIR, The Times of India has led the way in showing that in the midst of sharp differences between usthe English and Indiansthere are points of contact on which we can act with unison.
('18', 173, 4, 6, 349794) Such is the South African Indian question.
('18', 173, 4, 7, 349837) Notwithstanding our preoccupations, we may notdare notforget this big question.
('18', 173, 4, 8, 349917) Even whilst the Maharaja of Bikaner was hoping and appealing to the Dominions statesmen that the Indian settlers in the Colonies would receive fair and liberal treatment, a scheme was being hatched by the responsible officials of South Africa to deprive the Indians of the Transvaal of vested rights in breach of the compact of 1914, to which the Government of India was witness, if not party.
('18', 173, 4, 9, 350311) The Bill, which is now being discussed in the Press and which, according to the latest papers received, has passed the committee stage of the Union House of Assembly at the end of May last, virtually deprives the Indians of the Transvaal from [sic] holding fixed property even as shareholders of companies or as mortgagees, as they have hitherto successfully and legally done.
('18', 173, 4, 10, 350688) It further deprives them of the right of obtaining new trade licences throughout the Transvaal.
('18', 173, 4, 11, 350784) This means that Indian settlers, if they are not now efficiently protected, will be reduced to the status of menial servants, no matter what their capacity might be.
('18', 173, 4, 12, 350950) It was bad enough to restrict so as almost to prohibit fresh immigration.
('18', 173, 4, 13, 351024) It is intolerable to confiscate the economic and material rights of legally admitted immigrants and their descendants.
('18', 173, 4, 14, 351143) The duty of Englishmen residing in India and Indians is, in my
('18', 173, 5, 15, 351206) 1 This was published also in New India, 4 7 l919. Young India, 5 7 1919 and The Hindu, 7 7 1919. 2 The Associated Press of India released it on July 3, from Bombay.
('18', 174, 0, 1, 351371) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 175
('18', 174, 1, 2, 351416) humble opinion, clear.
('18', 174, 1, 3, 351439) We can create such an emphatic public opinion that we can shame the Europeans of South Africa into doing the right thing.
('18', 174, 1, 4, 351561) We can also by our united protest strengthen the hands of the Government of India in its endeavour, which it will make as trustee effectively, to protect the Indian settlers of the Transvaal from impending extinction.
('18', 174, 2, 5, 351779) Yours, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 4 7 1919
('18', 174, 3, 6, 351836) 149. LETTER TO SIR GEORGE BARNES
('18', 174, 4, 7, 351869) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, July 3, 1919
('18', 174, 5, 8, 351905) DEAR SIR GEORGE BARNES 1, You were good enough to write to me some months ago that you were inquiring about the South African Indian situation.
('18', 174, 5, 9, 352049) It has since gone from bad to worse.
('18', 174, 5, 10, 352086) You will gauge it from the enclosed cuttings.
('18', 174, 5, 11, 352132) Briefly, the position, if the Bill referred to in the enclosed becomes law, will be that Indians in the Transvaal will not be able to trade and hold fixed property, as they have hitherto been legally able to.
('18', 174, 5, 12, 352341) This is a manifest and direct breach of the compact of l914 to which the Government of India was witness, if not party.
('18', 174, 5, 13, 352461) And party or no party, can it for a moment tolerate legal confiscation of economic and material, as distinguushed from political, rights?
('18', 174, 5, 14, 352599) It is one thing to stop or restrict immigration, it is another to deprive legally admitted immigrants of the means of honest and honourable livelihood.
('18', 174, 5, 15, 352751) I know you will act, and that promptly.
('18', 174, 5, 16, 352791) The Bill might even have passed all stages.
('18', 174, 5, 17, 352835) I trust you will put the cable in motion and inquire.
('18', 174, 5, 18, 352889) Hoping you have benefited by the change.
('18', 174, 6, 19, 352930) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('18', 174, 7, 20, 352960) From a photostat: S.N. 6484 b

('18', 175, 3, 4, 353177) DEAR MR. EWBANK 1, I have long intended to write to you but something or other has intervened to prevent me from doing so.

('18', 175, 3, 7, 353416) Could I interest you in the movement?
('18', 175, 3, 8, 353454) My desire is to introduce hand spinning and hand weaving among the peasants who have no profitable employment practically during half the year and among lakhs of women and men who have spare time on their hands and who will not and do not do any profitable and honourable work.
('18', 175, 3, 9, 353732) If you approve of the idea, your active co operation will give a powerful impetus to the movement.
('18', 175, 3, 10, 353831) It is in this branch of our work that I would like you to join the movement.
('18', 175, 3, 11, 353908) It is totally non political in character and if you could take one of the pledges or, if not that, you could become an associate, I should greatly esteem it.

('18', 177, 4, 7, 357153) 153. SPEECH ON SWADESHI, BOMBAY 1
('18', 177, 5, 8, 357187) July 4, 1919 Shri Jerajani has shown in his speech that India is not an industrially backward country.
('18', 177, 5, 9, 357290) He and Narandas have done a great service by opening the Swadeshi Store.
('18', 177, 5, 10, 357363) From now onwards, I shall ask the people at every meeting how many of them have taken one of the swadeshi vows.
('18', 177, 5, 11, 357475) The vow of the third category is so simple that I even felt ashamed when including it, for there can be no vow which does not entail some suffering.
('18', 177, 5, 12, 357624) I cannot understand why people have not taken such a simple vow in large numbers.
('18', 177, 5, 13, 357706) There should be none in Bombay who has not taken one or other of the three vows.
('18', 177, 5, 14, 357787) If a majority of the people take the vow, some of them will start thinking from where they will get so much cloth and, in the result, they will themselves set to work or make others work.
('18', 177, 5, 15, 357975) Those friends, therefore, who have not taken the vow so far, should go to the office of the Swadeshi Sabha tomorrow and do so.
('18', 177, 5, 16, 358102) However, the person who takes the vow should resolve in his mind that he would himself spin the quantity of yarn he might need or arrange to get it spun, and weave his own cloth or get it woven.
('18', 177, 5, 17, 358297) If the person lacks this spirit, he will have taken the vow in vain.
('18', 177, 5, 18, 358366) The well to do should not think that they will pay and buy ready made cloth for themselves; they too should resolve as above.
('18', 177, 5, 19, 358492) If we remain sunk in lethargy, the country will be still further impoverished.
('18', 177, 5, 20, 358571) Finally, I shall merely say that you should, without delay, take the swadeshi vow which is within your capacity and see that you positively keep it.
('18', 177, 5, 21, 358720) Rather than take a vow without thinking and then fail to keep it, better not to take it at all.
('18', 177, 6, 22, 358816) [From Gujarati] Gujarat Mitra ane Gujarat Darpan, 13 7 1919
('18', 177, 7, 23, 358876) 1 The meeting was held under the auspices of the Swadahi Sabha.
('18', 177, 7, 24, 358940) Gandhiji was in the chair.

('18', 178, 1, 2, 359012) 154. SMUTS GANDHI AGREEMENT
('18', 178, 2, 3, 359040) So long as the Young India syndicate continue to permit me to supervise its contents and policy, so long do I propose to use this journal for placing before the country a programme of work which I hold to be of primary importance and in which I possess a special knowledge, and so long shall I continue to use these columns for a criticism, where such is necessary, of the Government doingsa criticism which shall often be helpful, but sometimes temporarily obstructive, when the Government needs obstruction in its progress towards something which is in reality harmful to the country at large.
('18', 178, 2, 4, 359636) I trust the readers of Young India will not grumble if they for the time being find its pages filled with references to the position of our countrymen in South Africa.
('18', 178, 2, 5, 359804) It is better that I allow its columns to be occupied with something useful, authentic and requiring immediate attention than that it should contain matters of which neither the contributors nor I may possess any special knowledge, or in which neither they nor I may be specially interested.
('18', 178, 2, 6, 360095) This does not mean that I claim any superiority for this manner of conducting a journal.
('18', 178, 2, 7, 360184) I merely state the aim for the time being of this journal.
('18', 178, 2, 8, 360243) I do hold however that no well conducted journal should contain irresponsible or ill informed criticism or deal with matters of which its conductors do not possess an adequate knowledge.
('18', 178, 2, 9, 360430) This question of the status of our countrymen in South Africa is a matter of no small importance.
('18', 178, 2, 10, 360528) The measure of our capacity for self government is the measure of our ability to feel for the meanest of ourselves.
('18', 178, 2, 11, 360644) The cause being just, the wrong being clearly demonstrable, we have to be the readier to act when the cause is of the helpless.
('18', 178, 2, 12, 360772) It is the magnitude of the wrong, not the person, that should arrest attention.
('18', 178, 2, 13, 360852) According to the above test, this question of the status of our countrymen in South Africa is of more immediate importance than even the all absorbing question of Reforms.
('18', 178, 2, 14, 361024) This question cannot await solution till after the Reforms are granted.
('18', 178, 2, 15, 361096) It must be dealt with now or never.
('18', 178, 2, 16, 361132) It is to be hoped therefore that India will witness a revival of the agitation that was started by the late Mr. Gokhale in 1913 and which culminated in the settlement of 1914. What, then, is the Smuts Gandhi agreement?
('18', 178, 2, 17, 361351) It is remarkable but it is true that every amelioration in the status of the Transvaal Indians
('18', 179, 0, 1, 361446) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 179, 1, 2, 361488) has been used afterwards often successfully by their opponents to take away further rights from them.
('18', 179, 1, 3, 361590) The Indian settlers have therefore always been engaged in resisting encroachment on their liberty.
('18', 179, 1, 4, 361689) Their progress thus has been negative.
('18', 179, 1, 5, 361728) The agreement is set forth in the two letters dated 30th June 1914, the one addressed to me on General Smuts behalf and the other being my reply thereto.
('18', 179, 1, 6, 361882) There is another letter from me written to Mr. Gorges, the then Secretary for the Interior, setting forth my interpretation of the term vested rights.
('18', 179, 1, 7, 362033) Anyone may see for himself that the reply of the 30th June was written in my representative capacity, the letter of the 7th July in my private capacity showing what I thought of vested rights in connection with the Gold Law and Township Amendment Act.
('18', 179, 1, 8, 362285) The curious reader will see the correspondence for himself reproduced elsewhere and will find no difficulty in interpreting it.
('18', 179, 1, 9, 362413) I would not press for the insertion of a definition of vested rights in the representative correspondence, because I felt that any definition in the correspondence might result in restricting the future action of my countrymen.
('18', 179, 1, 10, 362641) Thus my letter could not be used for the curtailment of our rights.
('18', 179, 1, 11, 362709) But the definition given by me as a matter of fact does not in any way whatsoever curtail existing rights.
('18', 179, 1, 12, 362816) There was even in 1914 and prior to it an attempt being made to interpret the two laws mentioned in my letter of the 7th July 1914 so as adversely to affect the rights of the Indians residing in the Gold area.
('18', 179, 1, 13, 363026) I therefore contended that the terms of the settlement required that no rights that were exercised by the Indians at the time of the passing of the two laws could be taken away even though the legal interpretation thereof went against our countrymen.
('18', 179, 1, 14, 363277) In support of my contention, I used Mr. Jaup de Villers own statement prepared for the Imperial Government.
('18', 179, 1, 15, 363385) If, therefore, my letter be part of the settlement, it could only protect Indians from statutory infringement of their liberty.
('18', 179, 1, 16, 363513) That letter could not be used, as it has been used, even by the Committee of the House of Assembly for creating a legal restriction.
('18', 179, 1, 17, 363646) Mr. Duncans independent interpretation of it will bear repetition.
('18', 179, 1, 18, 363713) He did not regard the Smuts Gandhi agreement as an agreement or an assertion that no more Indian licences should be obtained after that date.
('18', 179, 1, 19, 363855) The agreement was a protective agreement, under which an undertaking was given that the law should be administered with due respect to vested rights and that the Gold Law would not be put into force against the Indian community.
('18', 180, 0, 1, 364084) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 181
('18', 180, 1, 2, 364129) Whatever the interpretation of my letter or the whole settlement, the only question before Indiathe Government and the peopleis: Are Indians of the Transvaal who have served the Empire as faithfully as any of the other inhabitants of South Africa to be deprived of the right to reside and trade freely and to hold fixed property therein at least as they have done hitherto? The Government of India and the people can only answer it in one way.
('18', 180, 1, 3, 364573) And I hope that before the week is out, India will send a message of hope to her children who are battling against heavy odds.
('18', 180, 2, 4, 364700) Young India, 5 7 1919

('18', 181, 1, 2, 365682) 156. LETTER TO H. S. L. POLAK
('18', 181, 2, 3, 365712) July 5 [1919]
('18', 181, 3, 4, 365726) MY DEAR HENRY, I have your confidential memorandum.
('18', 181, 3, 5, 365778) I must confess that I do not like it.
('18', 181, 3, 6, 365816) We cannot accept merely formal legal equality with the full knowledge that administratively trade licences will be taken away.
('18', 181, 3, 7, 365943) We must take up an unbending and unbendable attitude on the question of trade and fixed property.

('18', 181, 3, 9, 366325) I am moving here in that direction.
('18', 181, 3, 10, 366361) You will see from the columns of Young India what is being done.
('18', 181, 3, 11, 366426) Mr. Sheppard of The Times of India has responded satisfactorily in the matter.

('18', 181, 5, 17, 367080) 157. THE DUTY OF SATYAGRAHIS
('18', 181, 6, 18, 367109) NADIAD, July 6, 1919
('18', 181, 7, 19, 367130) The above was the title given by Mr. Gandhi to the address which he delivered before a Nadiad audience on Sunday last.
('18', 181, 7, 20, 367249) Mr. Gokuldas D. Talati, President of the Nadiad Municipality, presided.
('18', 181, 7, 21, 367321) Between two and three thousand people were present.
('18', 181, 7, 22, 367373) The following is the substance of Mr. Gandhis speech as edited by himself:
('18', 181, 8, 23, 367448) Mr. Gandhi, speaking on the subject, said that he had a special claim on the people of Nadiad in particular and the population of Kaira in general, as he had lived
('18', 182, 0, 1, 367612) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 183
('18', 182, 1, 2, 367657) for so long in their midst and was surrounded with so much affection from them.
('18', 182, 1, 3, 367737) His largest experiments were carried out in Kaira.
('18', 182, 1, 4, 367788) It was no small matter for law abiding people to suspend the payment of revenue.
('18', 182, 1, 5, 367869) It was a very serious responsibility he had taken upon his shoulders of advising them to do so.
('18', 182, 1, 6, 367965) The actual working of that experiment showed that there was no cause for regret.
('18', 182, 1, 7, 368046) It was acknowledged by officers concerned that this was a most peaceful, orderly and becoming demonstration of their grievance.
('18', 182, 1, 8, 368174) It was this exemplary and successful act of civil disobedience which betrayed him into the miscalculation of April last and, if he then considered his mistake to be as big as the Vindhya Range, now after longer experience he felt that it was a Himalayan miscalculation.
('18', 182, 1, 9, 368444) Not only, however, was his claim upon the Kaira people based upon the revenue struggle, but also upon the recruiting campaign.
('18', 182, 2, 10, 368571) Mr. Gandhi further said: The first was to the peoples liking; recruiting by reason of long disuse in the training of arms and of absence of real affection was unattractive and unpleasant, and yet I know that you had begun to respond nobly and I feel confident that had the war been prolonged, Kaira would have quite voluntarily contributed from the middle classes probably not less than 1,000 recruits.
('18', 182, 2, 11, 368974) I had therefore hoped, as I still hope, that Kaira would play no mean part in the work of national regeneration and that my services to the motherland will be rendered largely through you or, perhaps more correctly speaking, Gujarat.
('18', 182, 2, 12, 369208) And so as I may have to offer civil disobedience at a very early date, I thought I would speak to you today about the duty of satyagrahis.
('18', 182, 2, 13, 369347) It is hardly possible to understand this duty without a correct appreciation of the meaning of satyagraha.
('18', 182, 2, 14, 369454) I have already given its definition but the mere definition often fails to convey the true meaning.
('18', 182, 2, 15, 369554) Unfortunately, popular imagination has pictured satyagraha as purely and simply civil disobedience, if not in some cases even criminal disobedience.
('18', 182, 2, 16, 369703) The latter, as you all know, is the very opposite of satyagraha.
('18', 182, 2, 17, 369768) The former, i.e., civil disobedience, is undoubtedly an important but by no means always the main part of satyagraha.
('18', 182, 2, 18, 369886) Today, for instance, on the question of Rowlatt legislation, civil disobedience has gone into the background.
('18', 182, 2, 19, 369996) As satyagraha is being brought into play on a large scale on the political field for the first time, it is in an experimental stage.
('18', 182, 2, 20, 370129) I am therefore ever making new discoveries.
('18', 182, 2, 21, 370173) And my error in trying to let civil disobedience take the people by storm appears to me to be Himalayan because of the discovery I have made, namely, that he only is able and attains the right to offer civil disobedience who has known how to offer
('18', 183, 0, 1, 370421) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 183, 1, 2, 370463) voluntary and deliberate obedience to the laws of the State in which he is living.
('18', 183, 1, 3, 370546) It is only after one has voluntarily obeyed such laws a thousand times that an occasion rightly comes to one civilly to disobey certain laws.
('18', 183, 1, 4, 370688) Nor is it necessary for voluntary obedience that the laws to be obeyed must be good.
('18', 183, 1, 5, 370773) There are many unjust laws which a good citizen obeys so long as they do not hurt his self respect or the moral being, and when I look back upon my life, I cannot recall a single occasion when I have obeyed a law whether of society or the State because of the fear of punishment.
('18', 183, 1, 6, 371053) I have obeyed bad laws of the society as well as of the State, believing that it was good for me and the State or the society to which I belonged to do so, and I feel that having regularly and in a disciplined manner done so, the call for disobedience to a law of society came when I went to England in 1888 and to a law of the State in South Africa when the Asiatic Registration Act was passed by the Transvaal Government.
('18', 183, 1, 7, 371477) I have therefore come to the conclusion that civil disobedience, if it has to be renewed, shall be offered in the first instance only by me as being the fittest to do so and the duty of fellow satyagrahis will be to assimilate for the time being the first essential just mentioned of civil disobedience.
('18', 183, 1, 8, 371781) In the instructions I have drawn up, I have suggested that civil disobedience by the others should not be taken up for at least one month after I have been taken charge of by the Government.
('18', 183, 1, 9, 371972) And then, too, by one or two chosen satyagrahis chosen in the sense above mentioned and only if it is found that no violence has been offered after my incarceration by the satyagrahis so called or others acting in co operation with them.
('18', 183, 1, 10, 372210) The next duty then is for the remaining satyagrahis themselves to observe perfect calm and quiet and to see that others do likewise.
('18', 183, 1, 11, 372343) You will, therefore, see to it that after I have offered civil disobedience, if I do, there is no hartal, no public meetings, and no demonstrations of any kind whatsoever so to give excitement.
('18', 183, 1, 12, 372537) And I feel sure that if perfect peace is observed after my incarceration, Rowlatt legislation will go by reason of that very fact.
('18', 183, 1, 13, 372668) But it is quite likely that the Government may remain perfectly obstinate.
('18', 183, 1, 14, 372743) In that event under the conditions I have already mentioned, it will be open to the satyagrahis to offer further civil disobedience and continue to do so till every satyagrahi has rendered a good account of himself.
('18', 183, 1, 15, 372959) For the intervening period, I have drawn up constructive work in the instructions.
('18', 183, 1, 16, 373042) I have suggested the swadeshi movement as an item swadeshi in a religious and true spirit without even a suspicion of
('18', 184, 0, 1, 373160) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 185
('18', 184, 1, 2, 373205) boycott, swadeshi which would enable the Viceroy down to the humblest ryot to take part in.
('18', 184, 1, 3, 373297) At the lowest estimate, 80 per cent of the population of India is agricultural.
('18', 184, 1, 4, 373377) This makes over 24 crores.
('18', 184, 1, 5, 373404) It is well known that, during half the year, this population remains practically idle or has at least many hours at its disposal for useful work.
('18', 184, 1, 6, 373550) If this population is given an easy, substantial and profitable work to do, one of the higher economic problems will have been solved.
('18', 184, 1, 7, 373685) In my humble opinion, such an occupation is hand spinning.
('18', 184, 1, 8, 373744) It can be easily learned by everybody and it is the most perfect way in my opinion of utilizing the idle hours of the nation.
('18', 184, 1, 9, 373870) Swadeshi is mainly a matter of production and manufacture.
('18', 184, 1, 10, 373929) The more goods we manufacture the more swadeshi there is in the country.
('18', 184, 1, 11, 374002) The vows have been framed in order to serve as an incentive to manufacture and production.
('18', 184, 1, 12, 374093) This work requires a large number of volunteers whose sole qualification needs to be perfect honesty and love of the country.
('18', 184, 1, 13, 374219) I would like every man and woman in India to devote themselves heart and soul to this work.
('18', 184, 1, 14, 374311) And I doubt not that in an incredibly short time we would have restored to its original vigour the lost art of weaving the finest cloth of the most effective design.
('18', 184, 1, 15, 374477) There is one more subject I have to touch upon.
('18', 184, 1, 16, 374525) Painful as it were, in their consequences, the tragic events of the mad mob in Ahmedabad and Viramgam in April last, some of the doings in Kaira were, if possible, still more tragic if you contemplate what might have happened.
('18', 184, 1, 17, 374752) I refer to the cutting down of the telegraph wires and the tearing down of the railway.
('18', 184, 1, 18, 374840) The acts of the mob in Ahmedabad betoken mad frenzy.
('18', 184, 1, 19, 374893) The acts in Kaira betoken deliberation.
('18', 184, 1, 20, 374933) They were also done in anger but even in anger there can be thoughtlessness or thoughtfulness.
('18', 184, 1, 21, 375028) The Kaira crimes, though far less disastrous in consequences than those of Ahmedabad, were from a satyagraha standpoint more inexcusable, if there can be any excuse for any crime whatsoever.
('18', 184, 1, 22, 375219) I understand that those who were responsible for the misdeeds of April have not all come forward to boldly confess the crime.
('18', 184, 1, 23, 375345) It was a pity that Kaira behaved so nobly during the revenue struggle should have forgotten itself during April, but it is a greater pity that the guilty ones should now try to hide themselves.
('18', 184, 1, 24, 375539) It is therefore the plain duty of satyagrahis to make an open confession if any of them is in any shape or form responsible for the crime and to persuade, if they have the knowledge, those who have committed the crimes to make the confession.
('18', 184, 1, 25, 375782) It is cowardly enough to tear down the railway and thus endanger the lives of
('18', 185, 0, 1, 375860) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 185, 1, 2, 375902) soldiers who were proceeding to restore peace and order.
('18', 185, 1, 3, 375959) It is still more cowardly not to come forward boldly and admit the wrong.
('18', 185, 1, 4, 376033) A hidden sin is like poison corrupting the whole body.
('18', 185, 1, 5, 376088) The sooner the poison is thrown off, the better it is for society.
('18', 185, 1, 6, 376155) And just as a bit of arsenic mixed with milk renders it none the less vitiating for the addition of pure milk, so also do good deed in a society fail to cover unexpiated sins.
('18', 185, 1, 7, 376331) I hope that you will strain every nerve to find out those whose mad grief betrayed them into unpardonable crimes and appeal to them to own up like men and thus purify the social, moral and political atmosphere of this district.
('18', 185, 1, 8, 376559) (I have considerably abridged the speech but added one or two sentences to complete or amplify my meaning.)

('18', 192, 7, 20, 393890) 161. LALA RADHA KRISHNAS CASE
('18', 192, 8, 21, 393920) When Babu Kalinath Roys case was taken up in these columns, I was asked by several Punjabi friends why I had not taken up Lala Radha Krishnas 2 case which was equally strong, if not stronger than Babu Kalinath Roys.
('18', 192, 8, 22, 394136) I respectfully told the friends that I did not know Lala Radha Krishnas case and that I would be glad to study it if the papers were sent to me.
('18', 192, 8, 23, 394281) I have now received the papers, namely, the charge, the defence statement, the judgment, Lala Radha Krishnas petitions and the translations of portions of the Pratap from which the statements in the charge sheet were taken.
('18', 192, 8, 24, 394505) These are all published in
('18', 192, 9, 25, 394532) 1 Of July 8 conveying the Governors desire to meet Gandhiji at Poona on Saturday 2 Editor of Pratap
('18', 193, 0, 1, 394632) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 193, 1, 2, 394674) this issue.
('18', 193, 1, 3, 394686) The reader, therefore, has complete data for coming to a definite conclusion.
('18', 193, 1, 4, 394764) In my humble opinion, the judgment is a travesty of justice.
('18', 193, 1, 5, 394825) The case is in some respects worse even than Babu Kalinath Roys.
('18', 193, 1, 6, 394890) There are no startling headlines as in The Tribune case.
('18', 193, 1, 7, 394947) The accused has been sentenced not on a section of the Indian Penal Code but on a rule temporarily framed as a war measure.
('18', 193, 1, 8, 395071) My meaning will be clear when the reader has the rule itself before him.
('18', 193, 1, 9, 395144) Let me remind him that it is not a rule passed by the Legislative Council.
('18', 193, 1, 10, 395219) It is a rule promulgated by the Government under the powers granted to it by the Defence of India Act.
('18', 193, 1, 11, 395322) Here is the whole of it:
('18', 193, 2, 12, 395347) (1) Whoever by words, either spoken or written, or by signs, or by visible representations or otherwise, publishes or circulates any statement, rumour or report
('18', 193, 3, 13, 395508) (a) which is false and which he has no reasonable ground to believe to be true, with intent to cause, or which is likely to cause, fear or alarm to the public or to any section of the public; or
('18', 193, 4, 14, 395703) (b) with intent to jeopardize, or which is likely to jeopardize, the success of His Majestys forces by land or sea, or the success of the forces of any power in alliance with His Majesty; or
('18', 193, 5, 15, 395894) (c) with intent to prejudice, or which is likely to prejudice, His Majestys relations with Foreign Powers; or
('18', 193, 6, 16, 396004) (d) with intent to promote, or which is likely to promote, feelings of enmity and hatred between different classes of His Majestys subjects
('18', 193, 7, 17, 396144) shall be punishable with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine, or if it is proved that he did so with intent to assist the Kings enemies with death, transportation for life or imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years.
('18', 193, 8, 18, 396450) (2) No court shall take cognisance of any offence against this rule save
('18', 193, 9, 19, 396523) upon complaint made by order of, or under authority from, the Governor 
('18', 193, 10, 20, 396595) General in Council, the Local Government or some officer empowered by the
('18', 193, 11, 21, 396669) Governor General in Council in this behalf.
('18', 193, 11, 22, 396713) It will be noticed that the rule is so drastic that an offence against it could not be taken cognisance of except under special orders of the Government or some officer appointed in this behalf.
('18', 194, 0, 1, 396908) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 195
('18', 194, 1, 2, 396953) Let us turn to the indictment.
('18', 194, 1, 3, 396984) Now a charge sheet should contain no avoidable inaccuracies and no innuendoes.
('18', 194, 1, 4, 397063) But we find that this indictment contains material inaccuracies.
('18', 194, 1, 5, 397128) One of the three statements claimed by the prosecution to be false is that the accused said in his paper that they (the crowd) were fired at in Delhi without any cause.
('18', 194, 1, 6, 397297) Now this is a dangerous inaccuracy.
('18', 194, 1, 7, 397333) The passage in question reads, they were, at least from their point of view, fired at without any cause. The words italicized have been omitted from the charge, thus giving a different meaning to the writing from the one intended by the writer.
('18', 194, 1, 8, 397578) From the third item, too, the relevant portion which alters the accuseds meaning in his favour has been omitted.
('18', 194, 1, 9, 397691) The third count concludes, the people threw stones and brickbats at the time when the authorities had already taken the initiative. The relevant and qualifying sentence in the article from which the above is extracted is: But it is possible that somebody among this huge crowd might have thrown stones on the police officers (before they resorted to firing).
('18', 194, 1, 10, 398050) Even admitting this to be true, we say that the wisdom and prudence of the authorities demanded that some other method than firing guns should have been adopted with a view to suppress this disturbance. This sentence with the portion italicized again alters the whole meaning.
('18', 194, 1, 11, 398327) If such an ommission was made by a defendant, it would amount to suppressio veri, and he would rightly put himself out of court.
('18', 194, 1, 12, 398456) Done by the prosecution, the omission has passed muster, but in reality it is far more dangerous than suppressio veri on the part of a defendant.
('18', 194, 1, 13, 398602) The Crown by a material omission, intended or otherwise, may succeed in bringing about an unjust conviction, as it appears to have done in this case.
('18', 194, 1, 14, 398752) The last paragraph of the charge contains an unpardonable innuendo:
('18', 194, 2, 15, 398820) The accused has published a number of seditious and inflammatory articles, but the Crown prefers to proceed under Rule 25. The suggestion that the accused has written seditious and inflammatory articles could only be calculated to prejudice the defence.
('18', 194, 2, 16, 399074) I have never seen an indictment so loosely drawn up and so argumentative as this.
('18', 194, 2, 17, 399156) In a properly constituted court of law, I venture to think that it would have been ruled out of order and the accused set free without having to enter upon any defence.
('18', 194, 2, 18, 399325) The judgment, too, I am sorry to say, leaves the same impression
('18', 195, 0, 1, 399390) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 195, 1, 2, 399432) on ones mind that the charge doesan impression of prejudice and haste.
('18', 195, 1, 3, 399503) It says: The prosecution have also established that each of these statements is false. Now I have, I hope, already demonstrated that two of the statements in the indictment would not be false, for they are statements torn from their context and incomplete.
('18', 195, 1, 4, 399760) No amount of evidence to prove the falsity of such incomplete statements could possibly be permitted to injure the accused.
('18', 195, 1, 5, 399884) There remain only two statements to be examined.
('18', 195, 1, 6, 399933) The first statement is, By the evening of the 31st March, forty Hindus and Mussulmans had been killed. Now it would be quite clear to anybody perusing the judgment that even now it is not known how many persons were killed.
('18', 195, 1, 7, 400157) I suggest that the deciding factor in examining the falseness or otherwise of the above statement is not the number killed but whether any people were killed at all.
('18', 195, 1, 8, 400323) If anything could then alarm the people, it was the fact of firing, not necessarily the number killed.
('18', 195, 1, 9, 400426) And the fact of firing is not denied.
('18', 195, 1, 10, 400464) As to the number, the newspapers including the Anglo Indian Press had different versions.
('18', 195, 1, 11, 400554) The learned judge dismisses the plea that other respectable papers contained about the same statements that the Pratap did.
('18', 195, 1, 12, 400678) I submit that it was a relevant plea in order to establish the defendants bona fides with a view to showing that he had reasonable grounds for believing the statements he published.
('18', 195, 1, 13, 400860) The second statement made by the accused is, It cannot be denied that most who were killed or wounded were innocent. Lala Radha Krishna in his petition pertinently observes that the Delhi authorities themselves took this view and in order to provide for the innocent sufferers in the riots opened a public fund.
('18', 195, 1, 14, 401172) Let me add to this that no attempt was made by the Crown to show that even one man killed or wounded among the crowd was guilty of any act of violence himself.
('18', 195, 1, 15, 401332) The court seems merely to have relied upon the fact that those who were killed were members of a violent and dangerous mob.
('18', 195, 1, 16, 401456) That fact does not necessarily prove that those actually killed were guilty of violence nor has the accused in his articles complained that the innocent suffered with the guilty.
('18', 195, 1, 17, 401635) His complaint naturally was that the firing was at all resorted to.
('18', 195, 1, 18, 401703) It is now necessary to examine the rule under which the accused was charged.
('18', 195, 1, 19, 401780) Lala Radha Krishna was charged under sub clause (a) of sub section I of Rule 25. In order to establish the guilt of the accused, it is necessary to prove (a) that the statement is false;
('18', 196, 0, 1, 401967) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 197
('18', 196, 1, 2, 402012) (b) that the accused has no reasonable ground to believe it to be true; (c) that it is published with intent to cause, or it is likely to cause fear or alarm to the public.
('18', 196, 2, 3, 402185) It has been made abundantly clear in the foregoing that the statements have not been proved to be false, and that even if they were, it has not been proved that the accused had no reasonable ground for believing them to be proved.
('18', 196, 2, 4, 402416) On the contrary, the defence statement gives clearly the grounds of his belief and lastly the prosecution never proved that there was any intent to cause fear or alarm, or that there was likely to be any fear or alarm to the public, we are satisfied that the publishing and circulating of these false statements did actually cause fear and alarm to the public. Lala Radha Krishna observes on this point, The prosecution witnesses were unable to cite any specific instances of such alarm having been caused by the articles in question. The judgment takes no note of the antecedents of Lala Radha Krishna, of the fact that although there was not the slightest reason for expressing regret for anything he had written, he expressed it in his statement to the court for any unconscious exaggerations and of the very material fact that the error, if error it was, regarding the number of the dead was corrected by him as soon as the official communique was published and that he published too the Civil and Military Gazette version.
('18', 196, 2, 5, 403444) This seems to be a question of manifest injustice.
('18', 196, 2, 6, 403495) We understand that Lala Radha Krishnas petition for release is still engaging the attention of His Honour the Lieutenant Governor of the Punjab.
('18', 196, 2, 7, 403640) We hope that the public and the Press throughout India will support the prayer for justice and that it will not go in vain.
