('18', 198, 1, 2, 405259) 164. SPEECH ON SWADESHI AT FERGUSSON COLLEGE, POONA 1
('18', 198, 2, 3, 405313) July 12, 1919
('18', 198, 3, 4, 405327) In addressing the students in Hindi, Mr. Gandhi said the question of swadeshi included the question of language, and he would prefer to address them in their lingua franca, Hindi, rather than in English; but it was about swadeshi in respect to clothing that he was there to speak to them.
('18', 198, 4, 5, 405616) Dr. Harold Mann had surveyed the conditions in a Deccan village near Poona and he had observed that a large part of the population was without work for a large part of the year and had to depend on daily labour, e.g., carrying milk to Poona, working in the Ammunition Factory, etc., and that for the most part it was the males only who found work in this direction.
('18', 198, 4, 6, 405982) How, asked Mr. Gandhi, did the women employ themselves?
('18', 198, 4, 7, 406038) They had no work, or they employed themselves with unprofitable work.
('18', 198, 4, 8, 406108) That was the condition all over India.
('18', 198, 4, 9, 406147) Sir Dinsha Wachha had calculated that during the period of the war, they had much less cloth for their consumption than they had in the five years preceding the war.
('18', 198, 4, 10, 406313) Should they wait for more mills to supply the shortage of cloth from which they were suffering ?
('18', 198, 4, 11, 406410) asked Mr. Gandhi.
('18', 198, 4, 12, 406428) It would take years before the mills could come effectively to their rescue.
('18', 198, 4, 13, 406505) Swadeshi alone could effectively and without loss of time supplement their supply of cloth.
('18', 198, 4, 14, 406597) Sir William Hunter 2 had calculated that one tenth of their population scarcely got one meal per day.
('18', 198, 4, 15, 406699) The speakers own experience of the peasant in Champaran proved the truth of the calculation.
('18', 198, 4, 16, 406792) He could say that most of the peasants in Champaran had to rest satisfied with scanty meals.
('18', 198, 4, 17, 406885) He said Mrs. Gandhi herself went about in the villages of the Champaran District and she revealed to him the painful fact that many of the women had not sufficient clothing to cover themselves with, and some of them had not had their bath for days together for want of clothing to change for the dirty scanty clothing on their bodies, which they could ill afford to wash!
('18', 198, 4, 18, 407257) Thousands of peasants burnt away their precious manure in winter to warm themselves with, only because they had nothing wherewith to buy warm clothing.
('18', 198, 4, 19, 407409) And what was at the root of all this misery?
('18', 198, 4, 20, 407454) One hundred and fifty years ago, they produced their own cotton, spun it and wove out of it their own cloth; today they had to depend on foreign market.
('18', 198, 4, 21, 407607) It would be tormenting to him to relate, and to them to hear, the painful process of the extinction of their handicrafts ill the past.
('18', 198, 4, 22, 407742) It was for
('18', 198, 5, 23, 407753) 1 Under the auspices of the Philosophical Club, R. P. Paranjapye, the Principal of the College presiding 2 1840 l900; historian, an authority on Indian affairs; author of Indian Empire; served in India for 25 years, and was sympathetic to Indian aspirations; member of the British Committee of the Indian National Congress in London
('18', 199, 0, 1, 408086) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 200
('18', 199, 1, 2, 408128) themthe students, who were the hope of the futureto study the conditions of the agriculturists, to think of how their lot could be improved and to set to them the example of their own lives.
('18', 199, 1, 3, 408319) They themselves could learn spinning and weaving in a short time, and go from village to village preaching to the peasants the need of swadeshi and explaining to them how they could fight starvation and famine by filling their time with spinning yarn and weaving cloth out of it.
('18', 199, 1, 4, 408599) It was a serious state of affairs for any country if its peasant population had to remain without work for six months in the year.
('18', 199, 1, 5, 408730) He explained to them the three vows that he had placed before the public, but told them that the purest swadeshi consisted in using cloth woven on handlooms out of hand spun yarn.
('18', 199, 1, 6, 408910) The question of machine made cloth apart, Mr. Gandhi said it was undoubted that the clothing he wore was more artistic than what the students wore.
('18', 199, 1, 7, 409058) Art, he explained, lay in producing something which could not be exactly imitated, which had on it the stamp of some ideal, which in short, had the soul of the artist in it.
('18', 199, 1, 8, 409232) Machine made cloth had no soul in it.
('18', 199, 1, 9, 409270) As to the greater durability of hand woven cloth, there was scarcely any doubt.
('18', 199, 1, 10, 409350) But if the audience did not share his views on art, they had the Indian mill made cloth to fall back upon while the peasants could manufacture their own yarn and cloth in their cottages.
('18', 199, 2, 11, 409537) From the point of view, then, of rejuvenation of their lost art, of service of the Motherland, and of protection of their peasant population, swadeshi was a thing without which none of them could do.
('18', 199, 2, 12, 409737) For some time to come, they would have to rest satisfied with cloth of a coarse texture, but it was little sacrifice on their part, considering the mighty issues involved.
('18', 199, 3, 13, 409909) The speaker emphasized that he did not hold out the handloom as a competitor of the power loom.
('18', 199, 3, 14, 410005) The objective was not that the former should supplant the latter.
('18', 199, 3, 15, 410071) It was rather that the former should supplement the latter.
('18', 199, 3, 16, 410131) What he meant to say, however, was that any amount of progress in our mill industry could not improve the condition of our agriculturists.
('18', 199, 3, 17, 410270) Only a revival of cottage industries, viz., hand spinning and hand weaving, could work their economic salvation.
('18', 199, 3, 18, 410383) He hoped they would discuss the whole question with their professors and that both they and the professors would see their way to support swadeshi in a religious spirit.
('18', 199, 4, 19, 410553) Principal Paranjapye, in rising to thank Mr. Gandhi, said that as Mr. Gandhi spoke in Hindi, he could not follow him fully.
('18', 199, 4, 20, 410677) He could only get the gist of his remarks.
('18', 199, 4, 21, 410720) But he could guess the rest.
('18', 199, 4, 22, 410749) He then mentioned some of the grounds on which, he said, he was opposed to the idea of what he thought to be a crusade of an unpractical nature.
('18', 199, 4, 23, 410894) One hundred years ago, he said, they might have produced their own cloth; similarly, they travelled large distances by means of primitive bullock carts and their caravans brought in and took out commodities to and from their country in that primitive fashion.
('18', 199, 4, 24, 411154) The railways had then come and ruined the profession of those carters.
('18', 199, 4, 25, 411225) Did Mr. Gandhi wish that the railways should be
('18', 200, 0, 1, 411273) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 201
('18', 200, 1, 2, 411318) destroyed and the primitive means of trade and communications be restored instead?
('18', 200, 1, 3, 411401) It was vain, he maintained, to strive to turn back the tide of time, and to seek solution of an economic question in a sentimental way.
('18', 200, 1, 4, 411537) Similarly, it would be absurd to say that the printing presses which had supplanted the copyists of the olden time should go, and allow the copyists to minister again to our needs of writing.
('18', 200, 1, 5, 411729) .He had not made up his mind in the matter, but Mr. Gandhi had left him unconvinced.
('18', 200, 2, 6, 411814) Young India, 16 7 1919
('18', 200, 3, 7, 411837) 165. SPEECH ON SWADESHI AT CITIZENS MEETING, POONA
('18', 200, 4, 8, 411888) July 12, 1919
('18', 200, 5, 9, 411902) Mr. Gandhi, who was introduced to the audience by Mr. Khadilkar, said speaking in Hindi, that at the outset he wanted to discuss swadeshi not from a political standpoint, but from an economic and religious one.
('18', 200, 5, 10, 412113) Swadeshi, as he understood it, was broad based on certain religious and economic principles according to which all men from the Viceroy to his peons downwards might accept it.
('18', 200, 5, 11, 412289) It recognized no distinction as of the Moderates or the Extremists among its votaries, and it was such that it was possible to bring men of all races, castes and creeds under its influence.
('18', 200, 5, 12, 412479) There was thus no place in it for boycott, which was the predominant element in, or which practically meant, the swadeshi of a few years ago.
('18', 200, 5, 13, 412621) He therefore wished to request them with all the force that he could command to keep the thought of boycott away from their minds while thinking of swadeshi.
('18', 200, 6, 14, 412779) He recalled a day when just after his return from South Africa he visited Poona and there said at a meetingthat what Poona thought one day, the rest of India would think on the next.
('18', 200, 6, 15, 412962) He said he was still of the same opinion.
('18', 200, 6, 16, 413004) He believed that no city in India could compare with Poona in its learning and its self sacrifice, and he had no doubt that if Poona saw eye to eye with him in the matter of swadeshi, it would relieve him from half of the task.
('18', 200, 6, 17, 413232) What, in his opinion, Poona lacked was faith and self confidence.
('18', 200, 6, 18, 413298) Poona still believed, be thought, that there was no salvation without their being Westernized.
('18', 200, 6, 19, 413393) It was only when Poona disabused itself of this belief that it could truly help in raising the country from its despondency.
('18', 200, 7, 20, 413518) Proceeding to explain swadeshi, Mr. Gandhi drew a homely analogy.
('18', 200, 7, 21, 413584) Supposing, he said, a man had ample provisions and a wife to prepare out of them dainty dishes for him, and if in spite of it he sent for his dishes from an outside hotel how should they describe him?
('18', 200, 7, 22, 413785) They should, he said, regard him as one out of his
('18', 200, 8, 23, 413836) 1 Here followed a few remarks by Gandhiji as editor, Young India, while publi shing the report of his speech; vide Note on Principal Paranjapyes Observations, 16 7 1919.
('18', 201, 0, 1, 414006) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 202
('18', 201, 1, 2, 414048) senses.
('18', 201, 1, 3, 414056) Similarly, a nation, which acted in the way this man did, could not but be characterized as one out of its senses, and India was an instance in point.
('18', 201, 1, 4, 414207) A hundred and fifty years ago, she produced her own cloth and produced fabrics of cotton and silk woven into a texture the fineness of which no cloth produced anywhere else in the world could compete with.
('18', 201, 1, 5, 414413) And today she depended on foreign countries for a large part of her cloth.
('18', 201, 1, 6, 414488) Last year, for instance, India paid 60 crores of rupees for the cloth imported from abroad.
('18', 201, 1, 7, 414580) This dependence was at once an act of folly and of sin.
('18', 201, 1, 8, 414636) If having given up their old profession of producing their own cloth, they had busied themselves with something more profitable, Mr. Gandhi said, he would have no quarrel.
('18', 201, 1, 9, 414808) But the fact was that they had not done so.
('18', 201, 1, 10, 414852) The peasant population, i.e., two hundred and forty million of our whole population, spent six months in the year idly.
('18', 201, 1, 11, 414972) He had lived among the agriculturists of Kaira and Champaran and he knew that they remained without work for half the part of the year.
('18', 201, 1, 12, 415108) The condition of these people could not be improved unless they became self supporting which for them meant the earning of their living and manufacture of their cloth by hand spinning and hand weaving.
('18', 201, 1, 13, 415310) And here he instanced the case of Vijapur, a village near Ahmedabad, where owing to the indefatigable efforts of Mrs. Gangabai Mazumdar, a widow of fine patriotism and selflessness, four hundred Mussulman women who had before nothing to do and who on account of the purdah could not go out to work, added to their income by spinning cotton in their own homes.
('18', 201, 1, 14, 415670) It was Gangabai who brought employment to those unemployed and her example deserved to be copied everywhere.
('18', 201, 1, 15, 415779) And, argued Mr. Gandhi, they should bethink themselves of England and Germany, how they tackled their food problem during the war, how they turned fallow land into arable and grew potatoes on it in six months time.
('18', 201, 1, 16, 415994) Spinning and weaving their own cloth was surely a less difficult task than growing potatoes.
('18', 201, 1, 17, 416087) That, however, was the economic aspect of the question.
('18', 201, 1, 18, 416143) He had still to put before them the question from a religious standpoint.
('18', 201, 1, 19, 416217) He had defined swadeshi as restricting oneself to the use and service of ones immediate surroundings to the exclusion of the more remote.
('18', 201, 1, 20, 416355) He thought it was scarcely humane for people to prefer remote surroundings to those nearest themselves, and humanity, said the great Tulsidas, was the basis of all religion.
('18', 201, 1, 21, 416529) He felt that the first and elementary duty of man was to use and serve his neighbours and that if he went farther for his needs and services, it argued on his part more regard for self than for others.
('18', 201, 1, 22, 416731) Mr Gandhi said: We have wasted a considerable part of our precious spare time, and it behoves us now to bestir ourselves to utilize it and to dedicate our labour to the land of our birth.
('18', 201, 2, 23, 416919) Mr. Gandhi then explained to them three swadeshi vows.
('18', 201, 2, 24, 416974) 1 He wished they could share his view that there was more art in hand spun and hand woven cloth than cloth manufactured in factories.
('18', 201, 2, 25, 417108) Even supposing that there could be one day in India mills enough to supply all the cloth they needed, there was nothing wherewith the women of the country could employ their sparetime better, or wherewith those who
('18', 201, 3, 26, 417323) 1 Vide Swadeshi Sabha Rules before 1 7 1919.
('18', 202, 0, 1, 417368) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 203
('18', 202, 1, 2, 417413) had no means of honourable living could get a means more honourable than spinning and weaving.
('18', 202, 1, 3, 417508) The chief part of swadeshi activity was production of.
('18', 202, 1, 4, 417563) as much cloth as possible, and the need of it could not be overestimated.
('18', 202, 1, 5, 417637) Perseverance, patriotism and self sacrifice were the essentials of success in their programme and Mr. Gandhi hoped that Poona would respond enthusiastically to his call and justify its proud traditions.

('18', 204, 1, 2, 420830) 168. SPEECH AT BOMBAY ON INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA 1
('18', 204, 2, 3, 420881) July 13, 1919 The problem which has brought us together today is a very important one and calls for an urgent solution.
('18', 204, 2, 4, 421001) If we do not come forward to share the suffering of Indians, wherever they may be, it can be said that we are not fit to be an independent nation.
('18', 204, 2, 5, 421148) The hardships of Indians in South Africa can be imagined only by those who have had to suffer them.
('18', 204, 2, 6, 421248) It was many years ago that Indians started going to South Africa.
('18', 204, 2, 7, 421314) In those days the way lay through Morocco.
('18', 204, 2, 8, 421357) Forty years ago, Indians in good numbers started going there under contract as indentured labourers.
('18', 204, 2, 9, 421458) On the expiry of their contract, they lived on as free citizens.
('18', 204, 2, 10, 421523) Many Indians, especially our Memon brethren, went there as traders to supply the needs of these indentured Indians.
('18', 204, 2, 11, 421639) When gold was discovered in the Transvaal, a large number of Englishmen from surrounding areas descended on it and succeeded, too, in making their fortunes.
('18', 204, 2, 12, 421796) Indians also earned, some more, some less.
('18', 204, 2, 13, 421839) Following this, a few people suggested to President Kruger that Indians should be expelled from the Transvaal.
('18', 204, 2, 14, 421950) He could not do this at the time, but later in 1885 a law was passed as a result of which our Indian brethren there were put to much hardship.
('18', 204, 2, 15, 422093) This law contained two important provisions, one which prohibited Indian settlers in the Transvaal from holding immovable property and another which required an Indian to pay 3 for taking out a trading licence.
('18', 204, 2, 16, 422304) One more law was passed later which is known as the Gold Act.
('18', 204, 2, 17, 422366) This also interfered with the enjoyment of their rights by Indians.
('18', 204, 2, 18, 422434) An agreement was arrived at in 1914, which however did not remove all the hardships of Indians.
('18', 204, 2, 19, 422530) The anti Indian laws which the Government had recently passed were repealed.
('18', 204, 2, 20, 422607) One of them was the Registration Act against which the satyagraha campaign had been directed.
('18', 204, 2, 21, 422701) This agreement between Mr. Smuts and me contained a provision to the effect that the existing rights of Indians would not be disturbed.
('18', 204, 2, 22, 422837) This provision is being interpreted by Indians in one sense and by the Transvaal authorities in another.
('18', 204, 2, 23, 422942) In 1913, when I had got
('18', 204, 3, 24, 422966) 1 Under the auspices of the Home Rule League with Faiz B, Tyabji in the chair
('18', 205, 0, 1, 423044) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 206
('18', 205, 1, 2, 423086) Indians ready to march into the Transvaal, Lord Hardinge, the then Viceroy of India, sent Mr. Benjamin Robertson to South Africa.
('18', 205, 1, 3, 423216) At that time, even here everyone felt that this would bring the desired results.
('18', 205, 1, 4, 423297) Then followed correspondence between Mr. Smuts and me which brought about some understanding.
('18', 205, 1, 5, 423391) Moreover, some Englishmen had also suggested that Indians should be refused licences in the Gold Area.
('18', 205, 1, 6, 423494) No one has succeeded so far in securing the repeal of the Act of 1885, which bears on the.
('18', 205, 1, 7, 423585) Indians right of ownership of immovable property.
('18', 205, 1, 8, 423635) But, in my capacity as a lawyer, I used to advise people that we were entitled to the use of lands mortgaged to us.
('18', 205, 1, 9, 423751) In this way, many of our Indian brethren came to hold lands.
('18', 205, 1, 10, 423812) Besides, two or more people forming a company could acquire land.
('18', 205, 1, 11, 423878) Because of this freedom, our Indian brethren have been holding lands there by forming corporations.
('18', 205, 1, 12, 423978) But now they have been depriving us of these rights too.
('18', 205, 1, 13, 424035) I admit of course that there was a provision to the effect that, without prejudice to their rights to the lands and immovable properties already held by them, Indians would not in future be able to acquire lands, even in the name of companies.
('18', 205, 1, 14, 424279) What is happening, however, is altogether unjust.
('18', 205, 1, 15, 424329) A law has been passed as a result of which, after May 31, no Indian will be able to carry on trade.
('18', 205, 1, 16, 424429) In this way, they are being deprived of trade rights which they have been enjoying for many years.
('18', 205, 1, 17, 424528) As Indians, it is our duty to raise a united voice and call the attention of the Government of India to this intolerable situation.
('18', 205, 1, 18, 424660) Our fight is not against the Indian Government; we have only to strengthen its hands.
('18', 205, 1, 19, 424746) It does not stand to lose anything by our doing so.
('18', 205, 1, 20, 424798) If at all the Imperial Government has been helping the South African Government in this matter, our raising a strong protest here will oblige it as well to take our side.
('18', 205, 1, 21, 424969) The South African Government accepted my contention that there should be no racial discrimination in the Immigration Act.
('18', 205, 1, 22, 425091) But today we find that the white population there has come forward to deprive people of their rights.
('18', 205, 1, 23, 425193) Unfortunately, the three able men who worked indefatigably for Indians in South Africa are no more.
('18', 205, 1, 24, 425293) One of them was Mr. Sorabji Shapurji Adajania.
('18', 205, 1, 25, 425340) As fate would have it, he has passed away.
('18', 205, 1, 26, 425383) Another
('18', 206, 0, 1, 425391) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 207
('18', 206, 1, 2, 425436) was Mr. Ahmad Mahomed Cachalia.
('18', 206, 1, 3, 425468) He also has passed away.
('18', 206, 1, 4, 425493) The third was Mr. Polak who has left South Africa and has settled in London.
('18', 206, 1, 5, 425570) There is still one person there, but he has to attend to this matter in addition to his own work.
('18', 206, 1, 6, 425668) In short, I shall merely say that when we find Indians in South Africa being unjustly deprived of their rights, we should help them.
('18', 206, 1, 7, 425801) I hope you will pass these resolutions with acclaim.
('18', 206, 1, 8, 425854) (1) That this public meeting of the Bombay citizens respectfully protests against the Asiatic Land and Trading Amendment Bill reported passed by the Parliament of the Union of South Africa as it contravenes the Smuts Gandhi Agreement of 1914 and it violates the elementary rights of the British Indians lawfully resident in the Transvaal and, therefore, calls upon the Government of India and the Imperial Govern ment to intervene so as to secure the repeal or the veto of the said Bill.
('18', 206, 1, 9, 426342) (2) That this meeting tenders its heartfelt sympathy and assurance of support to their Indian fellow citizens in the Transvaal who are heroically struggling against the unjust and the unwarrantable encroachments made by the said Bill upon their rights as citizens of the Empire.

('18', 209, 1, 2, 430350) 171. LETTER TO D. N. NAGARKATTI
('18', 209, 2, 3, 430382) [July 14, 1919] 1

('18', 212, 4, 6, 435525) 176. LETTER TO A. H. WEST
('18', 212, 5, 7, 435551) LABURNUM ROAD, GAMDEVI, BOMBAY, July 17, 1919
('18', 212, 6, 8, 435597) MY DEAR WEST, I have your undated letter from Durban expressing your keen disappointment at the absence of any news from me.
('18', 212, 6, 9, 435722) I simply cannot understand it.
('18', 212, 6, 10, 435753) I have written to you, Mrs. West and Devi, not many letters it is true, but enough to show you all that you are never away from my thoughts.
('18', 212, 6, 11, 435894) In one of the letters I expressed my difficulties and wished how glad I should be if you were by my side.
('18', 212, 6, 12, 436000) I have not left a single business letter of yours unanswered, even when I was practically on death bed.
('18', 212, 6, 13, 436104) I remember having advised Mr. Rustomjee to debit me with all the payments made to you in terms of your letter to me.
('18', 212, 6, 14, 436221) I remember, too, that in one of your letters you asked me to cable to Mr. Rustomjee about funds.
('18', 212, 6, 15, 436318) I refrained because at that time I felt by computation, and in this I was supported by Mahadev Desai, that Mr. Rustomjee must have received my letter.
('18', 212, 6, 16, 436469) But it is likely that my letters get lost in transit and it is also likely that the posting volunteer might have carelessly lost some of my letters.
('18', 212, 6, 17, 436618) For I have received complaints not only from you but from Polak, Ramdas and others, and I must write to you, what I have written to other friends, that they should bear with me and never think that I am neglectful about writing.
('18', 212, 6, 18, 436847) I wish I had more leisure to write as much as and as often as I would like to but that is not vouchsafed to me at the present moment.
('18', 212, 6, 19, 436981) I am writing to Mr. Rustomjee again regarding the 70. Recently I wrote to Manilal about Indian Opinion.
('18', 212, 6, 20, 437085) He asked me to supply him with funds or to let him revert to advertisements and business printing.
('18', 212, 6, 21, 437184) I still retain the view I held there and the more I see of the jobbery that goes on here, the indiscriminate manner in which
('18', 213, 0, 1, 437309) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 214
('18', 213, 1, 2, 437351) advertisements are taken and the more I think how these advertisements, etc., are nothing but an insidious method of indirect voluntary taxation, how all this debases journalism and how it makes of it largely a business concern, I feel more and more convinced of the rightness of my view.
('18', 213, 1, 3, 437640) Any way it would not be proper to blow hot and cold.
('18', 213, 1, 4, 437693) Either you must make Indian Opinion a business concern and then not expect the public to take philanthropic or patriotic interest in it, or to make it merely an organ representative of Indian aspirations in South Africa and then rely entirely upon public support and goodwill.
('18', 213, 1, 5, 437970) I have dissuaded Manilal from making it a business concern.
('18', 213, 1, 6, 438030) I have not sent him there to do business but to render public service.
('18', 213, 1, 7, 438101) I feel that Indian Opinion has served its purpose if only partially.
('18', 213, 1, 8, 438170) It has brought into being several Indian presses and several Indian newspapers.
('18', 213, 1, 9, 438250) They all in some shape or other somewhat serve the public.
('18', 213, 1, 10, 438309) Manilal lacks the ability, through no fault of his own, for leadership and for original work.
('18', 213, 1, 11, 438403) His effort, therefore, cannot be impressive.
('18', 213, 1, 12, 438448) I have therefore advised him, in consultation with you and Mr. Rustomjee and consistently with the obligations to the subscribers who have already paid, to wind up Indian Opinion, to get up Phoenix, to let you have what you want of the Printing Press, to parcel out the land as you will think best and to use the income also, as you consider advisable, to bring here most part of the books unless they are wanted there for a better purpose and himself to come away with them.
('18', 213, 1, 13, 438924) Ramdas has gone there primarily for business.
('18', 213, 1, 14, 438970) He seems to be well fixed, well cared for and happy in the thought that he is at last earning something without doing violence to his conscience.
('18', 213, 1, 15, 439116) He may stay as long as he likes.
('18', 213, 2, 16, 439149) I do not think I have made one suggestion in my letter [to] Manilal which occurred to me possibly after I wrote to him.
('18', 213, 2, 17, 439269) I make it now.
('18', 213, 2, 18, 439284) If you think that you would like to add to your business, the turning out of Indian Opinion you may do so.
('18', 213, 2, 19, 439391) Perhaps it would not be a bad thing.
('18', 213, 2, 20, 439428) You cannot give the Gujarati portion.
('18', 213, 2, 21, 439466) Give only the English portion, thus becoming a vehicle for transmission of authentic news to India and England about Indian disabilities and Indian doings in South Africa.
('18', 213, 2, 22, 439638) I would like you to consider it purely as a business proposition.
('18', 213, 2, 23, 439704) If you find it workable, then only elaborate my proposal.
('18', 213, 2, 24, 439762) If you find that as a business proposition it is useless, dismiss it altogether from your mind.
('18', 213, 2, 25, 439858) I am moving heaven and earth for getting redress about the

('18', 216, 1, 2, 443584) 179. SPEECH ON GANDHI SMUTS AGREEMENT, BOMBAY
('18', 216, 2, 3, 443630) July 18, 1919
('18', 216, 3, 4, 443644) Under the auspices of the Imperial Indian Citizenship Association, a public meeting was held in the Excelsior Theatre, Bombay, on July 18, 1919, to protest against the Asiatic Land and Trading Amendment Act recently passed by the South African Union Legislature.
('18', 216, 3, 5, 443907) The Hon.
('18', 216, 3, 6, 443916) Sir Dinshaw M. Petit, Bart., presided.
('18', 216, 4, 7, 443955) Mahatma Gandhi, seconding the first resolution moved by Sir N. G. Chandavarkar, said that when the Boer War broke out some years ago, Lord Lansdowne, one of His Majestys ministers, declared that one of the causes which had led to that war was the treatment meted out to Indians residing in the Transvaal by the Government of the country, and Lord Lansdowne added that it never pained him so much as when he remembered the hardships to which the Indians were subjected by the Transvaal Government.
('18', 216, 4, 8, 444452) This was said by Lord Lansdowne in 1899, and he (Mr. Gandhi) said the condition of their brethren in South Africa should certainly be not allowed to be worse than what it was in 1899. It should have been better than what it was before that war, but, on the contrary, the Indians in the Transvaal stood, on account of the new legislation, in a much worse position, as regards the right of acquiring land and trading, than they did before that war; for, before 1899, they enjoyed those rights with the help of the British Agent in that country.
('18', 216, 4, 9, 444995) They could trade freely and have mortgages on land and could even own land, but now this legislation proposed to deprive them of both these rights.
('18', 216, 5, 10, 445143) And to the question of the insistence, on a strictly legal interpretation of the agreement arrived at between General Smuts and him, he (the speaker) recalled the case of the late Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman, who had asked Lord Kitchner in regard to the Peace Treaty with the Boers to interpret the agreement from the point of view of the weaker party.
('18', 216, 5, 11, 445497) Mr. Gandhi urged that the agreement he had referred to should be interpreted in the same generous manner, namely, from the point of view of the Indians, who were the weaker party in this case.
('18', 216, 6, 12, 445690) Continuing, he said, H. E. the Viceroy had been exerting himself to his utmost on behalf of the Indians.
('18', 216, 6, 13, 445795) H. E. had made strong representations to the Imperial Government in this matter, and it was the duty of the whole of India to support H. E. He hoped H. E. would soon make a statement of what steps he had already taken and what he was still taking.
('18', 216, 7, 14, 446043) The Bombay Chronicle, 19 7 1919
('18', 217, 0, 1, 446075) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 218

('18', 218, 1, 2, 447849) 181. LETTER TO THE PRESS ON SUSPENSION OF CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE 1
('18', 218, 2, 3, 447912) LABIJRNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, July 21, 1919
('18', 218, 3, 4, 447950) SIR, The Government of India have given me, through His Excellency the Governor of Bombay, grave warning 2 that resumption of Civil Disobedience is likely to be attended with serious consequences to the public security.
('18', 218, 3, 5, 448170) This warning has been enforced by His Excellency the Governor himself at interviews to which I was summoned.
('18', 218, 3, 6, 448279) In response to this warning and to the urgent desire publicly expressed by Dewan Bahadur Govinda Raghava Iyer, Sir Narayan Chandavarkar and several editors, I have, after deep consideration, decided not to resume Civil Resistance for the time being.
('18', 218, 3, 7, 448529) I may add that several prominent friends belonging to what is called the Extremist Party have given me the same advice on the sole ground of their fear of recrudescence of violence on the part of those who might not have understood the doctrine of Civil Resistance.
('18', 218, 3, 8, 448795) When, in common with most other satyagrahis, I came to the con clusion that the time was ripe for the resumption of the Civil Resis 
('18', 218, 4, 9, 448928) 1 This letter was published also in New India and The Bombay Chronicle both dated 22 7 1919. 2 This was as follows: Bombay, 20th July 1919 Dear Mr. Gandhi, I am to inform you that the Government of India have desired His Excellency the Governor of Bombay to convey to you a grave warning of the consequences which must inevitably be anticipated from the resumption of any action or propaganda involving disobedience of the law and of the heavy moral responsibility that must lie on those who take or advise this course.
('18', 218, 4, 10, 449448) In making this communication to you, I am to say that His Excellency would add a further warning that any assumption that such action can be undertaken without most serious consequences to the public security, is entirely unwarranted by the situation in his presidency.
('18', 218, 4, 11, 449718) for Political Secretary to Government Source Material for A History of the Freedom Movement in India.

('18', 219, 1, 2, 449862) tance part of satyagraha, I sent a respectful letter 1 to His Excellency the Viceroy, advising him of my intention to do so and urging that Rowlatt legislation should be withdrawn, that an early declaration be made as to the appointment of a strong and impartial committee to investigate the Punjab disturbances with power to revise the sentences passed, and that Babu Kalinath Roy who was, as could be proved from the record of the case, unjustly convicted, should be released.
('18', 219, 1, 3, 450341) The Government of India deserve thanks for the decision 2 in Mr. Roys case.
('18', 219, 1, 4, 450417) Though it does not do full justice to Mr. Roy, the very material reduction in the sentence is a substantial measure of justice.
('18', 219, 1, 5, 450545) I have been assured that the Committee of Inquiry, such as I have urged, is in the process of being appointed.
('18', 219, 1, 6, 450656) With these indications of goodwill, it would be unwise on my part not to listen to the warning given by the Government.
('18', 219, 1, 7, 450776) Indeed, my acceptance of the Govern ments advice is a further demonstration of the true nature of Civil Resistance.
('18', 219, 1, 8, 450892) A civil resister never seeks to embarrass Government.
('18', 219, 1, 9, 450946) He often co operates and does not hesitate civilly to resist where resis tance becomes a duty.
('18', 219, 1, 10, 451041) He attains the goal by creating goodwill believing as he does that unfailing exercise of goodwill even in the face of unjust acts of a Government can only result in goodwill being ultimately returned by the Government.
('18', 219, 1, 11, 451260) Further suspension of Civil Resistance is, therefore, nothing but a practical application of satyagraha.
('18', 219, 1, 12, 451365) Yet it is no small matter for me to suspend Civil Resistance even for a day while Rowlatt legislation continues to disfigure our Statute book.
('18', 219, 1, 13, 451508) The Lahore and Amritsar judgments make suspension still more difficult.
('18', 219, 1, 14, 451580) Those judgments, read by me with an unbiassed mind, have left an indelible impression that most of the Punjab leaders have been convicted without sufficient proof and that the punishments inflicted on them are inhuman and outrageous.
('18', 219, 1, 15, 451814) The judgments go to show that they have been convicted for no other reason than that they were connected with stubborn agitation against the Rowlatt legislation.
('18', 219, 1, 16, 451976) I would, if I had my way, have therefore preferred to court imprison ment to retaining the restricted liberty vouchsafed to me by the Government of India.
('18', 219, 1, 17, 452131) But a satyagrahi has to swallow many a bitter
('18', 219, 2, 18, 452177) 1 Vide Letter to S. R. Hignell, 18 6 1919 2 The Governor General in Council reduced on July 6 Kalinath Roys term of imprisonment from 2 years to 3 months.
('18', 220, 0, 1, 452332) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 221
('18', 220, 1, 2, 452377) pill and the present suspension is one such.
('18', 220, 1, 3, 452422) I feel that I shall better serve the country and the Government and those Punjabi leaders who, in my opinion, have been so unjustly convicted and so cruelly sentenced, by suspension of Civil Resistance for the time being.
('18', 220, 1, 4, 452644) But this suspension, while it lightens my responsibility by reason of the feared outbreak of violence, makes it incumbent upon the Govern ment and the eminent public men who have advised suspen sion to see that the Rowlatt legislation is removed without delay.
('18', 220, 1, 5, 452905) I have been accused of throwing lighted matches.
('18', 220, 1, 6, 452954) If my oc casional Civil Resistance be a lighted match, Rowlatt legislation and persistence in retaining it on the Statute book are a thousand matches scattered throughout India, and the only way to avoid Civil Resistance altogether is to withdraw that legislation.
('18', 220, 1, 7, 453219) Nothing that the Government have published in justification of that legislation has moved the Indian public from the attitude of opposition to it.
('18', 220, 1, 8, 453366) I have thus suspended Civil Resistance to hasten the end of that legislation.
('18', 220, 1, 9, 453444) But satyagrahis will pay for its removal by their lives if it cannot be removed by lesser means.
('18', 220, 1, 10, 453541) The period of suspension is for satyagrahis an opportunity for further discipline in an enlightened and willing obedience to the laws of the State.
('18', 220, 1, 11, 453689) The right of Civil Resistance is derived from the duty of obedience voluntarily performed.
('18', 220, 1, 12, 453780) And satyagraha consists not merely, or even chiefly, in civilly resisting laws, but mainly in promoting national welfare by strict adherence to Truth.
('18', 220, 1, 13, 453931) I would respectfully advise fellowsatyagrahis and seek the co operation of all great and small in the propagation of pure swadeshi and promotion of Hindu Muslim unity.
('18', 220, 1, 14, 454099) Swadeshi is, I hold, a necessity of national existence.
('18', 220, 1, 15, 454155) No Englishman or Indian can view with equanimity the huge enforced waste of the labour of twenty crore peasants during half the year.
('18', 220, 1, 16, 454289) That labour can be quickly and immediately utilized only by restoring to the women their spinning wheels and to the men their handlooms.
('18', 220, 1, 17, 454426) This means the elimination of unnatural Lancashire interest and the Japanese menace.
('18', 220, 1, 18, 454511) The elimination of the unnatural Lancashire interest purifies the British connection and makes the position of equality possible.
('18', 220, 1, 19, 454641) The elimination of the Japanese menace will avert a national and Imperial disaster.
('18', 220, 1, 20, 454725) Extension of Japans hold upon India through her commerce can end only in Indias degradation or a bloody war.
('18', 220, 1, 21, 454834) The Hindu Muslim unity is equally a national and Imperial necessity.
('18', 220, 1, 22, 454903) A voluntary league between Hindus, Mahomedans and
('18', 221, 0, 1, 454953) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 222
('18', 221, 1, 2, 454995) Englishmen is a league in my conception infinitely superior to and purer than the League of Nations just formed.
('18', 221, 1, 3, 455108) Permanent union between the Hindus and Mahomedans is the preliminary to such Triple Union.
('18', 221, 1, 4, 455199) That unity can be materially advanced by the Hindus whole heartedly associating themselves with the Mahomedans in their very just aspirations regarding the Caliphate, holy Mecca and other holy places of Islam.
('18', 221, 1, 5, 455409) The swadeshi propaganda and work for Hindu Muslim unity require powers of organization, honesty of purpose, integrity in trade, and immense self sacrifice and self restraint.
('18', 221, 1, 6, 455584) It is, therefore, easy enough to perceive that swadeshi propaganda on the purest lines and promotion of Hindu Muslim unity cannot but have an indirect, though none the less effective, bearing on the movement for securing withdrawal of the Rowlatt legislation for which the Government can claim no justificationlittle as they can claim even nowwhen we give an unexampled demonstration of the qualities named above.
('18', 221, 2, 7, 455998) M. K. GANDHI

('18', 224, 4, 11, 461292) 185. THE LAHORE JUDGMENT
('18', 224, 5, 12, 461317) Whoever wages war against the Queen, or attempts to wage war, or abets the waging of such war, shall be punished with death or transportation for life, and shall forfeit all his property.
('18', 224, 6, 13, 461505)  Section 121, Indian Penal Code.
('18', 224, 6, 14, 461538) Lala Harkishan Lal, Bar at Law, Chaudhari Rambhaj Dutt, Vakil, and Mr. Duni Chand, Bar at Law and Messrs Allah Din and Mota Singh have been convicted by one of the Special Tribunals under Section 121 and 121A of the Indian Penal Code and have been sentenced to transportation for life and forfeiture.
('18', 224, 6, 15, 461839) The reader may dismiss from his mind Section 121A for the time being.
('18', 224, 6, 16, 461909) Having convicted the accused under Section 121, the Tribunal had no option but to pronounce the sentence of transportation for life and forfeiture.
('18', 224, 6, 17, 462057) That, it will be seen, is the lowest penalty the court could inflict, the highest being the penalty of death by hanging.
('18', 224, 6, 18, 462178) The Judges felt the severity to be so great in the last two cases that they were constrained to remark,
('18', 224, 7, 19, 462282) Allah Din and Mota Singh are minor offenders, and had it been in our power, we should in their cases have awarded much lighter sentences.
('18', 224, 7, 20, 462420) The learned judges had it in their power not to convict any of the accused at all or to convict them on other charges.
('18', 224, 7, 21, 462539) But they have said, We do not consider it necessary to record findings on other charges. Though the judgment covers twenty seven sides of the foolscap size, it is being presented to the readers of Young India, and I would urge every reader to go through it word by word.
('18', 224, 7, 22, 462810) For the Judges have made it the cause celebre of all the cases and shown to the world what
('18', 225, 0, 1, 462901) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 226
('18', 225, 1, 2, 462943) the Punjab, and incidentally the whole of India, is in their estimation.
('18', 225, 1, 3, 463016) This judgment, read together with the Amritsar one, forms the saddest commentary on British justice, when the judges are ruled by passion and prejudice and not by a sense of justice.
('18', 225, 1, 4, 463199) To me, the judgments are a proof of the contention I have ventured to urge that we need not be enamoured of British justice and that it, in its essence, is no better than any other justice.
('18', 225, 1, 5, 463389) We deceive ourselves into a false belief when we think that British Courts are the palladia of liberty.
('18', 225, 1, 6, 463493) Justice in British Courts is an expensive luxury.
('18', 225, 1, 7, 463543) It is often the longest purse that wins.
('18', 225, 1, 8, 463584) It is the crucial moments which provide the surest test.
('18', 225, 1, 9, 463641) The judges business is to rise superior to their surroundings.
('18', 225, 1, 10, 463704) The Punjab Tribunal, in my opinion, has signally failed to do so.
('18', 225, 1, 11, 463770) Mr. Winston Churchill at the time of the education crusade permitted himself to admit that even the judges were not free from political bias.
('18', 225, 1, 12, 463912) It is possible, though highly improbable, in this case that the Privy Council will or can set the matter right but if it does, what then?
('18', 225, 1, 13, 464050) At what cost will it have been done?
('18', 225, 1, 14, 464087) How many tens of thousands feeling, and having cause to feel, aggrieved by decisions of lower courts, can afford to go to appellate courts and finally to the Privy Council?
('18', 225, 1, 15, 464260) It is much to be wished that people would avoid litigation.
('18', 225, 1, 16, 464320) Agree with thine adversary quickly is the soundest legal maxim ever uttered.
('18', 225, 1, 17, 464397) The author knew what he was saying.
('18', 225, 1, 18, 464433) But it will be asked, what when we are dragged, as we often are, to the courts?
('18', 225, 1, 19, 464513) I would say: Do not defend. If you are in the wrong, you will deserve the sentence, whatever it may be.
('18', 225, 1, 20, 464617) If you are wrongly brought to the court and yet penalized, let your innocence soothe you in your unmerited suffering.
('18', 225, 1, 21, 464735) Undefended, you will in every case suffer the least and, what is more, you will have the satisfaction of sharing the fate of the majority of your fellow beings who cannot get themselves defended.
('18', 225, 1, 22, 464931) But I have digressed.
('18', 225, 1, 23, 464953) I do not wish to inflict on the reader my special views on law courts, though I hold them to be thoroughly sound.
('18', 225, 1, 24, 465067) This Lahore judgment shows clearly what our duty is as to the Rowlatt Act and as to the sentences.
('18', 225, 1, 25, 465166) The judgment is designed to condemn the Rowlatt legislation agitation.
('18', 225, 1, 26, 465237) The opening paragraphs of the judgments set forth in some detail the public agitation against the Rowlatt Bills which begin
('18', 226, 0, 1, 465361) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 227
('18', 226, 1, 2, 465406) with a protest meeting held at the Bradlaugh Hall on the 4th of February, 1919.
('18', 226, 1, 3, 465486) They refer to my letter 1 of the 1st March, including the Satyagraha Vow, and bring up the events to the 15th April, including the firing in Delhi, the disturbances at Amritsar, and the meetings at the Badshahi Mosque and say, Such are the main facts and the prosecution sets out to combine and connect these facts with the accused in such a way as to show that there was a conspiracy to secure the repeal of the Rowlatt Act by criminal means.
('18', 226, 1, 4, 465930) The Court indicates the criminal means in the very next sentence.
('18', 226, 2, 5, 465996) The defence has asked us to believe that there was no sort of organization of the hartal and that every individual shopkeeper in Lahore, Muzang and Bhag wanpura decided of his own accord that he must close his shop as a protest.
('18', 226, 2, 6, 466225) It then describes what it calls to be violent posters in order to show that the hartal was organized.
('18', 226, 2, 7, 466327) I can see no violence in any of them, but I can detect in them the agony of an embittered soul.
('18', 226, 2, 8, 466423) The criminality consists in the hartal having been organized and continued, langurkhanas2 having been opened during its continuance and meetings having been held during the time.
('18', 226, 2, 9, 466602) I venture to think that hartal is the inherent right of the people when they are deeply grieved by any action of the authorities.
('18', 226, 2, 10, 466732) From time immemorial, it has been held to be meritorious to organize hartals without using force as a means of protest against acts of the governing authority.
('18', 226, 2, 11, 466892) And when merit becomes a crime, it is a sacred duty to commit that crime, and imprisonment for it, instead of being a disgrace, becomes an honour that every good citizen should cherish.
('18', 226, 2, 12, 467078) And the least that he can do is to continue the agitation against the Rowlatt legislation so intense and formidable that Government must withdraw the Act or withdraw the liberty of the agitators.
('18', 226, 2, 13, 467274) And were I not afraid of an outbreak of violence in the present state of tension, I would certainly advise hartals again.
('18', 226, 2, 14, 467396) The tension was no doubt brought about, not by the advent of satyagraha, but by the folly of the Government in precipitating and almost inviting violence by arresting me whilst I was proceeding to Delhi, and if necessary to Lahore and Amritsar with the deliberate intention of calming the atmosphere and bringing about peace.
('18', 226, 2, 15, 467722) The Government invited violence by the mad act of arresting Drs.
('18', 226, 2, 16, 467787) Kitchlew
('18', 226, 3, 17, 467796) 1 Vide Letter to the Press on Satyagraha Pledged, 26 2 1919. 2 Community kitchens or places of congregation of the poorer people to have their frugal daily meals
('18', 227, 0, 1, 467958) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 228
('18', 227, 1, 2, 468000) and Satyapal, who were leaders of the people, but who whilst they were no doubt carrying on a stubborn agitation against the Rowlatt legislation, were able to curb the temper of the people and were entirely on the side of law and order.
('18', 227, 1, 3, 468237) The tension must some day go.
('18', 227, 1, 4, 468267) And if the Government persist in the folly of retaining the Rowlatt legislation, they must prepare for a repetition of hartals well organized but without any force being used and without a drop of blood being shed by the people.
('18', 227, 1, 5, 468496) When the masses have imbibed the message of satyagraha, we shall repeat from a thousand platforms Chaudhri Rambhaj Dattas formula which has been interpreted into threat by the Tribunal in order to prove the existence of criminal conspiracy.
('18', 227, 1, 6, 468737) The formula is: Remove our sufferings or we close our shops, suspend our business and we ourselves shall starve. There is no doubt that a great and effective demonstration was degraded by cries such as Hai Hai Rowlatt Bill 1, Hai Hai George mar gaya 2, or by an inspector of the C.I.D. having been beaten and driven out; or by disgraceful sheets like the Danda Akhbar or by the destruction of pictures of Their Majesties.
('18', 227, 1, 7, 469159) The accused could not be held responsible for them any more than Mr. Shafi and others who were endeavouring to bring about peace.
('18', 227, 1, 8, 469289) What right had the Government to launch out a prosecution for criminal conspiracy or, what is worse, for waging war against the King in respect of men who are not proved to have brought about any of these excesses, whose whole character and status make them almost proof against any such incitements?
('18', 227, 1, 9, 469590) Whatever may be the technical view of expression waging war, to dub a powerful agitation against an odious law an act of war is descent to the ludi crous.
('18', 227, 1, 10, 469745) One might as well incriminate a Government for the unautho rized crimes of its servants.
('18', 227, 1, 11, 469834) If the acts of Lala Duni Chand, Lala Har kishan Lal and his co accused were acts of wary no organized agita tion is possible in the country.
('18', 227, 1, 12, 469975) And as organized agitation must be the breath of public life when there is stagnation in the body politic, whe ther of a social, economic, or political character, it must be counted as a merit to wage war after the style of the Lahore accused.
('18', 227, 1, 13, 470219) The whole of the judgment is tinged with a political bias.
('18', 227, 1, 14, 470278) This is how the judges dismiss from their consideration the previous record of the accused:
('18', 227, 2, 15, 470370) Before proceeding to consider the case of each accused, it is necessary to
('18', 227, 3, 16, 470445) 1 Damn the Rowlatt Bill 2 Damn George; he is dead.
('18', 228, 0, 1, 470496) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 229
('18', 228, 1, 2, 470541) remark that each of them according to their station in life have been able to produce testimonials from more or less eminent members of the society to their moderation and loyalty.
('18', 228, 1, 3, 470722) These could doubtless have been multiplied as often as they wished.
('18', 228, 1, 4, 470790) Some of them again have been able to show that in recent times they have not merely prayed for the success of the British arms but have advocated War Loans, helped in recruiting and have even given relatives to the Indian Defence Force or clerks for Mesopotamia.
('18', 228, 1, 5, 471053) Perhaps all of these efforts were not very valuable, and it has to be remembered that some of the accused are men who are always in the limelight; but we have no doubt thatevery one of them, however much he may dislike the existing Government, at least preferred it to the prospect of German rule.
('18', 228, 1, 6, 471351) None of these things, however, really affect the matter before us.
('18', 228, 1, 7, 471418) When ones judgment is so warped, as is evident was the judges, from the passages above quoted, it is impossible to expect an impartial decision.
('18', 228, 1, 8, 471563) The issue raised by the case is abundantly clear, though not stated.
('18', 228, 1, 9, 471632) Can we, or can we not, legally carry on a sustained powerful agitation involving processions, hartals, fasting, etc., but eschewing, always and invariably violence in any shape or form?
('18', 228, 1, 10, 471818) The implication in the judgment is that we may not do so.
('18', 228, 1, 11, 471876) If the sentences are allowed by the Government to stand, it is quite clear that they are of the same opinion as the judges.
('18', 228, 1, 12, 472000) I for one would not welcome the release of the accused on any side issue or as an act of clemency.
('18', 228, 1, 13, 472099) There is nothing in the judgment to show that any of the accused either directly or indirectly encouraged violence.
('18', 228, 1, 14, 472215) And where there is absence of intent to do violence, it is absurd to call a peaceful combination a criminal conspiracy even though uncontrollable spirits may find their way into that combination and do mischief.
('18', 228, 1, 15, 472427) The happening of untoward incidents may be used as a warning to leaders.
('18', 228, 1, 16, 472500) They may be used for justifying the declaration of martial law but they ought not to be used for the purpose of making out peaceful, law abiding citizens as criminals and liars.
('18', 228, 1, 17, 472678) The duty of the Indian public is clear: by a quiet, persistent and powerful agitation, but without violence and irritation, to secure repeal of the Rowlatt legislation and the reversal of the sentences.
('18', 228, 2, 18, 472881) M. K. GANDHI Young India, 23 7 1919
('18', 229, 0, 1, 472917) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 230
('18', 229, 1, 2, 472959) 186. CERTIFICATE TO A. VENKATARAMAN
('18', 229, 2, 3, 472995) SABARMATI,

('18', 229, 7, 14, 473800) 187. LETTER TO SIR GEORGE BARNES ON TRANSVAAL ASIATIC LAW
('18', 229, 8, 15, 473858) BOMBAY, July 26, 1919
('18', 229, 9, 16, 473880) DEAR SIR GEORGE BARNES, I thank you for your full letter 1 of the 18th instant regarding the recently enacted Transvaal Asiatic Law.
('18', 229, 9, 17, 474013) In view of the last sentence 2 of your letter, I am publishing it together with my reply 3. I am deeply grateful that H.E. the Viceroy and you have been moving in the matter.
('18', 229, 9, 18, 474188) I am, however, sorry to have
('18', 229, 10, 19, 474217) 1 This letter reviewed at length the position in South Africa and regretted that protests from the Indian Government had been unavailing.
('18', 229, 10, 20, 474355) It also gave assurance that the Government would consider further action to be taken when the full text of the new statute was received.
('18', 229, 10, 21, 474492) 2 Of course, you are welcome to make any use you may think fit of this letter. 3 Published also in The Bombay Chronicle and New India, both of 29 7 1919.
('18', 230, 0, 1, 474646) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 231
('18', 230, 1, 2, 474691) to observe that the information placed at your disposal as to the true nature of the Bill is incomplete, if not misleading, and so is the information regarding the judgment of the Transvaal Supreme Court referred to in your letter.
('18', 230, 1, 3, 474923) Here is the true position regarding the Supreme Court judgment, Sections 130 and 131 of the Transvaal Precious and Base Metals Act, 1908, merely refer to residential rights.
('18', 230, 1, 4, 475097) They have no reference to trade rights which another judgment of the same Supreme Court has held to be inviolable so far as the existing Transvaal laws are concerned.
('18', 230, 1, 5, 475264) You will, therefore, see that the new law deprives the Indian settler in the Transvaal of his existing trading right.
('18', 230, 1, 6, 475382) Sections 130 and 131 of the Law of 1908 attempted to curtail residential rights; the new law superadds the curtailment of trade rights and thus completes the virtual ruin of Indians lawfully resident within the gold area of the Transvaal.
('18', 230, 1, 7, 475621) How can the Union Government with any cogency claim to have scrupulously observed the compact of 1914?
('18', 230, 1, 8, 475724) Let me add that the law of 1908 has always been a bone of contention between the Transvaal Government and the Indian community, and it was, I am thankful to say, because of the strenuous fight that the Imperial Government put up in our behalf that the provisions of Sections 130 and 131 remained practically nugatory.
('18', 230, 1, 9, 476042) You will perhaps now see what is meant by the promise, in General Smuts letter to me, to see that they (the existing laws) are administered in a just manner and with due regard to vested rights.
('18', 230, 1, 10, 476237) The vested rights regarding residence were the rights which were exercised and enjoyed by the Indians even before 1908, viz., the right of holding fixed property under leases throughout the Transvaal.
('18', 230, 1, 11, 476438) Let me recall a bit of old history.
('18', 230, 1, 12, 476474) Law 3 of 1885 itself had become a matter of protracted correspondence between the South African Republic and His Majestys Government through the British Agent at Pretoria.
('18', 230, 1, 13, 476646) The matter was then referred to the arbitration to the then Chief Justice of the Orange Free State.
('18', 230, 1, 14, 476746) He declared all legislation apart from Law 3 of 1885 as amended in 1886 to be contrary to the London Convention.
('18', 230, 1, 15, 476859) All laws, therefore, passed after the award in further restrictions of the liberty of British Indian settlers of the Transvaal were contrary to it and it was, I expect, for that reason, apart from the equity of the case, that Mr. Harcourt declared on 27th June, 1911, from his place in the House of Commons:
('18', 230, 2, 16, 477167) Complaints against that legislation (the Gold Law and Townships Amendment
('18', 231, 0, 1, 477241) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 232
('18', 231, 1, 2, 477283) Act) have been made and are now being investigated by the Government of the Union of South Africa, who have lately stated that there is no intention of interfering with any business or right to carry on business acquired ant exercised by Indians prior to the date of legislation.
('18', 231, 1, 3, 477563) Similarly, in 1912, Mr. De Villiers, the then Attorney General of the Transvaal said: No right or privilege which a Coloured person has at the present time is taken away by the new Act. Indians had a right to rely upon Mr. Harcourts assurance and Mr. De Villiers interpretation of the Act in question, and if the Transvaal judgment has gone against us, it is the duty of the Union Government not merely in virtue of the compact of 1914, but also of the assurance and the interpretation above referred to, now to amend the law of l908 and not to put a further restriction upon Indian liberty as the new law does.
('18', 231, 1, 4, 478175) I know you are overworked.
('18', 231, 1, 5, 478202) My only fear is that as you have to act upon briefs prepared for you, and as a powerful Government like the Union Government can far more easily gain your ear than a handful of British Indians of South Africa, their case may suffer simply from want of information.
('18', 231, 1, 6, 478467) Do you know that the Indians of South Africa raised an Ambulance Corps which served under General Smuts in South Africa?
('18', 231, 1, 7, 478588) Is the new law to be their reward?
('18', 231, 1, 8, 478623) I ought not to have to bring in the War services in order to secure the protection of an elementary right which considerations alike of honour and justice entitle them to.
('18', 231, 1, 9, 478795) I commend to your attention the Report of the Select Committee of the Union House of Assembly.
('18', 231, 1, 10, 478890) I will gladly lend you a copy, if you do not have one yourself.
('18', 231, 1, 11, 478954) Regarding fixed property, I see you have not got full infor mation I know you will share my sorrow that the Union Government, unmindful of their trust and equally unmindful of the written word, accepted an amendment
('18', 231, 2, 12, 479170) prohibiting the holding of mortgages by Asiatics on property, except as security for a bona fide loan for investment and providing that any Asiatic company which acquired fixed property after the 1st instant should dispose of the same within two years or .
('18', 231, 2, 13, 479427) a further period as fixed by a competent Court with a rider that in the event of failure to do so, the property might be sold by order of the court.
('18', 231, 2, 14, 479576) I am quoting from Reuter cable, dated the 23rd May, from Cape Town.
('18', 231, 2, 15, 479644) You will see that this completes legalized confiscation of property rights throughout the Transvaal and virtually the trade rights
('18', 232, 0, 1, 479775) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 233
('18', 232, 1, 2, 479820) within the gold area of Indian settlers.
('18', 232, 1, 3, 479861) There was no evasion of Law 3 of 1885. The Indians did openly what the law permitted them to do, and they should be left free to do so.
('18', 232, 1, 4, 479997) I do not wish to prolong this tale of agony.
('18', 232, 1, 5, 480042) The Government of India are bound to protect the rights of the 5,000 Indian settlers of the Transvaal at any cost.
('18', 232, 1, 6, 480157) Here is my solution.
('18', 232, 1, 7, 480178) Law 3 of 1885 authorizes the Government to appoint wards and streets in which Indians can hold fixed property.
('18', 232, 1, 8, 480289) In virtue of this authority, they can declare streets and wards of gold area township for Asiatic residence and ownership, and they can instruct receivers of revenue to issue trade licences in respect of such streets and wards to lawful Indian applicants.
('18', 232, 1, 9, 480545) This will be pending the Commission promised by the Acting Prime Minister, Mr. Malan.
('18', 232, 1, 10, 480631) The Government of India can see (by sending a strong representative) that the Commission does not prove as abortive as the Select Committee of the House of Assembly.
('18', 232, 1, 11, 480797) The Dominions may have the right to regulate immigration.
('18', 232, 1, 12, 480855) But as part of a professedly civilized Europe, they cannot restrict or take away the trading and property rights of lawfully resident settlers.
('18', 232, 1, 13, 480999) The proposed Commission should result in the abolition of all racial restrictions upon such settlers.
('18', 232, 2, 14, 481101) Young India, 30 7 1919

('18', 234, 9, 18, 484645) 190. CIVIL.
('18', 234, 9, 19, 484657) DISOBEDIENCE IS NOT SEDITIOUS
('18', 234, 10, 20, 484687) [July 27, 1919] 2
('18', 234, 11, 21, 484705) The Mahratta, quoting from the judgment in the Hindwasi case, had suggested that Gandhiji should clear up the point raised by the magistrate in the passage quoted.
('18', 234, 11, 22, 484869) Mr. Gandhi responded to the suggestion by the letter to The Mahratta.
('18', 234, 11, 23, 484939) The passage from the judgment is given below:
('18', 234, 12, 24, 484985) There is another aspect of satyagraha in its political garb which shows as plainly as the events at Delhi the inherentthe law breaking character of the doctrine.
('18', 234, 12, 25, 485147) The substance of the Satyagraha Vow is a matter of common knowledge.
('18', 234, 12, 26, 485216) By the Vow the individual claims the right to disobey civilly any
('18', 234, 13, 27, 485282) 1Vide Letter to N.P.Cowie 2 The letter to The Mahratta was published on this date.
('18', 235, 0, 1, 485365) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 236
('18', 235, 1, 2, 485407) laws which the Satyagraha Sabha decides should be disobeyed.
('18', 235, 1, 3, 485468) Now civil disobedience has never been explained.
('18', 235, 1, 4, 485517) In Bombay, it is well known, civil disobedience tools the form of selling proscribed literature, an offence under section 124 A., I.P.C., or in other words, an active disobedience of a criminal law.
('18', 235, 1, 5, 485716) Furthermore, civil disobedience of any law which safeguards the right of others is plainly subversive of all law and order, and is ipso facto calculated to bring Government, as the guardian of law and order, into hatred and contempt.
('18', 235, 1, 6, 485950) That is to say, this aspect of political satyagraha is in essence and effect seditious.
('18', 235, 2, 7, 486038) And here is Mr. Gandhis reply: After quoting from the magisterial judgment in the Hindwasi case, the dissertation of the magistrate on Civil Disobedience, you have asked me to clear the point raised in the judgment.
('18', 235, 2, 8, 486254) I gladly respond to your wish.
('18', 235, 2, 9, 486285) It is difficult to crowd into a paragraph more misconceptions about a grand doctrine of life, or mis statements of facts, than has been done in the paragraphs you have quoted.
('18', 235, 2, 10, 486461) The paragraph referred to begins:
('18', 235, 3, 11, 486495) There is another aspect of satyagraha in its political garb which shows as plainly as the events at Delhi the inherentthe law breaking character of the doctrine.
('18', 235, 4, 12, 486657) Until the mystery about Delhi is cleared up by an impartial judgment, we shall never know whose fault it was for the events that happened at Delhi.
('18', 235, 4, 13, 486805) Let it, however, be remembered that Civil Disobedience had not commenced on the 30th March last, nor on the 6th April.
('18', 235, 4, 14, 486924) Swami Shraddhanand contends that the law was broken by the authorities and that the handful of satyagrahis were busy, even at the peril of their lives, restraining the fury, alike of the mob and the local authority.
('18', 235, 4, 15, 487140) The judgment proceeds:
('18', 235, 5, 16, 487163) By the vow, the individual claims the right to disobey any law that the Satyagraha Sabha decides should be disobeyed.
('18', 235, 5, 17, 487281) Now in this sentence there is the sin of commission ant omission.
('18', 235, 5, 18, 487347) The Vow gives the votary the right to disobey civilly, not any laws which the Satyagraha Sabha decides upon, but such laws as may be selected by the Special Committee to be appointed by the votaries.
('18', 235, 5, 19, 487547) The distinction is important.
('18', 235, 5, 20, 487577) The learned magistrate has omitted to mention that in committing Civil Disobedience the Civil Resister is pledged to truth and nonviolence to person and property
('18', 236, 0, 1, 487739) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 237
('18', 236, 1, 2, 487784) not an unimportant qualification.
('18', 236, 1, 3, 487818) The next sentence betrays ignorance that is unpardonable in a judge.
('18', 236, 1, 4, 487887) He says, Civil Disobedience has never been explained. If he proposed to convict on the grounds of Civil Disobedience, it was his duty to have understood it thoroughly.
('18', 236, 1, 5, 488055) He had the whole of the Satyagraha Leaflet Series including, Thoreaus Classic on Civil Disobedience, 1 at his disposal.
('18', 236, 2, 6, 488175) WHAT IS CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE?
('18', 236, 3, 7, 488203) I must endeavour here to explain briefly what is meant by Civil Disobedience before I can show the absurdity of the sentences that follow.
('18', 236, 3, 8, 488342) Civil Disobedience is opposed to criminal or immoral disobedience.
('18', 236, 3, 9, 488409) Civil Disobedience therefore can be confined only to those laws which do not carry any moral sanction.
('18', 236, 3, 10, 488512) Laws in themselves may be either criminal or civil.
('18', 236, 3, 11, 488564) But a Civil Resister will not hesitate to commit a civil breach of artificial crime (law ?), e.g., Section 124 A of the Indian Penal Code, under which anything according to the vagaries or predilections of a judge may be termed sedition.
('18', 236, 3, 12, 488802) He will not commit any attack upon the rights of others.
('18', 236, 3, 13, 488859) He will never do an act which is calculated to bring any person or corporation in hatred or contempt but he will not hesitate to disregard or expose, irrespective of consequences to himself, any hateful or contemptible act of such person or corporation; and by so doing, he will protect such person or corporation from all undeserved hatred and contempt.
('18', 236, 3, 14, 489214) The law of sedition could never mean [that] tyranny or high handedness, even though they may be enshrined in a Statute book, should be submitted to, for fear of the tyrant being held in contempt.
('18', 236, 3, 15, 489410) A Civil Resister will therefore not impute motives but examine each act on merits.
('18', 236, 3, 16, 489493) Civil Disobedience is therefore based upon love and fellow feeling whereas criminal disobedience upon hatred and ill will.
('18', 236, 3, 17, 489616) Civil Disobedience therefore is to criminal disobedience what light is to darkness; and when the spirit of Civil Disobedience permeates, as I hope it will very soon permeate, the people of India, crimes or violence will be practically things of the past.
('18', 236, 4, 18, 489871) OBJECTION ANSWERED
('18', 236, 5, 19, 489890) What has been urged by friends and the Government is that whilst Civil Disobedience as a doctrine of life is admirable in itself, unthinking people not being able to distinguish between Civil and
('18', 236, 6, 20, 490086) 1 Vide Appendix Satyagraha Leaflet No.
('18', 236, 6, 21, 490125) 1, March 1919.
('18', 237, 0, 1, 490140) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 238
('18', 237, 1, 2, 490182) Criminal disobedience and being mentally disobedient as to what they do not relish are likely to mistake Civil Disobedience of the enlightened for any disobedience and thus resort to lawlessness.
('18', 237, 1, 3, 490378) This is an argument which has appealed, but it has not disproved the necessity or the grandeur of Civil Disobedience.
('18', 237, 1, 4, 490496) It emphasizes the necessity for caution in one like myself trying to practise Civil Disobedience on a new and extensive plane.
('18', 237, 1, 5, 490623) Your readers now will be able to assess at their true value the following concluding passage from the paragraph in question:
('18', 237, 2, 6, 490748) In Bombay, it is well known that Civil Disobedience took the form of
('18', 237, 3, 7, 490817) selling proscribed literature, an offence under Section 124 A I.P.C., or in other words an active disobedience of a criminal law.
('18', 237, 3, 8, 490947) The sale of proscribed literature was undertaken not for committing an active disobedience of criminal law but for questioning a prohibitory order of the executive authority and, as it has now turned out, the sale did not amount even to Civil Disobedience.
('18', 237, 3, 9, 491204) For, it did not attack any law or order.
('18', 237, 3, 10, 491245) The Civil Resister had misread (?) the prohibitory orders.
('18', 237, 3, 11, 491304) The paragraph then proceeds:
('18', 237, 4, 12, 491333) Furthermore, Civil Disobedience of any law which safeguards the rights of others is plainly subversive of all law and order and is ipso facto calculated to bring the Government as a guardian of law and order into hatred and contempt, that is to say, the aspect of political satyagraha is in essence and effect seditious.
('18', 237, 4, 13, 491654) After the explanation that I have offered of Civil Disobedience, further comment is superfluous.
('18', 237, 4, 14, 491751) And if Mr. Jethmal 1 had been convicted upon a total misconception of the doctrine of Satyagraha, he ought to be set free without delay.
('18', 237, 5, 15, 491888) Yours, etc., M. K. GANDHI Young India, 2 8 1919
('18', 237, 6, 16, 491936) 1 Jethmal Parasram, editor of Hindwasi, a Sindhi periodical

('18', 238, 3, 4, 492107) DEAR MR. HIGNELL, As you are aware, I am supervising and controlling the policy of Young India by the courtesy of its syndicate.
('18', 238, 3, 5, 492236) I have seen a confidential notice dated the 23rd instant served upon Young India as on other newspapers.
('18', 238, 3, 6, 492341) It runs as follows1: I shall see to it that the desire of the Government of India is observed by Young India to the fullest extent.
('18', 238, 3, 7, 492473) But the notice gives rise to disturbing reflections which I would like to lay before His Excellency.
('18', 238, 3, 8, 492574) Why is there this hypersensitiveness regarding news about Turkey?
('18', 238, 3, 9, 492640) Why should the terms of peace with Turkey, if they are honourable, cause the slightest excitement in India?
('18', 238, 3, 10, 492748) I was further disturbed as I came upon the letter addressed to the Prime Minister by influential Mahomedans at present residing in London.
('18', 238, 3, 11, 492887) Among the signatories I notice H. H. the Aga Khan, Chief of Bombay, Ex Justice Ameer Ali, Sir Abbas Ali Baig and others.
('18', 238, 3, 12, 493008) I have no doubt H. E. has seen that very weighty communication on the subject of the threatened dismemberment of Turkey and on the grave situation of anxiety and uneasiness that this report has created among the Mahomedans, which the signatories go on to say will become aggravated if the design attributed to the Peace Conference is carried into effect.
('18', 238, 3, 13, 493363) I have said I was disturbed, because I am daily receiving communications or seeing Mahomedan friends who tell me that they are going to be sold.
('18', 238, 3, 14, 493508) I have reassured them that H. E. is straining every nerve to place the correct view before His Majestys ministers and that there is no occasion for them to distrust the latter.
('18', 238, 3, 15, 493685) They have received my assurances with incredulity.
('18', 238, 3, 16, 493736) I feel that I ought to place the very serious position before H. E. Is it not possible to make some definite reassuring pronouncement?
('18', 238, 3, 17, 493871) If the worst fears of the Mahomedans are realized, there can only be an armed peace in India, not a real peace.
('18', 238, 3, 18, 493983) I am sure that no Reforms, however generously

('18', 239, 13, 20, 495078) 193. ADDRESS TO STUDENTS, SURAT
('18', 239, 14, 21, 495110) July 28, 1919
('18', 239, 15, 22, 495124) In the afternoon he addressed the students of the Sarvajanik College, and Sarvajanik School, laying particular stress on the students duty to be as careful of their time as of money.
('18', 239, 15, 23, 495307) He also exhorted the boys that it was none of their business to criticise the fitness of teachers just as it was not childrens duty to judge their

('18', 240, 1, 2, 495523) parents.
('18', 240, 1, 3, 495532) Their bounden duty was to respect them.
('18', 240, 1, 4, 495572) He explained to the boys why they were receiving education.
('18', 240, 1, 5, 495632) The main object was to build up character.
('18', 240, 1, 6, 495675) Education was not the means of earning a livelihood.

('18', 240, 4, 14, 496336) 194. SPEECH AT INAUGURATION OF SWADESHI STORE, SURAT
('18', 240, 5, 15, 496389) July 28, 1919
('18', 240, 6, 16, 496403) I shall say a few words sitting.
('18', 240, 6, 17, 496436) The inauguration ceremony of this Store has been performed by me.
('18', 240, 6, 18, 496502) I wish it ever to prosper, it being understood that the organizers will always maintain honesty and run the Store for the service of the people.
('18', 240, 6, 19, 496647) Mr. Kalyanji has told me that the Store will charge six and a quarter per cent profit on cloth for those who keep the vow of pure swadeshi and seven and a half per cent on cloth for those who have taken the vow of part swadeshi.
('18', 240, 6, 20, 496876) We need not feel for the other shops which may go out of business because of the opening of the Store.
('18', 240, 6, 21, 496979) These other shops will run if they compete in doing service or, in the alternative, only if the people of Surat lack sincerity, cherish no ideals and are inclined to foreign materials; in this latter case, they will run, no matter what percentage they charge as profit.
('18', 240, 6, 22, 497249) I will always pray to God that, right from a peonI shall go further and say, a sweeperto the Collector, everyone will refrain from buying foreign material and encourage swadeshi products, and you should join me in this prayer.
('18', 240, 6, 23, 497476) He alone prays sincerely who acts as he prays.
('18', 240, 6, 24, 497523) If you join me in the prayer, you will come to act accordingly.
('18', 240, 6, 25, 497587) Place noble ideals before others, cherish
