('18', 241, 1, 3, 497811) As I suggested, let everyone in this district take this vow and keep it.
('18', 241, 1, 4, 497884) It is a big problem how to bring round the sweeper, but in no way difficult to persuade the Collector to follow this ideal.
('18', 241, 1, 5, 498008) I shall now explain to you how the prosperity of the country depends entirely on our doing this.
('18', 241, 1, 6, 498105) I have read the history of some countries.
('18', 241, 1, 7, 498148) We see from it that all countries, in Europe, in America, and elsewhere attained prosperity only when the spirit of swadeshi had developed in them.
('18', 241, 1, 8, 498296) Without such a spirit, a country cannot prosper economically.
('18', 241, 1, 9, 498358) It helps progress from the religious point of view as well.
('18', 241, 1, 10, 498418) I shall speak about the economic aspect on this occasion.
('18', 241, 1, 11, 498476) History tells us that begums and queens used to spin.
('18', 241, 1, 12, 498530) You must have heard the words spinster 1 and wife 2. Spinster means one who spins.
('18', 241, 1, 13, 498613) Wife does not mean a spouse; it means one who weaves.
('18', 241, 1, 14, 498667) Every woman born used to spin while a girl; on becoming a wife, she used to weave and spin.
('18', 241, 1, 15, 498759) We come across these ideas in the shastras.
('18', 241, 1, 16, 498803) The countries which have reached this stage of economic development have prospered.
('18', 241, 1, 17, 498887) Seventy three per cent of Indias population lives on agriculture.
('18', 241, 1, 18, 498953) I have been saying that we should be precise in the language we use; some speak of eighty per cent, but a careful study of figures shows that 73 per cent, i.e., 21 crores of men and women are dependent on agriculture.
('18', 241, 1, 19, 499171) In this profession, people are idle for half the year or four months.
('18', 241, 1, 20, 499241) The zamindars acquire means which yield them income all the year round, but the cultivators do not work for the whole year and so earn less.
('18', 241, 1, 21, 499382) In Europe, wives have given up weaving and spinsters have given up spinning.
('18', 241, 1, 22, 499459) But they have done so because they have other industries.
('18', 241, 1, 23, 499517) I shall not go into the question whether these other industries are good or bad.
('18', 241, 1, 24, 499598) Be that as it may, the rulers in India are now trying to find subsidiary occupations for the cultivators which will put them on their feet If this is not done, in a few years it will so happen that they will stop paying the assessment they do.
('18', 241, 1, 25, 499842) I have been telling the people, politely and firmly, that, if they wish to prosper, they should popularize the use of swadeshi in such fashion that the cultivators will be enabled to spin and weave.
('18', 241, 1, 26, 500041) Everyone knows that all of us desire Indias prosperity.
('18', 241, 1, 27, 500097) Is there anyone who does not?
('18', 241, 1, 28, 500127) If you resolve to keep the vow of swadeshi you will know how to produce such cloth.

('18', 242, 3, 8, 500920) 195. SPEECH ON SWADESHI, SURAT
('18', 242, 4, 9, 500951) July, 28, 1919
('18', 242, 5, 10, 500966) Mr. Gandhi was on a visit to Surat the week before last.
('18', 242, 5, 11, 501023) While there, he opened a Pure Swadeshi Cloth Store and delivered on the evening of July 28, a lengthy address on the Principles of Swadeshi.
('18', 242, 5, 12, 501164) A detailed report of the speech, which was one of the most important till now delivered on the subject, is given below :
('18', 242, 6, 13, 501285) Before beginning the subject, Mr. Gandhi entered into a short, instructive digression.
('18', 242, 6, 14, 501372) A speaker who had preceded him had regretted the apathy of certain gentlemen towards satyagrahis, and observed that they seemed to shun them as though they feared the very name of satyagraha.
('18', 242, 6, 15, 501564) Adverting to these remarks, Mr. Gandhi said there were people and people, there were some who were subject to the feeling of fear, while there were others who were more fortunate and who were free from it.
('18', 242, 6, 16, 501770) But those who were free from the feeling had no right to be angry with those who were subject to the feeling.
('18', 242, 6, 17, 501880) When they felt, said Mr. Gandhi, that others should be fearless like them, and got irritated because they could not come up to their expectations, they needed to exercisewhat in English has felicitously expressed charity.
('18', 242, 6, 18, 502102) The best thing for a man who got angry was to spend his anger on himself and to try to understand that time, place and circumstance went a great way in the making of man.
('18', 242, 7, 19, 502273) SWARAJ IN SWADESHI
('18', 242, 8, 20, 502292) Turning to the subject proper, Mr. Gandhi said it was truly said that in swadeshi consisted our swaraj.
('18', 242, 8, 21, 502396) The country of which the people could not well order their own needs of food and clothing was not at all fitted to enjoy swaraj.
('18', 242, 8, 22, 502525) This was a self evident truth.
('18', 242, 8, 23, 502556) There was not a country on earth which was unable to provide for its food and clothing and was still enjoying swaraj.
('18', 242, 8, 24, 502674) However swaraj might be defined, it was undoubted that only those countries that were self sufficient enjoyed swaraj.
('18', 242, 8, 25, 502792) Even the uncivilized tribes of South Africa were enjoying swaraj.
('18', 242, 8, 26, 502858) These negroes
('18', 243, 0, 1, 502872) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 244
('18', 243, 1, 2, 502914) produced their own food stuffs and their clothing.
('18', 243, 1, 3, 502965) They lived on maize and game.
('18', 243, 1, 4, 502995) They clothed themselves in the hides of animals killed by them.
('18', 243, 1, 5, 503059) When these people began to get civilized, and thus to depend on others for their food and clothing, they lost even the paltry swaraj they were enjoying.
('18', 243, 1, 6, 503212) Every nation that thus became dependent on others for its two principal needs was reduced to such a plight.
('18', 243, 2, 7, 503320) JAPANESE MENACE
('18', 243, 3, 8, 503336) In a letter which he sent to the Press some days ago declaring continuance of suspension of civil resistance, Mr. Gandhi had said that swadeshi would eliminate the unnatural Lancashire interest and would help in purifying the British connection.
('18', 243, 3, 9, 503582) But he believed he had said a greater thing in the same letter, viz., that swadeshi would rid them of the Japanese menace.
('18', 243, 4, 10, 503705) If, said Mr. Gandhi, they did not realize what the Japanese menace meant for them, they did not know the first lesson of swaraj.
('18', 243, 4, 11, 503834) Japan was gradually and steadily extending its hold over them.
('18', 243, 4, 12, 503897) In the course of the last four years, it had increased its exports by several hundred per cent.
('18', 243, 4, 13, 503993) Wherever they turned their eye, they saw Japanese articles, Japanese matches, Japanese saris, Japanese soaps, Japanese umbrellas and so on.
('18', 243, 4, 14, 504133) What was the meaning of this?
('18', 243, 4, 15, 504163) It meant increasing domination of Japan.
('18', 243, 4, 16, 504204) Just as the sowcar 1 exploited and impoverished the poor agriculturist, even so, said the speaker, was Japan, exploiting and impoverishing India.
('18', 243, 4, 17, 504350) Japan was fast becoming Indias sowcar.
('18', 243, 4, 18, 504389) England must either fight or accept Japanese domination.
('18', 243, 4, 19, 504446) What was the object of the opium war 2 with China?
('18', 243, 4, 20, 504497) If China produced her own opium, the opium war would not have been waged.
('18', 243, 4, 21, 504571) Students of history knew that it was a war of blind self interest on the part of England.
('18', 243, 4, 22, 504661) So long as Englands relation with the Colonies was based on Englands self interest, it was not a pure relation.
('18', 243, 4, 23, 504773) But the Colonies took a very timely hint.
('18', 243, 4, 24, 504815) They taught themselves and they taught England also a lesson.
('18', 243, 5, 25, 504877) FISCAL AUTONOMY
('18', 243, 6, 26, 504893) They were talking of fiscal autonomy, said Mr. Gandhi.
('18', 243, 6, 27, 504948) He for one did not believe that fiscal autonomy would be worth anything if it was a gift from England.
('18', 243, 6, 28, 505051) Real fiscal autonomy lay in swadeshi.
('18', 243, 6, 29, 505089) Even the economists said that without fiscal autonomy, swaraj was meaningless.
('18', 243, 6, 30, 505168) But these very economists, when a remedy like the swadeshi was proposed to them by a man like himself, demurred to it.
('18', 243, 6, 31, 505287) Mr. Gandhi said he must disregard their objections, for it was his faith that in swadeshi lay fiscal
('18', 243, 7, 32, 505388) 1 Moneylender 2 The war of 1840 between China and Great Britain caused by the import of opium into China by foreign traders.
('18', 243, 7, 33, 505513) Fifteen years later another war broke out owing to the huge smuggling trade in opium whereafter the cultivation of opium in China was permitted and import from India was made legal.
('18', 244, 0, 1, 505695) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 245
('18', 244, 1, 2, 505740) autonomy as ample and vast and inexhaustible as the sea and it was such fiscal autonomy that they wanted.
('18', 244, 1, 3, 505846) And, continued Mr. Gandhi, even though England gave them fiscal autonomy, whom should they have to blame if they did not follow the eternal principles of swadeshi2?
('18', 244, 1, 4, 506011) Without swadeshi, they would fall into the meshes of Japan after being free from those of England, which would be tantamount to going from the frying pan into fire.
('18', 244, 1, 5, 506176) It would be impossible for them to set at naught the treaty obligations of England with Japan.
('18', 244, 1, 6, 506271) Their Government would warn them against imposing any duties on Japanese imports, on the ground that that would pave the way for another war.
('18', 244, 1, 7, 506413) Such a catastrophe might occur in the course of the next five years.
('18', 244, 1, 8, 506482) How, asked Mr. Gandhi, were they to save themselves from that catastrophe?
('18', 244, 1, 9, 506557) Only by grasping and following the principles of pure economics.
('18', 244, 1, 10, 506622) If there was a country on earth that did not produce its own food and clothing it deserved to be deserted, or no hopes of swaraj might be entertained with regard to it.
('18', 244, 1, 11, 506791) If swaraj could exist in such a country, it was bound to be nothing but what might be termed devilish swaraj.
('18', 244, 1, 12, 506901) The people of that country must either deceive and exploit other countries by their act and their diplomacy and obtain their food and clothing, or they must do so by force.
('18', 244, 1, 13, 507074) England was the only exception to the rule that every country that was civilized produced its own food and clothing.
('18', 244, 1, 14, 507191) She produced her own food stuffs, but she imported them also; she produced her cloth, but she imported it also.
('18', 244, 1, 15, 507303) And for this England had to maintain a great navy.
('18', 244, 1, 16, 507354) England was proud of her navy but that pride was, in the opinion of Mr. Gandhi, transient.
('18', 244, 1, 17, 507445) She could only be proud in that she could maintain such a navy, but the position she enjoyed thereby was purchased at the cost of heavy taxation on her people and of keeping a close watch on international highways.
('18', 244, 1, 18, 507660) If, said Mr. Gandhi, they wanted to purify British connection, purging it of all unnatural interest, they should demolish her economic theories.
('18', 244, 1, 19, 507805) The speaker was never enamoured of the British navy and had never thought of such a navy being necessary for India.
('18', 244, 1, 20, 507921) For England and Scotland, he observed, were small islands.
('18', 244, 1, 21, 507980) They abounded in vast country and it was therefore easy for them to maintain a navy.
('18', 244, 1, 22, 508065) India, on the contrary, was a vast country and not an island, but a peninsula.
('18', 244, 1, 23, 508144) It had no big coalfields, it was open to the invasion of the Afghan and the Tartar, of the Chinese and the Tibetan.
('18', 244, 1, 24, 508260) India, therefore, even if she could possess a navy could not rely solely upon it, she would have to maintain an army in addition and the expense of maintaining both would empty her resources.
('18', 244, 2, 25, 508452) BRITISH FISCAL POLICY
('18', 244, 3, 26, 508474) In the time of Queen Elizabeth, said the speaker, turning to a consideration of the fiscal policy of England, England also had to rely on swadeshi, so much so that the use of swadeshi articles was made obligatory by her.
('18', 244, 3, 27, 508695) Cloth coarser than the speaker was wearing used to be worn in royal households.
('18', 244, 3, 28, 508775) Englands adoption of the policy of free trade was but a recent affair.
('18', 244, 3, 29, 508846) Considerations that led to the adoption of
('18', 245, 0, 1, 508889) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 246
('18', 245, 1, 2, 508931) that policy were by no means mean.
('18', 245, 1, 3, 508966) But the defects therein imposed the load of a large navy on England which had crushed the nation.
('18', 245, 1, 4, 509064) England had adopted the free trade policy, but she was now veering in the other direction.
('18', 245, 1, 5, 509155) Mr. Joseph Chamberlain died fighting against Free Trade policy and a day would soon come when England would have to abandon the policy, or face a civil war.
('18', 245, 2, 6, 509312) A patient study of European history should, Mr. Gandhi thoughts wean them away from a blind imitation of Europe.
('18', 245, 2, 7, 509425) India should not imitate an experimenting nation, she should make her own experiments.
('18', 245, 2, 8, 509512) Using Mr. Sidgwicks phrase, the speaker said, India should not be the blotting sheet of European civilization.
('18', 245, 2, 9, 509623) She should not adorn herself with the cast off apparel of Europe.
('18', 245, 3, 10, 509689) A study of the history of other nations showed that those nations that had failed to maintain their economic independence for want of a policy of swadeshi had fallen.
('18', 245, 3, 11, 509856) In the same way, the nations that had been able to remain economically independent had always enjoyed swaraj.
('18', 245, 3, 12, 509966) Mr. Gandhi instanced the smaller European States.
('18', 245, 3, 13, 510016) They were, aid he, independent economic units because they followed swadeshi.
('18', 245, 3, 14, 510094) Every independent nation was a follower of swadeshi in its own way.
('18', 245, 3, 15, 510162) Switzerland and Denmark kept the trades and manufactures suited to their own people to themselves, and allowed no outsiders to interfere with them.
('18', 245, 3, 16, 510310) Indias swadeshi lay in producing her foodstuffs and he cloth.
('18', 245, 3, 17, 510372) As regards food stuffs they had fortunately no need to take a vow, as people used, for the most part, food stuffs produced in the country, excepting a very few who might be in need of Scotch oats.
('18', 245, 3, 18, 510569) As regards clothing, they were in a serious predicament.
('18', 245, 3, 19, 510626) Once the producers of the finest cotton and silken fabrics, today they were dependent on Japan and Lancashire.
('18', 245, 3, 20, 510737) And only swadeshi, repeated Mr. Gandhi, could free them from the unnatural Lancashire interest and the Japanese peril.
('18', 245, 4, 21, 510856) UNITED EFFORTS
('18', 245, 5, 22, 510871) But the speaker did not expect to achieve any great results working single handed He had no desire to work alone.
('18', 245, 5, 23, 510985) He earnestly desired the co operation of the 31 crores of his countryrnen, as also of Englishmen.
('18', 245, 5, 24, 511083) He confessed he was swadeshi mad.
('18', 245, 5, 25, 511117) Like Vaidarbhi rambling in search of Nala, and asking even the trees and stones that she passed by to show her Nala , he asked every little thing that he came across to show him the way to swadeshi.
('18', 245, 5, 26, 511316) He asked the people to gird up their loins with him even for a year, and he promised them that they could surprise the world by the results that would be achieved.
('18', 245, 5, 27, 511480) And he assured them they needed not the help of boycott or any such thing; they only needed to produce and to restrict themselves to the use of their own cloth.
('18', 245, 6, 28, 511641) There were many things that were essential for success in that direction.
('18', 245, 6, 29, 511715) Two of these were commercial morality in the producer and sympathy and fellow feeling in
('18', 246, 0, 1, 511804) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 247
('18', 246, 1, 2, 511849) the rich for their poorer brethren.
('18', 246, 1, 3, 511885) The rich should feel that the poor in the country should not be suffered to remain ill clad and they should be fired with an enthusiasm to provide cloth for them.
('18', 246, 1, 4, 512048) Every woman should resolve to give at least one of her spare hours to spinning cotton.
('18', 246, 1, 5, 512135) If indeed honesty, industry, patriotism and riches could combine.
('18', 246, 1, 6, 512201) W hat results would be achieved !
('18', 246, 2, 7, 512235) Mr. Gandhi asked the audience to fling away the superstition that the country could not do without a network of mills.
('18', 246, 2, 8, 512354) The speaker was not against mills.
('18', 246, 2, 9, 512389) But he maintained, and Sir Fazulbhai also admitted it, that it would take some 50 years before they could think of providing the whole of their country with mill made cloth.
('18', 246, 2, 10, 512563) As it was, there were figures to show there was more cloth produced in the country on handlooms than was being turned out by the mills.
('18', 246, 2, 11, 512699) And the speaker had no doubt that hand spinning and hand weaving, if introduced everywhere, would make the country self sufficing in a very small period.
('18', 246, 2, 12, 512853) The agricultural population of India was 21 crores; if every one of them spun and wove cotton during the idle period of four months in the year, a very large stock of cloth could be produced.
('18', 246, 2, 13, 513045) In conclusion, Mr. Gandhi emphasized the fact that every village in India was self sufficient in the olden times, and that they could be made such even now if people took keenly to the two suggestions of hand spinning and hand weaving he had made.
('18', 246, 2, 14, 513293) He exhorted the Surat people to send out large bands of volunteers to every village to preach and bring the idea of swadeshi home to them so as to cover the villages with a network of spinning wheels and handlooms.
('18', 246, 2, 15, 513508) Young India, 16 8 19l9
('18', 246, 3, 16, 513531) 196. JAGANNATHS CASE
('18', 246, 4, 17, 513552) It is not without extreme sorrow that I have to invite public attention to a third miscarriage of justice in the Punjab.
('18', 246, 4, 18, 513673) This time it is not a case of a celebrity like Babu Kalinath Roy or a lesser light like Lala Radha Krishna, the Editor of the Pratap.
('18', 246, 4, 19, 513807) The case of which the papers have been furnished me relates to one Mr. Jagannath, unknown to fame and unconnected with any public activity.
('18', 246, 4, 20, 513947) He has been sentenced by one of the Martial Law Tribunals to transportation for life, with forfeiture of property, under Section 121 of the Indian Penal Code, i.e., for waging war against His Majesty.
('18', 246, 4, 21, 514148) The facts of the case are lucidly set forth in his petition to be found elsewhere.
('18', 246, 4, 22, 514231) It is addressed to the Hon.
('18', 246, 4, 23, 514259) Sir Edward Maclagan, the Lieutenant Governor of the Punjab.
('18', 246, 4, 24, 514319) The reader will find also the judgment in the Gujran walla case in respect of fifteen accused of whom Mr. Jagannath was one.
('18', 246, 4, 25, 514444) The following is the text in the judgment dealing with the case:
('18', 247, 0, 1, 514509) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 248
('18', 247, 1, 2, 514551) Jagannath, accused 10, had the notices convening the meeting of the 5th, printed in Lahore and was present at the meetings of the 12th and 13th.
('18', 247, 1, 3, 514696) But we have no hesitation in holding that he was present at both and that his defence is worthless.
('18', 247, 1, 4, 514796) There is ample evidence to show that on the 14th April, he took a very active part in having the shops closed.
('18', 247, 1, 5, 514907) We are satisfied of his guilt and convict him under Sec.
('18', 247, 1, 6, 514964) 121, I.P.C. I submit that it was no crime on the accuseds part to have the notices convening the meeting of the 5th printed, nor to have been present at the meeting was of an incriminating character.
('18', 247, 1, 7, 515164) This is what the Court has to say about the meeting of the 5th April:
('18', 247, 2, 8, 515234) It is alleged that the people of Gujranwalla knew little and cared less about the Rowlatt Act and that on the 4th April certain of the accused decided to start an agitation against this Act on the same lines as had been adopted in other parts of the country at the instance of Gandhi.
('18', 247, 2, 9, 515519) A mass meeting was accordingly convened and held on the evening of the 5th April when the Rowlatt Act was condemned.
('18', 247, 2, 10, 515636) Under no statute known could these facts be held to involve any crime.
('18', 247, 2, 11, 515707) The judges themselves have stated as much:
('18', 247, 3, 12, 515750) We are not however satisfied in this case, that prior to the 12th April any indictable conspiracy had come into existence.
('18', 247, 3, 13, 515873) We therefore feel constrained to acquit those of the accused who are shown only to have taken part in the proceedings prior to that date.
('18', 247, 3, 14, 516011) It is difficult therefore to understand the reference of the Court to the accuseds presence at the meeting of the 5th or his having been an agent for getting the notices printed.
('18', 247, 3, 15, 516190) The Court proceeds,
('18', 247, 4, 16, 516210) On the evening of the 12th and during the day of 13th, certain of the accused in consultation with Bhagat agreed that they should follow the example set at Amritsar [of] burning bridges and cutting telegraph wires.
('18', 247, 4, 17, 516425) Now these facts, it is plain, undoubtedly prove a criminal conspiracy but the Court is silent as to which accused agreed upon the crimes recited in the paragraph.
('18', 247, 4, 18, 516588) It should be remembered that there was a meeting on the 12th of the District Congress Committee held prior to the evening meeting of the 12th referred to in the sentence quoted above.
('18', 247, 4, 19, 516772) I submit that it was necessary for the Court definitely to find that the accused was present at the agreement alleged to have been arrived at for burning bridges and cutting telegraph wires.
('18', 247, 4, 20, 516963) But there is nothing in the finding of the Court beyond a vague general statement about the accuseds presence at the meetings of the 12th
('18', 248, 0, 1, 517101) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 249
('18', 248, 1, 2, 517146) and 13th.
('18', 248, 1, 3, 517156) I would suggest that even if the accused was in Gujranwalla on the 14th April and took a very active part in having the shops closed, it would be no offence, unless he could be proved to have been party to the criminal agreement referred to.
('18', 248, 1, 4, 517398) Whilst, therefore, the judgment seems to afford no evidence of the accuseds crime, statements most damaging to the Court and conclusively in favour of the accuseds defence rested upon an alibi.
('18', 248, 1, 5, 517592) He stated that he left Gujranwalla on the 12th April by the 5 p.m.
('18', 248, 1, 6, 517659) train en route for Kathiawar where he had a case.
('18', 248, 1, 7, 517709) Now I admit that it is as easy to set up an alibi as it is difficult to prove it.
('18', 248, 1, 8, 517791) But anyone reading the petition can only come to one conclusion, viz., that the defence of alibi was completely established.
('18', 248, 1, 9, 517916) Mr. Jagannath produced local respectable witnesses to show that he had left Gujranwalla on the 12th.
('18', 248, 1, 10, 518017) He applied for subpoenas to summon witnesses from Kathiawar to show that he was in Dhoraji on the 16th April.
('18', 248, 1, 11, 518127) The Court rejected the application, but granted interrogatories, put the accused, a poor man, to the expense of Rs. 250 for the expenses of the Commission, and yet strange as it may appear, pronounced judgment against the accused without waiting for the return of the Commission.
('18', 248, 1, 12, 518407) He made an application for the stay of argument till after the receipt of replies to interrogatories.
('18', 248, 1, 13, 518509) The application was rejected.
('18', 248, 1, 14, 518539) In a second application, he urged that the Court should ascertain by telegram the result of the interrogatories.
('18', 248, 1, 15, 518652) Even that application proved unavailing.
('18', 248, 1, 16, 518693) The accused has rightly contended in the petition that on this ground alone the conviction was illegal and ought to be set aside.
('18', 248, 1, 17, 518823) The petition refers to the register of the Foujdar of Dhoraji seeing that he reached Dhoraji on the 16th April.
('18', 248, 1, 18, 518935) The accused shows also by the examination of 10 independent witnesses that he was in Dhoraji on that date.
('18', 248, 1, 19, 519042) He shows further by extracts from Railway Time Tables, that it takes 44 hours to reach Dhoraji from Delhi by the fastest train, and shows conclusively that it was physically impossible for him to be in Gujranwalla after 6 p.m.
('18', 248, 1, 20, 519269) on the 13th; though as a matter of fact he shows by other conclusive evidence that he left Gujranwalla on the 12th.
('18', 248, 1, 21, 519385) He produces proceedings of Jetpur Court where he had his case in Kathiawar.
('18', 248, 1, 22, 519461) There is therefore no ground whatsoever for keeping the accused in jail for a single moment.
('18', 248, 1, 23, 519554) The accused on his own showing is
('18', 248, 2, 24, 519588) a petty shopkeeper at Gujaranwalla, paying no income tax, being ignorant of Urdu as well as English and not possessed of any influence in big towns like Gujranwalla with a populations of 30,000 persons.
('18', 248, 2, 25, 519791) He being a man of humble position and status in life, with no education, has never taken part in politics,
('18', 249, 0, 1, 519898) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 250
('18', 249, 1, 2, 519940) nor was he a member of the local District Congress Committee or any other political body or association.
('18', 249, 1, 3, 520045) The humbleness of his position makes the injustice all the more galling and makes it doubly incumbent on the public to see that the meanest of the subjects of the King suffers no wrong.
('18', 249, 1, 4, 520231) The decision of His Honour the Lieutenant Governor in the case of Lala Radha Krishna raises the hope that speedy justice will be done in this case.
('18', 249, 1, 5, 520379) Bad as Babu Kalinath Roys and Lala Radha Krishnas cases were, this, if possible, is worse in that Martial Law Judges in their impatience, shall I say, to convict, declined to wait for a return of the Commission they themselves had granteda Commission on whose return hung the liberty, and might have been, even the life of the accused.
('18', 249, 2, 6, 520715) M. K. GANDHI Young India, 30 7 1919
('18', 249, 3, 7, 520751) 197. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR
('18', 249, 4, 8, 520807) LABURNUK ROAD, [On or after July 30, 1919] 1

('18', 249, 6, 10, 520918) DEAR SIR, I beg to enclose herewith a copy of Young India dealing with the case of one Jagannath who has been recently convicted and sentenced to transportation for life with forfeiture of property.
('18', 249, 6, 11, 521117) His petition for revision of the case and quashing the sentence, is, I understand, already engaging His Honours attention.
('18', 249, 6, 12, 521240) In my humble opinion palpable injustice has been done in this case.
('18', 249, 6, 13, 521308) The hasty pronouncement of judgment, by the Martial Law Tribunal without waiting for the return of the Commission issued by it is in itself fatal to the conviction.
('18', 249, 6, 14, 521473) The facts set forth in the petition seem completely to establish the defence of alibi.
('18', 249, 6, 15, 521560) Both therefore in substance and in law, I submit that the conviction is bad.
('18', 249, 6, 16, 521637) I therefore respectfully trust that His Honour will be pleased to set aside the conviction and restore the liberty of the poor petitioner.

('18', 250, 10, 13, 522272) 199. AN APPEAL FROM THE PUNJAB
('18', 250, 11, 14, 522303) Sannyasi Swami Shri Shraddhanandji, writing from Delhi regarding the Punjab, says :
('18', 250, 12, 15, 522387) I have been to the Punjab twice (i.e., since the tragedies of April last).
('18', 250, 12, 16, 522462) 3 I have been to Amritsar, Lahore, Gujranwalla, Sekhupura and Chachadkhana and heard and seen much.
('18', 250, 12, 17, 522562) On the 13th April in Amritsar not less than fifteen hundred persons must have been killed.
('18', 250, 12, 18, 522653) In the other places also many, though not so many as at Amritsar, must have been killed.
('18', 250, 12, 19, 522742) Of these, hundred were the sole wage earners of their families.
('18', 250, 12, 20, 522806) Some have been hanged or sentenced to transportation for life, others have been sentenced to undergo imprisonment for from ten to twenty years.
('18', 250, 12, 21, 522950) There must be one thousand families in the Punjab which are left only with their womenfolk and children.
('18', 250, 12, 22, 523055) It is our duty to reach them food and clothing.
('18', 250, 12, 23, 523103) Pundit Malaviyaji 4 has appealed to the public for one lac of rupees.
('18', 250, 12, 24, 523173) But I believe that we shall have to support many of these families for six months at least.
('18', 250, 12, 25, 523265) If so, we shall need one and a half lacs of rupees.
('18', 250, 12, 26, 523317) This estimate is based on the supposition that most of
('18', 250, 13, 27, 523372) 1 An appeal from the Punjab was published in Young India, 2 8 1919; vide the following item.
('18', 250, 13, 28, 523465) 2 1856 1926; earlier known as Mahatma Munshiram; nationalist leader, Arya Samajist and educationist.
('18', 250, 13, 29, 523566) He the founder of Gurukul Kangri, near Hardwar.
('18', 250, 13, 30, 523614) 3 The reference is to the disturbance and the martial law atrocities in the Punjab.
('18', 250, 13, 31, 523698) 4 Madan Mohan Malaviya (1861 19460; nationalist leader, educationist and founder of Banaras Hindu University

('18', 251, 1, 2, 523849) those suffering imprisonment will, during that time, have been discharged.
('18', 251, 1, 3, 523924) If you are in agreement with this proposal of mine, please beg of the rich people of Bombay donations and send the money to me.
('18', 251, 1, 4, 524052) I shall need also trustworthy volunteers for the work of distribution.
('18', 251, 1, 5, 524123) You can send such volunteers.
('18', 251, 1, 6, 524153) If possible, please send four or five such men.
('18', 251, 1, 7, 524201) The Swamis appeal is eloquent for its brevity and I hope that it will strike the right chord in many a breast.
('18', 251, 1, 8, 524312) I hardly think that it needs any commendation from me.

('18', 251, 1, 24, 526086) He is not to air his political views or to combine two missions in one trip.
('18', 251, 1, 25, 526163) Real success in national work can only be assured when workers develop the quality of losing themselves in their work to the exclusion of every other work for the time being.
('18', 251, 1, 26, 526338) By trying to do many things at the same time we succeed

('18', 252, 3, 5, 526756) 200. INTERVIEW TO A JOURNALIST 1
('18', 252, 4, 6, 526789) [BOMBAY, August 4, 1919]
('18', 252, 5, 7, 526814) As soon as he finished his letter, he turned round to me again and asked me what had brought me all the way from Madras.
('18', 252, 5, 8, 526935) I told him I had come to see Mr. R off on his way to England and then we fell to discussing the general situation.
('18', 252, 5, 9, 527050) I asked him whether he had any near idea of resuming civil disobedience.
('18', 252, 5, 10, 527123) He said it all depended on the Government and what they did to relieve the situation in the near future.
('18', 252, 5, 11, 527228) He did not want to complicate matters by any precipitate action of his as it might easily lend itself to mask real issues.
('18', 252, 5, 12, 527351) If the Government do not move in the matter pretty soon, relieve the situation in the Punjab and repeal the Rowlatt Act 2 , it will be his painful duty to resort to passive resistance again.
('18', 252, 5, 13, 527542) Should this contingency arise, he intends to break his internment order on the Madras border as being much the quieter side so that there may be no excuse for the Government to set in motion any positive measures on the plea of disorder or violence.
('18', 252, 6, 14, 527792) 1 This was published as by C.R.S. and was preceded by the following remarks: .
('18', 252, 6, 15, 527871) I went in and found Mr.Gandhi seated cross legged on his couch, dressed in his usual coarse hand woven clothes and with his spectacles on, busy writing a letter to some friend of his in Gujarati.
('18', 252, 6, 16, 528067) The letter paper, pencil and envelope were apparently of the more common swadeshi type, for I noticed the paper was none too fine, the pencil had to be pressed hard to make an impression, and the envelope would not easily open in the prevailing weather .
('18', 252, 6, 17, 528322) I noticed also that one of the curls of his spectacles had broken midway and was being held in position by a piece of thread knotted round his head.
('18', 252, 6, 18, 528471) I was wondering why a fresh curl had not been put in, but soon found a broken curl was not without its uses, as it served well enough for a toothpick on occasions.
('18', 252, 6, 19, 528635) Well, when Mr. Gandhi looked up from his writing and saw me, his thin asetic face lighted up with a charming smile as he recognized me, and bade me sit down and excuse him for a few minutes as he finised his letter. 2 This was one of the two Bills recommended by the Rowlatt Committee in 1918 ostensibly for curbing seditious activity and was passed in 1919, in the face of public opposition.

('18', 253, 1, 2, 529127) I asked him if he had any special message for the time for the people in South India and any special duty for the satyagrahis.
('18', 253, 1, 3, 529254) Yes, I want every man, woman and child to learn handspinning and weaving.
('18', 253, 1, 4, 529328) I want every satyagrahi to help to propagate this work.
('18', 253, 1, 5, 529384) Let every man learn to provide for his clothing in his house and many of our current problems will resolve themselves.
('18', 253, 1, 6, 529503) I am asking you to do nothing new.
('18', 253, 1, 7, 529538) It is not as though you have to skip over the centuries and go to ancient India for this kind of work.
('18', 253, 1, 8, 529641) Even a few decades back, every village had its hand looms and the people were wearing only clothes woven therefrom.
('18', 253, 1, 9, 529757) Spinning was being done normally in every house.
('18', 253, 1, 10, 529806) It is not neecha [mean] work.
('18', 253, 1, 11, 529836) Ranis [queens] in palaces have done this.
('18', 253, 1, 12, 529878) If this is resumed again we shall have done well by our country.
('18', 253, 1, 13, 529943) I am quite hopeful of results.
('18', 253, 1, 14, 529974) I have already set a thousand looms going in Gujarat and leading people like Mrs. Banker 1, Mrs. Petit 2 , Miss Anasuyabehn 3 have taken up spinning enthusiastically.
('18', 253, 1, 15, 530141) The mechanism is quite simple and a spinning outfit costs only about Rs. 3 8 0 to Rs. 4. The work is easily learnt in a couple of days.
('18', 253, 1, 16, 530277) For example you will find in the next room Mrs. T.A. Chettiar learning to spin.
('18', 253, 1, 17, 530357) She has been at it only from yesterday and a few more hours practice will make her quite fit for the work and quite competent to put other people in the way as I expect her to do.

('18', 254, 1, 2, 531000) 201. LETTER TO G.S. ARUNDALE 1
('18', 254, 2, 3, 531031) LABURNUM ROAD BOMBAY, August 4, 1919
('18', 254, 3, 4, 531068) DEAR MR. ARUNDALE 2 ,
('18', 254, 4, 5, 531090) I have read and re read your kind letter for which I thank you.
('18', 254, 4, 6, 531154) I am publishing the letter 3 in Young India together with this reply.
('18', 254, 4, 7, 531224) Much as I should like to follow your advice, I feel that I am incompetent for the task set forth by you in your letter.
('18', 254, 4, 8, 531344) I am fuly aware of my limitations.
('18', 254, 4, 9, 531379) My bent is not political but religious and I take part in politics because I feel that there is no department of life which can be divorced from religion and because politics touch the vital being of India almost at every point.
('18', 254, 4, 10, 531608) It is therefore absolutely necessary that the political relations between Englishmen and ourselves should be put on a sound basis.
('18', 254, 4, 11, 531739) I am endeavouring to the best of my ability to assist in the process.
('18', 254, 4, 12, 531809) I do not take much interest in the reforms because they are in safe hands and because reforms cum Rowlatt legislation mean to my mind a stalemate.
('18', 254, 4, 13, 531956) Rowlatt legislation represents a poisonous spirit.
('18', 254, 4, 14, 532007) After all, the English civilians can, unless Indian opinion produces a healthy reaction upon them, reduce the reforms practically to a nullity.
('18', 254, 4, 15, 532151) They distrust us and we distrust them.
('18', 254, 4, 16, 532190) Each considers the other as his natural enemy.
('18', 254, 4, 17, 532237) Hence the Rowlatt legislation.
('18', 254, 4, 18, 532268) The Civil Service has devised the legislation to keep us down.
('18', 254, 4, 19, 532331) In my opinion, that legislation is like the coil of the snake round the Indian body.
('18', 254, 4, 20, 532416) The obstinacy of the Government in clinging to the hateful legislation in spite of the clearest possible demonstration they have had of public opinion against it makes me suspect the worst.
('18', 254, 4, 21, 532606) With the views enunciated above, you will not wonder at my inability to interest myself in the reforms.
('18', 254, 4, 22, 532710) Rowlatt legislation blocks the way.
('18', 254, 4, 23, 532746) And my life is dedicated among other things to removing the block.
('18', 254, 5, 24, 532813) 1 Thid was in reply to his letter of July 26, appealing to Gandhiji that since civil disobedience had been suspended, he should join in working the Montagu Chelmsford Constitutional Reforms.
('18', 254, 5, 25, 533004) 2 Theosophist, and editor of New India 3 Vide Appendix Letter from G.S. Arundale, 26 7 1919
('18', 255, 0, 1, 533096) 256 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 255, 1, 2, 533138) Let there be no mistake.
('18', 255, 1, 3, 533163) Civil resistance has come to stay.
('18', 255, 1, 4, 533198) It is an eternal doctrine of life which we follow consciously or unconsciously in many walks of life.
('18', 255, 1, 5, 533300) It is the new and extended application of it which has caused misgivings and excitement.
('18', 255, 1, 6, 533389) Its suspension is designed to demonstrate its true nature, and to throw the responsibility for the removal of the Rowlatt legislation on the Government as also the leaders (you among them) who have advised me to suspend it.
('18', 255, 1, 7, 533613) But if within a resonable time the legislation is not removed, civil resistance will follow as surely as day follows night.
('18', 255, 1, 8, 533737) No weapon in the Government armoury can either overcome or destroy that eternal force.
('18', 255, 1, 9, 533824) Indeed a time must come when civil resistance will be recognized as the most efficacious, if also the most harmless, remedy for securing redress of grievances.
('18', 255, 1, 10, 533984) You suggest the desirability of unity.
('18', 255, 1, 11, 534023) I think unity of goal we have.
('18', 255, 1, 12, 534054) But parties we shall always haveand we may not find a common denominator for improvement.
('18', 255, 1, 13, 534144) For some will want to go further than some others.
('18', 255, 1, 14, 534195) I see no harm in a wholesome variety.
('18', 255, 1, 15, 534233) What I would rid ourselves of is distrust of one another and imputation of motive.
('18', 255, 1, 16, 534316) Our besetting sin is not our differences but our littleness.
('18', 255, 1, 17, 534377) We wrangle over words, we fight often for shadow and lose the substance.
('18', 255, 1, 18, 534450) As Mr. Gokhale used to say, our politics are a pastime of our leisure hours when they are not undertaken as a stepping stone to a career in life.
('18', 255, 1, 19, 534596) I would invite you and every editor to insist on introducing charity, seriousness and selflessness in our politics.
('18', 255, 1, 20, 534712) And our disunion will not jar as it does today.
('18', 255, 1, 21, 534760) It is not our differences that really matter.
('18', 255, 1, 22, 534806) It is the meanness behind that is undoubtedly ugly.
('18', 255, 1, 23, 534858) The Punjab sentences are inextricably mixed up with the Rowlatt agitation.
('18', 255, 1, 24, 534933) It is therefore as imperatively necessary to have them revised as it is to have the Act removed.
('18', 255, 1, 25, 535030) I agree with you that the Press Act requires overhauling.
('18', 255, 1, 26, 535088) The Government are actually promoting sedition by high handed executive action.
('18', 255, 1, 27, 535168) And I was sorry to learn that Lord Willingdon 1 is reported to have taken the sole responsibility for the in my opinion unwarrantedaction 2 against The Hindu and the Swadesha Mitran.
('18', 255, 1, 28, 535351) By it, they have not lost in prestige or popularity.
('18', 255, 1, 29, 535404) They have gained in both.
('18', 255, 1, 30, 535430) Surely there are judges enough
('18', 255, 2, 31, 535461) 1 1866 1941; Governor of Bombay; later Viceroy of India, 1931 6 2 The Government demanded a security of Rs. 2,000 from each of these Madras newspapers and banned The Hindu in the Punjab and in Burma.
('18', 256, 0, 1, 535661) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 257
('18', 256, 1, 2, 535706) in the land who would convict where a journalist has overstepped the bounds of legitimate criticism and uttered sedition.
('18', 256, 1, 3, 535828) I am not enamoured of the Declaration of Rights business.
('18', 256, 1, 4, 535886) When we have changed the spirit of the English civilian, we shall have made considerable headway with the Declaration of Rights.
('18', 256, 1, 5, 536015) We must be honourable friends, or equally honourable enemies.
('18', 256, 1, 6, 536077) We shall be neither, unless we are manly, fearless and independent.
('18', 256, 1, 7, 536145) I would have us to treasure Lord Willingdons advice and say no when we mean no without fear of consequences.
('18', 256, 1, 8, 536254) This is unadulterated civil resistance.
('18', 256, 1, 9, 536294) It is the way to friendliness and friendship.
('18', 256, 1, 10, 536340) The other is the age worn method of open violence on honourable lines in so far as violence can be allowed to be honourable.
('18', 256, 1, 11, 536465) For me the roots of violence are in dishounour.
('18', 256, 1, 12, 536513) I have therefore ventured to present to India the former, in its complete form called satyagraha, whose roots are always in honour.
('18', 256, 2, 13, 536645) Yours sincerely, M.K. GANDHI Young India, 6 8 1919

('18', 257, 1, 2, 537574) 203. LETTER TO MANUBHAI NANDSHANKAR MEHTA
('18', 257, 2, 3, 537616) LABURNUM ROAD, GAMDEVI, BOMBAY, [August 4, 1919] 1
('18', 257, 3, 4, 537667) BHAISHRI MANUBHAI,
('18', 257, 4, 5, 537686) I was in Vijapur last Thursday.
('18', 257, 4, 6, 537718) There, and on the way, I met thousands of men and women.
('18', 257, 4, 7, 537775) It was the movement for swadeshi which took me there.
('18', 257, 4, 8, 537829) There is a prominent lady from Broach, a widow, in Vijapur.
('18', 257, 4, 9, 537889) Spinning, and now weaving as well, is being promoted there through her.
('18', 257, 4, 10, 537961) Her name is Gangabehn 2 .
('18', 257, 4, 11, 537987) The aim behind this programme is to increase the production of cloth in the country.
('18', 257, 4, 12, 538072) Women, and men too, who have free time should devote it to spinning and, if they can, to weaving.
('18', 257, 4, 13, 538170) In this way, it is hoped to restore to the agriculturists an old time subsidiary occupation of theirs.
('18', 257, 4, 14, 538273) As part of this programme, at present 125 women spin in Vijapur and, depending on how much they work, earn daily two to four pice or even more.
('18', 257, 4, 15, 538417) These women did no work before they took this up.
('18', 257, 4, 16, 538467) Gangabehn and others work for the love of God.
('18', 257, 4, 17, 538514) A loom has also been installed recently.
('18', 257, 4, 18, 538555) I saw that the institution was very much short of space.
('18', 257, 4, 19, 538612) My request to the State is this.
('18', 257, 4, 20, 538645) Make one or two acres of land available near the station and immediately get a building ready, in which people may live and work.
('18', 257, 4, 21, 538775) I am prepared to pay rent for it.
('18', 257, 4, 22, 538809) If you can see to this, the work there will progress better.
('18', 257, 4, 23, 538870) If the Maharaja thinks well of this work, I should like him to advise the officers also to help.
('18', 257, 4, 24, 538967) If I get some encouragement, I am hopeful that, in a very short time, we shall have plenty of cloth produced in Vijapur taluka and the agriculturists and others will have a means of supplementing their income.
('18', 257, 4, 25, 539177) This is one matter on which I have to trouble you.
('18', 257, 5, 26, 539228) 1 Gandhiji was in Bombay On August 4, 1919, after having visited Vijapur, and later in the day left for Ahmedabad.
('18', 257, 5, 27, 539343) 2 It is to her that Gandhiji ascribes the discovery of the spinning wheel in Vijapur; vide and Autobiography, part V, Ch. XL.
('18', 258, 0, 1, 539469) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 259
('18', 258, 1, 2, 539514) I saw that the passengers in the train were packed like so many goats.
('18', 258, 1, 3, 539585) The carriages are too few and there is only one train.
('18', 258, 1, 4, 539640) That is not enough.
('18', 258, 1, 5, 539660) I should like you to do something about this, too, if possible.
('18', 258, 1, 6, 539724) I beg to be excused for this letter.
('18', 258, 2, 7, 539761) Yours, SHRI MANUBHAI NANDEHANKAR DIWAN BARODA
('18', 258, 3, 8, 539807) From a photostat of the Gujarati original in Gandhijis hand : S. N. 6796

('18', 259, 5, 24, 542038) The Hon.
('18', 259, 5, 25, 542047) Mr. C.Y. Chintamani 7 in his special contribution to India of the 4th July says that Sir Michael ODwyer 8
('18', 259, 6, 26, 542153) is said to have declared his intention of taking note of the anti Rowlatt legislation agitation and passive resistance demonstration before there was any disturbance of peace.
('18', 259, 6, 27, 542329) We know what kind of note he took of both the cause and the effect, and we know, too, what he succeeded to an eminent degree in disturbing the peace in the Punjab.
('18', 259, 6, 28, 542493) And though Sir Michael is no
('18', 259, 7, 29, 542522) 1 C. F. Andrews (1871 1940); British missionary whose humanitarian work in India won him the name Deenabandhu, i.e.; friend of the poor; vide Speech at Maritzburg, 27 12 1913 2 Gandhijis eldest son 3 His fourth and youngest son 4 Chhaganlal Gandhis brother 5 Son of Amritlal Gandhi, a cousin of Gandhiji 6 This is evidently a slip for eyes.

('18', 260, 0, 1, 542922) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 261
('18', 260, 1, 2, 542967) longer in India in body, he is certainly in our midst in spirit.
('18', 260, 1, 3, 543032) Witness the many Punjab cases that have been discussed in these columns.
('18', 260, 1, 4, 543105) The Martial Law judges will certainly not be to blame if the spirit of civil resistance is not dead either in the Punjab or in India.
('18', 260, 1, 5, 543239) But the ODwyerean spirit has travelled to far off Burma and touched the Lieut. Governor of the Province of British India 1 For, the Chief Secretary to Government of Burma, the A.P.I. 2 informs us, has written to the two Indian promoters of the All Burma mass meeting that was to be held in Burma on the first of August that, whilst there is no objection to the meeting discussing the Reform Scheme in Burma,
('18', 260, 2, 6, 543647) serious objection would be taken if extraneous matters are introduced either under the colour of the published resolutions, or as separate resolutions not on the agenda.
('18', 260, 2, 7, 543817) In particular, the Secretary goes on to say,
('18', 260, 3, 8, 543862) the Lieut. Governor has no intention of permitting meetings at which the adoption of passive resistance is advocated, or at which the policy of Government, in connection with the passing of the Rowlatt Act or the suppression of the recent disturbances in the Punjab, is called in question.
('18', 260, 3, 9, 544152) The public of Burma in discussing the political Reforms which should be adopted in Burma are in no way concerned with the events in the Punjab.
('18', 260, 3, 10, 544296) The Government of Burma have certainly taken time by the forelock.
('18', 260, 3, 11, 544363) We do not know what happened on the 1st of August in Rangoon nor do we know what reply the Indian promoters of the meeting returned to the Chief Secretary.
('18', 260, 3, 12, 544519) But it is clear that, so long as the spirit embodied in the words of the letter from which we have quoted remains alive, the Reforms that the people of Burma might get would not be worth having.
('18', 260, 3, 13, 544714) But an echo of the spirit is heard nearer Bombay also.
('18', 260, 3, 14, 544769) We now know, more fully than we did before, the cause of the High Court notice served upon some of the satyagrahi lawyers of Ahmedabad.
('18', 260, 3, 15, 544905) The notice was prompted by a letter addressed by the District Judge of Ahmedabad to the Registrar of the Bombay High Court.
('18', 260, 3, 16, 545029) We give the full text of the letter elsewhere.
('18', 260, 3, 17, 545076) 3 It remains to be seen what action the
('18', 260, 4, 18, 545116) 1 Burma became an independent state in 1935. 2 The Associated Press of India 3 This is not reproduced here.

('18', 261, 1, 2, 545641) High Court will take when the case is argued before it on the 25th instant.
('18', 261, 1, 3, 545717) But it is curious the way the District Judge has pre judged the issue.
('18', 261, 1, 4, 545788) He considers the activities of the Leaguewe suppose he means the Satyagrahe Sabha 1 to be illegal.
('18', 261, 1, 5, 545887) He does not hesitate to make the impudent suggestion that
('18', 261, 2, 6, 545945) there can be no doubt that the suspension is merely a device to avoid the possibility of punishment falling on the satyagrahis in respect of acts directly or indirectly due to their teaching and influence.
('18', 261, 2, 7, 546151) We use the adjective impundent advisedly, for the very next paragraph of this precious letter states the belief of the writer that
('18', 261, 3, 8, 546282) the above gentlemen are sincerely and conscientiously under the impression that the Rowlatt legislation is a crime.
('18', 261, 3, 9, 546398) As they have that impression, I would not blame them for going to the edge of the law to oppose it.
('18', 261, 3, 10, 546498) The imputaion of an unworthy motive to such men would be ungentlemanly in a stranger, it is unpardonable in one who claims to have the high opinion that the learned District Judge claims to have of the lawyers in question.
('18', 261, 3, 11, 546721) The last paragraph of the letter clearly discloses the feelings of the District Judge in the matter.
('18', 261, 3, 12, 546822) He says he has no power to deal with the two Barristers, and adds, very likely recent events in Ahmedabad may make it unnecessary to proceed against them, meaning, we presume, that they would be charged and convicted by the Special Tribunal.
('18', 261, 3, 13, 547064) They have not been charged, it is true.
('18', 261, 3, 14, 547104) But that was no fault of the District Judge.
('18', 261, 3, 15, 547149) He had made up his mind that they had committed a criminal breach of the law of the land.
('18', 261, 3, 16, 547239) Thus we see that the attempts are being made with more or less vigour to suppress civil resisters.
('18', 261, 3, 17, 547338) Those who are making the attempt are beating against the wind.
('18', 261, 3, 18, 547401) The spirit of civil resistance thrives under suffering.
('18', 261, 3, 19, 547457) Here and there a civil resister so called may succumb and
('18', 261, 4, 20, 547515) considered such conduct inconsistent with their professional status and duties in terms terms of their sanad.

('18', 261, 4, 23, 547868) On this submission, the Bombay High Court served notices on the lawyers, on July 12, in its desciplinary jurisdiction.
('18', 261, 4, 24, 547987) A copy of the District Judges letter reached Gandhiji, who published it in Young India along with his comments.
('18', 261, 4, 25, 548099) The High Court gave its ruling in the case against the lawyers on October 15. ('18', 262, 0, 1, 548380) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 263
('18', 262, 1, 2, 548425) under the pressure of suffering deny his doctrine.
('18', 262, 1, 3, 548476) But when once kindled it is impossible to kill the spirit of civil resistance.
('18', 262, 1, 4, 548555) The only pity of it is these traducers of civil resistance and civil resisters are consciously or unconsciously becoming the instruments for pro pagating Bolshevism as it is interpreted to us in India, i.e., the spirit of lawlessness accompained with violence.
('18', 262, 1, 5, 548816) Bolshevism is nothing but an extension of the present method of forcibly imposing ones doctrine or will upon others.
('18', 262, 1, 6, 548933) The Government of Burma, the Government of Punjab, the District Judge of Ahmedabad are all in their own way endeavouring forcibly to impose their will upon others, in this case, civil resisters.
('18', 262, 1, 7, 549128) But they forget that the essence of civil resistance is to resist the will of the wrongdoer by patient endurance of the penalty of resistance.
('18', 262, 1, 8, 549271) Civil resistance is, therefore, a most powerful antidote against Bolshevism and those who are trying to crush the spirit of civil resistance are but fanning the fire of Bolshevism.

('18', 263, 7, 16, 552384) Young India in common with other papers has received a confidential notice No.
('18', 263, 7, 17, 552463) 4515 dated 23rd July last from the Political Department, expressing the desire of the Govt.
('18', 263, 7, 18, 552555) of India that the terms of Peace with Turkey or any item of news on the subject which is likely to cause excitement in
('18', 263, 8, 19, 552674) have received my assurances with incredulity.
('18', 263, 8, 20, 552720) I feel that I ought to place the very serious position before H. E. Is it not possible to make some definite reassuring pronouncement?
('18', 263, 8, 21, 552855) If the worst fears of the Mohammedans are realised, there can only be an armed peace in India, not a real peace.
('18', 263, 8, 22, 552968) I am sure that no Reforms, however generously granted, will ever reconcile the Mohammedans to any dismemberment of Turkey or an encroachment upon their holy places.
('18', 263, 8, 23, 553133) I know that all these matters cannot be out of H. E.s mind, but considering myself as I do to be a well wisher of the Empire, I shall be failing in my duty if I did not bring to H. E.s notice serious matters that come within my knowledge.
('18', 263, 8, 24, 553372) May I hope that, if it is at all possible, a statement will be made regarding Turkish matters. (S. N. 6777) 1 The date is derived from the addressees acknowledgement dated September 5, 1919.

('18', 264, 1, 3, 553704) of India for such publication.

('18', 264, 4, 13, 554512) 208. LETTER TO ABDUL AZIZ
('18', 264, 5, 14, 554538) BOMBAY, August 8, 1919
('18', 264, 6, 15, 554561) DEAR MR. ABDUL AZIZ, When Sir Narayan Chandavarkar 1 wrote his open letter to me and the Government expostulated with me upon the then proposed renewal of civil wrongly called passive resistance, I respectfully responded by suspension for the time being, and therefore did not attempt any other reply.
('18', 264, 6, 16, 554863) Your open letter 2 however raises fundamental issues and requires a detailed reply to the various objections to civil resistance discussed in it.
('18', 264, 6, 17, 555009) At the outset, I wish to thank you for your kindness in thinking of me.
('18', 264, 6, 18, 555081) You will be interested to know that I had stalwart Pathans from your district working with me as civil resisters during the eight long years of the struggle in South Africa.
('18', 264, 6, 19, 555255) One of them was working in a Natal mine.
('18', 264, 6, 20, 555296) He was severely beaten by his foreman apparently for no other cause then that he had joined the civil resistance movement.
('18', 264, 7, 21, 555419) 1 1825 1923; judge of the Bombay High Court 2 This was published in The pioneer, 27 7 1919; vide Appendix Letter from M. Abdul Aziz, 27 7 1919
('18', 265, 0, 1, 555562) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 265, 1, 2, 555604) Being under the pledge not to resist the wrongdoer and yet to disobey his will, he meekly suffered the punishment for disobedience.
('18', 265, 1, 3, 555736) He came to me and bared his striped back as he was saying, I have suffered this for the sake of my pledge and you.
('18', 265, 1, 4, 555851) I am a Pathan and the man who laid his cruel hands upon me would not have gone unscathed any other time. His suffering and that of thousands like him secured, among other things, repeal of the abominadble poll tax of 3 which our poor countrymen, their wives and the grown up children had to pay annually as the price of freedom for the principal member to reside in Natal without indenture.
('18', 265, 1, 5, 556242) You ask me to give up the idea that wrought the freedon of the dumb labourers of Natal.
('18', 265, 1, 6, 556330) You wish me to give up the idea that has made Islam a living faith among the great faiths of the world.
('18', 265, 1, 7, 556434) No evil followed my civil disobedience of the order of expulsion served upon me by the authorities in Champaran in 1917. I claim that my resistance laid the foundation for the partial awakening of the poor ryots of Champaran and the Government of Bihar.
('18', 265, 1, 8, 556688) How shall I give up an idea which I have treasured for the past forty years and which I have consciously enforced in my own life with no mean success for the last thirty years?
('18', 265, 1, 9, 556865) But you cite the awful experiences of April last.
('18', 265, 1, 10, 556915) Have you really analysed the situation?
('18', 265, 1, 11, 556955) The sixth of April was observed from Cape Comorin to Peshawar and from Karachi to Calcutta by millions of men, womon and children an event the like of which has not occurred within living memory.
('18', 265, 1, 12, 557151) I do not know what happened that day in Peshawar.
('18', 265, 1, 13, 557201) But I do know that it passed off peacefully in all the chief cities and in thousands of hamlets of India.
('18', 265, 1, 14, 557307) I suggest to you that it was a striking demonstration of the possibilities of civil resistance.
('18', 265, 1, 15, 557403) On the 6th, there was no civil resistance actually offered.
('18', 265, 1, 16, 557463) It was a preparation day.
('18', 265, 1, 17, 557489) Any other Government in the world would have recognized this incoming new force, would have courageously yielded to it and removed the causa causansthe Rowlatt Act.
('18', 265, 1, 18, 557654) But the Punjab Government went mad.
('18', 265, 1, 19, 557690) They dictated terms to the Government of India and the policy of ruthless repression was commenced.
('18', 265, 1, 20, 557790) Two leaders were interned and deported.
('18', 265, 1, 21, 557830) I was prevented from proceeding to what they knew was a mission of peace to Delhi and, if necessary, to the Punjab, arrested 1 and brought under arrest to Bombay and there
('18', 265, 2, 22, 558002) 1 The arrest took place near Delhi on April 9; Gandhiji was released at Bombay the following day.
('18', 266, 0, 1, 558100) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 267
('18', 266, 1, 2, 558145) set free.
('18', 266, 1, 3, 558155) And there was a conflagration.
('18', 266, 1, 4, 558186) I submit that if the Punjab Government had deliberately and with malice aforethought planned an insurrection in the Punjab, they could not have taken more effective steps to do so.
('18', 266, 1, 5, 558367) And yet such was the efficacy of satyagraha that the whole of India outside the Punjab and three centres in Gujarat remained partically calm in the midst of the gravest provocation.
('18', 266, 1, 6, 558549) I have admitted my mistake.
('18', 266, 1, 7, 558577) What was it?
('18', 266, 1, 8, 558590) I miscalculated the capacity of the people to stand any amount of suffering and provocation.
('18', 266, 1, 9, 558683) It was possible for the Punjab people to remain quiet in spite of the provocation offered by the arrests I have mentioned.
('18', 266, 1, 10, 558806) But what happened was beyond endurance.
('18', 266, 1, 11, 558846) The people of Amritsar could not restrain themselves and brook the deportation of their leaders.
('18', 266, 1, 12, 558943) Neither you nor I can apportion the blame for what followed.
('18', 266, 1, 13, 559004) Satyagraha apart, the question will have to be solved whether the people were provoked into madness by the firing or whether the military were provoked to action by the mob.
('18', 266, 1, 14, 559178) Be that, however, as it may, how can I abandon the idea of resuming civil resistance because people in April, in some parts of Hindustan, owing to special causes resorted to violence?
('18', 266, 1, 15, 559362) Must I cease to do right because some people are likely at the same time to do wrong?
('18', 266, 1, 16, 559448) I admit the the question is not quite so simple as I have put it.
('18', 266, 1, 17, 559514) All action is controlled by a complexity of circumstances some of which are under the doers control and the others beyond his control.
('18', 266, 1, 18, 559649) He can therefore restrain himself only till he has obtained the maximum of control over the surrounding circumstances, and then trust to the Almighty to see him through.
('18', 266, 1, 19, 559819) And that is exactly what I have done in suspending.
('18', 266, 1, 20, 559871) I have shown that civil resistance in diametrically opposed to criminal resistance, that it is perfectly compatible with co operation and respect for the Government.
('18', 266, 1, 21, 560037) You cite Peshawar to show, I suppose, that the people unthinkingly, or actuated by mischievous people, jointed the dem onstration of the 6th April.
('18', 266, 1, 22, 560185) They may have done so.
('18', 266, 1, 23, 560208) My reading of the events is different from yours.
('18', 266, 1, 24, 560258) Had ther been no Rowlatt legislation, there would have been no demonstration, and therfore no handle given to the mischievous elements.
('18', 266, 1, 25, 560394) The wrong consisted not in the organizing of the demonstration or civil resistnace, but in the Government so defying public opinion as to produce an agitation they had little anticipated.
('18', 266, 1, 26, 560582) Is not the moral obvious?
('18', 266, 1, 27, 560608) The Government must bow to the force of public opinion and retrace their steps.
('18', 266, 1, 28, 560688) Assuming that the
('18', 267, 0, 1, 560706) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 267, 1, 2, 560748) powers of the Rowlatt Act are necessary, they must patiently cultivate public opinion and adopt such means and powers that enlightened public opinion will tolerate.
('18', 267, 1, 3, 560913) As it is, they have ignored the advice of their friends and held them up to ridicule by showing their incapacity for influencing the Government on matters of moment.
('18', 267, 1, 4, 561079) In my humble opinion, your letters,open and private, and those of other leders, should be addressed to the Government, asking them to right the wrong, not to me, tempting me away from the path of duty.
('18', 267, 1, 5, 561281) I hope it is common cause between us that the Rowlatt Act which has roused such opposition and which has cost treasures of blood must be removed.
('18', 267, 1, 6, 561427) If you have a remedy other than civil resistance, by all means apply it, and if you are successful, civil resistance falls away automatically.
('18', 267, 1, 7, 561570) The period of suspension is the period during which you and all the leaders who dread or disapprove of civil resistance can work with all your might to bring about the desired result.
('18', 267, 2, 8, 561754) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI Young India, 9 8 1919
('18', 267, 3, 9, 561806) 209. LETTER TO H.S.L. POLAK
('18', 267, 4, 10, 561834) M.K. GANDHI ON THE WAY TO POONA, August 8 [1919] 1
('18', 267, 5, 11, 561885) MY DEAR HENRY,
('18', 267, 6, 12, 561900) I am on my way to Poona to deliver an address on the Transvaal question and chat with the moderate leaders on swadeshi.
('18', 267, 6, 13, 562020) I have your letter.
('18', 267, 6, 14, 562040) If you will read my reply to Arundale published in Young India 2 you will find in it my reasons for remaining in politics.
('18', 267, 6, 15, 562163) The more I observe and the longer I live, the more do I find that you cannot divide your energies into watertight compartments.
('18', 267, 6, 16, 562291) You deny religion when you plead on the ground of your exclusive religious nature inability to help, say, a man so unjustly treated as Kallenbach.
('18', 267, 6, 17, 562438) I say that you fulfil your religious mission only when you take part in and alleviate human sorrow as often as you see it and are able to share it.
('18', 267, 6, 18, 562586) I know that Rowlatt Act takes away manliness from a nation.
('18', 267, 6, 19, 562646) I know that I have the ability to do something to secure its repeal.
('18', 267, 6, 20, 562715) I must act.
('18', 267, 7, 21, 562727) 1 From the contents; vide Speech at Deccan Sabha, Poona, 8 8 1919 2 ibid
('18', 268, 0, 1, 562800) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 269
('18', 268, 1, 2, 562845) take so much part in politics as is necessary for the due fulfilment of my religion.
('18', 268, 1, 3, 562930) My sympathies go out to you in your trials there surrounded as you are by so many conflicting elements.
('18', 268, 1, 4, 563034) I know you will do the right thing.
('18', 268, 1, 5, 563070) In my opinion you are mistaken about my estimates of people.
('18', 268, 1, 6, 563131) But I need not discuss them.
('18', 268, 1, 7, 563160) I do hope you have received Manilal Vyass papers, i.e., Young India containing all the facts and argu ments.
('18', 268, 1, 8, 563269) The matter is still engaging the attention of the Government of Bombay.
('18', 268, 1, 9, 563341) The Punjab sentences are being materially reduced.
('18', 268, 1, 10, 563392) They produce in me no satisfaction.
('18', 268, 1, 11, 563428) It is like robbing a man of all his pro perty and giving him back portion of it.
('18', 268, 1, 12, 563509) Mr. Montagu is reported to have said that Rowlatt Act is necessary.
('18', 268, 1, 13, 563577) Well, as I can say is that civil disobedience is equally necessary in that event.
('18', 268, 1, 14, 563659) 1 It is an insolent declaration to make that an Act which has involved such brutality is necessary.
('18', 268, 1, 15, 563759) I hope you will raise a great agitation over it.
('18', 268, 1, 16, 563808) Anyway, you will presently see a great agitation here.
('18', 268, 1, 17, 563863) Jamnadas left on Wednesday last, the 6th of August for Chindwara.
('18', 268, 1, 18, 563929) He has his wife and two friends with him.
('18', 268, 1, 19, 563971) They will all live together for the time being.
('18', 268, 1, 20, 564019) You will please do the needful.
('18', 268, 1, 21, 564051) You and Millie will not fail to make Jamnadas feel at home in that big city of yours.
('18', 268, 1, 22, 564137) He will in the initial stages require all the warmth that love can give in that, to him as to many, lonely place.
('18', 268, 1, 23, 564251) You will find out when Chindwara reaches London.

('18', 268, 1, 27, 564490) They are giving much time to it.
('18', 268, 1, 28, 564523) Spinning is becoming fashionable.
('18', 268, 1, 29, 564557) I wish Millie will write to me something on it for publication if she has at all followed what I have been writing.
('18', 268, 1, 30, 564673) Did you ever receive my cablegrams about civil resistance?

('18', 269, 1, 2, 565025) 210. SPEECH AT DECCAN SABHA, POONA 1
('18', 269, 2, 3, 565062) Friday, August 8, 1919
('18', 269, 3, 4, 565085) Mr. Gandhi got up amidst loud cheers, and moved the following resolution : The public meeting of the citizens of Poona, held under the auspices of the Deccan Sabha, hereby places on record its deep sympathy with the Brithsh Indian settlers in Sough Africa struggling for the elementary rights of citizenship, congratulates them on the brave and sustained struggle carried on by them, and assures them of hearty support from the motherland.
('18', 269, 3, 5, 565525) This meeting further desires to thank the Government of India for their advocacy of the Indians case and trusts that the Government of India and the Imperial Government will not rest satisfied until full justice has been done to the British Indian settlers in South Africa by the withdrawal of the Act recently passed and by the restoration of full rights of residence, trade and ownership.
('18', 269, 3, 6, 565916) Mr. Gandhi, speaking in Hindi, told the audience that it was impossible for them to have an adequate idea as to how severely the recently passed iniquitous measure had affected the interests of the Indians in South Africa.
('18', 269, 3, 7, 566139) It was a subject worthy of their serious consideration and it was their duty to help their suffering countrymen in every way.
('18', 269, 3, 8, 566265) Mr. Gandhi said he had a telegram from Bombay informing him of Sir George Barnes letter to him wherein the latter promised that the Government of India would give careful consideration to all that Mr. Gandhi had to say and that they were already in communication with the secretary of state in the matter.
('18', 269, 3, 9, 566571) He said he was grateful to the Government of India for their sympathetic attiude.
('18', 269, 3, 10, 566653) The new law, Mr. Gandhi declared, robbed the Indians of their clementary rights such as those of being domiciled citizens of South Africa, trading as others did, holding landed property, etc.
('18', 269, 3, 11, 566845) He recalled a Poona meeting held in 1896 under the chairmanship of Dr. Sir Ramkrishna Gopal Bandarkar, to protest against a similarly iniquitous enactment.
('18', 269, 3, 12, 567001) 2 Dr. Bandarkar on the occasion said that he never took part in politics, nor did he ever desire to do so, but as he was assured that the Indians in the Transvaal were suffering intolerable wrong, he had decided to preside at the meeting with the greatest pleasure.
('18', 269, 3, 13, 567267) Poona, the speaker reminded the audience, was a great centre of political, social and educational movements and its contribution therfore in the agitation in question should be very substantial.
('18', 269, 3, 14, 567462) Mr. Gandhi then
('18', 269, 4, 15, 567478) 1 The Deccan Sabha, held a meeting of the citizens in Kirloskar Theatre to protest against the Transaal legislation.
('18', 269, 4, 16, 567595) In the absence of the President of the Sabha, Hormusjee Wadia, Rao Bahadur Khopkar, retired Deputy collectore and Vice President, presided.
('18', 269, 4, 17, 567735) 2 Vide Appeal for Funds, 3 2 1897
('18', 270, 0, 1, 567769) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 271
('18', 270, 1, 2, 567814) referred to the encomiums paid to India for her sacrifices in war by Gen.
('18', 270, 1, 3, 567888) Smuts, on leaving for South Africa, and said that Gen.
('18', 270, 1, 4, 567943) Smuts recommended in effect that India should be accorded a treatment of equality, and still it was the Union Government, of which he was a member, that was passing the obnoxious legisation.
('18', 270, 1, 5, 568134) The Indians in South Africa were not, Mr. Gandhi emphasized, asking for political rights from the Union Government, nor were they demanding the right to sit in the South African Parliament.
('18', 270, 1, 6, 568324) There was, again, no fear of unrestricted immigration into the country.
('18', 270, 1, 7, 568396) It was a thousand pities that the Transvaalers grudged the Indians even the simple rights to reside and trade, or the right to purchase land with money out of their own pockets.
('18', 270, 1, 8, 568574) Did it become then to deprive Indians of their bare elementary right or snatching from the Indians mouths their scanty morsel?
('18', 270, 1, 9, 568701) Mr. Gandhi told the audience that the Indians there had now resolved 1 to reply by asking for full civil rights and to resort to civil resistance until those rights were granted.
('18', 270, 1, 10, 568880) The Transvaalers sought by the new legislation to rob the Indians of rights of trading in the gold area that were expressly given them by a Supreme Court decision.
('18', 270, 1, 11, 569044) They maintained that the new legislation did recognize vested rights and even attributed to the speaker his having tacitly given his consent to the legislation.
('18', 270, 1, 12, 569205) It was, said Mrs. Gandhi, a downright lie.
('18', 270, 1, 13, 569248) But they did not rest satisfied with that legislation.
('18', 270, 1, 14, 569303) Some of them, said Mr. Gandhi, were then striving for excluding the Indians altogether, by asking them to restrict their trade and business to their own locationswhich the speaker likened to Maharwadas and Bhangiwadas 2 in Indian villages  i.e., by asking them to trade among themselves!
('18', 270, 1, 15, 569591) In conclusion, Mrs. Gandhi said that the time had come for Indians in South Africa to resort to the civil resistance that they resorted to some years ago, and which was approved of and blessed by the late Mrs. Gokhale.
('18', 270, 1, 16, 569810) 3 While the Indians there were on the threshold of such a crisis, it behoved them here to understand the question thoroughly it behoved the Maharashtra perople, more than others, as they were noted for their learning and studiousness, to give their serious study to the situation in South Africa and to strive by body, speech and mind to bring about a solution of the question.
('18', 270, 1, 17, 570188) The resolution was supported by Prof.
('18', 270, 1, 18, 570226) Kale 4, Mr. Bhopatkar 5 , Mr. Deodhar 6, and unanimously carried.
