('18', 271, 1, 2, 570918) 211. SPEECH AT GUJARATI BANDHU SABHA, POONA
('18', 271, 2, 3, 570962) [August 8, 1919]
('18', 271, 3, 4, 570979) These days the theme of my addresses is swadeshi.
('18', 271, 3, 5, 571029) I save time from other activities and give all of it to swadeshi.
('18', 271, 3, 6, 571095) It is through swadeshi that we shall get swaraj.
('18', 271, 3, 7, 571144) When I spoke on Swadeshi and Swaraj at Surat, 1 it occurred to me that I shold explain to the people how swadeshi would cover all that I had at heart.
('18', 271, 3, 8, 571295) At the present time, I want to propagate this idea and it is my hope that, in a few days or maybe months, everyone in India, from the Viceroy down to this sweeper, will realize that swadeshi can bring swaraj.
('18', 271, 3, 9, 571504) To this end, it is imperative that the ideal of swadeshi should be kept pure; it is so great a thing that it should not be debased.
('18', 271, 3, 10, 571636) India is suffering at present from afflictions of three kinds: 1. DISEASE : At no time in the past were the people of India afflicted with so many diseases as at present.
('18', 271, 3, 11, 571807) The number of people rotting with disease in this country is greater than that in all the rest of the world.
('18', 271, 3, 12, 571916) 2. HUNGER : The simple fact borne out by experience during the past few years is that a large section of the Indian people do not have enough to eat.
('18', 271, 3, 13, 572066) Sir William Wilson Hunter said categorically forty years ago that three crores in India got only one meal a day, and that too consisting of no more than plain bread and salt.
('18', 271, 3, 14, 572241) More than this, they got no ghee, oil or chillies.
('18', 271, 3, 15, 572292) This was our misfortune forty years ago.
('18', 271, 3, 16, 572333) Every official has been obliged to admit in the blue books that Indias poverty is increasing day by day, and the cultivators lot, especially, is the worst, as they alone know who move in villages.
('18', 271, 3, 17, 572530) If you inquire of the people in Gujarat, you will know what great difficulty they experience in getting milk.
('18', 271, 3, 18, 572640) They are hard put to it to get milk even for an infant six months old.
('18', 271, 3, 19, 572711) Whenever I questioned the people in the villages around Ahmedabad, I was told that, let alone themselves, even their children could get no milk.
('18', 271, 3, 20, 572856) You will see from this that our present plight is much worse than it was forty years ago.
('18', 271, 4, 21, 572946) 1 Vide Speech at inaguration of swadeshi store, surat, 28 7 1919
('18', 272, 0, 1, 573011) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 273
('18', 272, 1, 2, 573056) 3. INSUFFICIENT COVERING FOR THE BODY : At present India is also afficited with a cloth famine.
('18', 272, 1, 3, 573152) According to Sir Dinshaw Wachas 1
('18', 272, 2, 4, 573186) estimate, four years ago people in India got 13 yards of cloth per head, whereas now they get only 9. That is, there has been a reduction of four yards per head and to that extent our poverty has increased.
('18', 272, 2, 5, 573393) When I was working in Champaran two yeras ago, I had personal experience of women protesting to me, without mincing words, that they did not have even a piece of cloth with which to cover their bare limbs; how, then, [they asked,] could they bathe and wash to keep themselves clean?
('18', 272, 2, 6, 573676) My heart bled to see our pure hearted sisters in such a pitiable condition.
('18', 272, 2, 7, 573752) A land afflicted with this triple disease loses the qualities of courage, fortitude and truthfulness.
('18', 272, 2, 8, 573854) The people of such a country have no dharma in them and I would even employ the term unmanly to describe them.
('18', 272, 2, 9, 573965) Here in India, too, we have been using this term these days.
('18', 272, 3, 10, 574026) When, with this idea in mind, I questioned people, one reply I got was that dharma should be restored.
('18', 272, 3, 11, 574129) No doubt we have lost our dharma, but, in the present circumstances, restoring it is quite a difficult job, for it is extraordinarily difficult for a man in utter misery to follow dharma.
('18', 272, 3, 12, 574317) Only a rare soul can do so.
('18', 272, 3, 13, 574345) I call such persons yogis.
('18', 272, 3, 14, 574372) Not all people, however, can become yogis.
('18', 272, 3, 15, 574415) And thus, for the purity of the atman, purity of the body is also essentral.
('18', 272, 3, 16, 574492) A pure atman can dwell only in a pure body. In order to revive the qualities of courage, and so on, this triple affliction should be got rid of.
('18', 272, 3, 17, 574637) A man who follows dharma in the midst of such suffering I would call a yogi.
('18', 272, 4, 18, 574714) For curing the disease, a bold effort, requiring knowledge, is called for.
('18', 272, 4, 19, 574789) We shall have to sacrifice our time to save people afflicted with such diseases.
('18', 272, 4, 20, 574870) We should first ascertain whether people go hungry because of their lethargy or because of want.
('18', 272, 4, 21, 574967) Of food, there is plenty in India; the hungry should have it.
('18', 272, 4, 22, 575029) But they need money with which to buy it, and it is for want of money that India is poor.
('18', 272, 4, 23, 575119) Swadeshi is needed to fight this state of affairs.
('18', 272, 4, 24, 575170) By swadeshi we mean protecting our cotton and silk.
('18', 272, 4, 25, 575222) This is my restricted definition of swadeshi in the circumstances which obtain today.
('18', 272, 4, 26, 575308) Last year, we
('18', 272, 5, 27, 575322) 1 Sir Dinshaw Edulji Wacha (1844 1936); prominent Indian Parsi politcian; President, the Indian National Congress, 1901
('18', 273, 0, 1, 575442) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 273, 1, 2, 575484) paid to foreign countries 56 crores of rupees for cotton goods and four for silk goods.
('18', 273, 1, 3, 575572) The revered Dadabhai Naoroji used to say that India was being drained of the funds.
('18', 273, 1, 4, 575656) It is true that a good deal of this money is spent on the military department and in paying pensions; personally, however, I would say that in no other way is so much money drained as on account of the absence of swadeshi.
('18', 273, 1, 5, 575879) Eighteen crores were paid last year for sugar.
('18', 273, 1, 6, 575926) There is much drain in other ways which I do not care to mention at the moment.
('18', 273, 1, 7, 576006) I want to get hold of the trunk and once that is done the drain in other ways will stop by itself.
('18', 273, 1, 8, 576105) Our first duty then, in the present circumstances, is to follow swadeshi in its restricted meaning; to this end, the three vows which I have given should be kept.
('18', 273, 1, 9, 576268) Get control of the trade in yarn and you will get the rest easily enough.
('18', 273, 1, 10, 576342) We are unable today to produce sufficient cloth to meet our needs.
('18', 273, 1, 11, 576409) Our mills cannot supply as much.
('18', 273, 1, 12, 576442) We should take steps so that India is enabled to produce things which she does not do at present; this is one problem.
('18', 273, 1, 13, 576561) I am at present discussing this problem with mill owners and, in the course of our conversation, Sir Fazalbhai Karimbhai told me that it would take fifty years still before the mills could supply cloth in the required quantity.
('18', 273, 1, 14, 576789) Should we then wait for fifty years?
('18', 273, 1, 15, 576826) We see from the report of the Industrial Commssion that in the country one third the quantity of cloth can be produced through hand weaving and that, if this industry is developed, things will become easier for us.
('18', 273, 1, 16, 577041) Mills require machinery and for this we are dependent on others.
('18', 273, 1, 17, 577106) Foreign countries do not have all that machinery to spare.
('18', 273, 1, 18, 577165) Some say that it takes a mill one year to obtain one machine and installing it presents much difficulty.
('18', 273, 1, 19, 577270) Having regard to all these obstacles, hand weaving seems very easy, for it does not require all this effort.
('18', 273, 1, 20, 577379) A man of average ability can learn the work in six months time and one with some intelligence can pick it up in three months.
('18', 273, 1, 21, 577505) The method of making yarn is altogether simple.
('18', 273, 1, 22, 577553) I took not more than 15 days to learn it.
('18', 273, 1, 23, 577595) A hundred and fifty years ago, we ourselves produced [our cloth].
('18', 273, 1, 24, 577661) Every mother in India did the work for the love of God.
('18', 273, 1, 25, 577717) Traces of this age old desire of the Indian woman for spinning are still visible.
('18', 273, 1, 26, 577799) When recently, I went to Vijapur and Kalol, I met nearly 20,000 men and women.
('18', 273, 1, 27, 577878) In the talks we had, the women told me that this was a good experiment, and an easy one.
('18', 273, 1, 28, 577967) If they were provided with a spinning wheel [they said] they too would work.
('18', 273, 1, 29, 578044) At present, a hundred and fifty women in Vijapur spin half a maund of cotton daily and, if supplied with cotton, four hundred women are ready to
('18', 274, 0, 1, 578189) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 275
('18', 274, 1, 2, 578234) The women at Kalol give the same reply.
('18', 274, 1, 3, 578274) My dear friend Mr. Chettiar came to see me from Madras.
('18', 274, 1, 4, 578330) When I saw that Mrs. Chettiar had also come, I told Mrs. Chettiar that I would detain her for eight days, for it would be quite a good thing if she learned spinning before she left.
('18', 274, 1, 5, 578512) She accepted my suggestion immediately and left after she had learnt the work.
('18', 274, 1, 6, 578591) She accepted it not because of her regard for me personally but because she loved the work.
('18', 274, 1, 7, 578683) This shows that spinning is a hereditary activity with us.
('18', 274, 1, 8, 578742) Those who read Darwin understand the theory of heredity.
('18', 274, 1, 9, 578799) If we refuse to take up this work, we shall lose this inheritance.
('18', 274, 1, 10, 578866) I appeal to you not to give up faith.
('18', 274, 1, 11, 578904) If we but try, a favourable environment will be created and we shall get back the inheritance we have disowned.
('18', 274, 1, 12, 579016) Principal Paranjapye 1 said that we would fail in the competition with the rest of the world.
('18', 274, 1, 13, 579110) But there is no question of competition in this.
('18', 274, 1, 14, 579159) This is a question, rather, of the economic freedom of peasants and of the poor.
('18', 274, 1, 15, 579240) The farmer is the father of the world.
('18', 274, 1, 16, 579279) Take the example of America or Japan.
('18', 274, 1, 17, 579317) They help the cultivator there.
('18', 274, 1, 18, 579349) Our Governor, too, is anxious [to know] how the cultivator may be helped.
('18', 274, 1, 19, 579423) The problem can be solved in accordance with the principle of economics.
('18', 274, 1, 20, 579496) It is my advice to young people to take up this work.
('18', 274, 1, 21, 579550) It is easy enough and requries no special effort, nor does it require much intelligence.
('18', 274, 1, 22, 579639) All that is necessary is some experience.
('18', 274, 1, 23, 579681) One enjoys greater freedom through this work.
('18', 274, 1, 24, 579727) The man who spins earns three annas daily, but the man who weaves earns eight annas.
('18', 274, 1, 25, 579812) Talking to the weavers of Madanwadi in Bombay, I came to know that many of them earned as much as one rupee, even two rupees, daily.
('18', 274, 1, 26, 579945) This industry is useful to us.
('18', 274, 1, 27, 579976) It should be widely popularized.
('18', 274, 1, 28, 580009) Even the educated class shuld learn a little of the craft.
('18', 274, 1, 29, 580068) In the same way as every boy in England knows some naval work, we should all learn this work.
('18', 274, 1, 30, 580162) If, thus, India understands this mantra 2 and starts working as a matter of religious duty, the countrys economic condition will improve and hunger and disease will disappear from our midst.
('18', 274, 1, 31, 580353) Since you understand the idea, it is my prayer that you will put it into practice.
('18', 274, 1, 32, 580436) [From Gujarati] Indian Opionion, 10 10 1919
('18', 274, 2, 33, 580480) 1 R. P. Paranjapye, Principal, Fergusson College, Poona 2 Magic formula, but here message
('18', 275, 0, 1, 580570) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 275, 1, 2, 580612) 212. THE ROWLATT ACT
('18', 275, 2, 3, 580633) Mr. Montagu has spoken.
('18', 275, 2, 4, 580657) He believes that the powers given to the executive by the Rowaltt Act are necessary.
('18', 275, 2, 5, 580742) And many friends ask whether, in view of this statement, the Act will be repealed.
('18', 275, 2, 6, 580825) My answer is that the Rowlatt Act will be repealed in the same manner as Mrs. Morleys Settled factthe Bengal Partition 1 was unsettled.
('18', 275, 2, 7, 580961) General Smuts had emphatically declared more than once that the Asiatic Regisration Act 2 would never be repealed.
('18', 275, 2, 8, 581076) It had to go in the year 1914. Whilst, therefore, I am certain that the Rowlatt Act will go because of my belief in the power of suffering, i.e., civil resistance, to overcome mountains, I cannot help feeling sad that even Mr. Montagu should have to support what is clearly insupportable, alike from the view of the evil in it and for the reason that public opionion hascondemned it in unmeasured terms.
('18', 275, 2, 9, 581480) Mrs. Montagu has to resort to bad logic and distortion of facts to sustain his position.
('18', 275, 2, 10, 581569) Surely the powers given to the executive are not necessary at present, for the simple reason that the Defence of India Act is still in operation and will be for some months to come.
('18', 275, 2, 11, 581751) And if the powers are really necessary, they can be given in another and less offensive and more restricted manner.
('18', 275, 2, 12, 581867) Mr. Montagu is the joint author with Lord Chelmsford of the reforms scheme such as it is.
('18', 275, 2, 13, 581957) It lies ill in his mouth to defend a measure which can only neutralize what good the reforms may be intended to produce.
('18', 275, 2, 14, 582078) But the purpose of writing this is not to argue about the untenability of the position taken up by Mrs. Montagu.
('18', 275, 2, 15, 582191) My purpose is to show that if the Rowaltt Act is to be persisted in, the Government must prepare for civil resistance which shall be perfectly respectful but which shall be unbending.
('18', 275, 2, 16, 582375) The issue is remarkably simple : Is the will of the people to prevail or that of the Government?
('18', 275, 2, 17, 582472) I venture to urge that a government, be it ever so powerful and autocratic, is bound to yield to unanimous public opinion.
('18', 275, 2, 18, 582595) It is a bad outlook before us if truth and justice have to surrender to mere physical force, whether it is wielded by an individual or a government.
('18', 275, 2, 19, 582744) My purpose in life is to demonstrate that the strongest physical force bends before moral
('18', 275, 3, 20, 582834) 1 Bengal was partitioned in 1905. Intense public agitation, involving boycott of British goods, ultimately led to the annulment of the Bengal Partition in 1911. 2 Vide Appendix Asiatics Registration Amendment Act (1908).
('18', 276, 0, 1, 583055) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 277
('18', 276, 1, 2, 583100) force when it is used in defence of truth.
('18', 276, 1, 3, 583143) If violence had not been offered by the people in April, notwithstanding provocation, the Rowlatt Act would have been withdrawn by now, as certainly as that I am penning these remarks.
('18', 276, 1, 4, 583328) I still hope that Mr. Montagu, Lord Chelmsford and those who have the power, will perceive that true prestige lies in doing justice and respecting public opinion.
('18', 276, 1, 5, 583491) But it may happen that they will think otherwise.
('18', 276, 1, 6, 583541) In that event, I would like those who are interested in the speedy success of civil resistance to prepare the atmosphere for its smooth working.
('18', 276, 1, 7, 583686) It will be a great trial of strength if we must engage in it.
('18', 276, 1, 8, 583748) But the result is a certainty.
('18', 276, 1, 9, 583779) That is the matchless beauty of civil resistance.
('18', 276, 1, 10, 583829) A people that has no remedy in the last resort for securing redress perishes.
('18', 276, 1, 11, 583907) The surest and the safest remedy is civil resistnace.
('18', 276, 1, 12, 583961) Europe furnishes a living warning against the method of violence.
('18', 276, 1, 13, 584027) Peace has brought no rest to that continent.
('18', 276, 1, 14, 584072) Wherever you look, there are strikes, there is violence and looting.
('18', 276, 1, 15, 584141) England, the greatest perhaps of all the victors, is not free from turmoil.
('18', 276, 1, 16, 584217) Victory has brought no satisfaction to the great mass of the people.
('18', 276, 1, 17, 584286) India has her choice between the broken reed of violence and the unbreakable, peaceful and elevating weapon of civil resistance, i.e., resistance by self suffering.
('18', 276, 1, 18, 584451) Young India, 9 8 1919

('18', 278, 1, 2, 586975) 216. LETTER TO THE PRESS 1
('18', 278, 2, 3, 587002) [POONA, August 13, 1919]
('18', 278, 3, 4, 587027) I have just received the following cablegram from Mr. Ibrahim Ismail Aswat, Chairman of the British Indian Association, Johann esburg :
('18', 278, 4, 5, 587163) Bill assented 23rd June, promulgated 3rd instant.
('18', 278, 4, 6, 587213) Restricts compaines acquiring further fixed properties and holding bonds as prior to company law.
('18', 278, 4, 7, 587311) Reaffirms Gold and Townships Acts operating on new licences after 1st May and restricting present traders and successors to particular townships.
('18', 278, 4, 8, 587457) Deputation waiting His Excellency urging withhold assent on ground class legislation.
('18', 278, 4, 9, 587543) Government promised another commission during recess investigate Indian question throughout Union as concession (to) the detractors in Parliament.
('18', 278, 4, 10, 587690) Fear futher restrictive legislation.
('18', 278, 4, 11, 587727) Community request you appeal Viceroy propose Royal Commission India representing Union (local) Indian (interests).
('18', 278, 4, 12, 587842) Convened Union Indian Conference 4th August, great success.
('18', 278, 4, 13, 587902) Decided united action.
('18', 278, 4, 14, 587925) Many of (the) associations pledged resist any cost.
('18', 278, 4, 15, 587977) The words in parentheses have been added by me to make the meaning clear.
('18', 278, 4, 16, 588051) The cablegram bears out what I have said in my letter to Sir George Barnes and what I have said in my letter to Sir George Barnes and what I said at the recent meeting at Poona.
('18', 278, 4, 17, 588229) 2 The restrictions are clear: (1) no further holding of landed property in the Transvaal; (2) no new trade licences within the area affected by the Gold Law and the Townships Act; (3) the present holders and their successors in title to be restricted as to trade to the townships in which they are now trading.
('18', 278, 4, 18, 588540) As I have already remarked, this means virtual ruin of the Indian settlers in the Transvaal.
('18', 278, 4, 19, 588633) The only means of livelihood to the largest number is trade, and the largest number of Indians is to be found probably within the gold area.
('18', 278, 4, 20, 588774) If the Act stands, they must die out in the natural course.
('18', 278, 5, 21, 588834) 1 This was published also in The Bombay Chronicle, 14 8 1919, and The Indian Review, August 1919. 2 Vide Speech at Deccan Sabha, Poona, 8 8 1919.
('18', 279, 0, 1, 588980) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 279, 1, 2, 589022) In the cablegram, the word assent occurs twice.
('18', 279, 1, 3, 589070) It says the Bill has been assented to and it refers to a deputation that is to wait on H. E. the Governor General of South Africa requesting him to withhold assent.
('18', 279, 1, 4, 589235) The second use of the word assent refers probably to a clause in the Letters Patent providing for the vetoing of class legislation.
('18', 279, 1, 5, 589367) The clause is undoubtedly to be used under exceptional circumstances.
('18', 279, 1, 6, 589437) No one can deny that the Asiatics Act constitutes a very exceptional circumstance warranting the exrcise of the Royal veto.
('18', 279, 1, 7, 589561) The most important part of the cablegram, however, is the fact that the commission promised by the Union Government is to be appointed as a concession to the detractors of Indians in the Union Parliament.
('18', 279, 1, 8, 589766) Unless, therefore, the Government of India take care, there is every likelihood of the commission, like the committee of the South African Assembly, proving to the British Indians a curse instead of a blessing.
('18', 279, 1, 9, 589977) It is, therefore, not unnatural that the British Indian Association urges that H. E. the Viceroy should propose a Royal Commission upon which both the Union and the Indian interests are represented.
('18', 279, 1, 10, 590176) Nothing can be fairer than the proposal made by Mr. Aswat.
('18', 279, 1, 11, 590235) I say so becasue, as a matter of right, no commission is really needed to decide that Indian settlers are entitled to trade in South Africa where they like and hold landed property on the same terms as the European settlers.
('18', 279, 1, 12, 590460) This is the minimum they can claim.
('18', 279, 1, 13, 590496) But under the complex constitution of this great Empire, justice is and has often to be done in a round about manner.
('18', 279, 1, 14, 590614) A wise captain, instead of sailing against a headwind, tacks and yet reaches his destination sooner than he otherwise would have.
('18', 279, 1, 15, 590744) Even so, Mr. Aswat wisely accepts the principle of a commission on a matter that is self evident, but equally wisely wants a commission that would not prove abrotive and that will dare to tell the ruling race in South Africa that, as members in an Empire which has more Coloured people than white, they may not treat their Indian fellow subjects as helots.
('18', 279, 1, 16, 591101) Whether the above proposal is accepted or some other is adopted by the Imperial Government, it must be made clear to them that public opinion in India will not tolerate confiscation of the primary rights of the British Indian settlers in South Africa.
('18', 279, 1, 17, 591353) M. K. GANDHI Young India, 16 8 1919
('18', 280, 0, 1, 591389) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 281

('18', 281, 1, 2, 593447) 219. SPEECH AT WOMENS MEETING, GODHRA
('18', 281, 2, 3, 593485) August 14, 1919
('18', 281, 3, 4, 593501) The womens meeting came off at 4 p.m.
('18', 281, 3, 5, 593539) Over one thousand women must have been present at the meeting.
('18', 281, 3, 6, 593602) Mrs. Jerbanu Merwanji Kothawala, the accomplished wife of Khan Saheb Kothawala, presided.
('18', 281, 3, 7, 593692) The following is the precis of Mr. Gandhis address to the ladies :
('18', 281, 4, 8, 593759) Mr. Gandhi said he was grateful to Mrs. Clayton for her presence at the gathering and he was sure he had his audience with him in expressing the sentiment.
('18', 281, 4, 9, 593915) After briefly introducting Mrs. Clayton to the ladies persent, the speaker said swadeshi was that spirit in them which required them to serve their immediate neighbours before others and to use things produced in their neighbourhood in preference to those more remote.
('18', 281, 4, 10, 594184) So doing, they served humanity to the best of their capacity.
('18', 281, 4, 11, 594246) They could not serve humanity neglecting their neighbours.
('18', 281, 4, 12, 594305) Similarly with their wants.
('18', 281, 4, 13, 594333) They were bound to supply them through the agency of their neighbours and therefore preferred their labour and wares to those of others.
('18', 281, 4, 14, 594470) India abandoned swadeshi a hundred years ago and had consequently become comparatively poor and helpless.
('18', 281, 4, 15, 594576) They were well able to supply all their cloth and to supply the worlds market to a certain extent when they were observing the law of swadeshi.
('18', 281, 4, 16, 594720) During that period, the majority of the women of India spun yarn as a national duty and the men wove the yarn so spun.
('18', 281, 4, 17, 594839) Now the 21 crore peasants of India had at least four months out of the year thrown on their hands.
('18', 281, 4, 18, 594938) They did not shirk work.
('18', 281, 4, 19, 594963) They had none to occupy their time and to supplement their earnings from cultivation.
('18', 281, 4, 20, 595049) Swadeshi therefore was a question of finding a subsidiary industry for their farmers.
('18', 281, 4, 21, 595135) No country in the world could prosper that had one third of time of the vast majority of its inhabitants lying unutilized.
('18', 281, 4, 22, 595258) Moreover, there were other men and women who had many hours in the day at their disposal.
('18', 281, 4, 23, 595348) If these idle hours of the nation were fully occupied in producing yarn and weaving it, they could manufacture the whole of their cloth and thus save crores of rupees going out of the country every year.
('18', 281, 4, 24, 595552) The condition of success was that cultured men and women took up spining and weaving.
('18', 281, 4, 25, 595638) The poorer people would follow their example.
('18', 281, 4, 26, 595684) Lady Dorab Tata, Lady Petit and Mrs. Jayji Petit had promised to learn the art of spinning and introduce it to their sisters Mrs. Ramabai Ranade proposed to introduce the music of the spinning wheel in her Seva Sadan.
('18', 281, 4, 27, 595902) Mrs. Banker worked six hours a day and produced fine yarn and made of it a gift to the nation.
('18', 281, 4, 28, 595997) They could expect no less from the sisters of Godhra.
('18', 281, 4, 29, 596051) Mr. Gandhi did not hesitate to recommend it to his European friends.
('18', 281, 4, 30, 596120) One such sister had already undertaken to work.
('18', 281, 4, 31, 596168) He hoped that those who did not need pecuniary assistance would make it a point of honour to give at least one hour a day to the nation for producing
('18', 282, 0, 1, 596318) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 283
('18', 282, 1, 2, 596363) As an encouragement in this direction, he called upon his hearers to pledge themselves henceforth not to buy foreign cloth.
('18', 282, 1, 3, 596487) Every village of Indian would thus become self supporting and self producing, so far as the two main wants of lifefood and clothingwere concerned.
('18', 282, 2, 4, 596634) The chairwoman exhorted the ladies present to help the movement in the direction Mr. Gandhi indicated.
('18', 282, 2, 5, 596737) Mrs. Clayton said she was glad she was able to be present at the meeting.
('18', 282, 2, 6, 596811) She always was in favour of home industries.
('18', 282, 3, 7, 596856) Young India, 20 8 1919
('18', 282, 4, 8, 596879) 220. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, GODHRA
('18', 282, 5, 9, 596917) August 14, 1919
('18', 282, 6, 10, 596933) The womens meeing 1 was followed by a brief recess.
('18', 282, 7, 11, 596985) The Vanita Vishram was visited at 6.30 p.m.
('18', 282, 7, 12, 597029) The public meeting came off at 9.15 p.m.
('18', 282, 7, 13, 597070) There was a very large audience.
('18', 282, 7, 14, 597103) It was held in open air.
('18', 282, 7, 15, 597128) Mr. Gandhis address dealt with the religious and the economic aspect.
('18', 282, 8, 16, 597198) At the outset, he said he was deeply grateful to Mrs. Clayton for president at the meeting.
('18', 282, 8, 17, 597290) He knew and appreciated the condition under which he had accepted the invitation of the organizers.
('18', 282, 8, 18, 597390) And he would endeavour faithfully to carry out the compact.
('18', 282, 8, 19, 597450) To him the economic and the religious aspects of swadeshi were far more attractive than the political, and as it was his dream that all, from the Viceroy down to the sweeper, should accept swadeshi, he was desirous of conducting swadeshi propaganda from the economic and religious standpoints.
('18', 282, 8, 20, 597744) He was thankful too that Mrs. Clayton had permitted the officials to be present at the meeting.
('18', 282, 8, 21, 597840) To him the religious aspect was all sufficient.
('18', 282, 8, 22, 597888) That elementary religion which was common to mankind taught him to be kind and attentive to their neighbours.
('18', 282, 8, 23, 597998) An individuals service to his country and humanity consisted in serving his neighbours.
('18', 282, 8, 24, 598086) If that was true, it was their religious duty to support their farmers, their artisans, such as weavers, carpenters, etc.
('18', 282, 8, 25, 598208) And so long as the Godhra farmers and weavers could supply the wants of the Godhra citizens, the latter had no right to go outside Godhra and support even (say) the Bombay farmers and weavers.
('18', 282, 8, 26, 598401) He could not starve his neighbour and claim to serve his distant cousin in the North Pole.
('18', 282, 8, 27, 598492) This was the basic principle of all religions and they would find it was also of true and humane economics.
('18', 282, 8, 28, 598600) India was suffering from a triple curse, the curse of diseasedisease not of a normal but of an abnormal kind, the curse of want of food, and, lastly, that of want of clothing.
('18', 282, 8, 29, 598776) All proceeded largely from the same causepoverty, and poverty was due largely to the economic drain.
('18', 282, 8, 30, 598877) They gave to the producers outside India in
('18', 282, 9, 31, 598921) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('18', 283, 0, 1, 598948) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 283, 1, 2, 598990) 1917 18 the enormous sum of sixty crores of rupees.
('18', 283, 1, 3, 599042) And they had not in any measure worthy of consideration provided the millions of our spinners and weavers with any other occupation.
('18', 283, 1, 4, 599175) The whole of the labour thus unwillingly set free was running to waste like a mightly torrent of water.
('18', 283, 1, 5, 599279) The evil could only be corrected by their reversion to swadeshi and by rehabilitating their spinners and weavers in their former honourable occupation.
('18', 283, 1, 6, 599431) He sought, in this gigantic task, the help of the officials, the millionaires and the other leaders of society.
('18', 283, 1, 7, 599543) It was the most urgent need of the country.
('18', 283, 1, 8, 599587) They had twenty one crore farmers.
('18', 283, 1, 9, 599622) His own experience and the experience of authoritative writers showed that they had nearly four months of the year lying idle on their hands.
('18', 283, 1, 10, 599764) This was a huge economic waste.
('18', 283, 1, 11, 599796) No wonder that they were poor.
('18', 283, 1, 12, 599827) Swadeshi therefore was the problem of inducing and enabling the farmers to take up the supplementary industry of spinning and weaving.
('18', 283, 1, 13, 599962) Their shastras and the history of spinning and weaving throughout the world showed that the queens down to their maids considered it an honour to spin cotton.
('18', 283, 1, 14, 600121) Weaving was largely specialized.
('18', 283, 1, 15, 600154) In those halcyon days when their mothers spun for the nation, they were able to produce the finest muslin.
('18', 283, 1, 16, 600261) They could still regain the lost art and with it the lost prosperity.
('18', 283, 1, 17, 600331) But one thing was needful for the people: to insist on getting only swadeshi cloth and on producing it themselves, as far as possible.
('18', 283, 1, 18, 600466) In the Punjab, thousands of women of high birth spun their own yarn and got it woven by professional weavers.
('18', 283, 1, 19, 600576) The swadeshi vows were designed to create a taste for swadeshi.
('18', 283, 1, 20, 600640) They must not be ashamed of coarse cloth.
('18', 283, 1, 21, 600682) As a matter of fact, there was more art about hand spun and hand woven cloth, however coarse, than about machine made cloth, however fine.
('18', 283, 1, 22, 600821) But art apart, they were bound by every tie of honour, every consideration of prudence and economics, to wear what cloth every village could produce and be satisfied with it, till their skill, industry and enterprise could produce a better quality.
('18', 283, 2, 23, 601070) At the close of the proceedings, the chairman said he was glad to be able to preside at the meeting.
('18', 283, 2, 24, 601171) He thanked Mr. Gandhi for his instructive address and exhorted the audience to support home manufacture.
('18', 283, 2, 25, 601276) A vote of thanks to their chair brought the meeting to a close.

('18', 283, 3, 27, 601363) 221. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, GODHRA
('18', 283, 4, 28, 601401) August 15, 1919
('18', 283, 5, 29, 601417) Mr. Gandhi then addressed a crowded meeting of the public on the situation in the Punjab.
('18', 283, 5, 30, 601507) He briefly reviewed the events of April last and said that it would be a blot upon British justice if the sentences and convictions, many of which he believed were bad, were not reversed.
('18', 283, 5, 31, 601695) It would be a greater blot on their patriotism if they did not insist upon an impartial investigation of the whole of the proceedings in the Punjab.

('18', 284, 1, 4, 602306) Young India, 20 8 1919
('18', 284, 2, 5, 602329) 222. SIR SANKARAN NAIR AND GOVERNMENT
('18', 284, 3, 6, 602367) It is difficult to understand what possessed his fellow member of the Viceregal Executive Council to attempt a refutation of Sir Sankaran Nairs irrefutable notes on Kaira and Champaran.
('18', 284, 3, 7, 602553) They have exposed nothing but their own incapacity to understand or appreciate their colleagues view point.
('18', 284, 3, 8, 602661) By their reply to Sir Sankarans notes, they have demonstrated the wooden nature of the bureaucratic system.
('18', 284, 3, 9, 602769) In trying to discredit Sir Sankaran Nair, they have evoked from him crushing rejoinders and still further discredited themselves.
('18', 284, 3, 10, 602899) If I have understood him rightly, Sir Sankaran Nair successfully endeavoured to prove the inelasticity of the present system and to answer the charge that the Congress or the educated Indians did not represent or care for the interests of the masses.
('18', 284, 3, 11, 603150) Let me take the Kaira affair.
('18', 284, 3, 12, 603180) I propose to deal with the note 1
('18', 284, 4, 13, 603214) from the Bombay Government.
('18', 284, 5, 14, 603242) The Governor in Council considers that the account given by Sir C. Sankaran Nair is so misleading that some authoritative correction of the views therein conveyed is essential before communication to the Secretary of State or Parliament.
('18', 284, 5, 15, 603480) They set about the work by sympathizing with Sir Sankaran over the difficulties of dealing with so complex and specialized a subject as the Land Revenue system.
('18', 284, 5, 16, 603641) I respectfully submit that this is a highly misleading statement.
('18', 284, 5, 17, 603707) There is nothing complex and specialized about the Land Revenue system except in so far as the administrators have made it so.
('18', 284, 5, 18, 603834) Sir Sankaran has left the complexity and specialization to the specialists and merely dealt with the main principles which even a layman can easily understand.
('18', 284, 5, 19, 603994) I had to undergo the torture of going through the bewildering Revenue Rules and their amendments made from time to time, which, I would full grant, can only be remembered and recalled, as occasion may require,
('18', 284, 6, 20, 604204) 1 Vide Appendix Note on the Kaira Case,12 8 1919
('18', 285, 0, 1, 604253) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 285, 1, 2, 604295) by specialists.
('18', 285, 1, 3, 604311) But those rules are really devised not for the relief of distress but for ensuring a scientific, rigorous and regular collection of land tax levied almost to the highest margin.
('18', 285, 1, 4, 604489) And I would freely admit further that it will tax even the great ability of Sir Sankaran Nair if he had to find out how best to collect revenue from cultivators who can ill afford to pay.
('18', 285, 1, 5, 604677) But not much ability was required to understand the simple problem whether there was failure of crops in Kaira in the year 1917, and whether the damage done by the excessive rains was such as to entitle the ryots to relief by way of suspension.
('18', 285, 1, 6, 604922) The Bombay Governments note frightens the laymen .
('18', 285, 1, 7, 604973) and in this category must be classed the Secretary of State and the Parliament by authoritatively saying that the resolution submitted to the Legislative Council and referred to by Sir Sankaran was thoroughly impracticable.
('18', 285, 1, 8, 605197) The impracticability consisted in the Honble Mr. Kamat proposing that the expert agency of the agricultural department should find the anna valuation.
('18', 285, 1, 9, 605348) The Government ask the reader on their mere ipse dixit to consider this very practicable suggestion as thoroughly impracticable.
('18', 285, 1, 10, 605477) The Honble Mr. Kamat suggested a comparatively independentthough still Government agency, to do the work instead of an interested Government agency, viz., the circle inspectors, and other officials in the lower ranks whose very promotion depends upon their ability to make full collection of the revenue even by coercive measures.
('18', 285, 1, 11, 605808) In further proof of Sir Sankaran Nairs misconception of fact and policy, the Government criticize his acceptance of my testimony based on the mere statement of interested cultivators.
('18', 285, 1, 12, 605992) As the framers of the note claim to be specialists having an intimate knowledge of the Revenue Department, I find it difficult to characterize this passage.
('18', 285, 1, 13, 606149) I can only say that they have been ill served by their subordinates.
('18', 285, 1, 14, 606218) If the cultivators, whose statements I accepted, were interested in one way, the circle inspectors, as I have already shown, were far more interested the opposite way.
('18', 285, 1, 15, 606386) The note omits, however, to mention that I did not rely upon the evidence of interested cultivators but checked their statements, in some cases, where it was possible, with my own eyes, in all cases with the evidence of disinterested and respectable men who were not concerned for their own sake in securing a suspension of the revenue collection.
('18', 285, 1, 16, 606734) I thus applied a threefold test and I venture to say that, when the same evidence was given in thousands of cases by thousands of men and women, it was impossible to question that testimony, and the Government, in order to support the interested
('18', 286, 0, 1, 606980) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 287
('18', 286, 1, 2, 607025) statements of their officials and in order also to be able to collect the revenue which they wanted, were obliged to discredit not only the testimony of the villagers concerned but that of practically the whole of the Kaira population.
('18', 286, 1, 3, 607261) Any authority, in any shape or form responsible to the people, would have recoiled from any such imputation.
('18', 286, 1, 4, 607370) Under our system, however, the word of the Government has come to be regarded with superstitious awe and it has to be accepted as the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth even though large masses of people require to be damned for that purpose.
('18', 286, 1, 5, 607627) The Government summarily reject Sir Sankaran Nairs appreciation of the past economic situation of the tract.
('18', 286, 1, 6, 607736) I challenge the framers of the note to go through the villages of the district, and find out for themselves from the dumb testimony of the dilapidated buildings in the villages and say, with hands on their hearts, what evidence those buildings bespeak.
('18', 286, 1, 7, 607989) The Government then take delight in being able to say that the agitation in Kaira did not have any considerable effects on the measures of relief actually sanctioned, and that the result was not to leave the decision as regards payment of the Government demand to the raiyats themselves.
('18', 286, 1, 8, 608277) I can only say so much the worse for the Government and the broken word of their accredited officers, one of whom, in the presence of nearly two hundred people including myself, said that suspension would be granted in cases of poor cultivators and that the question of inability on the ground of poverty would be decided in consultation with the leading men of villages.
('18', 286, 2, 9, 608649) This was confirmed by the Collector of the District.
('18', 286, 2, 10, 608702) That suspension was confined to the fewest cultivators possible, that the orders of suspension were suppressed from the public for over a month and that they were only discovered when the departmant was at its wits end as to what to do, even after having sold the cattle of absentee cultivators, attached and removed their jewellery, imposed chothai fines, attached valuable crops wroth a few thousand rupees for a paltry balance and after the statement of the Commissioners that he did not need, like his ignorant audience, the binding effect of a vow to make good his threat, that he would sell their crops, confiscate their holdings and never restore the names of the contumacious holders, is a tale too thoroughly discreditable to require any further elaboration, and I feel sorry that the new Governor, who has given evidence of his anxiety to hear both sides and to be as impartial as he can, has been, no doubt
('18', 286, 3, 11, 609620) 1 Vide Speech at Uttarsanda, 3 6 1918
('18', 287, 0, 1, 609658) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 287, 1, 2, 609700) unconsciously, made a vehicle for passing to the Imperial Parliament a note that is brimful of misleading statements, and innuendoes.
('18', 287, 1, 3, 609834) I never took advantage of this so called concession, meaning the orders discovered in June.
('18', 287, 1, 4, 609926) I merely made use of the knowledge gained at Uttersanda, and, as befits a satyagrahi, stopped the struggle.
('18', 287, 1, 5, 610034) Had I prolonged it, I would have been guilty of contumacy, incivility to the Government and indifference to the distress of those whom I had the privilege of guiding.

('18', 287, 4, 19, 611706) Their attention was again drawn to these order in a proper circular issued by me on the 22nd of May, and to ensure that proper effect was given to them, the Mamlatdars were advised to divide the defaulters in each village into two classes  those who could pay and those who were unable to pay on account of poverty.
('18', 287, 5, 20, 612022) If this was so, why were these orders not published to the people?
('18', 287, 5, 21, 612089) Had they known them on the 25th April, what suffering would they not have been saved from?
('18', 287, 5, 22, 612180) The expenses that were unnecessarily incurred by the Government in engaging the officials of the district in effecting executions would have been saved.
('18', 287, 5, 23, 612333) Wherever the assessment was uncollected the people lived with

('18', 288, 3, 17, 614094) And even now relief has been granted in a niggardly manner, involuntarily and without admission of mistake.
('18', 288, 3, 18, 614202) It is even claimed that what has now been granted is nothing new.

('18', 288, 4, 21, 614615) It grieves us to offer this criticism.

('18', 288, 4, 23, 614713) Thus, if the end was without grace, the Government, in their persistence in their self congratulation upon the manner in which they succeeded in drawing all but the last drop, turn their action into a criminal blunder.
('18', 288, 4, 24, 614932) Their note leaves untouched the contention of Sir Sankaran Nair that the tendency of the present system of Government is too scientific to be human and therefore tyrannical, and that justice has been generally wrung from an unwilling bureaucracy by

('18', 289, 2, 6, 615655) 223. WHAT TO DO?
('18', 289, 3, 7, 615672) That the Rowlatt Act must not stand in the face of the opposition of the whole country is or should be clear to everyone who has any regard for national honour.
('18', 289, 3, 8, 615833) As I have said so often, to secure its repeal is more important than the passing of the Reforms Bill.
('18', 289, 3, 9, 615935) It will be an object lesson in self government without a parliamentary statute.
('18', 289, 3, 10, 616015) We must obtain the repeal by orderly agitation.
('18', 289, 3, 11, 616063) What is an orderly agitation?
('18', 289, 3, 12, 616093) If it is meetings, resolutions and memorials, it will be said, we have already had these in abundance.
('18', 289, 3, 13, 616196) The argument will not be without force.
('18', 289, 3, 14, 616236) But governments have short memories.
('18', 289, 3, 15, 616273) If there are no meeeting and no resolutions, there will be officials enough to say that the people do not desire repeal of the Rowlatt Act nor do they bother about it.
('18', 289, 3, 16, 616441) Though it was well known that the silence over Mr. Hornimans deportation was deliberately brought about to restore quiet and equilibrium, there were not wanting responsible people to infer that the absence of noise over the deportation was due to the peoples acquiescence in the violence of the authorities.
('18', 289, 3, 17, 616749) It is moreover certain that the Act is not going to be repealed without serious and sustained effort.
('18', 289, 3, 18, 616851) My implicit belief in the certainty of repeal is based upon the equal certainty of serious and very powerful agitation going on in the country.
('18', 289, 3, 19, 616995) The belief is also based upon my conviction that the Act is harmful to the free growth of the people.
('18', 289, 3, 20, 617097) I would even contemplate with comparative equanimity isolated revolutinary crime rather than see a whole people living under the terror of an Act like the Rowlatt Act.
('18', 289, 3, 21, 617265) It deals with effects, leaving the cause severely alone.
('18', 289, 3, 22, 617322) It arms the police and the executive with arbitrary and demoralizing powers.
('18', 289, 3, 23, 617399) An executive that asks for extraordinary powers is as a rule to be distrusted.
('18', 289, 3, 24, 617478) Extraordinary
('18', 289, 4, 25, 617492) 1 Vide Sir Sankaran Nair and Champaran, 27 8 1919.
('18', 290, 0, 1, 617543) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 291
('18', 290, 1, 2, 617588) powers are asked by those who wish to cover their inefficiency or inability to cope with an evil.
('18', 290, 1, 3, 617686) It is like an unskilled surgeon wanting to use the knife where a lancet in a skilled hand would do equally well.
('18', 290, 1, 4, 617799) Often extraordinary powers are taken to cover wrongs done by authority, as I fear was done by the Punjab Government in April.
('18', 290, 1, 5, 617925) History would have been written differently if the Central Government had asked the Punjab Government to deal with the situation in the ordinary manner.
('18', 290, 1, 6, 618078) It is said that in two places at least the Governor told the police that the latter would be held responsible if any disturbance took place in their jurisdiction.
('18', 290, 1, 7, 618241) Believing then, as I do, that the Rowlatt Act is bad in every respect and that nothing bad can outlast honest effort, I entertain no misgivings about the Act being repealed long before the expiry of the time limit.
('18', 290, 1, 8, 618456) But that honest effort during the suspension period consists in meetings, memorials and resolutions.
('18', 290, 1, 9, 618557) I respectfully appeal to the leaders who have advised me to suspend civil resistance to do their duty.
('18', 290, 1, 10, 618660) Sir Narayan Chandavarkar even said that method other than civil resistance were open to the people.
('18', 290, 1, 11, 618760) Will he and the other leaders give the lead?
('18', 290, 1, 12, 618805) In addition to their work, I suggest a memorial, after the style of the Congress League Scheme Memorial 1, to be signed by thousands of people.
('18', 290, 1, 13, 618949) Such memorial, as the late Mr. Ranade used to say, have an educative value and are quite useful for the purpose of focussing public opinion.
('18', 290, 1, 14, 619090) Moreover, when civil resistance was started, I was told that it was premature, we had not exhausted all the other means at our disposal.
('18', 290, 1, 15, 619227) I ventured to say we had.
('18', 290, 1, 16, 619253) Adoption of the programme suggested by me avoids the possibility of a repetition of the charge of premature resumption of civil resistance, if unfortunately it has to be resumed.
('18', 290, 1, 17, 619432) From every point of view, therefore, I feel that we should for the time being revert to the old method of agitation and education of public opinion, always insisting on speakers confining themselves to facts, avoiding declamation or inflammatory language.
('18', 290, 1, 18, 619688) A proper explanatin of the Rowlatt Act is itself its severest condemnation.

('18', 291, 7, 19, 620672) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, AHMEDABAD, August 17, 1919
('18', 291, 8, 20, 620718) DEAR MR. ROBERTS 1, I write this to you rather than to Mr. Montagu because I do not wish to worry him when he is already over weighted with other worries and because I do not enjoy the privilege of knowing him so well as I have of knowing you.

('18', 291, 8, 22, 621073) I have written to him too

('18', 292, 1, 2, 621276) on the subject.

('18', 292, 1, 4, 621372) The reply strongly dissuaded me from resuming civil resistance and said that, if it was a mistake for me to have embarked upon it, it would be a crime to resume it.
('18', 292, 1, 5, 621537) It added that I ought to know that the Act would not be repealed or withdrawn.
('18', 292, 1, 6, 621616) So far as the crime is concerned I must commit it, if I am driven to it, and take the consequences.

('18', 292, 1, 9, 621855) And it is surprising that Mr. Montagu, with his very fine imagination, should not have seen the simple beauty of the absolute efficacy and the necessity of civil resistance.
('18', 292, 1, 10, 622029) However, time will do its work and show that it was not civil resistance that was responsible for the circumscribed violence of the people in April.
('18', 292, 1, 11, 622178) In the Punjab, the people were goaded into violence.

('18', 292, 1, 13, 622326) All the other parts of India remained perfectly calm.

('18', 292, 1, 16, 622622) I know nothing of this absoluteness about the non repeal of the Act.
('18', 292, 1, 17, 622691) I know that I shall give all I have towards securing its repeal.
('18', 292, 1, 18, 622756) It was conceived in unworthy distrust of the people; it was brought forth amid the universal opposition of Indian opinion and it was nurtured in repression.
('18', 292, 1, 19, 622913) This is enough to condemn it.

('18', 292, 1, 21, 623132) Is that a fit prelude to liberal reforms?
('18', 292, 1, 22, 623174) Should they not be heralded by repeal of the Act?
('18', 292, 1, 23, 623224) And what is the Rowlatt Act?
('18', 292, 1, 24, 623253) It is an Act from start to finish designed to rob the subject of his liberty without the slightest necessity for it.
('18', 292, 1, 25, 623370) Revolutionary crime is (or was) admittedly confined to such a small area that it is an insult to the people to fling in their face a repressive measure like the Rowlatt Act.
('18', 292, 1, 26, 623544) I would therefore like to paraphrase Mr. Montagus warning and say that, if it was folly to have passed the Rowlatt Act in the face

('18', 293, 4, 7, 624220) 226. LETTER TO H.S.L. POLAK
('18', 293, 5, 8, 624248) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, August 17, 1919
('18', 293, 6, 9, 624287) MY DEAR HENRY,

('18', 294, 12, 18, 626321) SIR, No possible exception can be taken to the impartial manner in which your South African correspondent has given a summary of the Indian position in the Transvaal in your issue of the 18th instant.
('18', 294, 12, 19, 626522) He has put as fairly as it was possible for him to do both sides of the question.
('18', 294, 13, 20, 626604) 1 Vide Letter to G.S. Arundale, 4 8 1919 and Letter to Abdul Aziz, 8 8 1919 2 This item should be read after item 25 3 This was reproduced in Young India, 20 8 1919, The Hindu and New India, dated 22 8 1919.
('18', 295, 0, 1, 626812) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 295, 1, 2, 626854) It is not the additional brown burden on the top of the black one which agitates the European Colonists in South Africa, but the crux of the whole question is, as your correspondent puts it, that South Africa cannot be run economically with the Indian in it, and the white people who have made the country, cannot be expected to commit race suicide.
('18', 295, 1, 3, 627204) This is not the problem that presents itself to the Boer living on the Veldt to whom the Indian trader is a blessing, nor to the European housewife in the big towns of the Transvaal who depends solely upon the Indian vegetable vendor for the the vegetables brought to her door.
('18', 295, 1, 4, 627482) But the problem presents itself in the manner put by your correspondent to the petty European trader who finds in the thrifty and resourceful Indian a formidable rival, and with his vote, which counts a great deal, and with his influence as a member of the ruling race, he has succeeded in making his own economic problem a race problem for South Africa.
('18', 295, 1, 5, 627837) In reality, the problem is whether the petty trader for his selfish end is to be allowed to override every consideration of justice, fair play, Imperial policy and all that goes to make a nation good and great.
('18', 295, 1, 6, 628048) In support of the gradual but certain squeezing out process, what has been called the Smuts Gandhi agreement has been pressed into service.
('18', 295, 1, 7, 628188) Now that agreement is embodied in two letters and two only of the 30th June, 1914: 1 the first one addressed to me on behalf of General Smuts by Mr. Gorges, Secretary for the Interior, and the second my acknowledgment of it bearing the same date.
('18', 295, 1, 8, 628435) The agreement, as the letters conclusively show, is an agreement on questions which were the subject of civilin the correspondence described as passiveresistance.
('18', 295, 1, 9, 628598) The settlement stipulates only for an extensionnever a restrictionof existing rights, and, as it was intended only to cover questions arising out of civil resistance, it left open all the other questions.
('18', 295, 1, 10, 628803) Hence the reservation in my letter of the 30th June, viz:
('18', 295, 2, 11, 628861) As the Minister is aware, some of my countrymen have wished me to go further.
('18', 295, 2, 12, 628939) They are dissatisfied that trade licences, laws of the different Provinces, the Transvaal Gold Law, the Transvaal Law 3 of 1885, have not been altered so as to give them full rights of residence, trade and ownership of land.
('18', 295, 2, 13, 629164) Some of them are dissatisfied that full interprovincial migration is not permitted, and some are dissatisfied that, on the marriage question, the Relief
('18', 295, 3, 14, 629317) 1 Vide Letter to E.M. Gorges, 30 6 1914and Appendix Letter from E.M. Gorges, 30 6 1914.
('18', 296, 0, 1, 629405) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 297
('18', 296, 1, 2, 629450) Bill goes no further than it does.
('18', 296, 1, 3, 629485) In this correspondence, there is not a word about the Indian settlers not getting trade licences or [not] holding fixed property in the mining or any other area.
('18', 296, 1, 4, 629647) And the Indians had a perfect right to apply for and get as many trade licences as they could secure and as much fixed property as they could hold, whether through forming registered companies or through mortgages.
('18', 296, 1, 5, 629862) After a strenuous fight for eight years, it was not likely that I would give away any legal rights, and if I did, the community I had the honour to represent would naturally and quite properly have dismissed me as an unworthy, if not a traitorous, representative.
('18', 296, 1, 6, 630126) But there is a third letter, totally irrelevant considered as part of the agreement, which has been used for the curtailment of trade rights.
('18', 296, 1, 7, 630268) It is my letter of the 7th July addressed to Mr. Gorges.
('18', 296, 1, 8, 630325) 1 The whole tone of it shows that it is purely a personal letter, setting forth only my individual views about vested rights in connection with the Gold Law and Township Amendment Act.
('18', 296, 1, 9, 630510) I have therein stated definitely that I do not wish to restrict the future action of my countrymen and I have simply recorded the definition of vested rights I discussed with Sir Benjamin Robertson on the 4th March, 1914, saying that by vested rights I understand the right of an Indian and his successors to live and trade in the township in which he was living and trading, no matter how often he shifts his residence or business from place to place in the same township.
('18', 296, 1, 10, 630984) 2 This is the definition on which the whole of the theory of evasion of law and breach of faith has been based.
('18', 296, 1, 11, 631096) Apart from the question of irrelevance of the letter, I claim that it could not be used, even if it could be admitted as part of the agreement, in the manner it has been.
('18', 296, 1, 12, 631267) As I have already stated on previous occasions, there was a prospect of an adverse interpretation of the Gold Law as to trade licences, and there was the tangible difficulty in getting land or leases of buildings and it was by the most strenuous efforts that Indians were able within Gold Areas to retain their foothold.
('18', 296, 1, 13, 631588) I was anxious to protect the existing traders and their successors even though the legal interpretation of the law might be adverse to the Indian claim.
('18', 296, 1, 14, 631741) The vested right, therefore, referred to in
('18', 296, 2, 15, 631785) 1 Vide Letter to E.M. Gorges, 7 7 1914 2 Vide Letter to Sir Benjamin Robertson, 4 3 1914
('18', 297, 0, 1, 631874) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 297, 1, 2, 631916) my letter of the 7th July was a right created in spite of the law.
('18', 297, 1, 3, 631983) And it was this right that had to be protected in the administration of the then existing laws.
('18', 297, 1, 4, 632079) Even if, therefore, my said letter can be incorporated in the agreement, by no canon of interpretation that I know can it be said to prevent the Indians morally (for that is the meaning of the charge of breach of faith) from getting new trade licences in virtue of the law of the land.
('18', 297, 1, 5, 632365) Indians openly and in a fair fight gained in their favour a legal decision to the effect that they could obtain trade licences against tender of the licence fee even within the Gold Area.
('18', 297, 1, 6, 632553) To this they were perfectly morally entitled.
('18', 297, 1, 7, 632599) There cannot be any question of a legal breach.
('18', 297, 1, 8, 632647) Their trade rivals would long ago have made short work of any legal breach.
('18', 297, 1, 9, 632723) Lastly, supposing that the law was adverse to the Indian claim, my definition could not be pleaded to bar any agitation for amendment of the law, for the whole of the settlement, in the nature of it, was of a temporary character; and the Indians, as definitely stated in my letter of the 30th June, could not be expected to rest content until full civic rights had been conceded.
('18', 297, 1, 10, 633103) The whole of the plea, therefore, of breach of faith is, I venture to submit, an utterly dishonest and shameless piece of tactics, which ought not to be allowed to interfere with a proper adjustment of the question.
('18', 297, 2, 11, 633319) M.K. GANDHI

('18', 298, 4, 7, 634193) 230. ANOTHER SCANDAL
('18', 298, 5, 8, 634214) It is my unpleasant duty to present another batch of cases to the reader from the Punjab which reveal a state of things that is utterly unbearable.
('18', 298, 5, 9, 634362) It is to be wished that H.E. the Viceroy will end the growing anxiety by appointing the promised Committee of Inquiry without delay.
('18', 298, 5, 10, 634495) Mr. Montagu has said from his place in the House of Commons that at least two out of the three judges of the Punjab Special Tribunals were judges of the High Court of three years, standing.
('18', 298, 5, 11, 634685) The public have been recently informed that, where the members were not High Court judges, they were eligible for that high post.
('18', 298, 5, 12, 634815) The poignancy of the sorrow that the atrocious injustices, such as I have had the painful duty of exposing, have caused is increased by the knowledge that the perpetrators of these injustices are judges in whose judgments the people have been accustomed to put the utmost trust.
('18', 298, 5, 13, 635094) This unevenness of temperament can only be accounted for by the supposition that the trained judicial intellect of the judges must have suffered temporary aberration by the events of the Punjab.
('18', 298, 5, 14, 635289) The desire to secure for Englishmen almost absolute immunity from physical harm from the natives, by inflicting exemplary punishments on someone or other, appears to have been the master passion overruling discretion, wisdom and justice.
('18', 298, 5, 15, 635527) It is not possible for me to understand the judgements that have come under my notice on any other hypothesis.
('18', 298, 5, 16, 635638) These reflections are caused by a perusal of the judgement and the evidence in the Hafizabad case.
('18', 298, 5, 17, 635737) The full text of the judgement and the evidence material to the case to be examined will be found printed elsewhere in this issue.
('18', 298, 5, 18, 635868) During the whole course of my practice of law, by no means inconsiderable, extending over an unbroken period of nearly twenty years, I have never come across cases in which capital punishment has been so lightly pronounced on

('18', 299, 1, 3, 636418) The case has been sent to me in regard to only one of the nineteen accused tried, viz., Karamchand, the 19th accused, a student of the Dayanand Anglo Vedic College.
('18', 299, 1, 4, 636583) But I have no hesitation in saying that there was no evidence before the Court to warrant a conviction against any of the accued for waging war.
('18', 299, 1, 5, 636728) The judges had a choice of offences for conviction.
('18', 299, 1, 6, 636780) The accused were charged under Sections 121, 147, 307, 486 (?), 149 of the Indian Penal Code.
('18', 299, 1, 7, 636874) Section 147 relates to rioting, carrying with it a maximum penalty of two years imprisonment.
('18', 299, 1, 8, 636968) Section 149 renders members of an unlawful assembly liable to the same penalty as any other member thereof.
('18', 299, 1, 9, 637076) Section 307 relates to attempts to murder, carrying the maximum penalty of ten years.
('18', 299, 1, 10, 637162) Section 486 appears to be an erroneous copy; it has no relevance to the evidence led before the court.
('18', 299, 1, 11, 637265) It was thus easy enough to convict on any of the milder sections if the judges had so chosen.
('18', 299, 1, 12, 637359) They however scented war in every act of the crowd during those three or four days of April.
('18', 299, 1, 13, 637452) Whilst therefore it is clear to me, as I hope it will be clear to every impartial student of the case, that the charge of waging war against the King is unsustainable in the absence of the specific evidence against the other accused, it is difficult to form a conclusive opinion as to their cases on the minor charges.

('18', 302, 2, 6, 644322) 231. LETTER TO THE TIMES OF INDIA 1
('18', 302, 3, 7, 644358) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, August 20, 1919 THE EDITOR THE TIMES OF INDIA
('18', 302, 4, 8, 644427) SIR, You will perhaps permit me to reply to Pennsylvanian s well meant advice to me.
('18', 302, 4, 9, 644512) I am aware that many Englishmen honestly hold the opinion Pennsylyanian does, and I thank him for providing me with an opportunity for removing some of the misunderstanding that exists about satyagraha.
('18', 302, 4, 10, 644715) Pennsylvanian has commended to me the example of his illustrious countryman, Abraham Lincoln.
('18', 302, 4, 11, 644809) I have endeavoured to the best of my ability to translate into my life one of his sayings, namely, Let us have faith that right makes might, and in that faith, let us, to the end, dare to do our duty as we understand it.
('18', 302, 5, 12, 645030) Pennsylyanian rightly insists on a moral revolution.
('18', 302, 5, 13, 645083) Now, satyagraha is that and nothing else.
('18', 302, 5, 14, 645125) Civil resistance is but a part, though a necessary part, of it.
('18', 302, 5, 15, 645189) Its root meaning is insistence on truth at all cost.
('18', 302, 5, 16, 645242) Life satyagrahis are under the pledge of absolute adherence to truth, non violence, poverty and chastity.
('18', 302, 5, 17, 645348) An institution is at present in existence at which practically the whole of the programme sketched by Pennsylyanian is being carried out.
('18', 302, 6, 18, 645486) 1 This letter, also published in Young India And New India of 23 8 1919, was written in reply to an open letter in The Times of India, a Few days earlier, in which the writer, Pennsylvanian, had appealed to Gandhiji to concentrate his efforts on the improvement of soc ety by a ceaseless propaganda for social education and revenue reform.
('18', 302, 6, 19, 645826) For the text, vide Appendix Letter from Pennsylvanian, 13 8 1919 2 These are the concluding words of Licolns address at Cooper Institute, New York City on February 27, 1860. 3 The reference is obviously to the Satyagraha Ashram founded by Gandhiji at Sabarmati in 1917.
('18', 303, 0, 1, 646096) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 303, 1, 2, 646138) English and American friends have visited it.
('18', 303, 1, 3, 646184) I invite Pennsylv anian to visit it and report upon it to the public.
('18', 303, 1, 4, 646254) He will find there that men and women belonging to all stations in life are living on terms of perfect equality, that the unlettered receive literary education in so far as the daily toil permits it, and that the lettered members do not hesitate to take up the pickaxe and the shovel.
('18', 303, 1, 5, 646539) He will find there that, besides agriculture, the inmates are under the obligation to learn the art of spinning and weaving.
('18', 303, 1, 6, 646664) By exploring the records of its past, he will discover that its members helped with medicine the people of the surrounding villages during the influenza epidemic, that they helped the famine committee to distribute grain among the poor, that they distributed again for the same agency several thousand rupees against manufacture by the needy weavers and thus added to the production in the country, that through their labour several women, who were but the other day earning nothing, are able, by spinning cotton during their leisure hours, to earn a few coppers daily.
('18', 303, 1, 7, 647234) In short, he will find that [some] of the items in the comprehensive programme skethced by Pennsylvanian are being worked there to the utmost extent of the capacity of the satyagrahis.
('18', 303, 1, 8, 647419) This is the silent moral revolution going on in our midst.
('18', 303, 1, 9, 647478) It suffers by advertisement and it is not without some hesitation that I have placed before the public the constructive work that is being done by life satyagrahis.
('18', 303, 1, 10, 647643) Let me add further that the advent of satyagraha has, to my knowledge, weaned many an anarchist from his blood thirstydoctrine.
('18', 303, 1, 11, 647771) He has found that secret societies and methods of secret murder have brought nothing but a military and economic burden on this unhappy land, that it has tightened the coil of the Criminal Investigation Department, and that it has demoralized and wrecked the lives of hundreds of youths who have been led astray by it.
('18', 303, 1, 12, 648090) Satyagraha has presented the rising generation with a new hope, an open road and an infallible remedy for most ills of life.
('18', 303, 1, 13, 648215) It has armed that generation with an indestructible and mathcless force which anyone may wield with impunity.
('18', 303, 1, 14, 648325) Satyagraha tells the Youth of India, self suffering is the only sure road to salvation .
('18', 303, 1, 15, 648414) economic, political and spiritual.
('18', 303, 1, 16, 648449) For the most part, satyagraha is evil resistance and civil assistance.
('18', 303, 1, 17, 648520) But sometimes it has to be civil resistance.
('18', 303, 1, 18, 648565) Here I must call to my assistance another illustrious countryman of Pennsy lyanian, Henry Thoreau.
('18', 303, 1, 19, 648664) He asks,
('18', 303, 2, 20, 648673) Must the citizen ever for a moment, or in the least degree, resign his conscience to the legislators?
('18', 303, 2, 21, 648775) He answers,
('18', 304, 0, 1, 648787) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 305
('18', 304, 1, 2, 648832) I think that we should be men first and subjects afterwards.
('18', 304, 1, 3, 648893) It is not desirable to cultivate a respect for the law so much as for the right.1 I think that the position taken up by Thoreau is unassailable.
('18', 304, 1, 4, 649038) The only question is that of the remedy to be applied for vindicating the rights of conscience.
('18', 304, 1, 5, 649134) The remedy in vogue is that of inflicitng violence on those who wish to wound your conscience.
('18', 304, 1, 6, 649229) Thoreau in his immortal eassy shows that civil disobedience, not violence, is the true remedy.
('18', 304, 1, 7, 649324) In civil disobedience, the resister suffers the consequences of disobedience.
('18', 304, 1, 8, 649402) This was what Danial did when he disobeyed the law of the Medes and Persians.
('18', 304, 1, 9, 649480) That is what John Bunyan1 did and that is what the raiyats have done in India from time immemorial.
('18', 304, 1, 10, 649580) It is the law of our being.
('18', 304, 1, 11, 649608) Violence is the law of the best in us.
('18', 304, 1, 12, 649647) Self suffering, i.e., civil resistance, is the law of the man in us.
('18', 304, 1, 13, 649716) It is rarely that the occasion for civil resistance arises in a well ordered State.
('18', 304, 1, 14, 649800) But when it does, it becomes a duty that cannot be shirked by one who counts his honour, i.e., conscience, above everything.
('18', 304, 1, 15, 649925) Rowlatt Act is legislation that affects the conscience of thousands of us, and I respectfully suggest that an appeal should be addressed by Englishmen to the Government that they withdraw an Act that hurts the self respect of the nation and that has roused such unanimous opposition, rather than that I should be asked to refrain from civil resistance in respect of it.
('18', 304, 2, 16, 650295) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Times of India, 22 8 1919

('18', 307, 6, 14, 654755) 238. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION, BOMBAY
('18', 307, 7, 15, 654809) BOMBAY, August 21, 1919
('18', 307, 8, 16, 654833) DEAR SIR, I had occasion to visit Godhra last week and, during my stay there, to visit the Stewart Library.
('18', 307, 8, 17, 654941) I found that several newspapers were regarded as undesirable for being placed on the library table.
('18', 307, 8, 18, 655041) I venture to suggest that the list of undesirable newspapers is quite arbitrary.
('18', 307, 8, 19, 655122) I find, for instance, that Young India is prohibited.
('18', 307, 8, 20, 655176) Now, that paper is today being published under my close supervision and I make bold [to] say that it is a journal which could be placed in the hands of a child.
('18', 307, 8, 21, 655337) It was prohibited on the 19th June, 1917. Since that day it has undergone many vicissitudes.
('18', 307, 8, 22, 655430) There is The Mahratta1 alsounder the ban.
('18', 307, 8, 23, 655472) It is one of the oldest established English weeklies largely read in Indian circles.
('18', 307, 8, 24, 655557) The Gujarati again is one of the oldest Gujarati papers.
('18', 307, 8, 25, 655614) One may not agree with the policy of these journals,
('18', 308, 0, 1, 655667) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 309
('18', 308, 1, 2, 655712) but I cannot help saying that it is a serious matter to withhold a journal from a pubic library for its policy.
('18', 308, 1, 3, 655824) I have simply chosen a few examples from the list.
('18', 308, 1, 4, 655875) So far as I know, not one of the newspapers, listed can be objected to on any defensible ground.
('18', 308, 1, 5, 655972) In my opinion, assuming that there should be censorship as to the periodicals, the matter should be placed in the hands of a Library Committee chosen by the local residents, of which your local representative may be an ex officio member, with the strict understanding that a newspaper or a book may be excluded only if, in the opinion of the Committee, it offends public morals.
('18', 308, 1, 6, 656351) I trust that you will give this very important matter your earnest and early consideration.
('18', 308, 2, 7, 656443) Yours faithfully, M. K. GANDHI Young India, 17 9 1919

('18', 309, 5, 7, 657756) 240. LETTER TO P.S. TO LORD WILLINGDON
('18', 309, 6, 8, 657795) LABURNUM ROAD, GAMDEVI, BOMBAY, August 22, 1919
('18', 309, 7, 9, 657843) DEAR SIR, I write this for submission to His Excellency on a somewhat personal matter of urgency.
('18', 309, 7, 10, 657941) Probably the name of Miss Esther Faering, of Danish extraction and, up to recently, if not still, working as Superintendent of a Girls School belonging to the mission in Tirucoilur, has been brought to His Excellencys notice.
('18', 309, 7, 11, 658167) It was probably two years ago that she, along with another Danish lady1, visted my Ashram at Ahmedabad.
('18', 309, 7, 12, 658271) Both the ladies took a special fancy for the Ashram and its ideals.
('18', 309, 7, 13, 658339) Miss Faering has since then met me three or four times and she has visted the Ashram, I believe, once after her first visit.
('18', 309, 7, 14, 658464) She has been a fairly regular correspondent and I believe she is attached to me like a child to its father, simply because, in her opinion, I represent in action the ideals she would fain enforce in her own life and is ever trying to.
('18', 309, 7, 15, 658699) She loves India as her own motherland and I know it would be a terrible wrench to her if she is ever banished from India, as she dreads she might.
('18', 309, 7, 16, 658846) Latterly, it seems she has been a suspect, very much shadowed.
('18', 309, 7, 17, 658909) It was her intention some time ago to leave the Danish mission, if she could.
('18', 309, 7, 18, 658987) I think I succeeded in weaning her from the desire.
('18', 309, 7, 19, 659039) I told her that it was her duty to fulfil her contract with the mission, so long as she was permitted to do so.
('18', 309, 7, 20, 659151) I have just heard that she is no longer in the mission.
('18', 309, 7, 21, 659207) If this is true and if she is permitted, I would be pleased to take her into the Ashram where she would be associated with me in
('18', 310, 0, 1, 659336) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 311
('18', 310, 1, 2, 659381) my non political work.
('18', 310, 1, 3, 659404) I believe her to be as truthful and straight a person as is to be found anywhere.
('18', 310, 1, 4, 659486) She ever lives in the fear of God and does her best to live a Christian life.
('18', 310, 1, 5, 659564) As her desire is to pass her life mostly in the midst of the people of India, I advised her to become naturalized.
('18', 310, 1, 6, 659679) I know she took steps in the direction and I revised for her the petition for naturalization.
('18', 310, 1, 7, 659773) But I do not know whether she has sent it.
('18', 310, 1, 8, 659816) I can only hope that His Excellency will meet her and form the same opinion about her that I have.
('18', 310, 1, 9, 659915) If any undertaking is required about her, it can be easily given.
('18', 310, 1, 10, 659981) If an assurance is necessary, I wish to assure His Excellency that I have not the slightest desire to avail myself of her services in the political field.
('18', 310, 1, 11, 660136) As probably Lord Willingdon is aware, the largest part of my work is social and moral or religious.
('18', 310, 1, 12, 660236) My most intimate associates take hardly any part in my political work.
('18', 310, 1, 13, 660307) The inmates of the Ashram are engaged in agricultural, industrial and educaional work, and if Miss Faering comes to the Ashram, she will take part in these activities, and if need be, I will undertake, in no other.
('18', 310, 1, 14, 660522) Miss Faering knows nothing about this letter but I am sending her a copy for the consolation that I am not unmindful of my duty to her as a privileged friend, as also for her endorsement of the undertaking I am promising herein.
('18', 310, 1, 15, 660751) I tender my apology for troubling His Excellency on a matter of a partly personal nature.
('18', 310, 2, 16, 660841) Yours faithfully, M. K. GANDHI
