('18', 312, 4, 6, 663385) 243. LETTER TO P.S. TO GOVERNOR, BOMBAY
('18', 312, 5, 7, 663425) AS AT LABURNUM ROAD, GAMEDVI, BOMBAY August 25, 1919
('18', 312, 6, 8, 663478) DEAR MR. COWIE, I see that I may not get an interview with H.E. for some time.1 I am however anxious to get some pronouncement on swadeshi from H.E. as early as possible.
('18', 312, 6, 9, 663649) I, therefore, propose to present for H. E.s consideration my conception of and arguments on swadeshi.
('18', 312, 6, 10, 663751) I do hope he will make time for reading it and, if possible, be pleased to comply with my request made at the end of the argument.
('18', 312, 7, 11, 663882) SWADESHI Swadeshi as conceived by me consists in producing cloth enough for the wants of India and in distributing it; and for the purpose of stimulating home production, it consists in inducing people to pledge themselves to the use of swadeshi cloth only, the right being retained where necessary to continue the use of foreign cloth at present in possession of the pledgee/votary.
('18', 312, 7, 12, 664266) The swadeshi is conceived only as a religious and an economic necessity; and although it is fraught with political consequences of a lofty, moral type in order that all may take part in it, the swadeshi propaganda is restricted to the religious and economic aspects only.
('18', 312, 7, 13, 664538) Swadeshi goods can be produced either through spinning and weaving mills or by hand spinning and hand weaving.
('18', 312, 7, 14, 664649) At the present moment, we are concentrating on hand spinning and hand weaving.
('18', 312, 8, 15, 664728) ARGUMENT We are so doing because the need of the peasantry, i.e., 73 p.c.
('18', 312, 8, 16, 664802) of the population, is an industry supplementary to agriculture.
('18', 312, 8, 17, 664866) This population has nearly four months in the year paractically idle on its
('18', 313, 0, 1, 664942) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 313, 1, 2, 664984) A humdred years ago, the majority of the women of India spun yarn either for profit or for pleasure and thousands upon thousands of professional weavers wove cloth enough for home consumption.
('18', 313, 1, 3, 665177) Whether the same can be done today, or not, it is unnecessary to inquire.
('18', 313, 1, 4, 665251) It is beyond question that if these millions of peasants can be induced to take to spinning and weaving, it will materially decrease the economic drain and enable them to supplement their earnings.
('18', 313, 1, 5, 665449) My own experience in several centres and among hundreds of women tells me that they are glad enough to revive the occupation of spinning and to get a few coppers.
('18', 313, 1, 6, 665612) I know that they were a blessing to many poor women of Vijapur during the late famine.
('18', 313, 1, 7, 665699) About 150 women, in that village alone, are today spinning about half a maund of yarn per day and getting on an average three pice each, enough for them to buy milk for their children.
('18', 313, 1, 8, 665884) I consider hand spinning and hand weaving as an automatic famine insurance.
('18', 313, 1, 9, 665960) Only last Friday I was surprised to find Miss Latham of East Khandesh telling me that the women of that district were pining for some home occupation that would enable them to turn a few honest coppers.
('18', 313, 1, 10, 666163) All that is necessary is to provide them with cheap spinning wheels and with dressed cotton.
('18', 313, 1, 11, 666256) Arrangements have already been made on a limited scale to supply both these things.
('18', 313, 1, 12, 666340) Both men and women are taking up the idea eagerly, but the thing can move far more rapidly if the movement receives patronage from high places.
('18', 313, 2, 13, 666484) REQUEST
('18', 313, 3, 14, 666492) I, therefore, request as follows : 1. H. E. may be pleased to give us a letter for publication approving of the swadeshi movement and especially of the introduction of hand spinning and hand weaving.
('18', 313, 3, 15, 666692) 2. The Registrar of Co operative Societies may be authorized to encourage hand spinning and hand weaving and devise means therefor.
('18', 313, 3, 16, 666824) 3. Collectors and other officials may be advised to encourage the movement and especially to encourage the cultivators to take up hand spinning and hand weaving.
('18', 313, 3, 17, 666986) 4. And if it is not a presumption, I would respectfully ask H.E. on my behalf to secure Lady George Lloyds patronage for my spinning classes.
('18', 313, 3, 18, 667128) Several titled ladies are, with a view to encouraging the industry among the poor classes, taking spinning lessons.
('18', 313, 3, 19, 667244) I would
('18', 314, 0, 1, 667252) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 315
('18', 314, 1, 2, 667297) consider it an honour to be allowed to present a spinning wheel to Her Excellency and to send her a lady teacher or to give her the lessons myself.
('18', 314, 1, 3, 667445) I may mention that the art of spinning is incredibly simple to learn.
('18', 314, 2, 4, 667515) Yours sincerely,

('18', 315, 0, 1, 669298) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 315, 1, 2, 669340) 245. SIR SANKARAN NAIR AND CHAMPARAN
('18', 315, 2, 3, 669377) The argument on either side .
('18', 315, 2, 4, 669407) his colleagues on the one and Sir Sankaran himself on the other .
('18', 315, 2, 5, 669473) is the same as for Kaira.
('18', 315, 2, 6, 669499) Sir Sankaran has argued that the bureaucracy took action only when it was moved by the driving force of the Congress, in other words, educated Indians.
('18', 315, 2, 7, 669651) His colleagues have argued that the bureaucracy has been ever vigilant of the interests of the masses whom educated Indians have never respresented and for whom they have cared little.
('18', 315, 2, 8, 669836) Further, the case for bureaucracy, so far as Kaira is concerned, is that, in the first place, they did nothing at all for the cultivators because they did not believe in their grievance, and secondly, if it be argued that something was done, it was done not because the Honble Gokuldas and other educated Indians, and in the last stages, Mr. Gandhi intervened, but because it was what they would have done without any such intervention.
('18', 315, 2, 9, 670273) In the Champaran case, the grievance is admitted, but it is stated on behalf of bureaucracy that Mr. Gandhis intervention did not in any way affect the course of action.
('18', 315, 2, 10, 670443) Sir Sankaran Nairs contention in both the cases is that whatever was done by the bureaucracy was wrung from them by the strenuous effort of educated Indians who have ever held the interests of the masses dear to their hearts.
('18', 315, 2, 11, 670669) I hope I have been able to show clearly that the grievance of the Kaira cultivators was real, and that whatever was given was after a very tough fight, and that the smallness of the relief granted was evidence of the smallness of the bureaucratic mind.
('18', 315, 2, 12, 670922) In Kaira, again, the grievance was not of long standing and there was callous indifference even at the fountainhead.
('18', 315, 2, 13, 671039) Lord Willingdon, well intentioned himself, allowed himself to be ruled by his unbending councillors who were immediately concerned with the Kaira affair.
('18', 315, 2, 14, 671193) My task, therefore, in dealing with Kaira was easy enough.
('18', 315, 2, 15, 671252) In Champaran, the grievance was old.
('18', 315, 2, 16, 671289) The contest was three cornered, in which tremendous interests were arrayed against the raiyat.
('18', 315, 2, 17, 671384) But I am happy to be able to bear testimony to the fact that the head of the Government, Sir Edwad Gait, was a strong man, who ruled instead of being ruled by his councillors and who did not hesitate to use his strength on behalf of the raiyats to the best of his ability.
('18', 315, 2, 18, 671657) Had there been any other or less sympathetic or less strong ruler, the course of history would have taken a different, and a tragic, turn.
('18', 315, 2, 19, 671796) The consequences would have been disastrous.
('18', 316, 0, 1, 671841) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 317
('18', 316, 1, 2, 671886) therefore, painful for me to criticize the Bihar Government Note on Champaran in answer to Sir Sankaran Nairs minute of dissent.
('18', 316, 1, 3, 672015) They do not deny the grievance, but they claim that they were waiting in order to be able to redress the grievance for the result of the settlement operations they had undertaken and that my intervention was practically of no consequence.
('18', 316, 1, 4, 672254) My position in dealing with the matter is rendered difficult by reason of my having been a member of the Committee of Inquiry.
('18', 316, 1, 5, 672381) I may not make use of records which were placed before the Committee by the Government, but which naturally have not been published as part of the Committees report.
('18', 316, 1, 6, 672547) I must confine myself, therefore, to the published reports only.
('18', 316, 1, 7, 672612) The Bihar Note makes much of the settlement operations.
('18', 316, 1, 8, 672668) I venture to submit that the settlement operations had little to do with the very large issues involved.
('18', 316, 1, 9, 672773) According to the Bangal Tenancy Act, which is applicable to Bihar, these operations automatically take place at stated intervals with a view to regulating the enhancement of rent payable by each individual tenant to the permanent holder.
('18', 316, 1, 10, 673011) The permanent settlement of Bengal has brought little permanence to the raiyats amongst whom the vast permanent holdings are parcelled out.
('18', 316, 1, 11, 673151) In Champaran, the majority of permanent holders are European planters.
('18', 316, 1, 12, 673222) They are like Rajas; although they are not clothed by law with any civil or criminal jurisdiction over the raiyatstheir tenantsthey succeed in exercising practically both jurisdictions over the objectly helpless tenantry of Champaran.
('18', 316, 1, 13, 673457) In this, they differ in no wise from Indian permanent holders.
('18', 316, 1, 14, 673520) But, as I said in one of my earliest notes 1 submitted to the Government, in the course of my independent investigation, whilst there can be no doubt that the latter (meaning the planters) have inherited a vicious system, they with their trained minds and superior position have reduced it to an exact science. These landlords have been given by the Bengal Tenancy Act the right, under stated circumstances, to enhance rents, with an equal right to the tenant to seek reduction under certain other circumstances.
('18', 316, 1, 15, 674033) as might be well imagined, reduction would be a rare thing.
('18', 316, 1, 16, 674093) Enhancement is an actuality haunting the tenant throughout his life.
('18', 316, 1, 17, 674162) And the settlement officers chief business is to revise these rents, re survey the plots occupied by each tenant and to investigate some of the disputes between landlord and tenants incidental to the tenancy.
('18', 316, 1, 18, 674371) Beyond this, the settlement officer cannot go.
('18', 316, 1, 19, 674418) He had no jurisdiction to investigate or decide upon any of the most important issues that were before the Champaran Committee for decision.
('18', 316, 1, 20, 674559) My own investigation was
('18', 317, 0, 1, 674584) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 317, 1, 2, 674626) confined only to grievances that were common to the majority of the Champaran raiyats regarding which no settlement operations were necessary, because no individual investigation was required or called for.
('18', 317, 1, 3, 674833) These grievances forced themselves on my notice as soon as I set my foot in Champaran, and I was not there many weeks before I had overwhelming evidence to prove them.
('18', 317, 1, 4, 675001) The chiefest of them was practically of a hundred years standing.
('18', 317, 1, 5, 675067) It had reduced the raiyats to the position of mere serfs.
('18', 317, 1, 6, 675125) This was the indigo grievance.
('18', 317, 1, 7, 675156) It was called the system of Tinkathia cultivation of indigo under which the raiyats were obliged to set apart a certain portion of their holding chosen by the landlord on which he had to grow indigo and later any other crop that the landlord required him to grow, and this he had to sell to his landlord at a price which hardly paid him for his labour.
('18', 317, 1, 8, 675509) Let the report of the Committee speak upon it :
('18', 317, 2, 9, 675557) The conditions under which indigo is grown by the tenants for the factories has in the past been the cause of disputes on several occasions, and though we do not consider it necessary to enter into the history of these disputes, we cannot explain the causes of the present unrest without giving some account of the system.
('18', 317, 2, 10, 675880) In essentials, it does not appear to have varied during the last 100 years.2 During these hundred years, whenever the grievance became unbearable, the raiyats sought relief by open violence.
('18', 317, 2, 11, 676071) Each time there was rioting, there was only a patchwork done.
('18', 317, 2, 12, 676133) The violence made their position, as a matter of fact, much worse than before.
('18', 317, 2, 13, 676212) The planters were able to bring the armed authority of law to their aid to quell it and the grievance which gave rise to violence was almost totally forgotten.
('18', 317, 2, 14, 676372) Sometimes punitive police was imposed upon the raiyats, and the only consolation that the latter were able to take for their madness was a little rise in the price they received for indigo.
('18', 317, 2, 15, 676562) But the forced growing of indigo and all the misery that it meant, continued without abatement, and the hold of the planters upon the raiyats grew tighter.
('18', 317, 2, 16, 676718) And when they found that violence was useless, they tried to resort to law courts with as little success as attended their efforts at rioting.
('18', 317, 2, 17, 676861) Sometimes they would get an equitable ruling, but in the unequal struggle they were bound to be worsted.
('18', 317, 2, 18, 676966) With the unliminted resources of the planters, the slender purse of the raiyats had a poor chance.
('18', 317, 2, 19, 677065) The records of the law courts of Champaran are there any day to support my statement.
('18', 317, 2, 20, 677151) The settlement officer could see or say nothing regarding this double failure.
('18', 317, 2, 21, 677230) I state with all the emphasis that I can command that the stroy of the last hundred years
('18', 318, 0, 1, 677320) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 319
('18', 318, 1, 2, 677365) of the Champaran raiyats is also the story of the failure of the authorities either to understand the inwardness of the situation or to grapple with it.
('18', 318, 1, 3, 677518) Every raiyat gave them a terrible warning, but to no purpose.
('18', 318, 1, 4, 677580) They tampered with the problem, never went to the heart of it.
('18', 318, 1, 5, 677643) And had it not been for my appearance in Champaran, had I not insisted on my right to remain there in the face of tremendous difficulties, and had I not brushed aside the advice of some friends to obtain a solution through law courts, and, what is more, had I not gone to the raiyats themselves to find out what they wanted, I make bold to say that the great relief that the Bihar Government gave would never have been given.
('18', 318, 1, 6, 678069) They would never have had the courage to bolt out the curse of forced indigo.
('18', 318, 1, 7, 678147) They knew that it was a curse, they knew that although the raiyats could not express it in words, it was the Tinkathia that ate into the very vitals of the community, and sapped their moral and material strength.
('18', 318, 1, 8, 678360) The Bihar Government are not ashamed to say that the majority of the Bihar Legislative Council, as ignorant as themselves, rejected the resolution brought forward by the only councillor who knew what he was talking I mean, Babu Brijkishore Prasadone of the truest men of Bihar.
('18', 318, 1, 9, 678638) The Government ought to have known then that the settlement officer could throw little light on this burning question.
('18', 318, 1, 10, 678757) Indeed, had there been no settlement operations, there would probably have been no Sarahbeshienhancement of rent in lieu of indigo.
('18', 318, 1, 11, 678889) I admit that the settlement officer himself was a courteous and sympathetic officer desirous of doing his duty; I admit also that because of his impartiality he succeeded in giving justice to the raiyats, when other officers would have failed; but he could throw no more light, because he was a settlement officer, than he otherwise would have done on the many question that the Committee had to decide.
('18', 318, 1, 12, 679293) It was not his province.
('18', 318, 1, 13, 679318) The comprehensive recommendations of the Committee are based, not upon the evidence of the settlement officer, but upon the records that were in possession of the Government, most of them bearing a date prior even to the date on which the settlement officer began his operation.
('18', 318, 1, 14, 679597) All the vices of forced indigo, which the Committee has brought to light, were already known to the Government.
('18', 318, 1, 15, 679709) The opposite question, therefore, arises: why did they not abolish the system before?
('18', 318, 1, 16, 679795) There were several settlement operations before the last one; why did they not avail themselves of these operations to redress the grievances dealt with by the Committee?
('18', 318, 1, 17, 679966) I do not wish to burden the reader with a detailed list of
('18', 319, 0, 1, 680025) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 319, 1, 2, 680067) the grievances found by the Committee to exist.
('18', 319, 1, 3, 680115) I content myself with saying that the Committee could have dealt with every one of them without the settlement, and what is more to the point, on the question of Sarahbeshi and Tawan, if the Government had listened to Babu Brijkishores voice in the wilderness, the raiyats would have been saved the robbery in the shape of Tawan, and the veiled robbery in the shape of Sarahbeshi.
('18', 319, 1, 4, 680496) I must explain these two terms for the edification of reader outside Bihar.
('18', 319, 1, 5, 680572) Tawan was the so called damages taken by the lease holding planter from his tenants for commutation of the indigo obligation at a time when the planter did not need indigo.
('18', 319, 1, 6, 680745) Sarahbeshi was an increase in rent taken by permanent holders under the same circumstance.
('18', 319, 1, 7, 680836) So Tawan and Sarahbeshi are the same as if a party to a supposed contract, finding it to be burdensome, releases himself from the burden, and takes damages in [to] the bargain from the other party for his own release.
('18', 319, 1, 8, 681054) Under ordianry conditions, he who wants a release pays for it.
('18', 319, 1, 9, 681117) That the raiyats also wanted it is beside the point.
('18', 319, 1, 10, 681170) They were helpless.
('18', 319, 1, 11, 681190) The Bihar Government almost give away their case when they say:
('18', 319, 2, 12, 681254) the position was further complicated by the fact that the system was based on contracts between the planters and the raiyats, and interference in an elaborate system of contractual relations is obviously a matter of extreme delicacy, and no Government could venture on such interference except on the clearest proofs of necessity.
('18', 319, 2, 13, 681585) Mr. Gandhis intervention, by bringing the discontent of the raiyats to a head and thus threatening the district with an outburst of lawlessness, compelled the Government to anticipate the programme which it had mapped out, but by that time the information which the local Government had always insisted on as being essential had been collected by the settlement staff, and it was only because they had this information at their disposal that the Committee were able to bring their labours to so speedy a conclusion.
('18', 319, 2, 14, 682101) It is true that my presence in Champaran brought the discontent of the raiyats to a head; had they not been granted relief, they would certainly have ceased to labour for the planters, which they were in no way bound to.
('18', 319, 2, 15, 682322) But I deny that my intervention threatened the district with an outbreak of lawlessness,if by lawlessness is meant that of raiyats; for my presence, I say without hesitation, was the greatest restraining force against any such outbreak.
('18', 319, 2, 16, 682559) My condition with the raiyats was that I would leave them the moment they resorted to violence.
('18', 319, 2, 17, 682655) I mixed with thousands of them, and I do not know a single instance in which my presence had any but the most sobering effect
('18', 320, 0, 1, 682781) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 321
('18', 320, 1, 2, 682826) upon the raiyats.
('18', 320, 1, 3, 682844) I deny also that it was because the Committee had the information contained in the Settlement Records that they were able to bring their labours to so speedy a conclusion.
('18', 320, 1, 4, 683016) As a matter of fact, the planters never ceased to agitate for my expulsion during my stay in Champaran.
('18', 320, 1, 5, 683120) I make no complaint about itI made none then.
('18', 320, 1, 6, 683166) But in declining to remove myself or my Bihar friends from Champaran, I had often to address the Government and myself the question whether, since it was their duty to deal justly by every subject, they would not of themselves redress the grievances of Champaran raiyats; and this is what I said, on the 31st1 May, in one of my letter to a Government official:
('18', 320, 2, 7, 683527) Cannot the Government secure that freedom?
('18', 320, 2, 8, 683570) This is a natural exclamation.
('18', 320, 2, 9, 683601) My answer is that they cannot, in cases like this, without such assistance as is afforded to them by my mission.
('18', 320, 2, 10, 683714) The Government machinery is designedly slow.
('18', 320, 2, 11, 683759) It moves, must move, along the line of least resistance.
('18', 320, 2, 12, 683816) Reformers like myself who have no other axe to grind but that of the reform they are handing for the time being, specialize and create a force which the Government must reckon with.
('18', 320, 2, 13, 683998) Reformers may go wrong by being overzealous, indiscreet or indolent and ignorant.
('18', 320, 2, 14, 684080) The Government may go wrong by being impatient of them or over confident of their ability to do without them.
('18', 320, 2, 15, 684190) I hope, in this case, neither catastrophe will take place and the grievances, which I have already submitted and which are mostly admitted, will be effectively redressed.
('18', 320, 2, 16, 684361) Then the planters will have no cause to fcar or suspect the mission of which I have the honour to be in charge, and they will gladly accept the assistance of voluteers who will carry on the work of education and sanitation among the villagers and act as links between them and the raiyats.
('18', 320, 2, 17, 684651) It is not without great grief that I have felt compelled to criticize the Bihar Government note, but I cannot help feeling sad that, in their anxiety to sustain a bad cause, they should have belittled a mission that was in no sense politicala mission that was undertaken solely in the cause of humanity, and a mission that included not merely the removal of the grievances of the raiyats, but which included the devising of methods for their education, their sanitation, and their general uplift, whether with or without the help of the Government and the planters.
('18', 320, 2, 18, 685217) That constructive programme, although other activities have claimed my attention, has not yet stopped.
('18', 320, 2, 19, 685320) Here and there, volunteers are still conducting their schools among the raiyats in face of heavy odds.
('18', 320, 2, 20, 685423) The local Government know this, and they know also that I had endeavoured to keep the mission outside the
('18', 321, 0, 1, 685529) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 321, 1, 2, 685571) political arena.
('18', 321, 1, 3, 685588) I kept its doings as much from the public press as was possible for me to do; and I would not still yield to the temptation of publishing the many letters I had the privilege of writing to the local Government on behalf of the raiyats.
('18', 321, 1, 4, 685824) The Government of India very much resemble a man cutting the very branch on which he is sitting.
('18', 321, 1, 5, 685921) Sir Sankaran Nair has stated the obvious truth.
('18', 321, 1, 6, 685969) In support of it he brought forward two most telling illustrations.
('18', 321, 1, 7, 686037) It would have been graceful and dignified if they had at least remained silent, if they could not have acknowledged it.

('18', 322, 1, 2, 687848) 247. LETTER TO G.E. CHATFIELD
('18', 322, 2, 3, 687878) LABURANUM ROAD, GAMDEVI, BOMBAY, August 28, 1919
('18', 322, 3, 4, 687927) DEAR MR. CHATFIELD, In view of H.E. the Governors pronouncement that he would like by every means in his power to encourage decent house building on behalf of the mill hands and such other workers, Anasuyabehn has thought of a suggestion which she thinks I should place before you.
('18', 322, 3, 5, 688209) There is a certain survey number being Govt.
('18', 322, 3, 6, 688254) porperty situated outside Delhi Darwaja on the Dudheshwar Road in the limits of Dariapur Kazipur.
('18', 322, 3, 7, 688352) This number is Revenue Survey No.
('18', 322, 3, 8, 688386) 441. If it can be given on a long lease, she will be prepared, in conjunction with some of the labourers, to build suitable lodgeings for them and a school for their children.
('18', 322, 3, 9, 688562) The idea is to locate the school and the houses on the same piece of ground.
('18', 322, 3, 10, 688639) I understand that several mill hands are ready to put up their savings for the promotion of the scheme.
('18', 322, 3, 11, 688743) You may not know that she is already conducting one or two co operative societies in conjunction with Mr. Ewbank, Registrar of such societies.
('18', 322, 3, 12, 688886) Her societies having achieved a fair measure of success, she is anxious to proceed a step further and make with your help the experiment above described.
('18', 322, 3, 13, 689040) If the proposal commends itself to you, as I hope it will, and if you wish to discuss the matter further with Anasuyabehn, you have but to drop her a note and she tells me she would see you.
('18', 322, 3, 14, 689231) If, on the other hand, you would far rather discuss it with her and me jointly, rather than carry on a correspondence, on hearing from you I shall give you the exact date of my coming to Ahmedabad.
('18', 322, 4, 15, 689429) Yours sincerely, M. K. G. [PS.] I reach Ahmedabad on Monday next.

('18', 324, 4, 6, 691341) 250. LETTER TO THE TIMES OF INDIA 1
('18', 324, 5, 7, 691377) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, August 29, 1919
('18', 324, 6, 8, 691416) SIR, I know that it can only be by patient efforts that one can hope to remove the ignorance that must necessarily attach to all questions arising a few thousand miles from us.
('18', 324, 6, 9, 691593) Eureka s letter published in your issue of the 28th instant is a case in point.
('18', 324, 6, 10, 691673) He has raised many issues.
('18', 324, 6, 11, 691700) I propose to confine myself only to the South African.
('18', 324, 6, 12, 691755) The question before the public today is not one of emigration but that of the livelihood and status of those who have legally settled in South Africa, and neither Lord Sinha nor H.H. the Maharaja of Bikaner could give away inherent rights of citizens of the Empire, nor did they do any such thing.
('18', 324, 6, 13, 692053) Indians have settled in South Africa for over 50 years; they are not known to have lowered the standard of living.
('18', 324, 6, 14, 692168) Will Eureka please remember that the first Indian settlers were imported by the Europeans of South Africa?
('18', 324, 6, 15, 692275) I refer to the introduction of indentured Indians.
('18', 324, 6, 16, 692326) I said in 1894, as I repeat now, that it was a criminal blunder on the part of the greedy Europeans of Natal to have imported indentured labour from India at miserably low wages when they had 400,000 stalwart Zulus in their midst who would gladly have worked if the employers had not wanted to make enormous profits.
('18', 324, 6, 17, 692643) Can South Africa, with any right on its side, starve the descendants of the original settlers and the brethren out of existence?
('18', 324, 6, 18, 692772) It is purposeless for me to go into the question how and by whom South Africa was won; but let me correct Eureka by informing him that it was aid sent from India under the late Sir
('18', 324, 7, 19, 692953) 1 Eureka had written advising Gandhiji not to agitate about British Indian rights in South Africa and argued that Indians had practically nothing to complain of as only Europeans had fought for and retained South Africa.
('18', 325, 0, 1, 693174) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 325, 1, 2, 693216) George White which saves Ladysmith and which probably turned the fortunes of war.
('18', 325, 1, 3, 693298) Let me further inform Eureka that the 10,000 troops that Sir George White took with him included many Indian followers who were just as indispensable for the military operations as any soldier.
('18', 325, 1, 4, 693492) Nor is this all.
('18', 325, 1, 5, 693509) When the fate of Ladysmith trembled in the balance, when the late Lieut.
('18', 325, 1, 6, 693582) Roberts, fighting against heavy odds, lost his guns at the battle of Colenso, I had the honour to be in charge of the ambulance corps of nearly 1,200 Indians, free and indentured, literate and illiterate, drawn from all classes.
('18', 325, 1, 7, 693811) 1 Some of the men who are now in peril of losing the means of their livelihood had the privilege of bearing the stretcher that carried the dying Lieutenant.
('18', 325, 1, 8, 693968) The corps served too at the reverse of Spionkop.
('18', 325, 1, 9, 694017) We were engaged to work without the range of fire, not because we had objected but because the authorities would not risk our lives, as we were not trained for military operations.
('18', 325, 1, 10, 694198) But Col.
('18', 325, 1, 11, 694207) Gallway sent the message that, whilst we were not obliged to work under fire, General Buller would be glad if we could remove the wounded that were lying at the Field Hospital at the base of the hill.
('18', 325, 1, 12, 694408) There was danger of the Boers descending from the hill.
('18', 325, 1, 13, 694464) Without the slightest hesitation and indeed with gladness for the opportunity, every one of the men with me responded to the call and removed the wounded to the base hospital at Frere Comp, a distance of 24 miles.
('18', 325, 1, 14, 694678) The wounded included the late General Woodgate and the brave officers under him.
('18', 325, 1, 15, 694759) The English newspapers and the politicians were so enthusiastic about this purely voluntary work of the Indians that even laudatory verses were composed, whose refrain was We are sons of the Empire after all.
('18', 325, 1, 16, 694968) Are these Indians of whom these verses were written now to sing We are helots of the Empire after all, for that is what Indian settlers in south Africa would be totally reduced to if the English and the Indian public of India do not make a great effort to ward off the impending calamity.
('18', 325, 1, 17, 695257) In my opinion, the case for the European traders of South Africa is so hopelessly bad that it has only to be persistently, truthfully and calmly exposed to the whole of the Empire and it must fall to pieces.
('18', 325, 2, 18, 695465) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI Young India, 3 9 1919
('18', 325, 3, 19, 695512) 1 Vide Indian Ambulance Corps in Natal, 14 3 1900 & Indian Ambulance Corps, 18 4 1900.
('18', 326, 0, 1, 695599) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 327
('18', 326, 1, 2, 695644) 251. AUDI ALTERAM PARTEM
('18', 326, 2, 3, 695669) The public have recently received many a shock from the Punjab and I had hoped that we shall be spared rude shocks regarding the events of April from any other quarter.
('18', 326, 2, 4, 695838) But the papers received from Nadiad and published elsewhere provide disillusionment.
('18', 326, 2, 5, 695923) On the 21st of April last, the Collector of Kaira wrote to the Nadiad Municipality as follows:
('18', 326, 3, 6, 696018) I have the honour to address the Municipal Board of Nadiad as representative of the people of the town, and in the first place to convey to them through the Board my appreciation of the very general respect for law and order which they maintained during the period of strain and excitement which is now happily passed away; special thanks are due to those of the leaders who used their influence in the direction of moderation.
('18', 326, 3, 7, 696446) It is on these people, the readers will be surprised, an additional police is to be imposed in connection with the very incidents on which they have been congratulated.
('18', 326, 3, 8, 696615) And the expenses are to be collected from the Patidars and the Banias of Nadiad and landowners of Barejadi.
('18', 326, 3, 9, 696723) To my knowledge, the Collector, who was during the period of disturbace stationed at Nadiad, was in close touch with the leaders who were acting in co operation with him and who were no less successful than the Collector himself in preventing any distrubance whatsoever in Nadiad.
('18', 326, 3, 10, 697004) Nobody can be more sorry than I for the derailment.
('18', 326, 3, 11, 697056) I have in the strongest language possible criticized before a large Nadian audience the dastrdly act and the cowardice of the actors in hiding themselves.
('18', 326, 3, 12, 697211) I have spoken freely to them about the miscarriage of justice, in this instance on account of the perpetrators themselves, by reason of the absence of evidence.
('18', 326, 3, 13, 697372) There is no doubt about a conspiracy of silence on the part of the actors.
('18', 326, 3, 14, 697447) But it is one thing to condemn offences, it is a totally different thing to punish men who cannot be proved to have had any connection with the guilt, I know that some of these Patidars and Banias have strained every nerve to get hold of the real offenders and to induce them to confess.
('18', 326, 3, 15, 697735) And the Collector knows this too.
('18', 326, 3, 16, 697769) Why should they be fined for assistance they have given?
('18', 326, 3, 17, 697826) Out of a population of 31,483 in Nadiad, 6,093 men are Patidars, 3,652 are Banias.
('18', 326, 3, 18, 697909) Should these men be punished because a few ruffians in a fit of madness go to the station and pull down the rails?
('18', 326, 3, 19, 698024) There is absolutely no connection
('18', 327, 0, 1, 698058) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 327, 1, 2, 698100) established between the Patidars and the Banias, and the perpertators of the crime.
('18', 327, 1, 3, 698184) The very instructive papers I am able to publish show the real reason.
('18', 327, 1, 4, 698255) The Inspector General of Police, without a tittle of evidence, has the audacity to say regarding the various crimes:
('18', 327, 2, 5, 698372) In so far as the investigations have proceeded, it appears that each was a separate manifestation of the spirit of lawlessness that has been diffused in the Kara and Ahmedabad districts by the teachings of Mr. M.K. Gandhi and his followers.
('18', 327, 2, 6, 698613) This is on a par with the argument that because a crow sat upon a branch and the branch fell, it was the crow that did it.
('18', 327, 2, 7, 698736) My teaching has been before the country for the last four years and the only pity is that I am without much following.
('18', 327, 2, 8, 698855) If I had a staunch band of followers in appreciable numbers, I would make lawlessness impossible, and the Inspector General of Police would have little work left for him to do.
('18', 327, 2, 9, 699032) My teaching is, Follow truth at any cost and never do violence to person or property. There was no lawlessness whilst my teaching was being actively enforced in Kaira or amid the thousands of mill hands in Ahmedabad.
('18', 327, 2, 10, 699249) They did not hurt a fly.
('18', 327, 2, 11, 699274) The recklessnes running through the Collectors letter out rivals that of the Inspector General of Police.
('18', 327, 2, 12, 699380) One of his grounds for advising imposition of the additional police and communal responsibility is:
('18', 327, 3, 13, 699480) The derailment was undoubtedly caused by Nadiad people who will shortly be placed before the special tribunal.
('18', 327, 3, 14, 699591) They are mostly Patidars.
('18', 327, 3, 15, 699617) The letter from which this is taken is dated the 26th May when the men arrested were not even tried and yet, with amazing self assurance, he states that the derailment was caused by Nadiad people, mostly Patidars.
('18', 327, 3, 16, 699831) There was no necessity for this indecent haste.
('18', 327, 3, 17, 699879) In one breath as the record shows, he himself suggests:
('18', 327, 4, 18, 699935) I will deprecate any appearance of haste in arriving at a conclusion as cases are pending before the special tribunal in respect of all the offences and the results of these trials may affect the issue.
('18', 327, 4, 19, 700138) If, for example, in any particular case, the ringleaders are convicted and adequately punished, it may be a question whether it is necessary or desirable to impose any additional police at all.
('18', 327, 4, 20, 700332) And in the next paragraph but one he recommends communal responsibility before the trial.
('18', 327, 4, 21, 700422) The other ground given by him is really the crux.
('18', 327, 4, 22, 700472) The Collector says:
('18', 327, 5, 23, 700492) This offence is clearly the direct outcome of the persistent agitation against Government which has been going on among the people of Nadiad for some years and, to my perosnal knowledge, since the beginning of 1918. Nadiad is
('18', 328, 0, 1, 700718) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 329
('18', 328, 1, 2, 700763) the centre of the agitation in the district.
('18', 328, 1, 3, 700808) It was the headquarters of Mr. M.K. Gandhi last year during the passive resistance movement a movement of opposition to the payment of Government dues and thus directly calculated to undermine, as it did in fact undermine, all respect for the officers of Government and for Government itself.
('18', 328, 1, 4, 701101) This is a misleading statement.
('18', 328, 1, 5, 701133) I deny that respect for the officers of the Government, or for the Government itself, was at all undermined by the movement I had the privilege of leading, unless the Collector means to convey that the people ceased to fear the Ravanias, the Talatis and the Mukhis.
('18', 328, 1, 6, 701399) 1 When I went to Kaira, I found that many people were in constant terror of these petty officials and I am glad to be able to testify that these very men now no longer fear them or even the higher officials.
('18', 328, 1, 7, 701607) I advised them to distinguish between respect and fear, and I would challenge the Collector to show that any of the men who took part in the movement, whilst they ceased to fear, showed the slightest disrespect to authority.
('18', 328, 1, 8, 701832) I submit that it is wrong to punish people unheard.
('18', 328, 1, 9, 701884) The people of Nadiad, and specially the Patidars and the Banias, who are the parties concerned, and the landowners of Barejadi ought at least in decency to be called upon to show why they should not be fined Rs. 22,000, bacause that is what the order amounts to.
('18', 328, 1, 10, 702147) Moreover, it is dishonest to fasten the guilt of a dozen drunkards of a big town on a whole population when the real cause of punishment is not the crime but the political activity of the people.
('18', 328, 1, 11, 702343) The paragraph regarding Banias is too amusing to cause indignation.
('18', 328, 1, 12, 702411) But I cannot help pitying the Collector of Nadiad for his ignorance of the true situation; for I know Mr. Ker well enough to understand that he does not wish to do wilful injustice.
('18', 328, 1, 13, 702593) I have no doubt he believes that I, being a Bania, leagued with Messrs Talati and Shah to mislead the Patidars into offering civil resistance.
('18', 328, 1, 14, 702736) The fact, however, is that it was only a month ago that I understood Mr. Shah was a Bania and it was the Collectors letter under discussion which enables me to find that Mr. Talati is also a Bania.
('18', 328, 1, 15, 702934) Up to the present moment, I had taken him to be a Patidar.
('18', 328, 1, 16, 702993) I have not gone about the world preaching satyagraha because I am a Bania.
('18', 328, 1, 17, 703068) My life companions in the development of satyagraha are Europeans and Indians drawn from all the corners of India.
('18', 328, 1, 18, 703183) Satyagraha is a soldierly instinct, and Banias are largely associated with money making rather
('18', 328, 2, 19, 703278) 1 Various revenue officals
('18', 329, 0, 1, 703305) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 329, 1, 2, 703347) than with fighting for a cause.
('18', 329, 1, 3, 703379) Hence I have had the fewest co workers from among fellow Banias.
('18', 329, 1, 4, 703444) My purpose, however, in dealing with the personal matter is to show how cruelly isolated the officials remain from us and thus deprive themselves of opportunity of knowing the people and, therefore, of serving them truly.
('18', 329, 1, 5, 703666) I hope that His Excellency the Governor will with his usual application personally investigate the matter.
('18', 329, 1, 6, 703773) In my humble opinion, no additonal police is required in Nadiad, but if it is considered by the Government that it is required for public safety, I claim that no case has been made out for making the Patidars and Banias of Nadiad and the landowners of Barejadi pay for it.
('18', 329, 1, 7, 704046) It is not the payment that wounds, but the unmerited slur cast upon men without being heard.

('18', 329, 3, 9, 704162) 252. LETTER TO THE PRESS
('18', 329, 4, 10, 704187) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY August 30, 1919
('18', 329, 5, 11, 704225) SIR, It has been my misfortune from time to time to report to the public deaths of Indians who have worked for and served India in far off South Africa.
('18', 329, 5, 12, 704378) One of the ablest of them, a cable from Mr. Rustomjee tells me, has just departed this life.
('18', 329, 5, 13, 704471) His name was Dawood Mahomed.
('18', 329, 5, 14, 704500) Mr. Dawood Mahomed rose from the ranks.
('18', 329, 5, 15, 704540) He never received any English education.
('18', 329, 5, 16, 704581) I am not sure that he passed through more than two standards in a vernacular school in India.
('18', 329, 5, 17, 704675) But his versatile ability and perseverance gave him such a wonderful grasp over languages without any book learning whatsoever, that I have known him hold discourse with people in Tamil, Hindi, Creole, French, Dutch and English, besides his mother tongue, Gujarati.
('18', 329, 5, 18, 704941) His native wit made him a popular speaker.
('18', 329, 5, 19, 704984) He was as keen a politician as he was a merchant.
('18', 329, 5, 20, 705034) And when the critical moment for decision came, he threw in his lot with the South African civil resisters, crossed the border and together with other merchants of note presented himself for arrest for crossing the sacred border of the Transvaal.
('18', 329, 5, 21, 705281) 1 Having carried on an extensive business with European business houses, he
('18', 329, 6, 22, 705357) 1 Vide The Late Mr. Hoosen Dawad, 24 9 1913
('18', 330, 0, 1, 705401) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 331
('18', 330, 1, 2, 705446) was well known to many Europeans and, owing to his great ability, commanded their respect.
('18', 330, 1, 3, 705537) And I am happy to be able to testify that for him, who was used to a luxurious life and who was at the time 50 years old, to have risked imprisonment for the sake of conscience was an act which raised him still further in the estimation of his many European friends rather than otherwise.
('18', 330, 1, 4, 705826) It was a privilege for me to find men in South Africa drawn from the commercial class giving freely of their time, their money and even voluntarily risking loss of personal freedom, by undergoing imprisonment, and property.
('18', 330, 1, 5, 706050) Mr. Dawood Mohomed was one of the best among these.
('18', 330, 1, 6, 706102) He was President of the Natal Indian Congress for a number of years and known to Indians all over South Africa.
('18', 330, 1, 7, 706214) In my humble opinion, though India knew him not, she has every reason to be proud of having produced Dawood Mahomed.
('18', 330, 1, 8, 706331) Indians in South Africa badly needed his service at the present moment.
('18', 330, 1, 9, 706403) They are the poorer for Mr. Dawood Mahomeds death and, may I add, poorer also for the death of that brave statesman, General Botha 1 .
('18', 330, 1, 10, 706538) The duty of India is, therefore, all the greater to see that the interests of her sons struggling for freedom are fully protected.
('18', 330, 2, 11, 706669) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 1 9 1919
('18', 330, 3, 12, 706725) 253. SPEECH AT WOMENS MEETING, DOHAD 2
('18', 330, 4, 13, 706764) August 31, 1919
('18', 330, 5, 14, 706780) In the afternoon, Mr. Gandhi addressed a meting of women on swadeshi and the importance of hand spinning.
('18', 330, 5, 15, 706886) Hundreds of women attended the meeting.
('18', 330, 5, 16, 706926) The following is the gist of Mr. Gandhis address: The protection of dharma is in the hands of women as men, being too much engrossed in worldly cares, often forget it and sometimes neglect it.
('18', 330, 5, 17, 707119) It is for the women to protect it as dearly as their children.
('18', 330, 5, 18, 707182) Hence, I have ever believed that the salvation of India lies in the elevation of her women.
('18', 330, 5, 19, 707274) Swadeshi is a great dharma which has been forsaken by most of the women of Gujarat.
('18', 330, 5, 20, 707358) None who neglects a neighbour can serve a distant man.
('18', 330, 5, 21, 707413) He who serves his neighbour
('18', 330, 6, 22, 707441) 1 Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa (1910 19) he passed away on August 28. 2 One of the principal towns of the Panch Mahals, a district in Gujarat.
('18', 331, 0, 1, 707599) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 331, 1, 2, 707641) serves the world.
('18', 331, 1, 3, 707659) It is irreligious to neglect our own artisans and encourage the foreign ones.
('18', 331, 1, 4, 707737) For a century we have been guilty of that sin through the stress of various circumstances.
('18', 331, 1, 5, 707828) As a result, we have deprived our own artisans of crores of rupees and transferred them into foreign hands.
('18', 331, 1, 6, 707936) And hence it is that India is suffering from starvation.
('18', 331, 1, 7, 707993) Our greatest needs are only two, viz., food and colthing.
('18', 331, 1, 8, 708051) Fortunately, the food we eat is produced in out own country.
('18', 331, 1, 9, 708112) But the cloth that we wear comes mostly from foreign countries.
('18', 331, 1, 10, 708176) As a result, we sent away sixty crores of rupees last year to foreign countries.
('18', 331, 1, 11, 708257) This is a matter of great shame.
('18', 331, 1, 12, 708290) It is our duty to be free from this position and the easiest way to do so is to do exactly as we did a hundred years ago.
('18', 331, 1, 13, 708412) Women should mainly take to spinning, while men must weave.
('18', 331, 1, 14, 708472) I have met hundreds of women since the launching of the swadeshi movement, and some of them have told me that they used to spin cotton, or that their mothers did so.
('18', 331, 1, 15, 708638) My own mother used to spin yarn and wear coarse cloth, though she could afford to purchase finer cloth and she did so simply out of love of it.
('18', 331, 1, 16, 708782) Spinning was not then regarded as a mean occupation.
('18', 331, 1, 17, 708835) Even queens in royal families used to spin out of pure love of it or out of fellow feeling.
('18', 331, 1, 18, 708927) It behoves our sisters in Dohad to revive that ancient and holy art.
('18', 331, 1, 19, 708996) I do not ask that a poor woman should give up her own present honest calling and take to spinning.
('18', 331, 1, 20, 709095) What I say is that as spinning is a simple and beautiful art and can be learnt easily, it can be taken up and left off at will.
('18', 331, 1, 21, 709223) If our poor sisters do a little spinning in their leisure hours, they can have a little income of their own, and give an impetus to a most essential indigenous handicraft.
('18', 331, 1, 22, 709395) In order to spread widely the gospel of swadeshi, womens earnestness is very essential.
('18', 331, 1, 23, 709483) Everyone of you should decide henceforth to wear swadeshi clothes.
('18', 331, 1, 24, 709550) To spin daily some quantity of yarn at least for the sake of your country must be your net resolve.
('18', 331, 1, 25, 709650) If the women of Dohad would but make up their minds, all their clothing could be obtained from Dohad itself.
('18', 331, 1, 26, 709759) Not only that the people of Dohad will be free from the trouble of importing cloth from abroad but most of the money they spend on cloth will flow into the pockets of the women and weavers of Dohad.
('18', 331, 1, 27, 709958) It requires some little sacrifice to bring about this result.
('18', 331, 1, 28, 710020) We shall have, for the time being at least, to rest content with coarse cloth woven by our people and be thankful to God, and banishing all idleness, should work the wheel in our moments of leisure.
('18', 331, 1, 29, 710219) I hope that every woman will be interested in this work.
('18', 331, 2, 30, 710276) At the close of the meeting, many women expressed a desire to begin
('18', 332, 0, 1, 710344) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 333
('18', 332, 1, 2, 710389) spinning immediately and some who knew that art volunteered to teach it to the new aspirants.

('18', 332, 3, 4, 710506) 254. SPEECH AT WEAVERS MEETING, DOHAD 1
('18', 332, 4, 5, 710546) August 31, 1919
('18', 332, 5, 6, 710562) I am much pained to see [some] 2 Antyaja 3 brothers [standing away from others].
('18', 332, 5, 7, 710643) I have studied Hindu religion [according] to my lights and I try to carry out its principles so far as I can.
('18', 332, 5, 8, 710753) I believe that no nation can really progress without religion.
('18', 332, 5, 9, 710816) But I cannot believe that there is any religion in regarding it a sin to touch any particular community.
('18', 332, 5, 10, 710921) To me even to think that it is pollution to touch any creation of God is sinful.
('18', 332, 5, 11, 711002) To me it is the height of irreligion to look upon every custom as part and parcel of religion.
('18', 332, 5, 12, 711097) Customs may be good or bad.
('18', 332, 5, 13, 711125) I think it to be a bad custom not to touch the Antyajas.
('18', 332, 5, 14, 711182) A little thinking would show that it is improper not to touch them on the score of their occupation.
('18', 332, 5, 15, 711283) If their occupation is dishonourable, ask them to leave it off.
('18', 332, 5, 16, 711347) If it is a sin to sweep our latrines, have done with it, and imagine the plight of your town under that circumstance.
('18', 332, 5, 17, 711465) Every mother removes the excreta of her child, she does it with pleasure and thinks it to be her duty.
('18', 332, 5, 18, 711568) And all of us bow to our mothers.
('18', 332, 5, 19, 711602) I do not use the language of exaggeration when I say that the Bhangis are a dirty people, that they eat meat and drink, I may say that we touch many who do such things, and that we do not refuse to associate with men and women who are dirtier than the Antyajas.
('18', 332, 5, 20, 711864) I do not want to put the prejudice of untouchability on a level with food and marriage regulations based on caste distinctions.
('18', 332, 5, 21, 711992) The latter is a matter admitting of differences of opinion.
('18', 332, 5, 22, 712052) For it is a question of choice.
('18', 332, 5, 23, 712084) We are not bound to subscribe to promiscuous inter dining and intermarriage.
('18', 332, 5, 24, 712161) But to regard any of Gods creatures as untouchable appears to me to be a sin.
('18', 332, 5, 25, 712239) I wish that the Hindus of Dohad may be free from this sin.

('18', 335, 1, 2, 716906) 257. VICTIMS, NOT GUILTY
('18', 335, 2, 3, 716931) The readers will recall our Lahore correspondents remarks about the Ramnager cases.
('18', 335, 2, 4, 717015) I have a file of papers in these cases, but I was unprepared to discuss them until I got at least the text of the judgement.
('18', 335, 2, 5, 717140) This is not before the readers.
('18', 335, 2, 6, 717172) The able petition on behalf of Lala Karamchandnot the same as the lad Karamchand who was sentenced to be hangedpresented by his old mother Ganga Devi shows in the graphic language of his son Devidass letter that the accused in the case are victims, not guilty.
('18', 335, 2, 7, 717433) If the simple narrative of Lala Karamchands son be true, and I think there is no reason to doubt its accuracy, the whole proceedings were a farce.
('18', 335, 2, 8, 717580) They constituted not a legal trial but a mockery of it.
('18', 335, 2, 9, 717636) The accused, twenty eight in number, were all tried together, the trial was finished in one day during which altogether 150 defence witnesses were examined, the accused were not informed of the charge against them except through the mouths of the prosecution witnesses.
('18', 335, 2, 10, 717906) How the judge could examine so many witnesses in a day passes comprehension.
('18', 335, 2, 11, 717983) In spite of repeated applications copy of notes of evidence or of the statements of the accused is not furnished.
('18', 335, 2, 12, 718097) The only inference is that no notes were kept.
('18', 335, 2, 13, 718144) Why were these cases rushed so?
('18', 335, 2, 14, 718176) The accused were arrested eight days after the alleged offence.
('18', 335, 2, 15, 718240) Order was completely restored throughout the Punjab by that time.
('18', 335, 2, 16, 718306) The trial took place on the 22nd May, five weeks after the alleged offence.
('18', 335, 2, 17, 718382) There was no occasion, then, for indecently rushing through the trial.
('18', 335, 2, 18, 718453) On the 17th April, a police officer notes in his diary that all was quiet, save that there was a partial hartal.
('18', 335, 2, 19, 718566) It is rightly suggested in the papers that mention would surely have been made in the diary of any serious offence.
('18', 335, 2, 20, 718682) The offence alleged is not such as could be committed in secret.
('18', 335, 2, 21, 718747) It is stated to have been openly committed.
('18', 335, 2, 22, 718791) Here at least there is enough to throw doubt on the prosecution story.
('18', 335, 2, 23, 718862) But the Judge had no doubt about it!
('18', 335, 2, 24, 718899) The story of the prosecution is varied from time to time.
('18', 335, 2, 25, 718957) Five maunds of fuel said to have been required for burning His Majestys effigy became reduced to a few straws!
('18', 335, 2, 26, 719068) At best all but one of the accused appear to have been mere spectators.
('18', 336, 0, 1, 719140) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 337
('18', 336, 1, 2, 719185) These facts are common to all the accused.
('18', 336, 1, 3, 719228) I have been supplied also with the papers regarding Lala Daulatram.
('18', 336, 1, 4, 719296) The facts therein set forth tally with those furnished in Lala Karmachands case.
('18', 336, 1, 5, 719377) I am convinced that twenty eight innocent men have been ignorantly condemned.
('18', 336, 1, 6, 719455) They should be set free.
('18', 336, 1, 7, 719480) Lala Karamchand is an old retired servant.
('18', 336, 1, 8, 719523) He has never taken part in politics.
('18', 336, 1, 9, 719560) For years past, he has been passing his time between Ramnagar and Hardwar, devoting it to religious pursuits.
('18', 336, 1, 10, 719670) Lala Daulatram is the son of one who has rendered meritorious service to the Government for a long period.
('18', 336, 1, 11, 719777) In fact, the whole family seems to belong to the official class.
('18', 336, 1, 12, 719842) It is cruel to think that such men should have been so shamelessly punished.
('18', 336, 1, 13, 719919) The judgement is self condemned.
('18', 336, 1, 14, 719952) It breathes vindictiveness and anger.

('18', 336, 3, 19, 720388) 258. DR.
('18', 336, 3, 20, 720397) SATYAPALS CASE
('18', 336, 4, 21, 720412) Dr. Satyapals statement, which is published in another column, shows what a gross injustice has been done in his case as in that of Dr. Kitchlew 1. They had to be absolved from any participation in the violence that occurred after their arrest.
('18', 336, 4, 22, 720657) What violence there ever was in Amritsar took place after they were arrested.
('18', 336, 4, 23, 720735) They were, therefore, accused of all sorts of things which they had never done, of speeches they had never made.
('18', 336, 4, 24, 720848) Dr. Satyapals clear, emphatic and courageous statement is a categorical denial of the whole string of charge against him.
('18', 336, 4, 25, 720970) He shows clearly that the speeches he made were incorrectly reported by the C.I.D. officials, and that every time he spoke, he preached the gospel of truth and non violence, and unceasingly warned the people against losing their temper and going in for any excesses.
('18', 336, 5, 26, 721237) 1 Dr. Saifuddin Kitchlew (1887 1963); Barrister and Congress leader of the Punjab
('18', 337, 0, 1, 721319) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 337, 1, 2, 721361) I have purposely refrained from printing a spirited letter addressed to me by Dr. Satyapals father in which he gives his own impressions of the case.
('18', 337, 1, 3, 721511) I cannot, however, resist the temptation of quoting some of the facts stated in it.
('18', 337, 1, 4, 721595) For instance, he says :
('18', 337, 2, 5, 721619) At first, it was not the intention of the Government to prosecute Drs.
('18', 337, 2, 6, 721690) Ktchlew and Satyapal who had been deported on the 10th April and, therefore, his (the approvers) confessional statement before the Magistrate of Amritsar did not incriminate them.

('18', 337, 2, 8, 722044) If this allegation is true, it is a severe reflection on the methods of [the] prosecution and it vitiates the whole of the proceedings.
('18', 337, 2, 9, 722180) Again, this letter says :
('18', 337, 3, 10, 722206) Dr. Satyapal was restricted from public speaking, etc., on the 29th March.

('18', 337, 3, 14, 722808) That was on the 28th March.
('18', 337, 3, 15, 722836) But if there was any conspiracy, it became one not on the 28th but on the 30th.
('18', 337, 3, 16, 722916) A platform ticket agitation carried on by Dr. Satyapal in January and February last was shamelessly brought into the trial to prejudice him, an agitation that was entirely harmless and successful, and about which Dr. Satyapal even received thanks from the station authorities.
('18', 337, 3, 17, 723193) The letter concludes :
('18', 337, 4, 18, 723216) For your information I may mention that Dr. Satyapal offered himself for military service in 1915 and was granted a temporary commission as a lieutenant, I.M.S. He was posted at Aden where, under very trying circumstances, he worked for one year to the satisfaction of his superior officers who gave him eulogizing testimonials at the time of his departure.
('18', 337, 4, 19, 723574) In 1918 he again volunteered for service but the arrangement fell through.
('18', 337, 4, 20, 723649) During the influenza and malaria epidemics he did his level best in his humble way to mitigate the suffering of his fellow townsmen, and was awarded non official sanads.
('18', 337, 4, 21, 723819) It is indeed a befitting sequel to be convicted under section 124A after such a record of services to the Government and public both.

('18', 339, 1, 2, 725440) 260. INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('18', 339, 2, 3, 725469) Mr. Montagus reply to the deputations 1 that waited on him on the South African question is reassuring so far as it goes.
('18', 339, 2, 4, 725591) It is a matterfor great satisfaction that he will secure Indian representation upon the Commission, provided, of course, that that representation is equal to that of the anti Asiatic party and provided further that the Commission has no power to diminish the existing rights of British Indians, and provided further that the Asiatic Bill just passed remains in abeyance and that the Commission is given the power to recommend its withdrawal.
('18', 339, 2, 5, 726033) The resolution of the managing committee of the Imperial Indian Citizenship Association published in another column runs along the lines suggested by us.
('18', 339, 2, 6, 726187) Past promises, considerations of equity and justice, the exemplary conduct of the Indian settlers of South Africa, their contribution to the late South Africa war, at the time of the Zulu rebellion and the European war, make an overwhelming case against any diminution of existing rights.
('18', 339, 2, 7, 726476) The Commission, in order to be just and effective, can only contemplate the relaxation, if not total removal, of the present restrictions for which the justification is the strong prejudice only against Indians on the part of the European traders.
('18', 339, 2, 8, 726724) But such unreasoning prejudice may be pleaded as a cause is a system of government that is inefficient and corrupt.
('18', 339, 2, 9, 726840) The Imperial Government to be truly Imperial must have, under certain circumstances, be they ever so rare, powers of effective intervention for the protection of weaker interests.
('18', 339, 2, 10, 727020) It is therefore not possible for Indian public opinion to accept Mr. Montagus dictum that an exercise of the veto is politically unfeasible.
('18', 339, 2, 11, 727161) The veto is not merely a moral check but, in exceptional cases, it must prove a very material and tangible check upon excesses and upon injustice.
('18', 339, 2, 12, 727308) The Empire to hold together must have some basic principles from which no member dare depart.
('18', 339, 2, 13, 727402) If Mr. Montagu is convinced, as he apparently is, of the injustice of the Asiatic Act and of its controverting the principles of the British Constitution, where is the difficulty about vetoing the Act?
('18', 339, 2, 14, 727604) The utmost that can happen is that South Africa may secede from the Imperial partnership.
('18', 339, 2, 15, 727694) Surely it were a thousand times better that South
('18', 339, 3, 16, 727744) 1 This was led by Surendranath Banerjea, on August 28; vide also Indians in South Africa, 7 9 1919.
('18', 340, 0, 1, 727844) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 341
('18', 340, 1, 2, 727889) Africa should cease to be a member of the Empire than that it should corrupt and undermine the whole of the Imperial fabric.
('18', 340, 1, 3, 728014) It is infinitely better that the Empire has fewer partners than there are, but all working together in the same upward direction than that it should, by coquetting with legalized confiscations and such other immoralities, sow the seeds of its own disruption.
('18', 340, 1, 4, 728273) And, after all, selfishness, greed and injustice are handmaids of cowardice.
('18', 340, 1, 5, 728350) There is no reason to fear that a wholesome and timely exercise of the Royal veto will create any great stir in South Africa.
('18', 340, 1, 6, 728476) The late Sir Henry Parkes, if my recollection serves me right, did issue a threat of secession or some such thing when the late Mr. Chamberlain dared to veto the Australian Immigration Restriction Act containing a racial bar.
('18', 340, 1, 7, 728702) But I am free to confess that so long as milder measures are available, the extreme remedy of vetoing ought not to be applied.
('18', 340, 1, 8, 728829) It is undoubtedly like a strong blister causing great though momentary pain, and, therefore, to be sparingly used.
('18', 340, 1, 9, 728944) The proposed Commission, if there is a strong Indian representation upon it, should prove effective enough for the purpose to be attained.
('18', 340, 1, 10, 729083) The thing, therefore, for the time being is to concentrate public opinion upon a strong Commission and a proper safeguarding reference under which it should act.
('18', 340, 1, 11, 729245) It was a great relief to find Mr. Montagu not falling into the Reciprocity trap prepared by Sir William Meyer, let me hope, in a hasty moment.
('18', 340, 1, 12, 729388) I am sorry Mr. Banerjea so easily fell into it.
('18', 340, 1, 13, 729436) It is murdering the language to use so good a word as reciprocity for so bad a cause as the one under notice.
('18', 340, 1, 14, 729546) If we must go in for a bad thing, we must at least recognize it by its correct name which is retaliation.
('18', 340, 1, 15, 729652) Personally, I do not believe in retaliation at all.
('18', 340, 1, 16, 729704) It always in the end returns with redoubled force on the retaliator.
('18', 340, 1, 17, 729773) But as The Times of India, which is rendering signal service to the cause of our countrymen in South Africa, very rightly points out, retaliation miscalled reciprocity can serve no earthly purpose in the present case.
('18', 340, 1, 18, 729991) Its main objection is its utter futility, and if we ever embark upon this very unpractical method, it will be hailed with satisfaction by the anti Asiatic party in South Africa, and we shall be cursed by the hundred and fifty thousand Indians whose very existence is at stake.
('18', 340, 1, 19, 730268) One may retaliate when the stake is good.
('18', 340, 1, 20, 730310) It is terrible to think of it when it is men and women who constitute the stake.
('18', 340, 1, 21, 730391) What comfort can it be to our countrymen in South Africa for India to be able to send to South Africa a few tons of coal and to shut the gates of India in the
('18', 341, 0, 1, 730550) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 341, 1, 2, 730592) face of a stray South African tourist as against the banishmentfor that is virtually the goal of the anti Asiatic partyof a hundred and fifty thousand Indian settlers, or at least their reduction to helotry.
('18', 341, 1, 3, 730800) The issue was stated by the late Sir William Wilson Hunter in clear and unmistakable language in 1896 or 95. Writing on this very question of British Indians in South Africa, he said, are they or not to enjoy the full status of British citizens in His Majestys Dominions?
('18', 341, 1, 4, 731072) It cannot be solved by the make shift of retaliation or reciprocity by whatever term it is recognized.
('18', 341, 1, 5, 731175) It can only be solved by correct statesmanship and correct conduct on our part.
('18', 341, 2, 6, 731255) Young India, 6 9 1919
('18', 341, 3, 7, 731277) 261. LETTER TO THE PRESS
('18', 341, 4, 8, 731302) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, September 6, 1919
('18', 341, 5, 9, 731343) THE EDITOR THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE
('18', 341, 6, 10, 731375) SIR, I had the privilege of being a guest of Maulana Abdul Bari Saheb of Firangi Mahal some time ago.
('18', 341, 6, 11, 731477) We on this side of India, barring the Mohammedans, know little of this great and good man.
('18', 341, 6, 12, 731568) He is one of the foremost religious preceptors in Islam and has thousands of followers all over India.
('18', 341, 6, 13, 731671) His unassuming and truthful nature turns his opponents into friends when they begin to understand him.
('18', 341, 6, 14, 731774) He and I discussed many problems of mutual interest, in the course of which I told him that so far as I could interpret Hindu opinion, I had no doubt that it would be solidly for the Mohammedans in the very difficult task of securing justice on the Turkish claims, difficult because the question was burdened with so many European complications that the Allied Powers might in a weak moment fail to decide it on grounds of justice alone.
('18', 341, 6, 15, 732212) He said to me with calm deliberation, but without any hesitation, If we do not help you and do justice to you, Hindus, I for one cannot claim nor even take for my fellow religionists your active help. I said, Surely, you do not for one moment consider that I have spoken in any spirit of bargaining.
('18', 341, 6, 16, 732512) The question that is behind the thought you have just now expressed, viz., that of cow killing, can be decided on its own merits
('18', 342, 0, 1, 732641) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 343
('18', 342, 1, 2, 732686) and can await solution, for the ripening of true friendship between us and for an impartial discussion. He immediately intervened as soon as I had finished the sentence and said, Please excuse me.
('18', 342, 1, 3, 732883) I know you want to help, because our cause is just and because we are children of the same soil, and not because you want any quid pro quo.
('18', 342, 1, 4, 733023) But do we not owe a duty to ourselves?
('18', 342, 1, 5, 733062) Islam will fall to pieces if it ever takes and never gives.
('18', 342, 1, 6, 733122) It must be faithful above all.
('18', 342, 1, 7, 733153) The nobilityof our creed (he used the expression khandani) requires us to be strictly just to our neighbours.
('18', 342, 1, 8, 733263) Here it is a question of taking service.
('18', 342, 1, 9, 733304) The Hindus will judge our faith, and rightly, by our conduct towards them.
('18', 342, 1, 10, 733379) That is why I say: if we take from you, we must give to you. I have only given the tiniest bit of the wonderful conversation I had with a priest who combines in him learning, true wisdom and humility.
('18', 342, 1, 11, 733580) The Maulana has been true to his word.
('18', 342, 1, 12, 733619) I know ever since this conversation, he has been preaching amongst his followers and friends the necessity of abstention from cow killing and today of all days, one of the most sacred of Islam, he has thought of the Hindus and sent me the following telegram :
('18', 342, 2, 13, 733879) In celebration of Hindu Muslim unity no cow sacrifices in Firangi Mahal this BakridAbdul Bari.
('18', 342, 2, 14, 733974) To which I have sent the following reply:
('18', 342, 3, 15, 734016) Delighted with your great act of renunciation.
('18', 342, 3, 16, 734063) Pray, accept Id Mubarak.
('18', 342, 3, 17, 734088) Would to God that all of us, Hindus, Mohmmedans, Christians, Parsis, Jews, belonging to all races, have the same virtue of charity, justness and breadth of vision.
('18', 342, 3, 18, 734252) The world will surely be the better for it.
('18', 342, 4, 19, 734296) Your, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 9 9 1919
