('18', 343, 8, 8, 734609) 263. OUR AIM
('18', 343, 9, 9, 734622) When I undertook to supervise the editing of Young India, it occurred to my friends and me whether it would not be more proper for me to run a Gujarati newspaper than to spend my time on writing Engish articles, revising them, thinking over them and summarizing them.
('18', 343, 9, 10, 734890) A more important question, however, washow could I serve India best?
('18', 343, 9, 11, 734959) I saw then that it was clearly my duty to continue Young India.
('18', 343, 9, 12, 735023) I know I can use my knowledge of English for the service of the people.
('18', 343, 9, 13, 735095) But my friends felt, and so did I, that it was necessary for me to run a Gujarati paper as well.
('18', 343, 9, 14, 735192) Favourable circumstances presented themselves.
('18', 343, 9, 15, 735239) I have owned a press.
('18', 343, 9, 16, 735261) I ran Indian Opinion for a long time, 2 though I did not allow myself to be known as its editor.
('18', 343, 9, 17, 735358) This is the first occasion when I appear in public as an editor.
('18', 343, 9, 18, 735423) I have welcomed it, but I am nervous.
('18', 343, 9, 19, 735461) I am fully aware of the responsibility I am undertaking.
('18', 343, 9, 20, 735518) This is not South Africa.
('18', 343, 9, 21, 735544) There I used to manage things somehow.
('18', 343, 9, 22, 735583) But here?
('18', 343, 9, 23, 735593) There is no lack of newspapers.
('18', 343, 9, 24, 735625) Of writers there are many.
('18', 343, 9, 25, 735652) My command of the language is severely limited.
('18', 343, 9, 26, 735700) Having stayed out of India for twenty years, my information about Indian problems is bound to be inadequate.
('18', 343, 9, 27, 735809) This is no mere language of modesty but a vivid picture of my condition.
('18', 343, 10, 28, 735882) 1 The Assistant Private Secretary, in his letter of September 7, quoting Gandhijis above telegram, informed him that it had been transferred to the Home department of the Government of India for disposal.
('18', 343, 10, 29, 736087) 2 From 1903 to 1914; H.S.L. Polak was the declared editor.
('18', 344, 0, 1, 736146) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 345
('18', 344, 1, 2, 736191) Despite these limitations of mine, I clearly see that I have something to give to India which no one else has in equal measure.
('18', 344, 1, 3, 736319) With much striving I have formulated some principles for my life and put them into practice.
('18', 344, 1, 4, 736412) The happiness I have found that way, I think, I have not seen in others.
('18', 344, 1, 5, 736485) Many a friend has testified to this.
('18', 344, 1, 6, 736522) It is my sincere aspiration to place these principles before India and share my happiness with her.
('18', 344, 1, 7, 736622) A newspaper is one means to that end.
('18', 344, 1, 8, 736660) For me, satyagraha is not a mere copy book maxim : it is my very life.
('18', 344, 1, 9, 736731) To me nothing but truth has any interest.
('18', 344, 1, 10, 736773) I am convinced that the country can never benefit by untruth.
('18', 344, 1, 11, 736835) In any case, I am firmly of the view that, even if untruth should seem profitable for the time being, we must not abandon truth.
('18', 344, 1, 12, 736964) I have been a seeker of this truth ever since I began to understand things.
('18', 344, 1, 13, 737040) I have been trying to practise it for 40 years.
('18', 344, 1, 14, 737088) Even so, I know that I have not attained perfect harmony in thought, word and deed.
('18', 344, 1, 15, 737172) What does it matter, though?
('18', 344, 1, 16, 737201) The more we strive to realize an ideal, the farther it recedes.
('18', 344, 1, 17, 737265) To pursue it the more vigorously is the only object worthy of endeavour.
('18', 344, 1, 18, 737338) We may stumble and fall, but shall rise again; it should be enough if we did not run away from the battle.
('18', 344, 1, 19, 737445) In the course of my seeking I have come by innumerable gems, which I want to place before India.
('18', 344, 1, 20, 737542) Navajivan is intended to be a sort of advertisement for them.
('18', 344, 1, 21, 737604) I saw, during my pursuit of truth, that it was our duty to give willing obedience to laws.
('18', 344, 1, 22, 737695) But I also saw, while doing this duty, that it was equally a duty to disobey a law if it fostered untruth.
('18', 344, 1, 23, 737802) What form should such disobedience take?
('18', 344, 1, 24, 737843) We should suffer the penalty for the breach of law involved in acting according to the truth.
('18', 344, 1, 25, 737937) This is known as civil disobedience.
('18', 344, 1, 26, 737974) Who is qualified for such disobedience and which law should be considered as fostering untruth cannot be decided by laying down definite rules.
('18', 344, 1, 27, 738118) Experience alone will help one to decide.
('18', 344, 1, 28, 738160) For that we need both time and means.
('18', 344, 1, 29, 738198) Let Navajivan be the means.
('18', 344, 1, 30, 738226) Even when fighting in circumstances none too favourable to them, the satyagrahis were able to maintain amicable relations with the officials, for in satyagraha there is no room for anger or ill will.
('18', 344, 1, 31, 738426) Truth has its effect on the other party, with the result that he harbours no distrust.
('18', 344, 1, 32, 738513) This ensures mutual respect and amicable relations between the two parties though they fight.
('18', 344, 1, 33, 738607) Navajivan will show with facts and
('18', 345, 0, 1, 738642) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 345, 1, 2, 738684) arguments that, in India too, though fighting in regard to matters on which we differ from the officials, we may still co operate with them on others.
('18', 345, 1, 3, 738835) But satyagraha is not limited to the relationship between the rulers and the ruled.
('18', 345, 1, 4, 738919) For social reform, too, it is a priceless weapon, one without a parallel.
('18', 345, 1, 5, 738993) The condition of women, our many evil customs, the difficulties which arise between Hindus and Muslims, the hardships of the untouchablesa great many of such problems can be solved in this way.
('18', 345, 1, 6, 739187) Navajivan will therefore discuss these matters whenever occasion arises.
('18', 345, 1, 7, 739260) The agitation against the Rowlatt Act was an object lesson in satyagraha.
('18', 345, 1, 8, 739334) Hence Navajivan will keep it alive before the public.
('18', 345, 1, 9, 739388) I have no doubt that the Act will be repealed before its time, for I have full faith in truth and in the strength of the satyagrahis.
('18', 345, 1, 10, 739522) It is my conviction that Indias economic regeneration lies only through swadeshi.
('18', 345, 1, 11, 739604) Swadeshi promotes dharma.
('18', 345, 1, 12, 739630) No country has ever prospered, or ever will, by turning its back on dharma.
('18', 345, 1, 13, 739706) Navajivan will, therefore, work strenuously to propagate the idea of swadeshi.
('18', 345, 1, 14, 739785) If anyone asks why, if I wished to serve India, I should not pour out my soul through English, I would say in reply that, being a Gujarati by birth and way of life, I can serve India best only by identifying myself completely with the life of Gujarat.
('18', 345, 1, 15, 740037) Even from a business point of view, I think I can put my gifts to the best use if I take Gujarat as the main field of my activities.
('18', 345, 1, 16, 740170) Moreover, to whom should I address my message in English?
('18', 345, 1, 17, 740228) Navajivan will take every possible occasion to show that it is in vain that we are so infatuated with English.
('18', 345, 1, 18, 740339) I do not mean to say that English has no place at all in our studies or in our life.
('18', 345, 1, 19, 740424) I only insist that our present use of English is indiscriminate.
('18', 345, 1, 20, 740489) India lives in farmers huts.
('18', 345, 1, 21, 740518) The weavers skill is a reminder of Indias glory, and so I feel proud in describing myself as a farmer and weaver.
('18', 345, 1, 22, 740632) I wish to see Navajivan reach the farmers and weavers in their huts and dwelling.
('18', 345, 1, 23, 740714) I want it to be in their language.
('18', 345, 1, 24, 740749) Hence Navajivan will always describe the joys and sorrows of the farmers and the others in their language.
('18', 345, 1, 25, 740856) If the farmers continue to live in fear, buried under heavy debt, if they are diseased in body, I see nothing but ruin in store for India.
('18', 345, 1, 26, 740995) I will always pray to God that in every home women read Navajivan.
('18', 345, 1, 27, 741062) Who will preserve dharma, if not women?
('18', 345, 1, 28, 741102) What would be
('18', 346, 0, 1, 741116) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 347
('18', 346, 1, 2, 741161) the fate of the future generation if the women remain in a state of ignorance and darkness and know nothing about Indias plight?
('18', 346, 1, 3, 741290) Navajivan will, therefore, arouse the women and will try to awaken the men to a sense of their duty towards them.
('18', 346, 1, 4, 741404) These are but a few of my aspirations.
('18', 346, 1, 5, 741443) To summarize what I have said, I shall state that Navajivan will be so run as to see that the animosity between the ruler and the ruled is replaced by friendship and the distrust between them by trust, that there is unity of heart between Hindus and Muslims, that India achieves economic freedom and that, all over the country, there is nothing but love.
('18', 346, 1, 6, 741798) The universe exists in love.

('18', 346, 1, 10, 742018) 1 A pessimist may ask : can a message of this nature be ever delivered to an illiterate India, especially when there are repressive Press laws in force?

('18', 347, 1, 2, 743147) 264. STORY OF KHEDA
('18', 347, 2, 3, 743167) To the many services to his credit, the Honble Mr. Gokuldas Kahandas Parekh 1 has added one more by writing a note on the Bombay Governments reply to Sir Sankaran Nairs minute 2 .
('18', 347, 2, 4, 743347) The note is a long one; we shall therefore content ourselves with giving the main points made by the Honble Mr. Parekh.
('18', 347, 2, 5, 743467) Sir Sankaran Nair had said that it was the educated classes and their organ, the Congress, which had been responsible for whatever reforms there had been and the relief that the people had succeeded in obtaining from the Government.
('18', 347, 2, 6, 743700) Officials have always accused the educated classes of being indiffernt to the condition of the masses and argued that they could not be accepted as the leaders of the people.
('18', 347, 2, 7, 743875) Replying to this charge, Sir Sankaran Nair has mentioned the two convincing instances of Champaran and Kheda agitations, showing that in both these places peoples rights had been defended by the educated and that relief had been obtained from officials with the utmost difficulty.
('18', 347, 2, 8, 744156) Replying to the points about Kheda, the Government stated that whatever relief it gave it did on its own, advancing several arguments in proof.
('18', 347, 2, 9, 744300) The Honble Mr. Parekhs note is in reply to this.
('18', 347, 2, 10, 744349) The reader will now be able to follow the summary below.
('18', 347, 2, 11, 744406) 1. In all the districts of Gujarat, except the Panch Mahals, land revenue collection has been ordered at the maximum rate, that is, the Government is collecting twenty per cent of the average annual produce.
('18', 347, 2, 12, 744614) 2. Before 1907, the Government never remitted land revenue or deferred its collection even in bad years.
('18', 347, 2, 13, 744719) It was after the second of the two Famine Commissions which were appointed, that is after the Commission of 1901, that the Government framed rules for this purpose.
('18', 347, 2, 14, 744884) Even this measure of justice was offered after agitation by the people.
('18', 347, 2, 15, 744956) 3. During the 1899 famine, there had been many complaints against the tyranny of officials in Broach and Surat districts.
('18', 347, 2, 16, 745078) The question was also raised by members in the Bombay Legislature.
('18', 347, 3, 17, 745145) 1 Member, Bombay Legislative Council.
('18', 347, 3, 18, 745183) Along with Vithalbhai Patel, he took interest in moving the Government to adopt a considrate stand on the question of kheda farmers.
('18', 347, 3, 19, 745316) 2 Vide Appendix Note on the Kaira Case, 12 8 1919.
('18', 348, 0, 1, 745367) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 349
('18', 348, 1, 2, 745412) Government had declared the complaints to be unfounded.
('18', 348, 1, 3, 745468) In the end, one of the gentlemen who had made the complaints toured these districts and conducted a private inquiry and collected and published evidence.
('18', 348, 1, 4, 745622) This obliged the Government to order an inquiry.
('18', 348, 1, 5, 745671) Mr. Maconochie was appointed the inquiry officer and he found most of the complaints justified.
('18', 348, 1, 6, 745767) Ultimately the Government was obliged to notify rules for remission and suspension in 1907. 4. The Bombay Government has stated that no failure of crops was known to have occurred in the years preceding the Kheda agitation.
('18', 348, 1, 7, 745991) Citing instances from the Government reports, the Honble Mr. Parekh has shown conclusively that cultivators in Kheda district had been suffering losses all along from 1911 to 1916. With the help of the same reports, he shows that the Government had to resort to increasing pressure on the people, such as the auctioning of their cattle and household chattels, to realize land revenue dues.
('18', 348, 1, 8, 746381) 5. Failure of crops was not all that the people of Kheda district had to bear; the plague and other similar diseases were also endemic among the cultivators.
('18', 348, 1, 9, 746539) 6. In 1917, excessive rains had damaged the bajra crop as also the bavta and kodra crops.
('18', 348, 1, 10, 746629) Subsidiary crops had also been damaged by rats and, at some places, paddy as well.
('18', 348, 1, 11, 746712) 7. The Honble Mr. Parekh has argued from this that revenue officers, from the highest to the lowest, take no account of peoples sufferings and do not stop revenue collection even if people have to incur debts or sell their cattle in consequence.
('18', 348, 1, 12, 746958) 8. There are no rules for determining the percentge of the crop yield; only rough estimates are made.
('18', 348, 1, 13, 747060) 9. Because members of the Home Rule League chose to describe the Government as the servant of the people, they incurred the displeasure of the officials and the latter discounted the genuine grievances of the people of Kheda, saying that these had been magnified by outsiders.
('18', 348, 1, 14, 747337) 10. The Government note makes it appear that Mr. Parekh himself and the Honble Mr. Patel had approached the Collector in a legal capacity.
('18', 348, 1, 15, 747476) The fact is that both of them, being residents of Kheda, had gone in their capacity as leaders and without fees, to show that they shared the peoples suffering.
('18', 348, 1, 16, 747637) 11. The Governments charges against the Gujarat Sabha were unfounded.
('18', 348, 1, 17, 747707) The members of the Sabha are respectabe gentlemen and
('18', 349, 0, 1, 747761) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 349, 1, 2, 747803) they are fully entitled to work in Kheda.
('18', 349, 1, 3, 747845) Its sphere of activities is the whole of Gujarat.
('18', 349, 1, 4, 747895) 12. The view that the Government does a favour every time it suspends land revenue collection is not correct.
('18', 349, 1, 5, 748005) The basic principles of such suspension were laid down by the Central Government.
('18', 349, 1, 6, 748087) Rules have been framed in keeping with these principles and it is not open to officials to disregard them at will.
('18', 349, 1, 7, 748202) 13. It was incumbent on the Bombay Government to have appointed a committee following the inquiry by the Honble Mr. Parekh, the Honble Mr. Patel, the Servants of India Society and Mr. Gandhi.
('18', 349, 1, 8, 748394) Its failure to do so is nothing but sheer injustice; had the Central Government not intervened, the people of Kheda would not have had even the relief they got.
('18', 349, 1, 9, 748555) Mr. Parekh has thus, with unanswerable arguments, lent strong support to Sir Sankaran Nairs minute and exposed the fallacies of the Bombay Government.
('18', 349, 1, 10, 748706) What is surprising is that, despite the weakness of its case, the Government should have clung to it so desperately.
('18', 349, 1, 11, 748823) Much like a coir rope that will not be untwisted even when burnt, 1 the Government, though in the wrong, is not prepared to admit its error, increasing by this refusal the distance between the ruler and the ruled.
('18', 349, 2, 12, 749037) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 7 9 1919
('18', 349, 3, 13, 749073) 265. FINE ON NADIAD AND BAREJADI
('18', 349, 4, 14, 749106) The Patidars and Banias of Nadiad and the landowners of Barejadi are in trouble.
('18', 349, 4, 15, 749187) A Government Resolution has been published ordering the stationing of additional police, under section 25 of the District Police Act, at Nadiad and Barejadi for a period of one year, and the recovery of the expenditure on this acount in Nadiad from the Patidars and Banias of that town and, in Barejadi, from the landowners of Barejadi and Nandej.
('18', 349, 4, 16, 749535) The expenditure in Nadiad has been estimated by the Government at Rs. 15,556 and that in Barejadi at Rs. 6,028. The general rule is that the person to be punished should be informed beforehand and given an opportunity to explain why he should not be punished.
('18', 349, 4, 17, 749795) Still more just, the accused should be duly prosecuted and a courts judgment obtained.
('18', 349, 4, 18, 749882) But the Government did
('18', 349, 5, 19, 749905) 1 Gujarati saying

('18', 350, 1, 2, 749968) neither.

('18', 350, 1, 4, 750068) Even this information about the fines has come out because papers were sent to the Nadiad Municipality for effecting recovery of fines.
('18', 350, 1, 5, 750204) Let us now go into the genesis of the fine.
('18', 350, 1, 6, 750248) It originated with the letter, dated June 7, from Mr. Robertson, the Inspector General of Police, and the letters of May 16 and 26 from Mr. Ker, the Collector of Kheda.
('18', 350, 1, 7, 750417) Prior to this, on April 21, in a letter addressed to Shri Gokuldas, the President of the Nadiad Municipality, Mr. Ker had congratulated the people of Nadiad in the following words on their preserving peace: I have the honour to convey my appreciation of the respect for law and order which the people of Nadiad showed during the period of strain and excitement, now happily over. 1 We are entitled to assume that, since the Collector chose to convey his views through Shri Gokuldas Talati 2 , he, too, was included among the people complimented.
('18', 350, 1, 8, 750963) But the ship changed course on May 16. Between April 21 and May 16, consultations had taken place between the Collector, Mr. Robertson and Mr. Pratt, the Commissioner of Northern Division.
('18', 350, 1, 9, 751152) At the instance of Mr. Robertson, the Collector supplied the number of additional police required and, on May 26, addressed a long letter to the Commissioner suggesting that the expenditure on account of the additional police force should be recovered from Patidars and Banias of Nadiad.
('18', 350, 1, 10, 751440) The principles which he accepts in paragraph 2, he violates in paragraph 3. In paragraph 2 he states :
('18', 350, 2, 11, 751543) I will deprecate any appearance of haste in arriving at a conclusion as cases are
('18', 350, 3, 12, 751625) pending before the special tribunal in respect of all the offences and the results
('18', 350, 4, 13, 751708) of these trials may affect the issue.
('18', 350, 4, 14, 751746) Nevertheless, in paragraph 3, he says that it had been decided to impose a fine on Nadiad.
('18', 350, 4, 15, 751837) The Nadiad cases had not concluded by the 26th.
('18', 350, 4, 16, 751885) They had not even been heard.
('18', 350, 4, 17, 751915) The Court pronounced judgment on them on August 12. And yet the decision to impose a fine on Nadiad was reached on May 16. In paragraph 4 of his letter 3
('18', 350, 5, 18, 752069) the Collector gives five reasons for imposing the fine:
('18', 350, 6, 19, 752125) 1. The derailment was undoubtedly caused by Nadiad people.
('18', 350, 6, 20, 752184) They are mostly
('18', 350, 7, 21, 752200) 1 Vide Audi Alteram Partem, 30 8 1919. 2 He later gave evidence before the Disorders Inquiry Committee.
('18', 350, 7, 22, 752304) 3 The letter was published in Young India, 30 8 1919.
('18', 351, 0, 1, 752358) 352 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 351, 1, 2, 752400) Patidars.
('18', 351, 2, 3, 752410) 2. This offence is clearly the direct outcome of the persistent agitation against Government which has been going on among the people of Nadiad for some years.
('18', 351, 2, 4, 752570) Nadiad was the headquarters of Mr. Gandhi last year during the passive resistance movement, a movement directly calculated to undermine, as it did in fact undermine, all respect for the officers of Government and for Government itself.
('18', 351, 3, 5, 752806) 3. The Patidars of Kaira district affect to despise the Banias as their clerks, but the agitation against the payment of land revenue, organized by the latter, became popular with the Patidars as it held out to them the prospect of some advantage.
('18', 351, 3, 6, 753054) When things came to a head the active part was naturally taken by the more enterprising Patidars, while the Banias remained in the background.

('18', 356, 4, 13, 765740) 268. TURKEY
('18', 356, 5, 14, 765752) The Turkish question concerns eight crores of Indian Muslims; and a question that concerns nearly one fourth of the nation must concern the whole of India.

('18', 370, 1, 2, 798854) there, some of my fellow prisoners and I were discharged from prison on the advice of the Commissioners, with the deliberate intention that they and I might be able to help the Commission to a right judgment by leading evidence on behalf of those whom we represented.
('18', 370, 1, 3, 799122) I hope that if His Excellency cannot see his [way] to follow the South African prece[dent] of his own accord, the Commission will strongly advise him to do so.
('18', 370, 1, 4, 799282) SOUTH AFRICAN SITUATION
('18', 370, 2, 5, 799306) It is now my pleasant duty to come to those portions of the Viceregal speech which are not open to exception.
('18', 370, 2, 6, 799416) His Excellencys pronouncement on the South African question is satisfactory so far as it goes.
('18', 370, 2, 7, 799511) Sir Benjamin Robertson who is already personally known to General Smuts can, in many respects, by his tact and diplomacy, smooth the way for a just and honourable settlement.

('18', 371, 0, 1, 800825) 372 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 371, 1, 2, 800867) 275. LALA LABHU RAM
('18', 371, 2, 3, 800887) Bad as are the cases from the Punjab which it has been my misfortune to examine from time to time, that of Lala Labhu Ram is no better.
('18', 371, 2, 4, 801023) Isolated cases of injustice will happen [in] the best regulated society and [under] a model Government.
('18', 371, 2, 5, 801127) But when injustice becomes the order of the day, it is time for honest men not merely to protest against it but to withdraw their support from a system of Government under which such organized injustice is possible, unless that system is changed and systematic injustice becomes an impossibility.
('18', 371, 2, 6, 801424) I have no desire to exaggerate the picture.
('18', 371, 2, 7, 801468) Nothing can be further from my intention than to exacerbate the relations between the two races.
('18', 371, 2, 8, 801565) And if I could prevent exacerbation by remaining silent, I should do so with the greatest gladness.
('18', 371, 2, 9, 801665) But I should fail in my duty if I did not draw the attention of the Government to injustices as they come under my notice.
('18', 371, 2, 10, 801788) They are like poison corrupting the whole system.
('18', 371, 2, 11, 801838) The poison must be expelled or the body perishes.
('18', 371, 2, 12, 801888) What is this case of Lala Labhu Ram then?
('18', 371, 2, 13, 801930) The reader had the facts of the case last week.
('18', 371, 2, 14, 801978) The evidence for the defence does not appear to be complete and yet it seems to be the whole of the evidence received by Lala Labhu Rams solicitors.
('18', 371, 2, 15, 802127) It is quite possible that that evidence was not recorded, for does not the judgment of the Court commence with the pregnant sentence: The evidence for the defence is worthless?
('18', 371, 2, 16, 802304) In one place the notes of evidence contain the remark: Cross examination for accused No.
('18', 371, 2, 17, 802393) 9. Nothing relevant!
('18', 371, 2, 18, 802414) The judges might have considered the defence evidence too as irrelevant.
('18', 371, 2, 19, 802487) Fortunately, one has the exhaustive petition of Mrs. Labhu Ram to fall back upon.
('18', 371, 2, 20, 802569) It must be accepted as a correct statement of the evidence in the absence of contradiction.
('18', 371, 2, 21, 802661) Mr. Labhu Ram is not a poor student lad like Karamchand or a petty trader like Jagannath.
('18', 371, 2, 22, 802751) He is a Civil Engineer; he belongs, says Malandevi, to a very respectable and loyal family of Lahore.
('18', 371, 2, 23, 802853) Several relations of his occupy responsible positions in the service of Government. He finished his studies in Glasgow.
('18', 371, 2, 24, 802973) He returned from England in 1912. He was for some time State Engineer in the Poonch State,
('18', 371, 3, 25, 803064) where he not only discharged his professional duties to the entire satisfaction of his superiors but materially helped the authorities in recruiting work.
('18', 372, 0, 1, 803219) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 373
('18', 372, 1, 2, 803264) was not a member of any political society or of any Samaj or Sabha nor did he even take part in any propaganda of any kind whatsoever.
('18', 372, 1, 3, 803399) He was not in the habit of attending any lectures even.
('18', 372, 1, 4, 803455) He took no part whatever in the recent hartal.
('18', 372, 2, 5, 803502) I have dealt with Mr. Labhu Rams position in society somewhat fully, because the case at the worst turns upon the credibility of witnesses.
('18', 372, 2, 6, 803642) Several of the accused, of whom Lala Labhu Ram was one, pleaded an alibi and, as I have had to remark in connection with one case, courts always look upon the defence of alibi with considerable distrust.
('18', 372, 2, 7, 803846) It is, therefore, necessary to dispose of the case at its worst and give the Court credit for fairness in weighing evidence.
('18', 372, 2, 8, 803971) I submit then that unless the Court has overwhelming and unimpeachable testimony against that of Lala Labhu Ram, who said he was not present at the Badshahi Mosque meeting and who was respectably supported, the Court was bound to accept his evidence and grant him an honourable discharge.
('18', 372, 2, 9, 804260) In such cases the status of the accused is a material consideration in coming to a decision, and I claim that Lala Labhu Ram enjoyed a status in society which should have stood him in good stead.
('18', 372, 3, 10, 804456) But the reader may dismiss the plea of respectability from his mind.
('18', 372, 3, 11, 804525) It would not be perhaps an unfair reasoning on the part of the opponents the upholders of the Punjab proceedings to say that, when the very best of men in the Punjab were under severe suspicion and were drawn into the turmoil of April last, the queston of respectability should be ruled out of account.
('18', 372, 3, 12, 804828) But the Punjab Commissions have gone infinitely further and in many cases, as the reader of these pages has by this time seen, ruled out practically the whole of the defence.
('18', 372, 3, 13, 805003) Mr. Labhu Ram was arrested on the 20th April, i.e., eight days after the day of the alleged offence.
('18', 372, 3, 14, 805104) He is supposed to have been one of the hundred men who were charged with a simultaneous assault on one of the police officer.
('18', 372, 3, 15, 805230) He was not known to this officer before, nor was there a single prosecution witness who had known the accused at all intimately before.
('18', 372, 3, 16, 805366) Identification is difficult at best of times.
('18', 372, 3, 17, 805412) It is most difficult, if not almost impossible, when it is a matter of picking out men from an excited crowd of several thousands.
('18', 372, 3, 18, 805543) Mr. Labhu Rams name does not occur in the police diary in which the names of the assaulters were noted down.
('18', 372, 3, 19, 805652) Out of 11 prosecution witnesses 6 had nothing to say about the accused Mr. Labhu Ram.
('18', 372, 3, 20, 805738) Witnesses, says Mrs. Labhu Ram,
('18', 373, 0, 1, 805770) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 373, 1, 2, 805812) who identified the petitioners husband are police employees or interested in them.
('18', 373, 1, 3, 805895) Most of them have appeared as prosecution witnesses in other Martial Law cases also.
('18', 373, 1, 4, 805980) This is a most damaging statement, if it is true.
('18', 373, 1, 5, 806030) It means that they were professional witnesses.
('18', 373, 1, 6, 806078) One would think that, as the accused was arrested eight days after the event, there would be some explanation given by the prosecution of the delay.
('18', 373, 1, 7, 806227) This is what the petitioner says about it :
('18', 373, 2, 8, 806271) The name of the petitioners husband not having been entered in the diary of the complainant, it is not stated how and when the Police came to know of his complicity.
('18', 373, 2, 9, 806437) This is a sample of the case for the prosecution.
('18', 373, 2, 10, 806487) The case for the defence is overwhelming.
('18', 373, 3, 11, 806529) Dr. Bodhraj, a well known physician of Lahore, Dr. Bholaram and his compounder gave evidence that Labhu Ram was busy with them in connection with the treatment of his ailing son at the time of the alleged assault.
('18', 373, 3, 12, 806743) The reader will be shocked to know that Mr. Labhu Rams sentence of transportation, with forfeiture of property has been commuted to 14 years.
('18', 373, 3, 13, 806885) Though I can appreciate and fully share a wifes sorrow and agony over an unmerited separation from her husband and, therefore, while I understand Mrs. Labhu Rams position in asking for a commutation, if a complete discharge might not be possible, I am unable to derive the slightest satisfaction from the fact of the commutation.
('18', 373, 3, 14, 807215) Mr. Labhu Ram is not a child.
('18', 373, 3, 15, 807245) He is a man of the world, of culture and fully aware of his responsibility.
('18', 373, 3, 16, 807321) If he took part in a cowardly assault on an inoffensive man who was but doing his duty, he deserves stern justice and no mercy.
('18', 373, 3, 17, 807449) For to the crime of an assault he has added that of deliberate perjury.
('18', 373, 3, 18, 807521) If, therefore, his case is not true, it is not one for mercy, and if it is true, justice would be hardly satisfied when he is discharged.
('18', 373, 3, 19, 807659) I do not deal with the monstrous method of the Court in taking judicial notice of a state of rebellion.
('18', 373, 3, 20, 807763) It is really an abuse of legal terms to consider the state of Lahore on the 12th of April as one of rebellion and a martial proclamation of the Government to be a document for judicial notice in the manner it has been.
('18', 373, 3, 21, 807982) The evidence before the Court does not sustain a charge of waging war against the King.
('18', 373, 3, 22, 808070) Only recently the people of Liverpool went much further than the Badshahi Mosque meeting.
('18', 373, 3, 23, 808160) But the long expected Commission has now been appointed, and if the reference includes the power to
('18', 374, 0, 1, 808260) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 375
('18', 374, 1, 2, 808305) revise the sentences, the members of the Commission will have an opportunity of pronouncing upon cases like Mr. Labhu Rams.
('18', 374, 1, 3, 808429) But I submit to the Punjab Government as also to the Government of India that, in cases where the recorded evidence itself shows a patent miscarriage of justice, they are bound in honour to discharge the accused without hiding themselves behind the Commission.
('18', 374, 2, 4, 808690) Young India, 10 9 1919

('18', 375, 4, 10, 810622) 277. SATYAGRAHA
('18', 375, 5, 11, 810638) [September 11, 1919] 1
('18', 375, 6, 12, 810661) I notice so much misunderstanding still prevailing about satyagraha, both among ourselves and the British, that, though I have written and spoken at great length about it, I think it necessary to say something more even at the risk of repeating myself.
('18', 375, 6, 13, 810914) The word satyagraha was coined in South Africa to describe a certain mode of action.
('18', 375, 6, 14, 810999) The great fight in which our brethren there were engaged was at first known, even in Gujarati, as passive resistance.
('18', 375, 6, 15, 811117) I once spoke about this struggle to a British audience; 2 the English chairman on the occasion observed that the helpless Indians, without a vote and without arms, had no alternative to passive resistance.
('18', 375, 6, 16, 811323) The chairman was a friend of mine.
('18', 375, 6, 17, 811358) He stated his view in all sincerity of heart, but I felt humiliated.
('18', 375, 6, 18, 811427) I knew for a fact that the struggle carried on by the Indian people in South Africa was no expression of their weakness.
('18', 375, 6, 19, 811548) The community there had deliberately chosen that particular form of struggle.
('18', 375, 6, 20, 811626) When it was my turn to speak, I corrected my friends idea and explained that a struggle such as was carrried on by the South African Indians could never be carried on by the weak and that I saw greater courage in that way of fighting than what the soldier needed.
('18', 375, 7, 21, 811890) 1 The article first appeared in the Pateti (Parsi New Year) Number of Sanj Vartaman, a Gujarati evening newspaper of Bombay.
('18', 375, 7, 22, 812015) In 1919, Pateti fell on September 11. 2 Vide Speech at Germiston, 7 6 1909.
('18', 376, 0, 1, 812091) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 377
('18', 376, 1, 2, 812136) When I was in England in connection with that very struggle, I saw that the suffragettes would set buildings on fire or assault officers with whips, and this sort of struggle, too, they described as passive resistance, and the public knew it by that name.
('18', 376, 1, 3, 812392) In the struggle carried on in South Africa, there was no room at all for such assaults.Hence I felt that there was a great danger in describing the struggle in South Africa as passive resistance.
('18', 376, 1, 4, 812588) In South Africa itself, I could not think of an English word which could become current.
('18', 376, 1, 5, 812677) At the meeting of Englishmen mentioned before, I used the expression soul force to describe our struggle; but I had not the courage to use it always to denote our struggle.
('18', 376, 1, 6, 812850) Intelligent English friends also realized the inadequacy of the expression passive resistance, but they could not give me another expression.
('18', 376, 1, 7, 812992) Civil resistance describes the struggle perfectly.
('18', 376, 1, 8, 813043) The phrase occurred to me by chance only a few days ago and I have been using it in English.
('18', 376, 1, 9, 813136) Civil resistance is wider in meaning than civil disobedience, though it suggests less than satyagraha.
('18', 376, 2, 10, 813239) Moreover, I saw in South Africa that our struggle had pure truth and justice in it and the force we employed was not brute force but soul force.
('18', 376, 2, 11, 813384) In however small a measure it may have been, it was yet soul force.
('18', 376, 2, 12, 813452) We do not find such force employed by animals.
('18', 376, 2, 13, 813499) Besides, there is always some energy of the soul flowing through truth and so we started describing the struggle in South Africa as satyagraha.
('18', 376, 3, 14, 813643) Thus, there is no exaggeration in asserting that the term satyagraha had its origin in the idea of purity.
('18', 376, 3, 15, 813750) We shall be able to understand now that satyagraha does not consist merely in a civil disobedience of law; often, it may consist in not committing such disobedience.
('18', 376, 3, 16, 813916) When we feel it to be our duty to commit civil disobedience, when we feel that not to do so would be a blot on our manliness and a degradation of the soul, saytagraha can consist only in such disobedience.
('18', 376, 3, 17, 814122) Such satyagraha may be employed not only against the Government but also against society; it can be employed as between husband and wife, father and son, friend and friend; in short, this valuable weapon may be used for almost any reform in any sphere.
('18', 376, 3, 18, 814375) It is a weapon which sanctifies both him who wields it and him against whom it is employed.
('18', 376, 3, 19, 814467) Its rightful use can never have an untoward result.
('18', 376, 3, 20, 814519) It is invariably attended with success.
('18', 376, 3, 21, 814559) If people employ duragraha in the name of satyagraha and unpleasant consequences follow, the latter is certainly not to blame.
('18', 377, 0, 1, 814686) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 377, 1, 2, 814728) Such satyagraha is often resorted to in families, whether people know it or not; that is, if a son feels that his father has been unjust, he does not give in to the injustice but cheerfully bears the punishment the father may mete out to him and, in this way, he ultimately succeeds in winning over the father, even if he were a formidable one, and securing justice from him.
('18', 377, 1, 3, 815104) But, slaves of inertia that we are, we hesitate to apply this law outside the domestic sphere.
('18', 377, 1, 4, 815199) Hence it is that I have considered satyagraha in social and political matters a new experiment.
('18', 377, 1, 5, 815295) The late Tolstoy 1 was the first to draw my attention, in a letter of his to me, to its being such.
('18', 377, 1, 6, 815395) It is the belief of many that satyagraha can be used only in matters concerning religion.
('18', 377, 1, 7, 815485) My wide experience proves just the contrary.
('18', 377, 1, 8, 815530) By employing it in other spheres, we introduce religion into them and by doing so we succeed the sooner in fact and save ourselves from no end of hypocrisy.
('18', 377, 1, 9, 815687) It is my firm conviction that some of the most imperceptible laws of economics are at work in satyagraha.
('18', 377, 1, 10, 815793) In this sense I believe satyagraha to be a practical method.
('18', 377, 1, 11, 815854) Maybe it will take some time before people accept it as such, since, being a new method in the sense indicated above, they may not understand it.
('18', 377, 1, 12, 816000) Is it any wonder, besides, that, when we are working for the best results, the thing should take some time?
('18', 377, 1, 13, 816108) When satyagraha has become an accepted method in India, political and social reforms, which at present take such a long time to bring about, will be effected in a much shorter period; the distance between the rulers and the ruled and their distrust of each other will disappear and in their place will grow love and trust.
('18', 377, 1, 14, 816431) It will be the same, we may be sure, as between the different sections of society.
('18', 377, 1, 15, 816514) Only one thing is necessary to ensure that the method spreads widely among the people.
('18', 377, 1, 16, 816601) I feel convinced that, if the leaders understand it in its purity and place it before the people, the latter will respond readily.
('18', 377, 1, 17, 816732) In order to understand it rightly, one must have faith in truth and non violence.
('18', 377, 1, 18, 816814) There is no need to define truth; of non violence.
('18', 377, 1, 19, 816865) I do not demand any very exacting interpretation in this context.
('18', 377, 1, 20, 816931) We should bear no ill will towards those from whom we wish to obtain justice; we should not seek our end by using violence against them or causing them any injury, but through courtesy, though
('18', 377, 2, 21, 817124) 1 For the correspondence between Gandhiji and him, vide Letter to Leo Tolstoy, 1 10 1909 & Appendix Tolstoys Letter to Gandhiji, 7 10 1909.
('18', 378, 0, 1, 817264) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 379
('18', 378, 1, 2, 817309) remaining unshaken in our resolve; this is all I mean by non violence here and only so much of it is necessary for bringing about reforms of this kind.
('18', 378, 1, 3, 817461) All our activities will take on a new form when the people have accepted satyagraha.
('18', 378, 1, 4, 817546) We shall spare ourselves much fuss, all too many pompous speeches, petitions and resolutions and much scheming.
('18', 378, 1, 5, 817658) Personally, the social, economic and political progress of the nation, which I see in satyagraha, I can see in nothing else.
('18', 378, 2, 6, 817783) [From Gujarati]
('18', 378, 3, 7, 817799) Navajivan, 14 9 1919
('18', 378, 4, 8, 817820) 278. SWADESHI IN A NUTSHELL
('18', 378, 5, 9, 817848) [September 11, 1919]
('18', 378, 6, 10, 817869) WHAT IS SWADESHI?
('18', 378, 7, 11, 817887) Mr. Gandhi puts his position regarding swadeshi in a nutshell in the Pateti number of the Sanj Vartaman: Swadeshi restricts all Indians to the exclusive use of articles made in India.
('18', 378, 7, 12, 818071) It contains our economic independence; swadeshi therefore means fiscal autonomy.
('18', 378, 7, 13, 818152) Without fiscal autonomy swaraj has no meaning; swadeshi therefore may be called swaraj also.
('18', 378, 7, 14, 818245) But India is in such a ruined condition that we are not in a position to produce all our necessaries.
('18', 378, 7, 15, 818347) It is, therefore, open to us to restrict swadeshi only to the most pressing of our necessaries.
('18', 378, 7, 16, 818443) The most pressing of our necessaries is clothing, and hence swadeshi consists, at present, in restricting ourselves to the use of cloth produced in India.
('18', 378, 7, 17, 818598) This swadeshi is a religion and it is not only for the Hindus or for Bombay; it is for all India and for all residents of India, Hindus, Mussulmans, Parsis, Christians, Europeans or Asiatics [men and women] 1.
('18', 378, 8, 18, 818808) HOW TO PROMOTE SWADESHI?
('18', 378, 9, 19, 818833) 1. By taking a vow to use exclusively swadeshi cloth.
('18', 378, 9, 20, 818887) 2. By helping in and increasing the production of cloth, as we do not at present produce cloth sufficient for our needs.
('18', 378, 10, 21, 819008) 1 The words in square brackets have been taken from Navajivan, 14 9 1919.
('18', 379, 0, 1, 819082) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 379, 1, 2, 819124) 3. It is the duty of every one of us to help in the production of cloth, be we rich or poor.
('18', 379, 1, 3, 819217) The rich may do by means of mills, but for the poor there should be means suitable to themselves wherewith theymay help in this great work.
('18', 379, 1, 4, 819357) These means are our old spinning wheels and handlooms.
('18', 379, 1, 5, 819412) If every woman understands it to be her duty to devote all her spare hours to spinning cotton, we can have yarn at the price of cotton.It every man devotes all his spare hours to weaving hand spun yarn, we can have cloth at the price of cotton.
('18', 379, 1, 6, 819657) Every man and woman can learn both these arts.
('18', 379, 1, 7, 819704) Spinning takes a week to learn; weaving eight weeks.
('18', 379, 1, 8, 819757) A spinning wheel costs 4 rupees.
('18', 379, 1, 9, 819790) A handloom cost from 25 to 40 rupees.
('18', 379, 1, 10, 819828) Both these can be easily made by our carpenters.
('18', 379, 1, 11, 819877) Those who cannot spin cotton gratis can get 3 annas for spinning a lb.
('18', 379, 1, 12, 819948) of yarn.
('18', 379, 1, 13, 819957) Those who cannot weave yarn gratis can get one anna at least for weaving a yard of cloth 24 inches broad.
('18', 379, 1, 14, 820063) I wish no one will raise the question of despair, viz., when and how can the whole country engage itself in spinning and weaving?
('18', 379, 1, 15, 820193) If every reader determines to spin and weave himself, he will give to the country at least the yarn that he has spun and woven.
('18', 379, 1, 16, 820321) And why should we not expect others also to muster the same courage and patriotism that is in us.
('18', 379, 1, 17, 820419) [If we are good, the whole world is good; likewise, if we are industrious, the whole world will be so.] As a result of the present movement about 2,000 wheels are working and about 200 weavers have begun to weave afresh.
('18', 379, 1, 18, 820640) Lady Tata, Lady Petit, Mrs. Jaiji Petit and other ladies have already begun or are to begin spinning.
('18', 379, 1, 19, 820742) So many of our Hindu sisters have learnt the art that it would be invidious to mention names.
('18', 379, 1, 20, 820836) I ask every reader to bethink himself of his duty.
('18', 379, 2, 21, 820887) Young India, 13 9 1919

('18', 380, 1, 2, 820955) 279. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI

('18', 380, 3, 4, 821016) BHAISHRI MAHADEV, I have your letter and your comments.
('18', 380, 3, 5, 821072) Your arguments about Indemnity 2 were considered and answered while we were in the train.
('18', 380, 3, 6, 821162) It does not matter if the paragraph, nevertheless, has been omitted.
('18', 380, 3, 7, 821231) We can write about it again if we think it necessary.
('18', 380, 3, 8, 821285) Polaks letter is ominous.
('18', 380, 3, 9, 821311) If the Princes are not to be examined, what use will a Commission be?
('18', 380, 3, 10, 821381) This important issue has been deliberately ignored.
('18', 380, 3, 11, 821433) I was also not happy with gouri after Durga.
('18', 380, 3, 12, 821478) Anyway that is what I wrote and noticed the thing only when I saw the issue.
('18', 380, 3, 13, 821555) I wrote gouri after Mani but crossed it out.
('18', 380, 3, 14, 821600) Durga Mahadev didnt sound well.
('18', 380, 3, 15, 821632) But we cannot, I think, be concerned with how things look or sound.
('18', 380, 3, 16, 821700) Some of the other mistakes to which you have drawn attention could have been avoided.
('18', 380, 3, 17, 821786) I showed all of them to Indulal.
('18', 380, 3, 18, 821819) I am a little better than I was yesterday.
('18', 380, 3, 19, 821862) I hope you are all right.
('18', 380, 3, 20, 821888) I shall arrive there on Saturday.

('18', 381, 4, 9, 823034) 281. GUJARATIMALS CASE
('18', 381, 5, 10, 823057) Gujaratimal is a lad eighteen years old, having received no more than Middle School education.
('18', 381, 5, 11, 823152) At the age of sixteen he got himself appointed as a dresser in the Military Department.
('18', 381, 5, 12, 823240) After working for about a year in Multan Cantonment, he went to Egypt and spent one year there, also on service.
('18', 381, 5, 13, 823353) He subsequently returned to the Punjab, taking one months leave.
('18', 381, 5, 14, 823418) He reached Madhranwala, his native village five miles from Hafizabad, on the 8th April.
('18', 381, 5, 15, 823506) He remained at his village getting his shop repaired.
('18', 381, 6, 16, 823560) to our astonishment some policemen came there on the 16th with warrants issued against him, and prosecuted him accordingly, leaving us in utter amazement, for we could not understand what the matter was.
('18', 381, 6, 17, 823764) Thus writes the seventy years old father of Gujaratimal.
('18', 381, 6, 18, 823821) This is not one of those cases in which a stranger can arrive at a firm decision merely on reading the evidence, which was reproduced in the last issue of Young India.
('18', 381, 6, 19, 823989) It will be remembered that the case of Gujaratimal is
('18', 381, 7, 20, 824043) 1 It referred to the Governments ban on the publication, of any matter relating to the terms of peace with Turkey which was likely to cause excitement in India.
('18', 381, 7, 21, 824204) For the text of the letter, vide Addenda.
('18', 381, 7, 22, 824246) 2 Crerar had written: I am not in possession of the document, but his statement at the end of his article that there was any disposition on the part of the Conference to ridicule arguments based on Muslim sentiments is opposed to all known facts of the case and its publication in India would be calculated to produce a totally erroneous impression. 3 Marmaduke Pickthalls article on Turkey was published in the New Age, 10 7 1919.

('18', 382, 1, 2, 824723) one out of nineteen tried together.
('18', 382, 1, 3, 824759) I had occasion to analyse the judgment in the case in connection with that of Karamchand, 1 and all I have said about that judgment naturally applies in this case, as in that of the lad Karamchand.
('18', 382, 1, 4, 824957) But upon reading the evidence, it is not possible to come to a positive conclusion that the defence of alibi was completely established.
('18', 382, 1, 5, 825094) The whole of the evidence, as the reader must have observed, has been taken in such a scrappy manner that one is unable to know what has been omitted.
('18', 382, 1, 6, 825245) It is also clear from the evidence that the prosecution witnesses are mostly policemen orconnected with the police, and that the accused were not arrested red handed, but most of them were arrested some time after the affair.
('18', 382, 1, 7, 825471) Certainly Gujaratimal, who is said to have been the principal speaker and one of the assailants, was not arrested red handed, but two days after the date of the alleged assault.
('18', 382, 1, 8, 825649) Gujaratimal was sentenced to be hanged.
('18', 382, 1, 9, 825689) His sentence was subsequently commuted to transportation, and still more subsequently, according to what his father has heard, to seven years rigorous imprisonment.
('18', 382, 1, 10, 825854) It is a serious matter to sentence a lad of eighteen years, who denies his guilt, who denies having been present at the scene itself and who has only lately rendered service to the Crown, to be hanged on the strength of the very questionable evidence of identification by witnesses of no standing.
('18', 382, 1, 11, 826152) To these observations I would add a summary of the facts supplied by the father of Gujaratimal, and respectfully submit that if the facts supplied by the father be true, he is entitled to a complete discharge without further investigation.
('18', 382, 1, 12, 826392) And even without those, the whole case requires a thorough investigation.
('18', 382, 1, 13, 826466) The father says :

('18', 382, 4, 17, 826695) Gujaratimal was also among the crowd.
('18', 382, 4, 18, 826733) Now comes the most material part of the fathers statement.

('18', 382, 6, 20, 826848) 3,4,7,8,9,15,16,18,19, who aftewards gave evidence against him could
('18', 382, 7, 21, 826917) identify him, nor even Lieutenant Tatam.
('18', 382, 7, 22, 826958) If this is true, Gujaratimal has certainly been wrongly convicted.
('18', 382, 7, 23, 827025) And what shall we say of the value of all the identification evidence when

('18', 383, 5, 21, 828958) 282. A SHAMEFUL SIN
('18', 383, 6, 22, 828978) [September 14, 1919] 1
('18', 383, 7, 23, 829001) TO MY SISTERS : I want to talk to you on a matter simple and yet of very great importance, a matter on which depends, and without which is impossible, the salvation of India.
('18', 383, 7, 24, 829176) Man in his stupidity may forget his
('18', 383, 8, 25, 829212) 1 The Gujarati original was published in Navajivan, 14 9 1919.
('18', 384, 0, 1, 829275) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 385
('18', 384, 1, 2, 829320) duty towards woman, but should that prevent woman from doing her duty towards her sisters?
('18', 384, 1, 3, 829411) I have received a letter from Dohad giving news which is shameful to us all.
('18', 384, 1, 4, 829488) The correspondent writes that the women of the Dhed community there who cannot procure work which may be done at home go out for labour, which they procure at the price of their chastity.
('18', 384, 1, 5, 829676) The male members of these womens families craven creatures know this fact, but are sleeping over it.
('18', 384, 1, 6, 829777) I have used the word Dhed for this community, but they are weavers.
('18', 384, 1, 7, 829845) I do not know why some weavers are known as Dheds.
('18', 384, 1, 8, 829896) But if we always keep in mind the sad fact that, in spite of their clean calling, these people are regarded as untouchables, some of us are sure some day to be free from the sin of untouchability.
('18', 384, 1, 9, 830093) As women for want of other work have to go out for labour, so also have men.
('18', 384, 1, 10, 830170) Hence, when they saw that I was ready to supply them with yarn, they pledged themselves to do no other work than weaving, provided I guaranteed to them a regular daily supply of a maund of yarn.
('18', 384, 1, 11, 830365) My correspondent further informs me that the chief reason why they took this pledge was their knowledge of the immorality I have referred to.
('18', 384, 1, 12, 830507) You may rest assured Dohad is not a solitary sink of this iniquity.
('18', 384, 1, 13, 830575) When I was in Umreth, I was told that most of the women there added to their little income by winnowing pulses for merchants.
('18', 384, 1, 14, 830701) They have to go to them to receive and return the pulses and there they have to put up with all sorts of indecent jokes and abuse.
('18', 384, 1, 15, 830832) It has been my misfortune to hear this tale of woe at numerous places during the course of my four years wanderings throughout India.
('18', 384, 1, 16, 830966) It seems to me that a hundred years ago, when millions of our mothers used to spin cotton, such things must not have been happening.
('18', 384, 1, 17, 831099) I therefore beg to request my wealthy and educated sisters that, if they are anxious to protect the chastity of their poor sisters, they must take a prominent part in the movement for handspinning and handweaving.
('18', 384, 1, 18, 831313) I do not desire at this place to repeat all the arguments why I prefer these occupations to any other.
('18', 384, 1, 19, 831416) Suffice it to say that spinning has been regarded as an ancient, noble calling which even queens made their own.
('18', 384, 1, 20, 831529) It is very easy to learn spinning.
('18', 384, 1, 21, 831564) Any ordinary carpenter can make a spinning wheel.
('18', 384, 1, 22, 831614) If millions of our sisters work the wheel, all the yarn they may produce can be consumed in India alone.
('18', 384, 1, 23, 831719) And that being almost as useful as food stuffs, spinning cannot be regarded as a temporary occupation.
('18', 384, 1, 24, 831822) It does not require great physical labour and it can be left off and taken up at will and hence it is an occupation to fill our leisure hours with.
('18', 385, 0, 1, 831970) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 385, 1, 2, 832012) some good women were to take up this work, they would be able to put an end to the enormities I have mentioned above.
('18', 385, 1, 3, 832130) They will thereby be ensuring for some of our sisters suitable work for want of which they may have to seek other work in which their chastity is jeopardized.
('18', 385, 1, 4, 832289) Sister reader, even if you be rolling in wealth, you are bound to protect the chastity of your poor sisters.
('18', 385, 1, 5, 832398) I have pointed you out the royal road.
('18', 385, 1, 6, 832437) I hope you will think over it this week : I hope to show next week the various ways in which every woman can help in this work.
('18', 385, 2, 7, 832565) Young India, 17 9 1919
('18', 385, 3, 8, 832588) 283. HOW TO REMOVE THE BLOT
('18', 385, 4, 9, 832616) [September 14, 1919] 1
('18', 385, 5, 10, 832639) TO MY SISTERS : Last time I showed by some illustrations how, on account of our negligence, idleness or indifference, our poor sisters fall an easy prey to temptation for want of some independent work.
('18', 385, 5, 11, 832841) It is quite proper that we are horrified at the plight of thousands of our sisters in far off Fiji.
('18', 385, 5, 12, 832941) For that we are accusing the Government of Fiji and asking the Government of India to make strenuous efforts to put a stop to the indentures which breed immorality in Fiji.
('18', 385, 5, 13, 833114) To do so is our clear duty.
('18', 385, 5, 14, 833142) But what are we doing for the women, more numerous than in Fiji, suffering before our very eyes?
('18', 385, 5, 15, 833239) For removing the blot nearer home we do not need to pass resolutions demanding justice from Government.
('18', 385, 5, 16, 833343) For that we ourselves have to work to the utmost of our capacity.
('18', 385, 5, 17, 833409) Every one of you, sisters, has to find out a remedy to end this evil.
('18', 385, 5, 18, 833479) It is the object of this paper to help you in thinking out the remedies.
('18', 385, 5, 19, 833552) As we found last week, the best protection for the chastity of our poor women, and to tell the truth, of all women, is the spinning [ wheel].
('18', 385, 5, 20, 833694) Perhaps you will say, we can understand that for poor women, but what have other women to do with the spinning wheel? There is a proverb among us, a very good proverb, that, an idle man ruins himself and his country.
('18', 385, 5, 21, 833911) I can say from my own experience that idleness feeds our passions.
('18', 385, 5, 22, 833978) If our monied sisters were to devote
('18', 385, 6, 23, 834015) 1 This is in continuation of the preceding item.
('18', 386, 0, 1, 834064) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 387
('18', 386, 1, 2, 834109) their leisure to some useful work instead of gossiping or some other needless activity, they would engage their mind, hands and feet in a fruitful manner and [if] they were to take to spinning, they would serve a double purpose.
('18', 386, 1, 3, 834338) A sister became a widow only a few days ago.
('18', 386, 1, 4, 834383) She came to know of the work of spinning.
('18', 386, 1, 5, 834425) As she cannot go out of her house for at least one year, belonging as she does to a good family, she has taken up the work of hand spinning.
('18', 386, 1, 6, 834566) Within six days she has been able to send half a pound of fine spun yarn.
('18', 386, 1, 7, 834640) It is her devout wish that she might be able to spin enough yarn for her family before she leaves the widows corner.
('18', 386, 1, 8, 834757) But I have digressed.
('18', 386, 1, 9, 834779) We are considering how to help poor women who go astray on account of force of circumstances.
('18', 386, 1, 10, 834873) If you are able to devote all your time to the work of reclamation, you would go to the villages, find out what your poor sisters are doing there, teach them, if they do not know, how to spin, supply them dressed cotton, paying them the labour [charges] for spinning it into yarn.
('18', 386, 1, 11, 835154) The Bombay Swadeshi Sabha has undertaken the work of supplying cotton and, in a short time, many places will be selected for that purpose.
('18', 386, 1, 12, 835293) The local Sabha also has opened such a branch and provides facilities for supplying such cotton.
('18', 386, 1, 13, 835390) I do confess that all cannot give all their time for such work.
('18', 386, 1, 14, 835454) Those who can devote only [a few] hours and are not in a position to [leave] their own native village or city [may] well take care of their own locality.
('18', 386, 1, 15, 835608) Large hearted women cannot be satisfied with merely taking care of themselves.
('18', 386, 1, 16, 835687) They must infect others with their purity.
('18', 386, 1, 17, 835730) Hence, such sisters will try to understand and better the lot of their neighbours.
('18', 386, 1, 18, 835813) They may open a club for spinning in their own locality, supporting and instructing their less fortunate sisters.
('18', 386, 1, 19, 835927) If you cannot do that much, if you do not believe in your capacity for persuading your other sisters or have no heart for it, you can at least learn spinning for yourself and, by doing that work for a fixed period every day, you can set an example to your other sisters and, if you spin your yarn free of charge, you can to the extent help your poor sisters by making it possible to pay them a higher rate.
('18', 386, 1, 20, 836334) You will see in Navajivan from time to time examples of sisters who have already begun such work.
('18', 386, 1, 21, 836432) It is my hope that you would all take part in such a movement according to your capacity a movement which nourishes the life of the nation, which helps its poor, which protects the chastity of its women and which is calculated to bring economic independence to India in a simple and easy manner.
('18', 386, 2, 22, 836728) Young India, 1 10 1919
('18', 387, 0, 1, 836751) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 387, 1, 2, 836793) 284. ADVERTISEMENTS
('18', 387, 2, 3, 836813) [September 14, 1919] 1
('18', 387, 3, 4, 836836) We have reproduced this letter because the criticism Shri Khandwala makes is also made by other friends.
('18', 387, 3, 5, 836941) Shri Khandwalas fear is unnecessary.
('18', 387, 3, 6, 836978) Labouring under the false belief that advertisement can be secured by money alone, the correspondent believes that swadeshi articles will not get support from Navajivan, which accepts no advertisements.
('18', 387, 3, 7, 837181) Money is not at all required to spread information as to the place of getting a thing when it is needed by the country.
('18', 387, 3, 8, 837301) When the scope of Navajivan is properly known and its workers organized, it will be our endeavour to bring to light the obscure industries of our country in these columns even at some expense to the proprietor, if necessary.
('18', 387, 3, 9, 837526) When advertisements are inserted by payment, it is well nigh impossible to control their matter or language.
('18', 387, 3, 10, 837635) Of the various advertisements that have come under our notice, ninety nine per cent are totally useless.
('18', 387, 3, 11, 837740) The advertisements that are most paying relate to medicine and it is our belief that the deceitfulness and obscenity that are often found in such advertisements are harmful to the country.
('18', 387, 3, 12, 837929) We know many friends who have contracted disease by using advertised medicines.
('18', 387, 3, 13, 838009) Who has not been deceived by advertisements regarding other things?
('18', 387, 3, 14, 838077) It is our mistaken belief that we get newspapers cheap because they take advertisements.
('18', 387, 3, 15, 838166) It is forgotten that the things that are advertised are bought by the readers and it is the readers who have ultimately to pay for the advertisement charges.
('18', 387, 3, 16, 838324) The price of medicine does not lie in the drug so much as in the bottle, the cork and most of all in the advertisement.
('18', 387, 3, 17, 838444) Hence, sometimes, we pay one rupee for a medicine worth a pice only.
('18', 387, 3, 18, 838513) If there were no system of advertisements, we are sure to save at least half the price.
('18', 387, 4, 19, 838601) Young India, 24 9 1919
('18', 387, 5, 20, 838624) 1 The first two sentences of this and the following item have been taken from Navajivan, 14 9 1919, in which they originally appeared in Gujarati.
('18', 388, 0, 1, 838771) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 389
('18', 388, 1, 2, 838816) 285. SWADESHI V. MACHINERY?
('18', 388, 2, 3, 838844) [September 14, 1919]
('18', 388, 3, 4, 838865) In reply to a correspondent, Mr. Gandhi expresses his views about the compatibility or otherwise of machinery with swadeshi : I have observed that this doubt is felt by many people, and accordingly I have given the reply too.
('18', 388, 3, 5, 839091) Pure swadeshi is not at all opposed to machinery.
('18', 388, 3, 6, 839141) The swadeshi movement is meant only against the use of foreign cloth.
('18', 388, 3, 7, 839211) There is no objection to weaving mill made cloth.
('18', 388, 3, 8, 839261) But I do not myself wear mill made cloth and in the explanations to the swadeshi vow I have certainly suggested that it should be the ideal of every Indian to wear hand spun and hand woven cloth.
('18', 388, 3, 9, 839457) If, fortunately for India, crores of people happen to translate this ideal into practice, the mills may perhaps have to suffer some loss.
('18', 388, 3, 10, 839595) But if the whole of India makes that pure resolve, I am sure that even our mill owners would welcome that resolve, respect its purity and associate themselves with it.
('18', 388, 3, 11, 839763) But it takes long to outgrow inveterate habits.
('18', 388, 3, 12, 839811) There is thus room in the country for both the mill industry and the handlooms weaving.
('18', 388, 3, 13, 839899) So let mills increase as also spinning wheels and handlooms.
('18', 388, 3, 14, 839960) And I should think that these latter are no doubt machines.
('18', 388, 3, 15, 840020) The handloom is a miniature weaving mill.
('18', 388, 3, 16, 840062) The spinning wheel is a miniature spinning mill.
('18', 388, 3, 17, 840111) I would wish to see such beautiful little mills in every home.
('18', 388, 3, 18, 840174) But the country is fully in need of the hand spinning and hand weaving industry.
('18', 388, 3, 19, 840255) Agriculturists in no country can live without some industry to supplement agriculture.
('18', 388, 3, 20, 840342) And in India, which is entirely dependent on favourable monsoons, the spinning wheel and the handloom are like Kamadhenus 1 .
('18', 388, 3, 21, 840468) This movement is thus intended in the interests of 21 crore peasants of India.
('18', 388, 3, 22, 840547) Even if we have sufficient mills in the country to produce cloth enough for the whole country, we are bound to provide our peasantry, daily being more and more impoverished, with some supplementary industry, and that which can be suitable to crores of people is hand spinning and hand weaving.
('18', 388, 3, 23, 840841) Opposition to mills or machinery is not the point.
('18', 388, 3, 24, 840892) What suits our country most is the point.
('18', 388, 3, 25, 840934) I am not opposed to the movement of manufacturing machines in the country, nor to making improvements in machinery.
('18', 388, 3, 26, 841050) I am only concerned with what these machines are meant for.
('18', 388, 3, 27, 841110) I may ask, in the
('18', 388, 4, 28, 841128) 1 Kamadhenu is the mythical cow which bestowed anything one wished for.
('18', 389, 0, 1, 841200) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 389, 1, 2, 841242) words of Ruskin, whether these machines will be such as would blow off a million men in a minute or they will be such as would turn waste lands into arable and fertile land.
('18', 389, 1, 3, 841416) And if legislation were in my hands, I would penalize the manufacture of [labour saving] 1 machines and protect the industry which manufactures nice ploughs which can be handled by every man.
('18', 389, 2, 4, 841608) Young India, 17 9 1919

('18', 389, 7, 11, 842127) 287. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI

('18', 389, 9, 14, 842259) It is not good that your health is not improving.
('18', 389, 9, 15, 842309) If you forget Anand and come here for some time you are bound to get better.
('18', 389, 9, 16, 842386) And if you do not there is nothing to prevent you
