('18', 390, 4, 18, 843919) 288. VICEROYS SPEECH
('18', 390, 5, 19, 843940) His Excellency the Viceroys speech at the time of the opening of the session of the Legislative Council deserves attention.
('18', 390, 5, 20, 844064) Generally, such speeches have something to tell us.
('18', 390, 5, 21, 844116) But in this speech there is more to think over and act upon than to learn.
('18', 390, 5, 22, 844191) From among the many points covered in the speech, for the present I wish to draw the peoples attention only to the following: (1) the problem of Turkey, (2) the problem of the Punjab and, incidentally, that of the Commission and of Indemnity, (3) the problem of South Africa and (4) that of Fiji.
('18', 390, 6, 23, 844488) PROBLEM OF TURKEY
('18', 390, 7, 24, 844506) I am sorry to say that the most disappointing part of the entire speech of the Viceroy is that which refers to the problem of Turkey.
('18', 391, 0, 1, 844640) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 391, 1, 2, 844682) In reporting the speech telegraphically, newspaper correspondents say that out of the 55 minutes which the Viceroy took to read out his speech, he took hardly a minute over the sentences which referred to Turkey.
('18', 391, 1, 3, 844895) I should admit that even in a minute the speaker can say much, that is, can make an important point.
('18', 391, 1, 4, 844996) But in these sentences which the Viceroy took a minute to read out, I find nothing but disappointment.
('18', 391, 1, 5, 845099) His Excellency has stated that he had done his best to see that the fullest possible expression was given to the feelings of Muslims, that not only had the Government of India made strong representations to the Imperial Government, urging the views of the Indian Muslims, but that these views had also been presented directly to the Peace Conference by our representatives.
('18', 391, 1, 6, 845473) Moreover, lest sufficient weight might be not attached to their words, three prominent Muslims, selected to accompany these representatives of ours to the Peace Conference, had also been associated with them.
('18', 391, 1, 7, 845682) Indian Muslims [he said] might rest assured that their feelings had been fully conveyed.
('18', 391, 1, 8, 845771) His Excellency has in this way evaded an important question.
('18', 391, 1, 9, 845832) What comfort can it be to the Muslims that he did his best to convey their feelings?
('18', 391, 1, 10, 845917) It is not only the Muslims who feel on this issue, but the Hindus too, their blood brothers.
('18', 391, 1, 11, 846010) Let us hope that the Viceroy conveyed their feelings as well.
('18', 391, 1, 12, 846072) Even if he has, what does it profit us?
('18', 391, 1, 13, 846112) What one would like to know is whether the British statesmen have made this question their own.
('18', 391, 1, 14, 846208) That they have advocated the cause of the Muslims does not mean much.
('18', 391, 1, 15, 846278) Do they feel in the matter as the Muslims feel?
('18', 391, 1, 16, 846326) And if they do, the question is, what stand are they going to take before the Peace Conference?
('18', 391, 1, 17, 846422) To give a hungry man full opportunity to say that he is hungry is like branding a man who has sustained burns.
('18', 391, 1, 18, 846533) Muslims do not want vakils to express their feelings.
('18', 391, 1, 19, 846587) They want water to quench the fire of their suffering.
('18', 391, 1, 20, 846642) And the Viceroy has provided no reply to the important question whether the British statesmen are ready to give them this water or whether the Muslims will get it.
('18', 391, 1, 21, 846806) It is the duty of the people and of the leaders, as also of the Maharaja of Bikaner, to have this matter clarified.
('18', 391, 2, 22, 846922) THE PUNJAB
('18', 391, 3, 23, 846933) In his reference to this issue, the Viceroy has taken no account of the peoples feelings.
('18', 391, 3, 24, 847023) Just as, at the time of the passing of the Rowlatt Act, popular feeling were brushed aside as so much rubbish, so now His Excellency has dismissed the agitation which followed in
('18', 392, 0, 1, 847202) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 393
('18', 392, 1, 2, 847247) much the same manner, and has laid down a principle which I very much hope the people will fight.
('18', 392, 1, 3, 847345) That principle is this : The members of this Council will agree that no Government should deviate from a policy which it regards as essential, on account of any threat of agitation. The right principle, as against this, one which recognizes public opinion and exalts both the rulers and the ruled, is this : All governments must abandon a policy against which people carry on a sustained agitation. That is why I have been saying all along that, so long as the Rowlatt Act exists on the Statute Book, that is to say, so long as the Government stubbornly persists in its opinion in opposition to public opinion, even the best Reforms imported from Engand are worthless.
('18', 392, 1, 4, 848014) It is, therefore, essential that the people make Herculean efforts to demolish the fearful principle laid down by the Viceroy.
('18', 392, 1, 5, 848141) Even history is against His Excellency.
('18', 392, 1, 6, 848181) I need not go far into the past for instances.
('18', 392, 1, 7, 848228) The reductions in the sentences against Babu Kalinath Roy, Lala Radhakishan and others, held in high respect in the Punjab, are due to popular agitation.
('18', 392, 1, 8, 848382) We have no reason to doubt that the policy considered essential by the Government was to pass heavy sentences and to uphold them.
('18', 392, 1, 9, 848512) Had Lala Goverdhandas not come from the Punjab, had we not known about Kalinath Roy and others and had public resentment not been expressed with one voice throughout the country, I am sure there would have been no reduction in these sentences.
('18', 392, 1, 10, 848756) But the Viceroy seems to think it humiliating to submit to public opinion.
('18', 392, 1, 11, 848831) In the West the officials have to submit to public opinion, whether they like it or not, as we learn in our schools and read in the papers.
('18', 392, 1, 12, 848971) If the Viceroy believes that in India submitting to popular opinion is a humiliation for the Government, we can easily show to him that this is his delusion.
('18', 392, 1, 13, 849129) Poets have sung praises of Ramachandra for abandoning Sita in deference to public opinion, 1
('18', 392, 2, 14, 849222) not publicly expressed, and that is what has made him a revered figure right to this day.
('18', 392, 2, 15, 849312) Unless and until respect for public opinion is revived in India, the people will not be contented and happy.
('18', 392, 2, 16, 849421) If the principle laid down by the Viceroy is not only his personal view but that of his Government as well, the later ought to change it and the people will see to it that it does.
('18', 392, 3, 17, 849602) 1 According to the last book of Valmikis Ramayana, believed by modern scholars to be a later addition, Rama, when he was king of Ayodhya, came to know that some of his subjects thought ill of Sita for having lived in the custody of Ravana, her abductor.
('18', 392, 3, 18, 849856) On his orders, she was taken to the forest and abandoned on the banks of the Ganga, where she found shelter in Valmikis hermitage.
('18', 393, 0, 1, 849987) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 393, 1, 2, 850029) But His Excellency did not stop with laying down this principle.
('18', 393, 1, 3, 850094) He said that those who had held out threats of agitation thought it necessary to carry out their threats and unhappy results followed.
('18', 393, 1, 4, 850229) In saying this, His Excellency has acted as judge, though he himself has appointed a Commission to see that justice is done.
('18', 393, 1, 5, 850354) It is the Commission which will decide whether the violence was the result of the agitation or of the serious mistakes of the Government.
('18', 393, 1, 6, 850492) It is surprising that, in the face of this, the Viceroy should assert that the painful events which occurred were the result of the agitation.
('18', 393, 2, 7, 850635) EDUCATED AND CLEVER MEN
('18', 393, 3, 8, 850659) I must also say that the Viceroy has done me an injustice.
('18', 393, 3, 9, 850718) In my speech in April about the incidents in Ahmedabad, I had said that those incidents would not have occurred if some educated and clever men had not had a hand in them.
('18', 393, 3, 10, 850890) Everyone who reads the speech will see that my words did not apply to any other place.
('18', 393, 3, 11, 850977) I still adhere to what I said, but the Viceroy had no right to apply my words to any place other than Ahmedabad.
('18', 393, 3, 12, 851090) He did apply them to the Punjab, however.
('18', 393, 3, 13, 851132) I still know nothing about the Punjab at first hand.
('18', 393, 3, 14, 851185) From my study of some cases there which have come to my knowledge, it is clear to me that, despite incitement by any number of educated and clever men, the violence which broke out would never have broken out were it not for the serious errors of Sir Michael ODwyer, whether he did all that he did deliberately or otherwise.
('18', 393, 3, 15, 851510) When, on April 6, people all over India, in cities and in small villages, fasted and observed a hartal, we witnessed a peaceful and solemn demonstration such as we have never known in the country at any time in the past.
('18', 393, 3, 16, 851731) Hundreds of thousands of men and women proved to the world that we are one nation, that we suffer with one another and that we are swayed by the same emotions.
('18', 393, 3, 17, 851891) Till this date, however, people had done nothing particularly reprehensible.
('18', 393, 3, 18, 851968) The demonstration on the 6th incensed the Punjab Government and Sir Michael ODwyer committed a series of inexcusable blunders.
('18', 393, 3, 19, 852095) This provoked the people and they too made mistakes.
('18', 393, 3, 20, 852148) The Commission will judge these incidents, not by the standard of satyagraha but by standards which are universally accepted in the West in these days and, instead of deciding whether or not people made mistakes, will decide who committed the first mistake.
('18', 394, 0, 1, 852406) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 395
('18', 394, 1, 2, 852451) COMMISSION His Excellency the Viceroy has informed us in his speech that a Commission has been appointed for the purpose.
('18', 394, 1, 3, 852573) I have seen criticism regretting that this is a Committee and not a Royal Commission, and that some injustice has been done by the refusal to appoint a Royal Commission.
('18', 394, 1, 4, 852743) It seems to me that there is no great difference between a Royal Commission and a Committee appointed by the Viceroy.
('18', 394, 1, 5, 852861) The appointment of a Royal Commission is notified in England and the Commission submits its report to the Imperial Government.
('18', 394, 1, 6, 852988) In the present case the appointment of the Committee is notified by the Government of India and it will submit its report to the Viceroy.
('18', 394, 1, 7, 853126) Even so, the members of the Commission appointed in India cannot be nominated without the consent of the Secretary of State of India.
('18', 394, 1, 8, 853260) We have had experience of Royal Commissions having been appointed, which proved unavailing, and of local Committees having been appointed and of justice done by them.
('18', 394, 1, 9, 853427) To me, therefore, there seems to be no great difference between a Royal Commission and a Committee appointed by the local Government.
('18', 394, 1, 10, 853561) The outcome of the Committees labours depends in some measure on the members who constitute it.
('18', 394, 1, 11, 853657) Examining these names, we see that, though we cannot be enthusiastic over all the names, we cannot say, on the whole, that the members are biased men or that they are not men of independent judgment.
('18', 394, 1, 12, 853857) The Chairman is Lord Hunter.
('18', 394, 1, 13, 853886) He is not a man of Imperial standing, but he was Solicitor General of Scotland and we have, therefore, no reason to fear that he will hesitate to express independent views.
('18', 394, 1, 14, 854059) As for the other members, we have a standard of reference by which to judge them, and that is Sir Chimanlal Setalvad.
('18', 394, 1, 15, 854177) We have no reason to criticize his appointment; on the contrary, we would enthusiastically welcome the Committee if all the other members were of the same calibre.
('18', 394, 1, 16, 854341) Sir Chimanlal Setalvad is an advocate of established reputation and, what is more, takes part in public life.
('18', 394, 1, 17, 854451) He was also a follower, a supporter and a friend of an able man and lover of freedom like Sir Pherozeshah Mehta.
('18', 394, 1, 18, 854564) We may, therefore, trust to his acting impartially and fearlessly in doing justice and carrying others with him as well.
('18', 394, 1, 19, 854685) If, thus, from Bombay they have selected an independent minded and capable leader, we may assume that in selecting others too a like standard has been followed more or less.
('18', 394, 1, 20, 854859) Sahibzada Sultan Ahmed is a brother of Sahibzada Aftab Ahmed Khan, a member of the India Council.
('18', 394, 1, 21, 854957) However, what the Committees report is will depend on us, that is, on our brethren in the Punjab.
('18', 395, 0, 1, 855055) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 395, 1, 2, 855097) they come forward to tell the truth without fear and if no Indian comes to give us false evidence to further his own base interests, we need have no fear about the Committees report.
('18', 395, 1, 3, 855280) Though the Committee can hold secret sessions for reasons which may appear sufficient to it, it will generally take evidence in public.
('18', 395, 1, 4, 855416) It will have, thus, to base its report only on this evidence.
('18', 395, 1, 5, 855478) In some of the cases in the Punjab, the injustice has been so patent that even an illiterate person can see it.
('18', 395, 1, 6, 855590) What other opinion can the Committee express about them?
('18', 395, 1, 7, 855647) I should admit that I entertain no fear about what its report will be.
('18', 395, 1, 8, 855718) The only fear is about our ability to lead evidence properly.
('18', 395, 1, 9, 855780) Personally, I do not have this fear either, and want the reader, too, not to have it.
('18', 395, 1, 10, 855866) The Honble Madan Mohan Malaviya, Sannyasi Swami Shri Shraddhanand and the brave Pandit Motilal Nehru have taken upon themselves to collect evidence and there is no reason, therefore, to fear that evidence would not be presented properly.
('18', 395, 1, 11, 856104) Thus, instead of concerning ourselves with what kind of a Committee it is, we should really direct our attention to how we can place all the facts before it.
('18', 395, 1, 12, 856262) It is also for us to see that the question whether the Committees terms of reference include a review of the judgements already pronounced and the sentences already passed is clarified beyond doubt.
('18', 395, 1, 13, 856461) Though the Viceroys words seem to imply as much, any doubt on an important issue like this must be removed.
('18', 395, 1, 14, 856569) The reader will remember that the Committee is not only for the Punjab, but that Bombay province is also included in the scope of its inquiry.
('18', 395, 1, 15, 856712) We shall, therefore, have to prepare for it.
('18', 395, 1, 16, 856757) To me it seems that we need to give our main attention to obtaining an unambiguous statement of the Committees terms of reference and preparing ourselves for presenting our case to it.
('18', 395, 2, 17, 856942) INDEMNITY
('18', 395, 3, 18, 856952) And now remains the question of indemnity.
('18', 395, 3, 19, 856995) Indemnity means the immunity of officers against civil or criminal proceedings for their actions.
('18', 395, 3, 20, 857093) The Viceroy has said that they intend to introduce in the present session a Bill granting such immunity and there has been a good deal of protest against this.
('18', 395, 3, 21, 857253) Even telegrams have been sent to the Viceroy on behalf of certain public bodies to say that such an Indemnity Bill ought not be passed before the Committees report is published.
('18', 395, 3, 22, 857431) I wish to place before readers my understanding of a law of this nature.
('18', 395, 3, 23, 857504) The officers should not be held personally responsible for their actions under Martial Law.
('18', 395, 3, 24, 857596) Even apart from Martial Law,
('18', 396, 0, 1, 857625) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 397
('18', 396, 1, 2, 857670) officers are not liable to criminal or civil proceedings for any orders passed by them under the oridinary law, even if those orders are subsequently proved to be wrong or to have been passed out of prejudice or malice.
('18', 396, 1, 3, 857890) The Government may, however, hold a departmental inquiry and can dismiss them, but they cannot be made answerable in any court of law.
('18', 396, 1, 4, 858025) Acts under Martial Law are always protected through special legislation and everyone accepts this as a general principle.
('18', 396, 1, 5, 858147) That is why I say that we need have no fear if the Government wants to pass an Indemnity Act right now.
('18', 396, 1, 6, 858251) We should allow the Bill to be passed if its provisions are unobjectionable.
('18', 396, 1, 7, 858328) We do not want to send to the gallows the officers who gave or issued wrong orders and the judges who wrongly passed death sentences.
('18', 396, 1, 8, 858462) Even if we ask for such power, we shall not get it.
('18', 396, 1, 9, 858514) They will remain immune against such punishment.
('18', 396, 1, 10, 858563) Every State needs such protection.
('18', 396, 1, 11, 858598) Even when we come to enjoy swaraj, the State will retain this power.
('18', 396, 1, 12, 858667) The officers will then too commit grave mistakes and the public will get excited; even under swaraj the people will resort to violence; if the spirit of pure satyagraha has not come to prevail in India by then, there will be Martial Law and firing, followed by appointment of Commissions.
('18', 396, 1, 13, 858956) Even under swaraj Indemnity Acts will be passed to protect the authority of the State.
('18', 396, 1, 14, 859043) But then, as now, the actual provisions will need to be looked into.
('18', 396, 1, 15, 859112) About this Bill, too, I would therefore say that, rather than complain that it has been brought in prematurely, we had better have a careful look at its provisions.
('18', 396, 1, 16, 859277) For instance, we may not object to a clause providing that the officers who issued orders for firing would not be liable to prosecution for murder or that they could not be sued for damages.
('18', 396, 1, 17, 859468) But we should strenuously oppose any provision making such officers immune against departmental inquiry or dismissal for misconduct or incompetence.
('18', 396, 1, 18, 859617) We should also oppose a provision to the effect that all sentences and orders, whether just or unjust, would remain and could not be modified.
('18', 396, 1, 19, 859760) These are only some illustrations.
('18', 396, 1, 20, 859795) Thus, my humble view is that we are only justified in opposing undesirable provisions in the Bill.
('18', 396, 2, 21, 859894) SOUTH AFRICA
('18', 396, 3, 22, 859907) His Excellencys pronouncement on this question will not be considered unsatisfactory.
('18', 396, 3, 23, 859993) The decision to send Sir Benjamin Robertson to present our case is a welcome one.
('18', 396, 3, 24, 860075) His presence there cannot but have a powerful effect on the whites of South Africa.
('18', 397, 0, 1, 860159) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 397, 1, 2, 860201) cables we have received from that country suggest that the white traders there are still bent on mischief and complain that the new law is not being properly administered.
('18', 397, 1, 3, 860373) In these circumstances, the presence of a representative of the Indian Government will prove useful on issues of this kind.
('18', 397, 1, 4, 860497) According to my understanding of His Excellency the Viceroys pronouncement, the representatives referred to in Mr. Montagus announcement will also be appointed.
('18', 397, 1, 5, 860658) If these representatives are strong and independent men, I have no doubt that they can be very effective and the injustices from which our countrymen suffer will be very much mitigated.
('18', 397, 2, 6, 860844) FIJI The Viceroys announcement about Fiji is entirely satisfactory and we can now hope that, before the year is out, the conditions in which our sisters suffer outrage will have disappeared, and the indentured labourers will have been set free from their bondage.
('18', 397, 2, 7, 861108) We need not believe, of course, that with the ending of the system of indenture, the immorality which has taken root will disappear forthwith.
('18', 397, 2, 8, 861251) The ending of the system will absolve the Government and the people from the ever increasing blame which is being laid at their door.
('18', 397, 2, 9, 861385) For the past, of course, our shame remains.1

('18', 397, 5, 12, 861467) 289. A DIALOGUE2
('18', 397, 6, 13, 861484) We publish here a dialogue exactly as it took place only a few days ago.
('18', 397, 6, 14, 861557) To make it interesting to the readers, some of the sentences have been broken up and the picture of Hind Devi has been touched up a little.
('18', 397, 6, 15, 861697) Except for these changes, the questions and answers are reproduced exactly as they occurred.
('18', 397, 6, 16, 861790) The value of the dialogue lies in the fact that it actually took place.
('18', 397, 6, 17, 861862) The names of the speakers have been purposely left out.
('18', 397, 6, 18, 861918) A : Jai Sachchidananda.
('18', 397, 6, 19, 861942) I wonder if you recognize me?
('18', 397, 6, 20, 861972) B : You did not have this ochre robe on then!
('18', 397, 6, 21, 862018) A : True, father, I was initiated into this dress by a certain mahatma.
('18', 397, 6, 22, 862090) B : Did you not give any thought to the matter?
('18', 397, 6, 23, 862138) A : I had faith in the mahatma.
('18', 397, 6, 24, 862170) I used to reflect a little on religion, and so I knew that what the mahatma advised could be done.
('18', 398, 0, 1, 862269) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 399
('18', 398, 1, 2, 862314) B : Do people reverence you when they see you in this dress?
('18', 398, 1, 3, 862375) A : Yes, father, they do, to be sure.
('18', 398, 1, 4, 862413) B : Are you worthy of such reverence?
('18', 398, 1, 5, 862451) A : Oh, no !
('18', 398, 1, 6, 862464) How can I claim that I am?
('18', 398, 1, 7, 862491) I am full of attachments and aversions.
('18', 398, 1, 8, 862531) B : You beg for alms, no doubt?
('18', 398, 1, 9, 862563) A : Yes, I do.
('18', 398, 1, 10, 862578) B : Do you say anything when receiving the alms?
('18', 398, 1, 11, 862627) A : Not much, but occasionally I do preach.
('18', 398, 1, 12, 862671) B : Have you done any study?
('18', 398, 1, 13, 862700) A : Only a little.
('18', 398, 1, 14, 862719) I have read a few shastras in Prakrit.
('18', 398, 1, 15, 862758) B : Are you happy leading such a life?
('18', 398, 1, 16, 862797) A : I wish I were!
('18', 398, 1, 17, 862816) This is an idle quest in which I am engaged.
('18', 398, 1, 18, 862861) I would certainly do what is good for me.
('18', 398, 1, 19, 862903) Can you show me the way?
('18', 398, 1, 20, 862928) B : I should very much like to ask you to discard this dress, and that is easily done.
('18', 398, 1, 21, 863015) But now it is better to think how best you may live so as to be worthy of it.
('18', 398, 1, 22, 863093) A : Indeed, that would be best.
('18', 398, 1, 23, 863125) B : I know well enough that you are a devotee of Hind Devi.
('18', 398, 1, 24, 863185) A : That certainly is my ambition.
('18', 398, 1, 25, 863220) B : Have you beheld the Goddess?
('18', 398, 1, 26, 863253) A : I do not catch the point.
('18', 398, 1, 27, 863283) B : Do you have a mental picture of Hind Devi?
('18', 398, 1, 28, 863330) A : I have not thought about the matter.
('18', 398, 1, 29, 863371) B : I fancy that the Goddess wears a sari made in Japan.
('18', 398, 1, 30, 863428) The sleeves of her satin blouse made in Paris are bordered with Parisian lace.
('18', 398, 1, 31, 863507) On her forehead is a small vermilion mark made with imported stuff.
('18', 398, 1, 32, 863575) On her wrists are English bangles.
('18', 398, 1, 33, 863610) In her right hand are spikes of bajri,glittering like gold and of jowar with grains like pearls.
('18', 398, 1, 34, 863707) In her left hand is a bit of rotten, dusty cotton thread.
('18', 398, 1, 35, 863765) The Devi has the colour of the wheat near by; her face is downcast; she looks as if she had been crying.
('18', 398, 1, 36, 863870) Around her, her children, evidently famished, are with painful slowness working in the fields.
('18', 398, 1, 37, 863965) On the left are spinning wheels covered with white ants; the cotton strings round the wheels have snapped, the spindle holders are about to drop down; around her are seated our womenfolk, dozing.
('18', 398, 1, 38, 864161) A few weavers are engaged in weaving bits of cloth.
('18', 398, 1, 39, 864213) A : Yes, that is a faithful picture of the Goddess.
('18', 399, 0, 1, 864265) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 399, 1, 2, 864307) B : Do you understand, then, what the Goddess is saying to both you and me?
('18', 399, 1, 3, 864383) A : To be sure, that we must work.
('18', 399, 1, 4, 864418) B : Yes, of course, it is that.
('18', 399, 1, 5, 864450) He who performs no yajna, does no physical work, is a thief.
('18', 399, 1, 6, 864511) That is what the Gita says.
('18', 399, 1, 7, 864539) 1 But dont you think the Goddess is telling us something more than that?
('18', 399, 1, 8, 864612) A : Oh, do tell me, yourself.
('18', 399, 1, 9, 864642) B : From her looks, the Goddess seems to appeal to us that we should help her to be rid of those foreign garments, to clean the spinning wheels for those sleepy women and set them spinning again.
('18', 399, 1, 10, 864838) A : What you say sounds as true as gold.
('18', 399, 1, 11, 864879) B : Well then, we shall succeed in determining what you should do, so that you may live as befits your ochre robe.
('18', 399, 1, 12, 864994) Many a sadhu dishonours his robe.
('18', 399, 1, 13, 865028) These are a burden on the nation; you will surely admit as much!
('18', 399, 1, 14, 865093) A : No one can deny it.
('18', 399, 1, 15, 865117) B : Then, you should learn spinning and weaving, teach them to others and so ensure their and your regeneration.
('18', 399, 1, 16, 865230) Your spinning wheel will preach for you.
('18', 399, 1, 17, 865271) A : Indeed, I feel I have been rather hasty in donning this robe.
('18', 399, 1, 18, 865337) My intention was good, but now I shall lose no time to pick up spinning and weaving.

('18', 399, 5, 22, 865470) THE TRANSVAAL ASIATICS The news received last week from the Transvaal adds fat to the fire.
('18', 399, 5, 23, 865562) At a Congress of the representatives of municipalities in the Transvaal, merchants associations, trade unions and other institutions, a resolution was passed to the effect that the administration of the anti Asiatic laws was slack and needed tightening up.
('18', 399, 5, 24, 865819) The Congress has protested against giving citizenship rights to Asiatics.
('18', 399, 5, 25, 865893) It has, moreover, decided to establish a South Africans league, in other words, an
('18', 399, 6, 26, 865976) 1 III, 12
('18', 400, 0, 1, 865986) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 401
('18', 400, 1, 2, 866031) association of the whites of South Africa.
('18', 400, 1, 3, 866074) The object of this association will be to acquire the immovable property at present owned by Asiatics after paying them reasonable compensation and to take all possible measures to eliminate skilfully the Asiatics living and doing business in the Transvaal.
('18', 400, 1, 4, 866332) Another telegram received from Pretoria is also suggestive of the feelings of the whites.
('18', 400, 1, 5, 866422) Representatives of municipalities, merchants associations and other institutions gathered at a mammoth meeting, where the question of the Transvaal Asiatics was discussed.
('18', 400, 1, 6, 866594) The chairman painted a dark future for South Africa if the problem remained unsolved.
('18', 400, 1, 7, 866680) The meeting passed a resolution moved by Mr. Munnik, to the effect that the ever increasing influence of Asiatics held a serious threat to the economic and social life of the Transvaal whites.
('18', 400, 1, 8, 866873) Hence immediate legislation to solve the problem was advocated.
('18', 400, 1, 9, 866937) The Cape Times, severely criticizing Mr. Montagus reply to the deputation which waited on him under the leadership of Mr. Surendranath Banerjea, says that the Secretary of State for India was not well informed about the difficult and delicate problem in the Transvaal.
('18', 400, 1, 10, 867206) The paper reminds him that the Government had cast all its weight against the amendment moved by Mr. Collins to the law recently passed in the Transvaal in which he sought to prevent Indians from carrying on trade in any part of the Transvaal.
('18', 400, 1, 11, 867450) Mr. Montagu should have made it clearer to the deputation that the Union Parliament had very much appreciated Indias help to the Empire and should have detailed with greater understanding the difficulties experienced by the Government of South Africa in solving the Indian problem.

('18', 404, 6, 16, 873497) 296. LABH SINGH 4
('18', 404, 7, 17, 873515) No mere reduction of sentence, it is most humbly submitted, can be a consolation to Your Excellencys memorialist or in an adequate measure will right the wrong that has been done him or meet the ends of justice.
('18', 404, 7, 18, 873727) This is an extract from the latest petition of Mr. Labh Singh, Barrister at Law.
('18', 404, 7, 19, 873808) I am sure this petition will not fail to evoke from the reader both sympathy and admiration; sympathy because of the wrong that has been done him and admiration because the jail has not broken the spirit of the young Barrister.
('18', 404, 7, 20, 874036) He asks for no mercy; he pleads for justice, if he can secure it.
('18', 404, 7, 21, 874102) But in spite of H. E. the Viceroys remarks to the contrary, the spirit of justice is moving so slow and there seems to be such a disinclination even in the high quarters to do real justice that one almost despairs of getting it.
('18', 404, 7, 22, 874331) Look at Sir Edward Maclagans speech in reply to the Honble Pandit Malaviyajis resolution for the appointment of a Commission.
('18', 404, 8, 23, 874457) 1 It appears from the contents that this letter was written about the same time as the letter to the addressee dated Before September 21, 1919.
('18', 404, 8, 24, 874601) 2 The title in the original carries the suffix: M.A., L.L.B. (Cantab), Barrister at Law.
('18', 405, 0, 1, 874690) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 405, 1, 2, 874732) recalls the warning of the Viceroy against the temptation to minimize the events of last April. I do not think, His Honour proceeds, that even while the disorders were in progress, people outside the Punjab fully realized the extreme gravity of the situation. He adds,
('18', 405, 2, 3, 875001) Had it not been for the rapidity with which the disturbances were made, had they been allowed to proceed but a little further than they did, the lives and property of all classes of people would have been in the most imminent danger.
('18', 405, 2, 4, 875235) This is merely begging the question and anticipating the verdict of the Committee of Enquiry.
('18', 405, 2, 5, 875329) Regarding the sentences, His Honour again begs the question by saying that the findings of the Special Courts should be accepted because they represent the unanimous conclusions, in each case, of three experienced officers.
('18', 405, 2, 6, 875553) But the unanimity and experience are beside the point when behind them lies a temporary aberration of the intellect.
('18', 405, 2, 7, 875670) His Honour, however, attempts to silence his critics by saying,
('18', 405, 3, 8, 875734) Although I have examined many cases, I have not found one in which I felt justified in impugning the substantial correctness of the finding of the Court.
('18', 405, 3, 9, 875888) In the face of this emphatic opinion I despair of securing or expecting justice either for Mr. Labh Singh or for any of the great Punjab leaders, who are at present adorning the Punjab jails.
('18', 405, 3, 10, 876080) I do however feel tempted to say, with due deference to the Lieut. Governor of the Punjab that, if he has not found a single case for challenging the correctness of the findings of the Special Courts, of all the many cases that have come before the public, it has not been my good fortune to find many judgments to inspire confidence in their correctness.
('18', 405, 3, 11, 876436) Let me illustrate my point by taking this very case of Mr. Labh Singh.
('18', 405, 3, 12, 876507) He is not a man of straw.
('18', 405, 3, 13, 876533) This is the full text of the Judges remarks in his case :
('18', 405, 4, 14, 876591) Labh Singh, accused 4, took an active part in the inception of the agitation against the Rowlatt Act and was present at meetings of the 12th and the 13th.
('18', 405, 4, 15, 876746) On the latter date, he is said to have at first opposed the commission of acts of violence, but finally agreed.
('18', 405, 4, 16, 876858) He was seen in several places with the mob on the 14th but appears to have rendered assistance to the authorities on that date.
('18', 405, 4, 17, 876986) We find him guilty under section 121, I.P.C. The whole of this judgment, the reader will find reproduced in the issue of Young India, July 30th.
('18', 405, 4, 18, 877131) I ask where is, in the above remarks, anything but good, said even by the Judges about Mr. Labh
('18', 406, 0, 1, 877227) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 407
('18', 406, 1, 2, 877272) Singh, except the expression but finally agreed?
('18', 406, 1, 3, 877321) On the Judges own showing there was nothing indictable in the acts prior to the 12th April.
('18', 406, 1, 4, 877413) The whole of the conviction is based upon the uncorroborated testimony of an approver, notwithstanding the fact that there was incontestable evidence to show that he endeavoured to render assistance to the authorities (I am quoting the Judges words) after the supposed approval by him of acts of violence.
('18', 406, 1, 5, 877719) But, in order to accept the approvers testimony, the Court says at the end of the judgment, Labh Singh evidently repented of his action. Let the reader remember that this is the same judgment in which poor Jagannath was sentenced in the face of a clearly established alibi, and even before replies to the interrogatories issued by the Commissioner had been received.
('18', 406, 1, 6, 878086) No wonder Mr. Labh Singh says,
('18', 406, 2, 7, 878117) The order of the Lieut. Governor, it is humbly submitted, goes only to confirm and perpetuate what is a great and serious miscarriage of justice.
('18', 406, 2, 8, 878263) It is admitted that, beyond signing the notice for the 5th April, Mr. Labh Singh neither convened nor addressed a public meeting at Gujranwala or elsewhere at any time within 12 to 15 months preceding the occurrence of the 14th April.
('18', 406, 2, 9, 878498) Mr. Labh Singh further says,
('18', 406, 3, 10, 878527) The court proceeded to the judgment with inordinate haste and without waiting for the answers to the interrogatories issued to some of the witnesses for the defence.
('18', 406, 3, 11, 878693) I do not wish to burden these notes with more quotations from the very able and convincing statements of Mr. Labh Singh and his two petitions, but I would ask every lover of India and every public man to carefully study these three documents together with the judgment in the case.
('18', 406, 3, 12, 878975) I think that we owe a very plain duty to Mr. Labh Singh and his co prisoners.
('18', 406, 3, 13, 879053) According to Sir Edward Maclagan, they are all clearly guilty.
('18', 406, 3, 14, 879116) According to the evidence before the public, they are all clearly innocent.
('18', 406, 3, 15, 879192) We may not allow young men of brilliant ability and moral worth to have their careers blasted for life by our indifference.
('18', 406, 3, 16, 879316) Posterity will judge us by our ability to secure justice in the cases such as I have had the painful duty of placing before the public.
('18', 406, 3, 17, 879452) For me, justice for the individual, be he the humblest, is everything.
('18', 406, 3, 18, 879523) All else comes after.
('18', 406, 3, 19, 879545) And I hope that the public will take the same view.
('18', 406, 3, 20, 879597) If the convictions stand, it will not be because we are unable to secure justice but because we are unwilling and incompetent, for I feel that even the Government of India and the
('18', 407, 0, 1, 879777) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 407, 1, 2, 879819) Punjab Government will find it hard to withstand a unanimously expressed public opinion based on facts and couched in the language of moderation.

('18', 408, 5, 10, 881476) 300. SPEECH ON KHILAFAT, BOMBAY 3
('18', 408, 6, 11, 881510) September 18, 1919
('18', 408, 7, 12, 881529) I am glad to be able to be present at this gathering and I thank you for inviting me.
('18', 408, 7, 13, 881615) The question we have met to discuss this evening is not new to me.
('18', 408, 7, 14, 881682) Ever since my arrival, I have been mixing among Mohammedans of all shades of opinion and I know that it is a question among questions.
('18', 408, 7, 15, 881817) On a right solution of it depends the future peace of this land.
('18', 408, 7, 16, 881882) It therefore affects not only the Mohammedans of India but it affects the Hindus and other as well.
('18', 408, 7, 17, 881982) It is a great Empire question.
('18', 408, 7, 18, 882013) I was therefore pained to see that H.E. the Viceroy had only one minute out of fifty five of his speech to the Legislative Council to devote to this question.
('18', 408, 7, 19, 882172) He might usefully and legitimately have reversed the order.
('18', 408, 7, 20, 882232) I have publicly and respectfully warned His Excellency of the gravity of this question.
('18', 408, 7, 21, 882320) With it is bound up all that is most sacred in Islam.
('18', 408, 7, 22, 882374) I can enter into your feelings for I know that Hindus would feel if their religious honour was at stake.

('18', 410, 6, 12, 886335) 302. THE INDEMNITY BILL
('18', 410, 7, 13, 886359) The much talked of Indemnity Bill is now before the public.
('18', 410, 7, 14, 886419) I observe that the fact of the Bill being now brought forward is still being attacked.
('18', 410, 7, 15, 886506) Sir Narayan Chandavarkar, with his great legal knowledge, has joined the attacking army in fine form.
('18', 410, 7, 16, 886608) He considers that constitutional law and precedent alike require that an Indemnity Bill can be properly passed only by the Imperial Parliament and not by the local legislation, and that the former can only do so after a Royal Commission has reported to it.
('18', 410, 7, 17, 886865) He is able to quote in support of his contention Diceys opinion.
('18', 410, 7, 18, 886930) It is not therefore without a deep sense of humility that I express a different opinion.
('18', 410, 7, 19, 887019) I hold strong views about parliamentary interference.
('18', 410, 7, 20, 887073) No doubt, at times, that interference becomes a blessing, but I contemplate a time, not far distant, when we shall have a legislature wholly responsible to the
('18', 410, 8, 21, 887233) 1 The source is damaged.
('18', 411, 0, 1, 887258) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 411, 1, 2, 887300) people in all that is of vital importance to them.
('18', 411, 1, 3, 887351) Parliamentary interference then, would be as intolerable to us as it is to Australia, Canada or South Africa.
('18', 411, 1, 4, 887461) When we have regained full national consciousness, we shall not hang on to the leading string even of the mother of parliaments.
('18', 411, 1, 5, 887590) We shall wade, if necessary, as others have done, to purity and peace through strife, passion and prejudice.
('18', 411, 1, 6, 887699) I am quite prepared for rude shocks, when properly elected popular representatives meet for the first time untrammelled by official frown and untempted by official favour.
('18', 411, 1, 7, 887871) That being my view, I am able to contemplate with equanimity the passage of an Indemnity Bill even through the present legislature, which has only a shadow of popular representation and control.
('18', 411, 1, 8, 888066) Moreover, to take a practical view of the question, I imagine we shall find it fairly tough work to set up a precedent in India and secure the passage of an Indemnity Bill through the Imperial Parliament.
('18', 411, 1, 9, 888271) I must respectfully dissent also from the view that such a Bill can only be properly passed after a Commission has reported.
('18', 411, 1, 10, 888396) I venture to submit that the Bill as published is almost harmless and it is a Bill we should be bound to pass as it is even after the Commission has reported.
('18', 411, 1, 11, 888555) I do not for a moment doubt that the officer who ordered the inhuman floggings did so under the bonafide belief that he was saving the Empire.
('18', 411, 1, 12, 888698) I would not have us as individuals to exercise the right of suing that officer for damages.
('18', 411, 1, 13, 888790) I would have him dismissed, if I had the power, for incompetence, and this right of administrative action is preserved intact by the Bill.
('18', 411, 1, 14, 888929) After all, we do not wish to be vindictive or to make scapegoats of subordinate officers.
('18', 411, 1, 15, 889019) Popular imagination and belief hold the Punjab Government and the Government of India to be the real offenders.
('18', 411, 1, 16, 889131) I believe that they have not protected themselves under the Bill.
('18', 411, 1, 17, 889197) The Viceroy cannot get a certificate of good faith from his Secretary nor Sir Michael ODwyer from his.
('18', 411, 1, 18, 889300) They would therefore be obliged to discharge the burden of proving that they adopted extraordinary powers for a good and sufficient cause.
('18', 411, 1, 19, 889439) Lastly, in my humble opinion, we shall but unnecessarily irritate our English friends by seeming, as we would seem to them, to oppose an indemnity being granted to subordinate officers.
('18', 411, 1, 20, 889625) They would appreciate our fight against the Punjab satrap and the Viceroy.
('18', 411, 1, 21, 889700) They will not understand even our delay in granting protection to under officers against actions at law.
('18', 411, 1, 22, 889805) And we have so many good fights to fight that I would reserve all our powder and shot for a fight which we must fight.
('18', 411, 1, 23, 889924) We must hold
('18', 412, 0, 1, 889937) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 413
('18', 412, 1, 2, 889982) the honour of innocent victims from Lala Harkishan Lal down to the young lad Karamchand, as a sacred trust.
('18', 412, 1, 3, 890090) The Privy Council may, for technical reasons, throw out the appeals that are now pending.
('18', 412, 1, 4, 890180) All, again, may not be able to appeal.
('18', 412, 1, 5, 890219) And the Government may prove unyielding and grant relief only in the cases actually disposed of by the Privy Council.
('18', 412, 1, 6, 890337) We dare not rest satisfied with that.
('18', 412, 1, 7, 890375) We must, therefore, see to it that we obtain a full, public and impartial investigation of all the cases in which we believe that palpable injustice has been done.
('18', 412, 1, 8, 890539) The question therefore to consider is : Has Lord Hunters Committee the ample power of entering upon such an investigation?
('18', 412, 1, 9, 890662) If it has not, I would unhesitatingly tender the advice I did in South Africa, namely, that of abstaining from any participation in giving evidence before the Committee.
('18', 412, 1, 10, 890832) Secondly, I would agitate for the release of the political offenders so called, such as Lala Harkishan Lal, Lala Goverdhan Das, Dr. Satyapal, Dr. Kitchlew and others.
('18', 412, 1, 11, 890999) They must be able to give their evidence with the same freedom and the same dignity as the viceroy and Sir Michael ODwyer if the latter will condescend, as they ought, to give evidence before the Committee.
('18', 412, 1, 12, 891206) Thirdly, we should concentrate our energy upon collecting, marshalling and sifting evidence of the witnesses in the Punjab and elsewhere.
('18', 412, 1, 13, 891344) This work requires a sustained effort, organizing ability, harnessing of the best talent of the country and absolute fearlessness and integrity in presenting the case before the Committee.
('18', 412, 1, 14, 891533) And if we can prove but a fourth of the charges that are suggested by the formidable list of questions framed by the ever watchful Panditji, we shall have vindicated the position that we have taken up all along the line.
('18', 412, 1, 15, 891754) Punishment of the erring officers is not our goal.
('18', 412, 1, 16, 891805) An honourable discharge of the men whom we hold to be innocent and whom we believe to be wrongly convicted is our deliberate aim.

('18', 413, 1, 2, 892000) 303. LETTER TO G.S. ARUNDALE
('18', 413, 2, 3, 892029) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, September 20, 1919
('18', 413, 3, 4, 892071) DEAR MR. ARUNDALE, Regarding your request 1 for something from me on the Punjab Week, I can only say that it is our clear duty to secure full justice and expose the wrong we fell has been done to the people of that unhappy province.
('18', 413, 3, 5, 892304) There are three ways of doing it : (1) To contribute towards the expenses.
('18', 413, 3, 6, 892379) (2) To study the facts as they gradually percolate to us and to publish them.
('18', 413, 3, 7, 892457) (3) To hold meeting in every street and corner to pass resolutions demanding an open and impartial inquiry into the affairs of April and the aftermath.
('18', 413, 3, 8, 892609) I observe that Lord Hunters Committee will not investigate individual cases and that two judges will be appointed for the purpose.
('18', 413, 3, 9, 892740) We must see to it that the judges are judges whom we can trust and that they have ample powers including the power to take fresh evidence.
('18', 413, 3, 10, 892879) And in order that both the investigations are properly conducted, we must demand the release, on parole, if need be, of political prisoners.
('18', 413, 3, 11, 893020) In my humble opinion, all reform will be worthless if we cannot secure the needed redress and the repeal of an Act to keep which, as I believe, justice has been flung to the winds.
('18', 413, 4, 12, 893201) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI New India, 26 9 1919
('18', 413, 5, 13, 893252) 1 This was made on September 13 in connection with the organizing of a Punjab Distress Week from September 28 to October 5, for raising funds to relieve distress and carry on a vigorous Press campaign.
('18', 413, 5, 14, 893454) Arundale had observed: A message from you would not merely stimulate our own Presidency, but would be a clarion call as well to the whole of India.

('18', 414, 6, 12, 894063) 305. NOTES
('18', 414, 7, 13, 894074) NATIONAL EDUCATION
('18', 414, 8, 14, 894093) We draw the readers attention to the article 2 on the ancient educational centres of India.
('18', 414, 8, 15, 894185) So long as education in the country is not imparted by persons of integrity and conditions are not created in which the highest knowledge will be available to the poorest of Indians, so long as a perfect confluence of education and dharma has not taken place and education has not been brought into relation with conditions in India, so long as the intolerable burden imposed on the minds of the young by imparting education through a foreign medium has not been lifted, so long will there be no upsurge of national life; there is no denying this.
('18', 414, 8, 16, 894733) Purely national education should be imparted in the regional language.
('18', 414, 8, 17, 894804) The teachers must be of a high calibre.
('18', 414, 8, 18, 894844) The school should be situated in surroundings where the student has fresh air and water, where he enjoys peace, where the building and the adjoining land are object lessons in healthful living; and the educational pattern must
('18', 414, 9, 19, 895071) 1 The addressee received this letter on September 21, 1919. 2 This was written by Mavji Damji Shah, and published in Navajivan, 21 9 1919. It purported to be a translation of a Marathi original.
('18', 415, 0, 1, 895266) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 415, 1, 2, 895308) beone which will instruct [the pupil] in the main professions and religions of India.
('18', 415, 1, 3, 895394) A friend has expressed his willingness to bear all the expenses of such a school.
('18', 415, 1, 4, 895476) He desires that in this school free primary education should be provided to children in Ahmedabad.
('18', 415, 1, 5, 895575) He wants that there should be not one but many such schools in Ahmedabad.
('18', 415, 1, 6, 895649) We think land will be available near Ahmedabad and a building can be put up, but we know that it will be difficult to find well educated teachers possessing good character.
('18', 415, 1, 7, 895822) We submit to the educated classes of Gujarat that they would do well to turn their eyes in this direction.

('18', 415, 2, 18, 897088) BUSINESS MENS DUTY TO THEIR ASSISTANTS
('18', 415, 3, 19, 897127) We draw the attention of the business community to the letter from a correspondent writing under the pseudonym of Sarvodaya.
('18', 415, 3, 20, 897252) Our correspondent is himself a respectable business man of Bombay.
('18', 415, 3, 21, 897319) We have often heard painful complaints from assistants in Bombay.
('18', 415, 3, 22, 897385) They are made to work from early morning till ten at night, with the result that they find no time for devotions, or for reading, nor can they attend to their health.
('18', 415, 3, 23, 897552) This pitiable condition of those who serve the people argues a deficiency in national life.
('18', 415, 3, 24, 897644) The relationship between a business man and his servant must be one of mutual regard and loyalty, like that between father and son.
('18', 415, 3, 25, 897776) Such regard and loyalty should prompt the assistant to give up his dear life for his master, if
('18', 416, 0, 1, 897872) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 417
('18', 416, 1, 2, 897917) need be.
('18', 416, 1, 3, 897926) He should ever remain honest towards his master.
('18', 416, 1, 4, 897975) The masters loyalty lies in being kind to the assistant while taking work from him, in being mindful of his health and in improving his lot.
('18', 416, 1, 5, 898116) Wherever there is a realization of this mutual obligation, we shall observe that results are excellent.
('18', 416, 1, 6, 898220) In this respect, we would do well to emulate the British.
('18', 416, 1, 7, 898278) Generally, the assistant has fixed hours of work, short enough to leave him time for his household work, for exercise, and for devotions if he is religiously inclined.
('18', 416, 1, 8, 898446) The work that an English master can get from his assistant in eight hours, the employers among us, sometimes, cannot exact even in sixteen hours.
('18', 416, 1, 9, 898592) We would place before the masters their own interests.
('18', 416, 1, 10, 898647) In exacting work from the assistants for eight or twelve or fourteen hours, they have to keep working themselves.
('18', 416, 1, 11, 898761) We are not in this world that we may think of our business the whole day.
('18', 416, 1, 12, 898835) Business is a means; when it comes to be an end and dominates all our thoughts, we become its slaves.
('18', 416, 1, 13, 898937) It is the duty of the business man to emancipate himself from such a state in time.
('18', 416, 1, 14, 899021) The problem Kavi Nanalal is trying to solve in his valuable articles has a close bearing on this subject.
('18', 416, 1, 15, 899127) We have already grasped the general trend of his articles that a nation without the time or the means for innocent joy in its life will have its vitality slowly drained away.
('18', 416, 1, 16, 899302) Just as man needs sleep, so also he needs to be free from anxiety, such as that which attends on business, etc., to have innocent, childlike fun and be light hearted.
('18', 416, 1, 17, 899469) If this comes about, the nation will be born anew every day and just as the daily rising of the sun appears ever fresh to us, so where the people have the means and the time for innocent joy the national life will ever be found radiant and full blown, not lack lustre and faded.
('18', 416, 1, 18, 899748) We present this idea with our compliments to the business men, appeal to them to think over the matter and advise them to implement the suggestions of Sarvodya in some way or other.
('18', 416, 2, 19, 899930) OF TEMPORARY AND PERMANENT VALUE
('18', 416, 3, 20, 899963) People are busy with two kinds of activities in this world.
('18', 416, 3, 21, 900023) One kind is of temporary value, and aims only at momentary happiness.
('18', 416, 3, 22, 900093) Good people eschew such activity or work but slightly towards this end.
('18', 416, 3, 23, 900165) The other is of permanent value and is eschewed by the cowardly because it requires continuous effort.
('18', 417, 0, 1, 900268) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 417, 1, 2, 900310) Today in India, too, there are these two kinds of activities going on.
('18', 417, 1, 3, 900381) We see the people too much occupied with thoughts of the minor injustices and oppressions of the Government.
('18', 417, 1, 4, 900490) We find this interesting because we have occasion to employ or hear spicy words.
('18', 417, 1, 5, 900571) By keeping itself too absorbed in such activity a nation does not rise, but falls rather.
('18', 417, 1, 6, 900661) This does not mean that one need not so fight oppression that it will never happen again.
('18', 417, 1, 7, 900751) All that is meant here is that we should not make oppression the main concern of public life.
('18', 417, 1, 8, 900845) This will have no interest for the millions either.
('18', 417, 1, 9, 900897) Of course, where oppression is the main thing, the people are for ever occupied with defending themselves and, in such circumstances, to talk to the people about any other activity is like singing before one suffering the pangs of hunger.
('18', 417, 1, 10, 901136) In India we have not yet reached that stage.
('18', 417, 1, 11, 901181) The policy of the British Government is a mixed affair; it has both justice and injustice.
('18', 417, 1, 12, 901272) In its conception the policy must be admitted to be just, but those who carry it out make mistakes time and again and injustice results; the people have to work to get these mistakes rectified.
('18', 417, 1, 13, 901466) It is but their duty to do so.
('18', 417, 1, 14, 901497) It is, however, the duty of newspapers to find out which activity will conduce to the enduring happiness of the people and to help them to carry it on and to guide them.
('18', 417, 1, 15, 901667) It is our emphatic view that among all such activities of enduring value, the swadeshi movement is the chief.
('18', 417, 1, 16, 901777) It is their duty, likewise, to discover the way of providing the best education to the people, the means whereby the peasants life of want may be made worth while and to ascertain the causes of, and seek remedies for, the innumerable diseases which afflict the people.
('18', 417, 1, 17, 902046) All these activities tend towards the uplift of the people.
('18', 417, 1, 18, 902106) Hence the reader will see by and by that we employ Navajivan more especially to further these activities of enduring value.
('18', 417, 1, 19, 902230) So long as all the aspects of the nations life are not developed, its real uplift will be impossible.
('18', 417, 1, 20, 902332) Only if the people take up such activities will they achieve and enjoy pure swaraj.
('18', 417, 1, 21, 902416) Therefore, though we shall vigorously oppose injustice wherever we find it and point out the way which seems best to us, we shall employ the pages of Navajivan to consider how the activities of enduring value may be promoted and we hope readers will welcome this decision of ours.
('18', 418, 0, 1, 902697) VOL. 18 : 1 MAY, 1919 28 SEPTEMBER, 1919 419
('18', 418, 1, 2, 902742) NAVAJIVAN CLUB
('18', 418, 2, 3, 902757) If we are to realize the aims of Navajivan, it is not enough that we go on merely writing articles or dispatching copies to subscribers.
('18', 418, 2, 4, 902894) We would never feel that we were doing our work well until the message of Navajivan reached all the men and women of Gujarat, educated and uneducated.
('18', 418, 2, 5, 903045) This great task cannot be accomplished by the contributors and the managers of Navajivan, all by themselves.
('18', 418, 2, 6, 903154) It needs the fullest co operation of the readers and subscribers of Navajivan.
('18', 418, 2, 7, 903233) We want that they do not rest satisfied with reading the copy themselves but read it aloud to the uneducated members of their family.
('18', 418, 2, 8, 903367) Our suggestion goes even further than this.
('18', 418, 2, 9, 903411) We know that there are many persons who cannot afford even an anna a week.
('18', 418, 2, 10, 903486) There are many more who, though they can read, have no desire to know what developments are taking place in the country, do not want to read newspapers and, if they read at all, they read things which do not cost them the least effort.
('18', 418, 2, 11, 903722) Those of our readers who are fired with enthusiasm and who approve of the aims of Navajivan can carry its message to both these classes.
('18', 418, 2, 12, 903859) We suggest to such readers that they start Navajivan clubs or associations, keeping before them a limited object.
('18', 418, 2, 13, 903973) The members of such a club should meet on a fixed day, at a fixed hour, at a fixed place, read an issue of Navajivan from the beginning to the end and have a discussion over it.
('18', 418, 2, 14, 904151) The thing is easily done, but grand results may be obtained from it.
('18', 418, 2, 15, 904220) Every reader would be able to evaluate these at the end of the year if he kept a diary.
('18', 418, 2, 16, 904308) Pure thoughts, pure actions and pure sentiments have a profound effect on the people.
('18', 418, 2, 17, 904394) Were we to make pure ideals our daily companion, we could tread with ease the difficult path of this world.
('18', 418, 2, 18, 904502) It will be our constant endeavour to see that Navajivan does not become the means of conveying a single unworthy or low sentiment or incorrect news or of indulging in rude language, and we charge the reader with keeping watch over us lest we stray from this.
('18', 418, 2, 19, 904761) We take our readers relation with us to be not a commercial but an intimate and normal one.

('18', 419, 3, 14, 906276) We have received four or five poems from a Bhil gentleman in which he humbly but earnestly requests members of his community and other Hindus to desist from the cruel slaughter of goats before the Mother on the sacred eighth day in Navaratri 2 , the day of sacrifice, and on the auspicious Dashera day.

('18', 419, 3, 16, 906677) We believe it to be the duty of every Hindu to stop, as early as possible, this violence which some Hindus, believers in the duty of compassion, commit on the pretext of offering a sacrifice to the Goddess.
('18', 419, 3, 17, 906884) If we appeal to our Muslim brethren to stop cow slaughter, we on our part must stop this violence.

('18', 424, 1, 2, 915603) 308. MORE PUNJAB TRAGEDIES
('18', 424, 2, 3, 915630) It is my misfortune to have to present two more cases from the land of sorrow to the reader of Young India.
('18', 424, 2, 4, 915738) I call Punjab the land of sorrow because I find, on the one hand, a series of cases in which, if the records of cases are to be believed, a manifest injustice has been done and, on the other, an apparent determination on the part of the Punjab Government not to undo the wrong.
('18', 424, 2, 5, 916016) For, as I have already said in these columns, a mere reduction of sentences without admission of at least an error of judgment is no comfort to the men who protest their innocence or to the people at large who believe in their innocence and wish to see justice done.
('18', 424, 2, 6, 916283) I must confess that I am uninterested in reduction of sentences if the prisoners are guilty and it is a crime to keep them in duress if they are innocent.
('18', 424, 2, 7, 916438) The reader will see the petitions on behalf of Mr. Gurdial Singh and Dr. Mahomed Bashir.
('18', 424, 2, 8, 916527) Both are high spirited menone a Sikh of culture, the other a Mohammedan doctor having before him a life full of promise.
('18', 424, 2, 9, 916648) If they have waged war, if they have incited to murder, there can be no question of remission of the sentences passed against them.
('18', 424, 2, 10, 916780) Thereforethe fact that Dr. Bashirs sentence of death has been commuted, whilst it must be a matter of some feeble consolation to Mrs. Bashir, can be none to Dr. Bashir or to the public.
('18', 424, 2, 11, 916966) Let us glance at Mr. Gurdial Singhs case.
('18', 424, 2, 12, 917008) His brother has sent me a long letter asking me even to publish it.
('18', 424, 2, 13, 917076) As the main facts are contained in the petition, I refrain from publishing the letter for fear of tiring the reader, but I will make use of such statements from it as may be necessary to demonstrate the enormity of the injustice done in the case.
('18', 424, 2, 14, 917323) Says the brother,
('18', 424, 3, 15, 917341) He only attended the constitutional and the orderly meeting of the 6th April.
('18', 424, 3, 16, 917419) He was on the 14th and 15th confined to bed.
('18', 424, 3, 17, 917464) The local sub assistant surgeon (Government employee) attended on him, gave his prescription, which I am sending to you in the original along with the papers.
('18', 424, 3, 18, 917623) I have seen this prescription.
('18', 424, 4, 19, 917654) Seriously sick with appendicitis, my brother could not join the so called unruly mob in breaking the glass panes of the Tehsil windows.
('18', 424, 4, 20, 917790) As regards prosecution witnesses against my brother, I have only to add that my brother was not informed of the names of such persons.
('18', 424, 4, 21, 917925) He knew them by seeing them in the Court.
('18', 424, 4, 22, 917967) My brother was, as a matter of fact, not informed of the
('18', 425, 0, 1, 918024) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 425, 1, 2, 918066) charge against him except through the mouth of the prosecution witnesses.
('18', 425, 1, 3, 918140) I hold that if this statement is correct, it is enough to ensure Mr. Gurdial Singhs discharge.
('18', 425, 1, 4, 918235) No accused could thus be taken by surprise and expected where and when to plead.
('18', 425, 1, 5, 918316) Surely he was entitled to see the charge, and not gather it through the prosecution witnesses.
('18', 425, 1, 6, 918411) The letter in my possession then analyses the antecedents of the witnesses for the prosecution and shows the animus they had against the accused.
('18', 425, 1, 7, 918557) Naturally the public cannot be expected to judge the credibility of witnesses upon exparte statements made by or on behalf of the accused, but these statements show, if they are true, that an immense amount of perjury must have taken place on the part of the prosecution witnesses.
('18', 425, 1, 8, 918839) I admit that this case is not as clearly established on behalf of the prisoner as many others I have examined, for I have not the whole of the papers for presentation to the public.
('18', 425, 1, 9, 919021) But assuming the truth of the statements made authentically on behalf of the prisoner, it is clear that the case requires looking into.
('18', 425, 1, 10, 919157) Dr. Mahomed Bashirs is another such case.
('18', 425, 1, 11, 919199) The pathetic petition by his wife and Dr. Bashirs statement itself before the Court, which sentenced him to death, if true, show that the courts judgement had been completely warped.
('18', 425, 1, 12, 919382) Dr. Bashir may or may not have lied butthe Court had most decidedly nothing before it to warrant the remark that the defence evidence was worthless; for Dr. Bashir, as will be seen from the statement published in another column, categorically denied many of the statements and facts imputed to him.
('18', 425, 1, 13, 919681) I do not intend to burden this criticism with any extracts from the very brief and business like statement presented to the Court by Dr. Bashir, but I would commend it to the careful attention of the reader.
('18', 425, 1, 14, 919889) He cannot help the conclusion that the statement deserved a better fate than a contemptuous dismissal from the Court.

('18', 426, 4, 14, 921345) Mr. Gandhi then commenced this sermon, in the course of which he said that he had at present started the movement for the manufacture of swadeshi cloth.
('18', 426, 4, 15, 921498) It was a matter of vital necessity to the people; next to food, clothing is a necessity of life and it should be supplied from the country itself.
('18', 426, 4, 16, 921645) At present our dependence on other countries has made us helpless and poor.
('18', 426, 4, 17, 921721) In the year 1917 18, the country had to send away 60 crores of rupees for foreign cloth only.
('18', 426, 4, 18, 921815) This is in no way edifying to them and steps must be taken to arrest the drain.
('18', 426, 4, 19, 921895) This can be done only with a sustained and energetic movement which will also demand a degree of sacrifice from them.
('18', 426, 4, 20, 922013) He had discussed the question with eminent Indian experts who said that it would take a period of fifty years to supply swadeshi cloth to the whole country through mills.
('18', 426, 4, 21, 922184) Under the circumstances, he had been urging the manufacture of cloth through handloom.
('18', 426, 4, 22, 922271) The idea had become already extremely popular and high class Indian ladies had taken zealously to spinning cotton and swadeshi Bhandars were being opened at different places.
('18', 426, 4, 23, 922446) In Kathiawar, similar ways and means should be adopted for the spread of swadeshi.
('18', 426, 4, 24, 922529) The movement was in no way harmful to any and therefore it should be carried on peacefully.
('18', 426, 4, 25, 922621) Women should utilize their spare time and begin spinning.
('18', 426, 4, 26, 922679) The native spinning wheels can be had cheaply and if they wished their welfare they should without waste of time introduce into every house spinning wheels and handlooms.
('18', 426, 4, 27, 922850) It alone would ensure happiness and economic contentment.

('18', 428, 2, 7, 926075) He therefore suggested to Mr. Nanalal Kavi, who was the head and the heart of the movement in Rajkot, to go to some villages and, by living among and like them, to study their wants and their habits.
('18', 428, 2, 8, 926275) Then he would discover the best method of rendering social service.
('18', 428, 3, 9, 926343) The speaker at one time thought that social service was best known and organized in Europe.
('18', 428, 3, 10, 926435) Experience had taught him otherwise.
('18', 428, 3, 11, 926472) He was of opinion that nowhere was social service treated so much a religious duty as in Indian.
('18', 428, 3, 12, 926569) He instanced the marvellous manner in which the Kumbh at Hardwar was organized.
('18', 428, 3, 13, 926649) The Himalayas were a standing testimony to our organizing ability and our instinct for social service.
('18', 428, 3, 14, 926752) Thousands of pilgrims who ascended the Himalayas up to Jamnotri were catered for without difficulty in a spirit of service and not of commercial gain.
('18', 428, 3, 15, 926903) The matchless caste organization was an instance of vast social service organization.
('18', 428, 3, 16, 926989) The late Sir W.W. Hunter used to say that India was remarkable for the absence of any need of Poor Law.
('18', 428, 3, 17, 927093) Castes regulated service in the event of disease, death and poverty.
('18', 428, 3, 18, 927162) He did not wish to glorify caste.
('18', 428, 3, 19, 927196) He recognized its defects and its excesses as it at present existed.
('18', 428, 3, 20, 927265) He merely mentioned it as an illustration to prove his proposition that social service was recognized in India as a duty.
('18', 428, 3, 21, 927387) Unfortunately most of our old institutions had petrified.
('18', 428, 3, 22, 927445) His point was that the old institutions and methods should be studied, revivified and reorganized in so far as it may be necessary to suit new conditions.
('18', 428, 3, 23, 927600) We were likely to go wrong if we rejected the old without due examination.
('18', 428, 4, 24, 927675) Young India, 8 10 1919
('18', 428, 5, 25, 927698) 313. HOW NOT TO DO IT
('18', 428, 6, 26, 927720) At the very earnest request of Mayadevi, 16 year old wife of Kesar Mal, I reproduce elsewhere her picturesque petition praying for the release of her young husband, 21 years old.
('18', 428, 6, 27, 927899) The case presented seems to be unanswerable, but a good cause has been spoiled by a bad advocate.
('18', 428, 6, 28, 927997) Though the petition is that of Mayadevi, it is quite clear that it is the handiwork of a draughts man who has written in a fit of rage against what he has, undoubtedly and with good cause, believed to be a monstrous injustice.
('18', 428, 6, 29, 928224) But anger is short madness and noblest causes have been damaged by advocates affected with temporary lunacy.
('18', 428, 6, 30, 928333) The petition is overlaid with useless adjectives and declamation.
('18', 428, 6, 31, 928399) Whilst it
('18', 429, 0, 1, 928409) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 429, 1, 2, 928451) has been a pleasure to me to dissect the many business like petitions that have come from that land of sorrow, in the present instance I have been obliged to labour through violent language to what I consider to be a right conclusion.
('18', 429, 1, 3, 928686) I do not happen to know the draughtsman of the petition.
('18', 429, 1, 4, 928743) Mayadevi, who has sent a covering letter equally violently worded, gives me no information about the draughtsman.
('18', 429, 1, 5, 928857) But I do wish as a practised draughtsman to warn writers of petitions, whether they be pleaders or otherwise, to think of the cause they may be espousing for the time being.
('18', 429, 1, 6, 929031) I assure them that a bare statement of facts unembellished with adjectives is far more eloquent and effective than a narrative glowing with exuberant language.
('18', 429, 1, 7, 929191) Petition writers must understand that they address busy men, not necessarily sympathetic, sometimes prejudiced, and almost invariably prone to sustain the decisions of their subordinates.
('18', 429, 1, 8, 929379) In the case of the Punjab, they approach a Viceroy and a Lieutenant Governor who have preconceived ideas.
('18', 429, 1, 9, 929485) Petitions have to be read and analysed by public workers and journalists who have none too much time at their disposal.
('18', 429, 1, 10, 929605) I know to my cost how difficult it is for me to do full justice to the value of the papers that pour in upon me week to week from the Punjab.
('18', 429, 1, 11, 929747) I make a present of my valuable experience to young patriots who wish to try the art of advocating public causes by writing petitions or otherwise.
('18', 429, 1, 12, 929895) I had the privilege of serving under the late Mr. Gokhale and, for a time, under the G.O.M. of India.
('18', 429, 1, 13, 929997) Both told me that if I wanted to be heard I must be brief, I must write to the point and adhere to facts, and never travel beyond the cause under notice, and I must be most sparing in my adjectives.
('18', 429, 1, 14, 930196) And if some success has attended my effort, it is due to my acceptance of the golden advice given to me by the two illustrious deceased.
('18', 429, 1, 15, 930333) With this preface and warning, I proceed to the analysis of the case of young Kesar Mal.
('18', 429, 1, 16, 930422) I am anxious that the excellent case of young Kesar Mal might not be overlooked by reason of bad draughtsmanship of the petition.
('18', 429, 1, 17, 930552) The wonder to me is that so many petitions have been written with a marked ability and amazing self restraint.
('18', 429, 1, 18, 930663) But when a badly drawn [up] document comes their way, it is the business of public workers to sift the grain from the chaff and present the former to the public.
('18', 429, 1, 19, 930825) Let it be remembered that this is one of the Hafizabad cases arising out of the tumult that took place at Hafizabad station during which Lieut.
('18', 429, 1, 20, 930969) Tatam is alleged to have been the object of the mischievous attention of the crowd that had gathered at that station.

('18', 431, 2, 13, 934547) AN UNWORTHY DEFENCE
('18', 431, 3, 14, 934567) One almost despairs of getting justice when one reads the debates that have taken place in the Viceregal Council and the defence put forth for every vile and vindictive act done in the Punjab in the name of prestige, law and order.

('18', 434, 2, 4, 940619) We can see from them how subordinate officers can mislead the Government.

('18', 434, 2, 6, 940741) The first step of the Government was wrong.
('18', 434, 2, 7, 940785) Misled by the Collectors report, the Government stationed additional police at Nadiad and Barejadi.
('18', 434, 2, 8, 940885) It realized that this was a mistake, but was not prepared to admit as much.
('18', 434, 2, 9, 940961) The Government thus found itself in a position in which it had no choice but to defend the mistake anyhow.

('18', 437, 4, 8, 948146) 316. THE PUNJAB COMMITTEE
('18', 437, 5, 9, 948172) Surprising changes keep taking place in the Punjab Committee.

('18', 438, 4, 17, 951138) 317. REQUEST TO CONTRIBUTORS
('18', 438, 5, 18, 951167) So many writers send their articles to us.
('18', 438, 5, 19, 951210) We congratulate them on their enthusiasm and on their love for Navajivan.
('18', 438, 5, 20, 951284) We shall certainly find room for the kind of articles which, in our humble view, the people are eager to read.
('18', 438, 5, 21, 951395) Since we cannot write to every contributor separately, we make a few suggestions here.
('18', 438, 5, 22, 951482) For the present, we are not inclined to give much space to essays.
('18', 438, 5, 23, 951549) Whenever we are favoured with contributions by writers of established reputation, we shall include them.
('18', 438, 5, 24, 951654) The principal need of the people is not good thoughts but good deeds.
('18', 438, 5, 25, 951724) Navajivan could be stuffed with beautiful translations from the ancient classics if the purpose were to place the best thoughts before the people.
('18', 438, 5, 26, 951871) The public seems to have had enough of such things.
('18', 438, 5, 27, 951923) It is, therefore, our attempt, by presenting before the public concrete instances of ideas which have been put into practice, to win faith in them.
('18', 438, 5, 28, 952071) Accordingly we propose to put before the people experiences which have something of use to
('18', 439, 0, 1, 952162) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('18', 439, 1, 2, 952204) Thus reports of the activities of all those who have been doing some sincere work will find a place in Navajivan.
('18', 439, 1, 3, 952318) The contributors should have some pity for the editor and the poor compositors.
('18', 439, 1, 4, 952398) It is therefore required of them that they write only on one side.
('18', 439, 1, 5, 952465) It is also very necessary for them to write in as good a hand as they possibly can, for we cannot copy out the articles they send us.
('18', 439, 1, 6, 952599) Some are under the impression that any kind of handwriting is good enough in Gujarati.
('18', 439, 1, 7, 952686) This suggests want of patriotism on their part.
('18', 439, 1, 8, 952734) We should take pride in writing a clear and beautiful hand in our own language and be ashamed of writing a slovenly hand.
('18', 439, 1, 9, 952856) Especially when writing for publication, everyone should regard it as his sacred duty to be doubly careful.
('18', 439, 1, 10, 952964) We are reminded, in this context, of a poem by a veteran writer.
('18', 439, 1, 11, 953029) It is to this effect : Never write anything without giving thought to it; having written something, go through it carefully and write it over again; in rewriting, cut it down to half its length; go through this once more, think again and reduce the half to a half again; read over yet again the one fourth that now remains and, if you are the least in doubt cut out something still further.
('18', 439, 1, 12, 953420) Even after all this, you will find the editor so merciless that he will have to cut out something more.
('18', 439, 1, 13, 953524) This advice is for those learning to write, but veteran writers have profited a great deal from it.
('18', 439, 1, 14, 953624) We importune every writer to try out this well tested advice and note the results.
('18', 439, 1, 15, 953707) The late Mr. Gokhale, when he wanted to write even a short letter, would first turn it over in his mind for five to ten minutes, think out the words and then write it out; he would cancel it to write out a second one, show it to friends, politely listen to their comments and only then would he take his letter to have been finalized.
('18', 439, 1, 16, 954042) The result was that he acquired control over a foreign language which few have had.
('18', 439, 1, 17, 954126) His writing was replete with courage, truth and such other qualities, and yet one found no sting in it anywhere.
('18', 439, 1, 18, 954239) In a wall which a clever artisan builds, not a single brick will be seen to have been wrongly set; those who read the writings of this builder in language have the same experience with regard to the edifice of words he constructs.
('18', 439, 1, 19, 954470) We should have greater love still for our mother tongue.
('18', 439, 1, 20, 954527) If our enthusiastic and kind contributors keep these suggestions in mind, their contributions will stand greater chance of being accepted; besides, writings so shaped under the hammer of thought will prove useful to the people.
